fields.headline: Winter break tops the agenda
fields.standfirst: Europe's biggest clubs attempt to lay down the law
fields.trailText: Europe's most powerful clubs yesterday unveiled a comprehensive blueprint for the future of football, featuring a two-week winter break and only two blocks of international matches a year.
fields.body:
Europe's most powerful clubs yesterday unveiled a comprehensive blueprint for the future of football, featuring a two-week winter break and only two blocks of international matches a year.

The G14 clubs, which include Manchester United, Liverpool and Real Madrid, want internationals to be restricted to one period in October and another in the European summer as part of a globally unified calendar.

"Official club games must take priority over international friendly matches," said the group, which was set up in 1998 to lobby Fifa and Uefa in the interests of the leading teams.

The Football Association said it was "open-minded" on the idea of playing internationals in blocks. But it stressed that the importance of national team matches should not be overlooked.

"The success of the domestic game can be directly related to the success of the national side," said the FA spokesman Steve Double. "Probably the best example of that is that the boom in football here in the 90s has been directly linked to England getting to the World Cup semi-final in 1990.

"Also, the clubs benefit from having their own players gain international recognition by [seeing] their value on the transfer market increasing."

On the proposal for a winter break, Double added: "It is on the agenda but when, and for how long, should it be, particularly in this country when the weather can be equally bad at the beginning of February and November?"

The clubs are also calling for compensation when their players are on international duty amounting to 50% of revenue made by national associations; a summer month free of all football; pre-qualifying for international tournaments; and a European transfer window from July 1 to January 30.

They also insist there should be no Uefa Cup or Champions League matches during the Sydney Olympics, from September 15 to October 2. But that was immediately rejected by Uefa.

"Twenty or 30 years ago it would have been feasible," said the Uefa general secretary Gerhard Aigner, "but now with the number of matches played each week there is absolutely no way the games could be shifted from their original dates."

Meanwhile, Uefa's president Lennart Johansson has said he hopes to persuade the European Union to overturn the Bosman ruling and treat football as a special case.

"We are still trying every day to make the European Union understand the problems we are having with the effects of the Bosman ruling," he said.

"I would say six foreign players per side should be the limit. Then the way would be open for homegrown players to feature more at their clubs."

Johansson also wants a European-wide wages ceiling to enable clubs to compete on a more equal footing.

Sir Alex Ferguson has backed proposals which would stop English clubs from fielding more than two non-EU players. "There are good non-EU players in the country but a limit should be imposed," the Manchester United manager said. "I would like know the exact details of the proposals but, if it means a maximum of two players being allowed, it sounds fair."

Ukraine will be England's opponents on May 31 for their final match at Wembley before Euro 2000.

Proposed calendar

July 18 Start of pre-season.

Aug 27-Oct 15 National leagues and continental club competitions.

Oct 18-Nov 2 Reserved for international matches.

Nov 5-Dec 23 National leagues continue.

Dec24-Jan 6 Two-week break from football.

Jan 7-May 18 Conclusion of national championships and continental club competitions.

May 20-June 15 Reserved for international matches.

June 16-July 17 Break.

webTitle: South Africa claim World Cup bid unharmed

fields.headline: South Africa claim World Cup bid unharmed
fields.standfirst: Nigeria trouble dismissed as far away and irrelevant
fields.trailText: The organisers of the South Africa World Cup bid have denied suggestions that crowd trouble at the African Nations Cup in Nigeria will harm their chances of hosting the competition in 2006.
fields.body:
The organisers of the South Africa World Cup bid have denied suggestions that crowd trouble at the African Nations Cup in Nigeria will harm their chances of hosting the competition in 2006.

"Nigeria is a sovereign country some six hours' flying time from London and seven hours from South Africa," said Danny Jordaan, the South Africa bid committee's chief executive officer. "We do not assume that events in Kosovo, just one hour's flight from Germany, will affect the German and English bids. The events in Nigeria are simply nothing to do with South Africa."

Political intrigue continues to dog the Nations Cup. Ivory Coast's military leader yesterday threatened to force his country's football team into army service should their performances on the pitch not improve in future.

The Elephants were released from military detention on Thursday after being held for two days following their ignominious exit from the cup on Monday.

"I asked that you be taken there so you could reflect a while," general Robert Guei told the players through an Ivory Coast newspaper. "You behaved unworthily. You should have avoided us the shame. Next time you will stay there for military service. You will be sent to the barracks until a sense of civic pride gets into your heads."

The detention drew concern from European teams, whose players had been detained, and outrage from Fifa, the world governing body. Fifa's president Sepp Blatter sent a letter to the president of the Ivory Coast Football Association, Ousseynou Dieng, calling on him to intervene.

Following Morocco's elimination from the competition, the Coventry midfielders Mustapha Hadji and Youssef Chippo will be at Old Trafford for today's game against Manchester United - but they will be watching from the stands.

The pair began their return trip following the 2-0 defeat by Nigeria on Thursday, but the Coventry manager Gordon Strachan is loth to select them.

"We are waiting to see if they get back in time but they played on Thursday night and have done a lot of travelling," he said. "I had already picked my starting line-up for the game and I will go with that."

Their international team-mate, the Southampton midfielder Hassan Kachloul, who is likely to be on the bench at home to West Ham today, has cited a lack of team spirit as the cause of Morocco's early elimination.

"I'm happy we're out because I don't think the team had the same sense of purpose," he said. "We had no team spirit. Many of the players couldn't even talk to the technical crew, not least share a joke. It would have been an injustice if we had qualified for the quarters."

Meanwhile Nigeria's Arsenal striker Nwankwo Kanu has claimed the Super Eagles are the best football team in Africa. "We have the best quality individual players and overall the best team in Africa," he said.

Their Dutch coach Jo Bonfrere, who parted company with the Nigerians over his pay and was re-engaged only in December, added: "Three more matches and the African Cup is ours. I've always believed this team is among the best in the world."

The first of those games is against Senegal in the quarter-finals on Monday. The other ties see Cameroon face Algeria and South Africa take on Ghana tomorrow and Egypt meet Tunisia on Monday.

webTitle: Some advice for Clarrers: never bet on your own team

fields.headline: Some advice for Clarrers: never bet on your own team
fields.trailText: Darren draws on some predictably dodgy experience and lays down a few guidelines on the finer aspects of having a punt.
fields.body:
Monday
Me and Steve Claridge go back a long way. You might say I taught Clarrers everything he knows about the game. You know, the difference between a yankee and a forecast; where to place your stake in a spread on the total the subs' shirt numbers add up to; plus the banker method of knowing which drop of water to watch for in the back-window-of-the-coach-on-the-road-to-away-games condensation derby. Always the one on the left, by the way. Trust me.

Ever since that day in the dressing room before an under-13 county game when he bet me a score that the pitch would take a long stud (this was the tail end of the longest drought in living memory), Clarrers has regarded Darren Tackle as something of an oracle on matters of a gambling nature. Even now it is yours truly's mobe what rings when Clarrers wants a tip for the 3.30 at Market Rasen (once it happened when I was sat on the bench at Hillsborough, and Danny Wilson got all upset because every time he hears a phone he think it's the chairman ringing to sack him). Oh aye, he's always looked to us has Clarrers. Which Wattsy reckons is why, over the course of his career, the geezer's lost more than 300 long 'uns in the pockets of your bookie classes.

So you can imagine, Darren Tackle was shocked to his core when he read in the paper that Steve Claridge has been backing hisself at the bookies to score a hat-trick and Portsmouth to win. Clarrers, Clarrers, have you not been listening all these years? A professional backing his own team is a big no-no, especially when you play for Portsmouth.

A bet on a match in which you is taking part should be viewed as an insurance policy: if you win you get the win bonus, and if you lose you've laid a little off on the result so you're still quids in. It may have worked once, Clarrers, but don't make a habit of it. Next time remember: there's no point putting all your sponds in one basket.

Course the FA reckons there won't be a next time. The old farts has come out with some nonce in their time, but telling us we can't bet on matches we is involved in takes the Wagon Wheel. Are they saying they want us to spend our time thinking about the dogs or the horses when we should be concentrating on our game? Because that's what'll happen. You can bet your life on it.

Thursday

Training's taken up with Demo's new method of mobbing the referee after a decision's gone against you.

"There's only one cast-iron way of making sure no one's sent off when you surround the ref," he says. "And that's to play for ManU. But in the meantime, try this for size."

And he gives everyone their instructions: Wattsy screaming from the front, Vic yelling in from the side, Bob to bend down and apparently tie his shoelaces round the back so when Hermann gives the ref a nudge he falls backwards over Bob and on to the deck. Whereupon his cards spill out of his pocket and Darko nicks them, thus ensuring no one gets so much as a yellow. All very intimidating, except yours truly couldn't help noticing the words Darren and Tackle do not feature.

"Precisely, Dazz lad," says Demo when this is pointed out to him. "That's because for the purposes of this training exercise, you, lad, are to take the role of the referee."

Since when did leading professionals put that much effort into a training session? Also, it seemed to me as I was sprawled on the ground with one of the Bosnians doing a folk dance on me chest, that they all got the hang of it straight away. So why repeat the drill 17 times?

Anyhow, by the end me nerves is shot. Not to mention me new Tacklewear training top which is that covered in gob it's beyond the reach of the driest of cleaning. So I rings up Rodney and tells him I is in no fit state to do the photo shoot he'd got organised for the afternoon.

"No worries, boy," he says. "It's for a charity so there's no fee anyhow."

"No fee, Rodds?" I splutters. "It's about time I got myself a decent bleedin' agent."

"Behave, boy," he says. "You and me, we're attached at the hip. You're not going anywhere." Want a bet?

webTitle: No sweaty pyjamas as Hoddle awaits the butterflies

fields.headline: No sweaty pyjamas as Hoddle awaits the butterflies
fields.trailText: Jon Brodkin finds the former England manager in a positive frame of mind but unable to disguise the fact that he has not yet fully settled into his new job.
fields.body:
Glenn Hoddle looked relaxed enough yesterday, perched on a barrier at Southampton's training ground. But there was no disguising the fact that he has not fully settled into his new job. Referring to Stuart Ripley as Paul suggested it was time for a name game: "Hello, I'm Glenn and I like God."

Ripley, it should be said, is out injured, and the most important introductions of the week have been of a different kind. The players, Hoddle explained, have been getting to know his "principles". Tactical rather than religious, one assumes.

Whichever, Hoddle is back in the swing and loving it. He started yearning for the training ground and the match-day buzz after "six or seven months" of his year-long exile. Today, when West Ham visit the Dell for his first match in charge, he expects the exciting sensation of butterflies to return.

"If I don't have that then I've probably made the wrong decision," he said. "Normally you have that. But I'll sleep. I always sleep well." No danger of sweat-drenched pyjamas, Graham Taylor-style, then.

Hoddle has a confidence in his ability which no criticism of his beliefs or mocking of Eileen Drewery can disrupt. And why not when on Monday 5,500 people went along to a reserve game to welcome him to the Dell?

Listening to John Gorman, his trusted No2, it was easy to believe that football has missed Hoddle as much as Hoddle has missed the game.

"I think he's special," Gorman said. "It's been an unusual week for Glenn and you can see his enthusiasm is totally back.

"He's got so much to offer and he's been missed by the game with his technical and tactical ability. He's got ideas that bring a bit more out of players. Hopefully the lads have learned a lot from him already. When he's fit he's not bad at demonstrations." With little money to spend, coaching will count for a lot.

The sight of Gorman cheerily putting a clutch of defenders through their paces after most players had disappeared showed why Hoddle sets such stall by the Scot.

The pair had already worked together for Swindon and England. Gorman had agreed with Reading that he could leave his post as assistant if Hoddle offered him a job. Hoddle trained with Reading a couple of times before becoming a Saint.

"We just seem to gel," Gorman said. "I'm very, very enthusiastic. He likes that bubbliness and he's sometimes a bit more of the straight guy. He's the boss."

That much is obvious. The media throng was larger yesterday than it might normally be in a whole month. The training-ground gates were locked to keep out intruders. On the field the hand of Hod is also clear.

"If anything this week the players have trained too hard," Gorman said. "They've been trying to impress in every session." No surprise when Hoddle spent three afternoons analysing the squad with the coaches who remain from Dave Jones's reign.

He has by no means eased himself back as he starts his 12-month contract. On top of training and watching the reserves, he has squeezed in two Sheffield Wednesday games in league and FA Cup. Not that he is in a rush.

Hoddle insists he will impose his style gradually. Yes, he said, the sweeper system remains his preferred option "but that assessment will be fairer in two months than in the first week".

Already, though, the basic change is clear. "We won't be as direct as we were," says the centre-half Dean Richards. "He likes us to pass it through the midfield."

Pivotal to that policy should be Matt le Tissier, who has been assigned a special programme to help him back to his best. The 31-year-old is expected to return to training next week after hamstring and calf injuries.

"We've had a long chat," Hoddle said. "Saints have relied on him for so many years and he's been thrown in too early and ends up back in treatment.

"It's not really a weight problem but there are certain things we'll be changing. We've set out a plan for him and he's taken a lot on board. Now we've got to guide him through like we would any player coming back from injury."

The Hoddle comeback is running smoothly so far. "You quickly get back into it," Gorman said. "It's like riding a bike." But why should the Southampton fans believe he is the man for the job? "I don't think they should at the moment," Hoddle said. The real work starts today.

fields.headline: Hide and seek
fields.trailText: The African Cup of Nations can always be relied upon to supply some glorious football, but comedy is never far from view. Particularly when Zambia are in town - which isn't for long, unfortunately.
fields.body:
The African Cup of Nations can always be relied upon to supply some glorious football, but comedy is never far from view. Particularly when Zambia are in town - which isn't for long, unfortunately.

The Zambian national team are currently in hiding after vanishing hours after their final game. "I know their spirits were low," said a spokesman for the Confederation of African Football, "but to leave so soon has disturbed a lot of people."

The team's performance, while disappointing, was hardly surprising given their warm-up to the event. A tour of the Americas in December was halted after the players complained that their training pitch was poor and that they were fed "junk food", that their hotel rooms were overcrowded and they weren't given any money. They played one game against Honduras - which they lost 7-1 - and, with five games still to play, suddenly disappeared. One of the players paid for their rescheduled flights on his own credit card.

There has been an outcry in Zambia where, despite the fact that their national side is terrible, everyone expects them to win everything they enter. Sounds just like England, really.

fields.headline: Nilis next on Liverpool's list
fields.trailText: Liverpool will turn to the veteran Belgian international Luc Nilis to solve their well-documented goalscoring problem if they fail to persuade Leicester City to part with Emile Heskey.
fields.body:
Liverpool will turn to the veteran Belgian international Luc Nilis to solve their well-documented goalscoring problem if they fail to persuade Leicester City to part with Emile Heskey.

The Merseyside club have lined up a £500,000 deal with Nilis's Dutch club PSV which may see the 32-year-old move to Anfield on a two-year contract. However, Nilis's hopes of moving to England to finish his career in the Premiership will end if Leicester agree to sell Heskey after the League Cup final against Tranmere Rovers this month.

Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier has spent the past few days attempting to bring forward a secret deal struck with Leicester more than six months ago sanctioning Hes key's transfer to Anfield this summer.

Liverpool indicated they would increase to £9.5m their initial offer of £8m if the Leicester manager Martin O'Neill agreed to sell Heskey before the end of the month. He will be out of contract in 16 months' time.

Nilis is one of European football's more respected forwards, making his name with Anderlecht where he scored more than 100 goals in six seasons. He has been courted by several clubs in recent weeks, notably Sheffield Wednesday who attempted to sign him shortly before Christmas.

Although PSV have said they do not wish to sell him, he would be available on a Bosman-inspired free transfer at the end of the season.

Benfica's Jorge Cadete has arrived in Bradford for talks with City's chairman Geoffrey Richmond and manager Paul Jewell. The 31-year-old former Celtic striker is expected to watch today's game against Arsenal and has a loan deal on the table until the end of the season with a view to a permanent move, depending on whether Bradford stay up.

Sheffield United yesterday signed the Stockport County forward Laurent D'Jaffo for £175,000, minutes before the noon deadline. Petr Katchouro has moved in the opposite direction on loan.

Burnley have bought Bournemouth's centre-half Ian Cox for £500,000. The 28-year-old Carshalton-born Trinidad and Tobago defender, who scored 50 goals in 265 appearance for the south coast club, has agreed a 3-year deal.

webTitle: Likely lad with stars in his eyes

fields.headline: Likely lad with stars in his eyes
fields.standfirst: Liverpool's all-purpose 19-year-old Steven Gerrard says he has what it takes to be Kevin Keegan's next big thing
fields.trailText: Ian Ross hears Liverpool's all-purpose 19-year-old Steven Gerrard explain how he has what it takes to be Kevin Keegan's next big thing.
fields.body:
It is said that Kevin Keegan has difficulty establishing a rapport with anyone not imbued with his outrageous sense of optimism. If so, Steven Gerrard can look forward to a happy partnership with the England coach if, as expected, he is called up for the first time against Argentina later this month. Gerrard is not lacking in confidence in his own abilities, despite his 19 years.

"I think I'm ready for England," he says, with the Scouse burr of a Brookside extra. "Why not? I've done well for Liverpool against some very good players.

"To be honest, I'm not surprised by where I am now because people always told me I had the ability. I do believe I can go on and achieve more. It has all happened very quickly for me and now it is a case of handling the experiences that come my way."

Others may be a little more surprised. Only 18 months ago Gerrard - who was raised on a council estate in the scally playground of Liverpool's Huyton district - was playing his football in the Liverpool youth team, dreaming of a tap on the shoulder from the first-team manager.

When the break came, however, things did not pan out quite as anticipated. After a brief appearance as a substitute against Blackburn Rovers last season, he was pitched in from the start against Tottenham Hotspur and asked to mark David Ginola. "It didn't go well at all," Gerrard reflects with endearing honesty. "He was too good."

Gerrard has shown a marked improvement in his handful of senior games since then. But despite developing a preference for the centre of midfield, if he wins Keegan's approval it will almost certainly be as a full-back.

"I have seen Kevin Keegan at a couple of our recent games," Gerrard says. "He was here when I played at right-back against Coventry. I did quite well and I heard afterwards he was pleased with me. If he was to bring me into the England squad as a right-back I'd try my best. If that is the best chance for me to get in, so be it.

"But the right-back thing only came about because of injuries to others. The boss [Gérard Houllier] asked me to mark Harry Kewell against Leeds United at Elland Road, and I did quite well."

Already Gerrard has played right-back, left-back, on the right side of midfield and in central midfield for Liverpool. "I'm just waiting for one more injury up front and I'll be in there, scoring goals," he says, a reference to the enduring absence of his injured, long-time friend Michael Owen.

"But I do prefer being in the middle. It helps being versatile, though, because when we have both Dietmar Hamann and Jamie Redknapp fit I will be behind them in the midfield pecking order. If I do want to make a career in central midfield at Liverpool, I may have to be very patient."

Gerrard joined Liverpool as a tin can-kicking eight-year-old, but is now one of the Merseyside club's most versatile and valuable players.

"I grew up on a council estate and loved every minute of it; that's where I learned to play football. Loads of my friends are unemployed and doing nothing with themselves, so I thank God I had something to aim for, a target."

The jealousy bit
The result, it appears, is a realistic outlook on his chosen profession. While hardly oblivious to its attractions, Gerrard - like Owen - is a reluctant participant in football's after-hours fame game.

"I'm getting noticed more now when I'm out shopping or in town," he says. "I do still get a buzz out of people stopping me in the street. You have to be prepared and ready for things, though. Things have happened to me off the field that I really never expected.

"After I was sent off against Everton earlier this season, I had people being aggressive towards me and spreading stories about me doing different things. If you play for Liverpool or Everton and live local, I think you will get people spreading rumours and doing the jealousy bit.

"Robbie Fowler has made mistakes but he's learned from it. He deals with it very well and he'll be a good role model if it does start happening to me in the same way he got it."

Gerrard clearly also draws strength from Houllier, a manager who in his eyes has found a neat compromise between local lads made good and expensive foreign imports.

"Gérard is very concerned that the young lads - me, Jamie Carragher, David Thompson, Michael Owen - have a good life on the field and away from it," he says. "He takes a big interest in where we live; he is very much a father figure to us and that's something we appreciate.

"Certainly some of us were concerned when he brought in all the foreign lads. I hadn't even heard of most of them - then again, they probably hadn't heard of me. But they've all settled in and they're a good laugh. We are mixing well and learning from each other.

"There is no division: in the canteen you won't ever see the local boys on one table and the foreign lads on another. We share everything."

And so, if Gerrard's progress is indeed rewarded with a call from his country in 12 days' time, he will resist the temptation to celebrate in the manner of the so-called Spice Boys - the pre-Houllier clique of Liverpool players whose fondness for the high life tarnished the club's reputation.

"I didn't really know much about all that Spice Boys business," he admits. "But I'm made up that I wasn't part of it."

webTitle: Coppell on his uppers but far from down

fields.headline: Coppell on his uppers but far from down
fields.standfirst: Palace have not bought a player for 13 months but are hanging in there
fields.trailText: Roy Collins meets Crystal Palace manager Steve Coppell and hears how the club has found the threat of extinction a liberating experience.
fields.body:
Immediately Steve Coppell has finished the telephone conversation with what sounds like an old pal, he attempts to set the record straight over rumours that Charlton are trying to sign his forward Hayden Mullins for a larcenous £500,000. Actually he spells it out: "That's b..o..l..l..o.." - then reveals that the caller was none other than Alan Curbishley, Charlton's manager.

It is understandable that those lacking Coppell's university degree in economics often put two and two together and make five. Outsiders simply cannot understand that a club whose financial problems have exposed their bare bones are not daily prey to football's vultures. It is not the most serious of the misapprehensions about Palace's plight.

The overwhelming view of Palace, whose debts of £15m are mounting by £25,000 a week, is of a club who should be on a 24-hour suicide watch; of staff brought to such depths of despair by the constraints of administration that they cheer themselves up by sinking their noses into Victor Hugo or giving Leonard Cohen a spin. In fact, their laughter is in danger of lifting off the workhouse roof.

Coppell began his last team-talk by telling his players that none of them was to play well "or you'll be sold by five o'clock". He says: "This is the tightest set of players I've ever been involved with and it's because of our situation. Walter Smith tells me it has been exactly the same at Everton; that almost from the day he was told he had no money to spend, the players began turning in great performances.

"Once you know there is no money, and we haven't bought a player in 13 months, it's your responsibility to get the best out of the ones you've got. And the player has the responsibility as well. If he had a bad game last week, he has to work hard to make sure he plays better next week because there is no rotation policy here."

Coppell has to fill in a purchase order for the squad's smallest basic daily needs, then hope that four or five days later he will get permission from the administrator to go ahead. If he were to write "centre-forward" on one of the dockets, the administrator would send for the men in white coats. At least, following Mathias Svensson's recent £600,000 move to Charlton, no more players need to be sold this season.

Like his players, Coppell has found the threat of extinction a liberating experience. He has also discovered a surprising number of silver linings, saying: "Half the headache when you're a manager is that you are judged on your signings. Well, I haven't made any and I now think it would be a good idea to operate transfer windows. Then for the rest of the year, it would be a test of management and coaching.

"It is all too easy for everyone to say 'my players aren't good enough', 'I need this, that and the other'. But if your players are not good enough, can you make them any better?"

There is another rich reward from being in football penury. Even the most jackal-like of agents do not knock on the doors of empty larders. Most give Coppell a three-monthly check-call, saying something like: "Situation changed, Steve?"

"No?"

"Okay, I won't bother you."

Coppell has become so accustomed to empty pockets that if a financial fairy-prince offered him a fortune tomorrow, he would no doubt echo the words of lottery winners who claim it will not change their lives.

He says: "If a new owner walked in and gave me £3m, I wouldn't have a clue how to spend it. We don't really have a scout so I don't know which players are out there."

One would have expected Coppell's desk to have contained a voodoo doll of Mark Goldberg, the mug punter who lost £23m in a few months before being forced to hand over the keys to the administrator. But it is just another misapprehension even though, at their first meeting, Goldberg told Coppell he was buying the club and replacing him with Terry Venables.

"We were going well in the Premiership at the time but at least he was up-front. Did I believe in Mark? I think that's the wrong word but it was hard not to be enthused by him. He is such an upbeat person and he didn't hide behind limited liability. Okay, in the end he did a shit deal but it was a shit deal done with his money."

A would-be purchaser named Jerry Lim is hovering in the wings. But pie in the sky is the worst diet for a club in Palace's situation, and the threat of closure is still real. First Division clubs are the most vulnerable to closure, says Coppell, "because everyone is taking a gamble. You have to be in Division One to get to the Premiership so clubs at the bottom say, 'we've got to stay in'; they take a gamble on wages and if the gamble fails, they have nowhere to go.

"The First Division is such a bitch of a division. The teams at the top have already lost six or seven games and by the end of the season they will have lost 10, one game in four. And that's success."

Coppell admits to being on the steepest learning curve of his 14 years in management. He says: "People think I know about economics but I'm just learning about voluntary administration, bankruptcy and insolvency laws, phrases that used to fly over my head.

"But I see this as the ultimate managerial challenge; it's modern-day management at the cutting edge. No big club will come in for me because they know the situation and they want to see how it is resolved. Above all, I want to see how it is resolved. I want to see it through."

webTitle: Ponting's power propels Australia to yet another trophy

fields.headline: Ponting's power propels Australia to yet another trophy
fields.standfirst:
Australia 337-7
Pakistan 185
Australia won by 152 runs
fields.trailText: Ricky Ponting smashed 78 off only 80 deliveries as Australia clinched the triangular one-day series with an overwhelming victory over Pakistan in the second of the best-of-three day-night finals in Sydney yesterday.
fields.body:
Ricky Ponting smashed 78 off only 80 deliveries as Australia clinched the triangular one-day series with an overwhelming victory over Pakistan in the second of the best-of-three day-night finals in Sydney yesterday.

Their total of 337 was their highest in one-day internationals, eclipsing their 332 for three against Sri Lanka in Sharjah in 1989-90, and proved far too good for the Pakistanis as Glenn McGrath, Australia's player of the year, took five for 49.

The victory sealed the series 2-0 after Australia's six-wicket win in the first match in Melbourne on Wednesday. It was their ninth in a row in one-day internationals, only two short of the record held jointly by West Indies and England.

The openers Mark Waugh (53) and Adam Gilchrist (51) had set the stage for Ponting but they were aided by a woeful performance in the field by Pakistan.

The daunting run-chase then began badly for the Pakistanis as they slumped to 43 for four. Yousuf Youhana (41), Moin Khan (33) and Azhar Mahmood (27) all contributed in the middle order but never threatened to change the course of the match.

"They are definitely worthy world champions," said Pakistan's captain Wasim Akram, whose team also lost to Australia in last year's World Cup final at Lord's.

 Shoaib Akhtar has asked Nottinghamshire to wait until February 20 before deciding whether he will play county cricket at Trent Bridge next season. If the Pakistani fast bowler is chosen for all four of his country's summer tours he will be available for only five championship games and the county will turn instead to the New Zealand all-rounder Chris Cairns.

webTitle: Hall.com to find a sheer genius

fields.headline: Hall.com to find a sheer genius
fields.trailText: • Online offerings become ever more surreal. Devotees of the inimitable Stuart Hall can now congregate at The Church Hall at BBC Online to hear the sage's irreverent observations on the beautiful game. Surfers will be able to relive such wonders as this radio rambling: "To damn with faint praise or t'were there one whose fire through genius kindles and fair flame inspires." Has Leeds beating West Ham 1-0 ever been more poetic? It's sure to be a knockout.

Devotees of the inimitable Stuart Hall can now congregate at The Church Hall at BBC Online to hear the sage's irreverent observations on the beautiful game. Surfers will be able to relive such wonders as this radio rambling: "To damn with faint praise or t'were there one whose fire through genius kindles and fair flame inspires." Has Leeds beating West Ham 1-0 ever been more poetic? It's sure to be a knockout.

 The Uefa website makes it clear how England will fare in Euro 2000. Its guide to Kevin Keegan's team refers to "skipper Alan Shearer and his bunch of no hopers".

 The administrators at First Division Crystal Palace have come up with another ingenious way of raising funds. In next Saturday's game with Sheffield United, season-ticket holders can, for only £25, vote for the slogan of their choice to adorn the players' shirts. The smart money is on "Palace 'till I die". More like "Palace 'till I'm sold for a pittance next week".

 Apparently Bradford have pointed out to Villa that when someone offers to take away your rubbish you usually pay them .

 Luton's Nigerian defender Efetobar Sodje, banned from wearing his trademark bandanna during the African Nations Cup, now says he will wear a "secret" one. He sports the head scarf because his mother says it will bring him luck. "I had a chat with my mum and we have agreed I wear a secret bandanna whenever I play," he said. Not that he plays very often. Yet to appear off the Nigerian bench, he has turned his attentions to tapping the market in invisible lucky charms. Nice.

 Darlington's attempt to stop their Feethams pitch waterlogging has failed. They placed thousands of worms on the playing surface to improve drainage, but all the worms drowned.

 According to an inquiry by the Israel Football Association, four players who had sex with "call girls and girlfriends" before the 5-0 Euro 2000 play-off defeat by Denmark are "not fit to wear the national colours again". But the players claimed nobody had forbidden them to hire call girls. Besides, some had hired prostitutes the night before a match against Austria which the Israelis had won 5-0. Double standards?

fields.headline: Negri falls into black hole
fields.standfirst: Rangers' Italian goalscoring machine has not played a serious game for 20 months
fields.trailText: Ian Archer reports on Rangers' Italian goalscoring machine Marco Negri who has not played a serious game for 20 months. There is something badly wrong with this guy but no one knows quite what it is.
fields.body:
When Saturday comes, much of the nation turns its thoughts to football. Those who have season tickets take their places at the grounds. The disenfranchised turn on Sky and watch Rodney Marsh tell them what is happening on his private monitor. And the seriously angry prepare themselves for an outburst on a radio phone-in.

That tribe, however, does not contain Marco Negri, even though he will earn an estimated £18,000 this week from the game. Rangers' Italian striker has not kicked a ball for his club in the past 20 months and, even more exasperating, no one is able to explain why he is merely a bystander.

The Negri case is more baffling than that of Stan Collymore, whose demons have been pored over in public and whose physical and mental stresses are well documented, even if they appear nonsensical to those who would jump a retaining wall and write a cheque to the club in order to play for Aston Villa for five minutes.

The history of the reluctant professional simply ends on April 1 1998, the last time he pulled on a Rangers jersey. Despite the best attempts of the Scotia Nostra, a desperate band of tartan sports hacks, to crack the story, the truth remains not so much elusive as completely barren. There is something badly wrong with this guy but no one knows quite what it is.

Walter Smith signed Negri for the Scottish champions in June 1997 from Perugia for £3.5m and even the manager's move to Everton has not allowed him to shed any light on the transfer. He remains tight-lipped, as does everyone else involved, including several garrulous players who have left Ibrox and who are not normally reticent with their off-the-record briefings.

At first it seemed that Smith had uncovered a gem. Negri scored a phenomenal 23 goals in his first 10 matches for Rangers and even if the standard of the opposition rarely rose above the pedestrian, it was the highest goal-per-game tally in Europe.

The fans, of course, loved him but even then there were hints that the affection was not shared. A goal might be acknowledged with the briefest of handshakes with a few team-mates but even if he felt some joy it was not shared with the supporters. Right from the start Negri gave the impression that he would have preferred to be elsewhere.

That alienation had been illustrated even before the scoring run started. Rangers' first match that season was a Champions League qualifier in the Faroe Islands. Waiting for an incoming plane in the sparse terminal on that rocky outcrop in the Atlantic is not exactly the most glamorous of events. While the rest of a gregarious squad swapped jokes and played cards, Negri sat at the other end of the lounge, talking to no one.

At the time it was assumed that his unfamiliarity with the English language made him shy and after a few dressing-room japes he would become one of the lads. The other players thought so and in the meantime they were happy to let him secure the win bonuses. But Negri stubbornly resisted all invitations to join the players' club.

By December he had scored 30 goals and had made friends with another Italian, the full-back Sergio Porrini. The two men went to play squash and Negri got hit, seriously it was said, in the eye. He was out injured for weeks and the rumour factory worked overtime. He played little after recovering, adding only two goals, and during that period Smith seemed to give up on him.

Smith was replaced by Dick Advocaat, the ultimate pragmatist. The Dutchman may have made overtures to Negri but he now sees him as the man who never was. To recoup Rangers' outlay, Negri was shipped to Vicenza on loan but returned with a back injury at the same time as the Italian media was reporting a fall-out.

Last month Rangers took him to Florida for their midwinter break and very briefly Advocaat enthused. Negri had attended all nine of the non-compulsory training sessions. But asked about him this week, the manager said tersely: "He's got a hamstring injury."

Negri remains largely idle, although he turned out in a friendly in Rotterdam last week. Not a soul is letting on why. The Italian will have earned almost £1.5m in wages since he last kicked a ball in earnest for Rangers. It must be the easiest way to earn a living.

fields.headline: Airdrie liquidator looks to Archibald
fields.trailText: Steve Archibald, the former East Fife manager and Scotland striker who is reported to have declared an interest in buying Airdrie, has been urged to show his hand.
fields.body:
Steve Archibald, the former East Fife manager and Scotland striker who is reported to have declared an interest in buying Airdrie, has been urged to show his hand.

The First Division club were placed in provisional liquidation this week with debts of £750,000 but will hold an emergency general meeting on Monday, when shareholders will be asked to allow the constitution to be changed to clear the way for a takeover bid.

"I'm happy to speak to Steve Archibald, indeed anyone else who may have an interest," said Blair Nimmo, the liquidator.

George Peat became treasurer of the Scottish Football Association again yesterday with a surprise defeat of the Hearts chief executive Chris Robinson in a vote of the member clubs.

Peat, who resigned the post last year after leaving the Airdrie board, is now a director of Stenhousemuir.

fields.headline: Read my hips, Dr Freud
fields.standfirst: Jim White explores the wider, weirder world of sport
fields.trailText: The fear of institutionalised anti-Celticism provoked ridicule this week as the bodylanguage of Old Firm referees came under scrutiny. But think of the possibilties of a bodylanguage expert in every stadium.
fields.body:
Now we know what the chief executives of football clubs do with themselves. In a week that suggested they have more time on their hands than is strictly healthy, Gordon Bennett of Aberdeen was cautioned by police for kerb crawling. Meanwhile Alan McDonald, his counterpart at Celtic, distinguished himself by revealing he had hired a psychologist to assess whether the body language of Hugh Dallas, the referee in an Old Firm game last season, provoked crowd disturbances.

According to McDonald, Dallas was particularly overfamiliar with the backside of Giovanni van Bronkhorst, patting it fondly when the handsome Rangers player went to take a corner. Seconds later Dallas was brought to his knees by a coin flung from the stands by an enraged Celt. The two incidents, McDonald contended, were not entirely unrelated.

Ever since McDonald held a press conference to reveal his findings early this week, senior Celtic figures have been distancing themselves from his remarks. The club's manager John Barnes and the captain Tom Boyd both ridiculed the idea, particularly as slo-mo video evidence suggests Dallas's hand was several inches north of the Van Bronkhorst rear end at the time in question.

Meanwhile the Scottish press has had a romp at the club's expense, suggesting McDonald's behaviour fits a pattern of Celtic paranoia, the lingering assumption that the Scottish football establishment is out to do them down.

This fear of institutionalised anti-Celticism led a branch of the supporters' club back in 1990 to hire a pair of private detectives to follow the referee Jim McCluskey. Their brief was to establish that McCluskey was a member of an Orange Lodge and thus inclined to Rangers. The investigation failed to uncover evidence of any sort of masonic activity, the referee's trouser bottoms remaining steadfastly around his ankles. Indeed you wonder why the supporters' club went to the expense, as all they needed to do was engineer an opportunity to shake the man by the hand.

I believe, though, that McDonald has been ridiculed unfairly. He is not so much a whirly-eyed fanatic as a visionary. Think of the possibilities of a body-language expert in every stadium, brought in to analyse the psychological wellbeing of players and officials alike. What would they make of Martin O'Neill, leaping about on the touchline as though an army of soldier ants had taken up residence in his underpants? Or how would they diagnose the urge Benito Carbone has to remove his shirt at every opportunity, unless it is to prove to his mum that he did indeed remember to wear a vest?

If only bodylanguage experts had always been around. Remember David Pleat's one-man pitch invasion at Manchester City when Luton Town won to stay in the First Division and send their hosts down? Expert assistance could have been summoned to help a man overcome the internal demons which had driven him to wear grey slip-on shoes.

Body-language diagnosis could have saved money, too. No need for the expense of a full-scale drug test, for instance, when close analysis of Maradona's goal celebration during the 1994 World Cup when he attempted congress with a camera lens would have told officials all they needed to know about his narcotic habit.

Indeed McDonald need only commission a shrink to monitor Roy Keane and he will acquire more than enough evidence to prove his idea is a good one. Why is Keane always so anxious to engage the referee in debate about his neutrality? Surely, since the Manchester United captain has expressed an interest in eventually joining Celtic, he is merely demonstrating that he shares their rigour in ensuring referee impartiality.

fields.headline: Year today, gone tomorrow
fields.standfirst: Don't waste your year off dreaming about where you would like to go one day. Hit the road today. Emily Barr  starts the budget adventure rolling
fields.trailText: Don't waste your year off dreaming about where you would like to go one day. Hit the road today. Emily Barr starts the budget adventure rolling.
fields.body:
Everybody is always planning to go travelling. It is one of those activities, like writing a book, that is filed under for "one day". In the 18th century, it was fashionable to do the Grand Tour of Europe. Today, it can be anywhere, and increasing numbers of people are taking the radical step of reinventing themselves as temporary nomads.

Budget travelling over an extended period is an established phenomenon, with its own stereotypes - everyone hates a smug backpacker - its own literature (Alex Garland et al ) and even a specialised menu, headed by banana pancakes. On the road, there are travellers from Japan, America, Europe, Australasia, Korea and anywhere else that can wield the necessary economic might. The only thing the travellers have in common is that all of them have translated "one day" into "today".

The first stop for the would-be backpacker is a travel agent, unless you are planning to travel overland, in which case you just need a ticket to Dover. I spent hours with a preternaturally patient consultant at Bridge the World, whose reassurance that I could travel alone, without meeting a lonely or dramatic end (probably), was worth at least as much as his practical advice. Think of somewhere you've always wanted to visit, on any continent, and take it from there.

If I was planning my round-the-world trip again, I would visit fewer places and see them in greater detail. Some countries, needless to say, are easy (but comparatively expensive) for the western traveller; places such as America and New Zealand. Some are entirely alien, and there are always surprises. In general, the further removed you are from your normal context, the more rewarding the experience. I love Asia; Africa and South America grip people in the same way, and lead them to go back time and time again.

It can be comforting, after making the decision to go away, and acting on the decision with a certain amount of trepidation, to discover that what you have done is nowhere near as unusual as you'd thought. Plenty of people arrive in somewhere like Bangkok, go to the Khao San Road, and slip into a comfort zone. Areas set up to meet travellers' needs such as this can help with battery recharging between adventures, but it would be all too easy to spend weeks drinking with compatriots, watching Hollywood movies and laughing at the freaks. It is, I think, important to hold on to the sense of adventure, to throw away the Lonely Planet from time to time and get off the well-worn circuit. You have the entire world to escape to, and absolute freedom.

The next pre-departure stop is the doctor. When everyone else in the waiting room has flu or a bawling baby, and you are there because you're heading for the tropics, you have to smile. Some countries, such as Brazil, insist on seeing a yellow fever vaccination certificate, while for most developing countries you should be innoculated against typhoid, tetanus, polio and hepatitis A, and talk to a doctor about malaria pills (this is not, of course, an exhaustive list). On Ko Poda, a spectacular Thai island, I swam into some spiky underwater coral, and 20 needles snapped off, embedding themselves in my fingers and thigh. I crawled out of the sea, blood pouring down my leg. As I performed amateur surgery, with an earring sterilised in vodka, I was glad of my tetanus jab.

The chances of theft are probably smaller than people think. It is, however, important to have good insurance. The cheaper one-year policies only cover trips of up to six weeks. If you're away for longer, and try to claim, they will find out. Of course they will. They're an insurance company.

A diary and a camera will ensure you have something to gaze at wistfully when you get home. A travelling e-mail address, from yahoo, hotmail, england.com or countless others, is handy for keeping in touch with everyone at home, although it takes away much of the remoteness of the experience. Daily contact with home is not really the point of chucking it all in to see the world, but the odd e-mail session can be extremely comforting.

Beyond all this, you just need a certain amount of energy. The unexpected lurks at every turn. There is humour in the least likely places. People in developing countries are fascinated by us, particularly if we are fascinated by them. Meanwhile, there is ignorance in the most "developed" of places. On an American train, a Texan girl asked where I was from. "England," I said. "Can you speak French?" she wondered. I spoke a few words for her entertainment. "Did you learn English at school?" she asked. "You speak it quite well."

Top 10 for 2000

1 Cambodia
2 Cuba
3 Ghana
4 Lebanon
5 Hong Kong
6 Ukraine
7 Argentina
8 Las Vegas
9 Libya
10 Kerala, India

Footprints on The Beach
Young travellers are becoming increasingly adventurous and travelling to more far-flung destinations, with many looking for the experiences highlighted in Alex Garland's novel The Beach.

Research commissioned by Visa and STA Travel especially for Student Travel Week and to tie in with the release of the film The Beach on Friday, shows that 18-30-year-olds believe that independent travel is an essential rite of passage before embarking on a career or university course.

Despite Leonardo DiCaprio's on-screen appeal, only 7% of young women would choose to be shipwrecked with him. Favourite was Brad Pitt, with Ewan McGregor second, followed by Johnny Vaughan. Jennifer Lopez topped men's wish-list, followed by Boddington's ad girl Melanie Sykes and MTV presenter Cat Deeley.

Backpacker's tips

 Keep small amounts of money in different places.
 To avoid carrying a lot of cash around with you, make use of ATMs.
 Carry a credit card for emergencies.
 Note emergency contact numbers for your bank and/or card issuers.
 Photocopy front and back of cards in case of emergency.

fields.headline: Land of the giants
fields.standfirst: Elephants labour in the shadows of Kerala all year round. But for one day they were paraded through the streets. Photographer  Martin Godwin was there to capture the majestic scene
fields.trailText: Elephants labour in the shadows of Kerala all year round. But for one day they were paraded through the streets. Photographer Martin Godwin was there to capture the majestic scene.
fields.body:
Just before the elephant march last month in Thodupuzha, Kerala, I went for my first ride on one of those silent, giant, gentle creatures. Maybe that ride made me slightly blasé. And maybe knowing that elephants in that southern Indian state were beasts of burden, moving logs, lumbering down those long, rutted, dusty roads, blinded me to the revelation that was to be our day out.

A small crowd - a few Indians and a lot of European tourists - is what I anticipated. Nothing to get too excited about, even if tusked elephants are getting as rare as tigers, thanks to poachers.

We were staying in a house on the beach in nearby Kovalam whose owner had told us about the march. The event was scheduled for the following day. But, then, one can never be quite sure about timetables in India.

We had wanted to see the elephant march in the state capital, Trivandrum. It was an annual event, apparently, but it hadn't happened when we supposed it was going to and we had forgotten about it. Then along came this one-off march in Thodupuzha, part of a local festival with bullock-cart races and a produce exhibition and talks on organic farming.

I, my wife and three children set out in a rented car with a driver, for a four-and-a-half-hour air-cooled journey (well, we had the windows down) over potholed, slightly alarming roads across a land of rivers, waterfalls and hill stations under the high ranges of the Western Ghat mountains.

Before we saw the elephants in Thodupuzha, it was the people. Every flat surface in town had somebody standing on it. Spectators were crammed on top of every building, every window was full of faces. Buses, swamped by humanity, were marooned in the middle of the high street - punctuated by the town's main electric power cable - with onlookers struggling on to their roofs. One hundred thousand people had flooded in to glimpse 130 spectacularly bedecked - and seemingly bemused - elephants.

It was hot, yet not a bead of sweat could be seen on the faces around us. My family and I were the only Europeans in town, and thus the second biggest attraction after the elephants.

We edged our way through the crowds to a playground, inside which the elephants had been gathered prior to the march. These creatures were not bred for show, they were working elephants, each with its rider perched high on its shoulders.

The elephant march began, and we were ushered out of the playground. Colourful umbrellas swayed in the riders' hands; one brushed the cable, a cascade of sparks arced over the heads of the crowd.

This was not the noise of some English carnival, the elephants were silent, so was that vast throng. Elephants may be part of the landscape and legend of India but to see that many - some of the vast animals that work all year round in the distant forests of Kerala - was awesome not just to five hot Londoners, but to the other 100,000 people in Thodupuzha.

fields.headline: Ski briefs
fields.trailText: * The Andorran slopes of Soldeu-El Tartar are now linked by lift with those of Pas de La Casa - but the two resorts are still unable to agree on a common pass. So what if you pay in advance for a lift pass in one or other, only to find that, by the time you get there, an accord has been struck? Tour operator Panorama (01233 211998) says it will let you upgrade on arrival for a small extra payment. It is also offering packages where you can spend one day in each of the five main areas. Instead of buying a one-week local lift pass, ranging from £60-£80, you can opt for a £189 bulk deal of day tickets for lifts in Arinsal , Pal , Arcalis and the two newly-connected neighbours. The deal includes transport to and from your accommodation - departing at 8.30am and returning at 4pm.

Also on offer are discounted one-week chalet packages for £499 in Val d'Isère , with a flight on the same date from Gatwick, and in St Anton , departing from Heathrow next day. The prices represent cuts of £185 and £200.

* If you can slope off on February 12, catered chalets in Courchevel , Val d'Isere and La Tania cost from £339 per person including midday flight (British Airways from Manchester and Air 2000 from Gatwick), transfers and half-board accommodation with unlimited wine. Le Ski (01484 548996).

Roger Bray

webTitle: Paul Theroux: Tabasco sauce | A radio | A Swiss Army knife

fields.headline: Paul Theroux never travels without...
fields.trailText: Tabasco sauce | A radio | A Swiss Army knife
fields.body:
A necessity: A bottle of Tabasco sauce. Just a little bit takes the curse off revolting meals. "You want some more 'aso adobo' [dog stew], Meesta Paul?"

A luxury: A small Sony 9-band short-wave radio, to hear the bongs of Big Ben on the hour.

A memento: A Swiss Army knife. You seldom use the thing, but the Phillips head screwdriver comes in handy, and what if your horse had a stone in its hoof?

If only: A flying carpet. I cannot stand air travel.

 Fresh Air Fiend, Travel Writings, 1985-2000 by Paul Theroux is published by Hamish Hamilton at £20.

fields.headline: Beautiful south
fields.standfirst: As Nice gears up for the start of this year's carnival,  Peter Lennon tastes the high life on the Riviera
fields.trailText: As Nice gears up for the start of this year's carnival, Peter Lennon tastes the high life on the Riviera.
fields.body:
I t was in 1880 that the Nice Mardi Gras carnival broke free of its masked-ball confinement and took to the streets, pasting the populace with flour, eggs and confetti. But progress and the "free" market must have its way and, by the 1980s, under the ubiquitous hand of Mayor Jacques Médecin, it was conducted in the modern way: fenced-off places and promenades fitted with commercial sentry boxes at each entry. But you can still get a bit of the carnival - running this year from February 10-March 7 - free in the side streets.

(By the way don't mention Jacques Médecin when you are in Nice. Never you mind why, just don't mention him).

So you have brassy bands and leggy parades, floats and big heads, giant representations of the theme of the year. And the battle of the flowers as the procession comes down the avenue Jean Médecin ( Jean , his father, not Jacques) and for a day takes over from the cars on the Promenade des Anglais.

But Nice, founded by the Phoenicians, owned in turn by Italy and France, has more to it than parades. There is the radiant Cours Saleya, a sunny Italianate space resplendent with stalls of crystallised fruit, cheese and sausages surrounded by cafés.

For those who yearn for the days when counts and princesses arrived at the Riviera with refugee status and hardly a tiara to their name (the Russians were co-founders with the English of "modern" Nice), there is the touching Russian Orthodox Cathedral.

Inside, it is a jewel- and icon-encrusted bazaar as much as a church. It was built by the Tsar as an offering for the health of his haemophilic son. Now it's a kind of Aladdin's cave of pious and pathetic relics carrying the patina of aristocratic grief.

But if the soul must (and should) be satisfied, there is the Musée Matisse. Conventional museums are, in a sense, the scaffolding that holds high, and a little out of emotional reach, the works that made an artist great. The Musée is mostly of works that did not make Matisse famous. Most are from his home, objects that he lived among all his life.

Here is Matisse's very first painting, a still life of books executed with painful earnestness while this 20-year-old law student was living through a long convalescence. It is a sombre work: two piles of dark books on a newspaper. The gravity of the application is obvious; there is an endearing suggestion that he was seeking conventional solutions to this new craft (so different from the fabricated certainties of law). It has a touching conformity that contrasts with the wild free fantasy of his Jazz series one room away.

Or for a more sedentary morning, you can just sit in a café, eat splendid ice cream and see what the local newspaper, Nice-Matin, has to say for itself.

Oh damn, I'm going to have to mention Jacques Médicin. His ex-wife chose this very day to inexplicably return to Nice after a six-year absence and has been instantly nabbed by the flics and tossed in the clink on some fiscal matter. There was an old warrant waiting for her from the days in 1990 when Mayor Jacques - who had for 25 years presided over what was called "a cocktail of clannism and clientism"-felt it prudent to take off for Argentina. His suitcases, when opened at Orly airport, turned out to be full of used notes.

He returned eventually to pay a few months' debt to society and then went off last year to Uruguay, where, the French tell us, he "flows the happy days". The unfortunate ex-Mme Médicin was just temporarily caught by a stale warrant.

That's Nice for you. I wanted to spare the town its blushes, but there it is, Médicin front page news again. But Nice is a broad . . . well, I wouldn't say church exactly; more a broad casino, and they don't blush easily.

However, none of this affects the casual visitor, the one with a taste for historical relics, sea breeze and good food.

If you want to feel you are part of a spectacle when you eat, there is the splendid Brasserie Flo on rue Sacha Guitry. It was once a theatre and now the cooks, in full view on stage, perform behind a glass panel, eternally Waiting for Wesker.

And if you are yearning to pretend you have broken the bank at Monte Carlo, stop off for tea on the Hotel Negresco on the Promenade des Anglais. Then on to Menton by the Grande Corniche. Originally an old Roman road, this is a spectacular ride in and out of tunnels to resplendent views familiar from car chases in To Catch a Thief to The Persuaders. If you are delicate, vertigo-wise, you can throttle down to the Moyenne Corniche or, if a downright coward, there is the Corniche Inférieure.

Menton, the lemon town, has a particular charming feature: you toil up the steep, angled streets of the old town, up and up, past the Eglises des Pénitents Blancs and Noirs, and, rising above the living, you visit the dead. Right on top is the the graveyard, the Cimetière du Vieux Chateau. Angels of the muscular and rather skinhead type obstinately try flapping their stone wings over the weedy tombs, while the wide, washed blue sky suggests an escape highway to eternity for the righteous. The rest of us can sip our Pernod and wait for the charabanc to the nether region.

Despite massive real-estate development, the Riviera preserves very convincing fragments of its mythical past. We stayed at the Hotel Aiglon, a luxurious little mansion on the Ave de la Madone. It has been family run since 1925.

You take breakfast in the library, where old mahogany bookcases declare the literary taste of its anglophile founder: Mrs Belloc Lowndes; Conan Doyle; Galsworthy and, rare, a novel by E Philips Oppenhemier, a once best-selling author whose pencil-thin heroines and sleek-haired English heroes dispatched spies on the Riviera unmessily with fists to the delight of members of the Army and Navy Club in London.

A flaking yellow copy of one of his novels, magazine size as was the format then, is literary marmalade for my breakfast.

5 best museums

1 Musée Matisse 164 Avenue des Arènes de Cimiez (93 81 08 08)

Book illustrations including James Joyce's Ulysses, fabric design, his complete works in bronze and paintings from every era.

2 Musée Chagall (Musée National Message Biblique) Avenue du Docteur Menard (93 81 75 75)

Modern museum housing more than 500 paintings, drawings, prints and stained glass by the Russian-born local resident. Attractive Mediterranean garden and café.

3 Musée d'Art Moderne et d'Art Contemporain

Promenade des Arts (93 62 61 62)

Nice's newest museum. Impressive grey marble and glass setting for hundreds of pop art, neorealistic, and avant garde pieces, including Yves Klein, Tinguely, Warhol and Lichtenstein.

4 Musée des Arts et Traditions Populaires

15 Rue Droite (93 62 05 54)

Odd collection of everyday objects and elaborate tromp l'oeil frescoes housed in a grand, 17th-century palais.

5 Musée Raoul Dufy 77 Quai des États Unis. (93 62 31 24)

Raoul Dufy spent much of his later life in Nice, and this small museum contains many of his charming if somewhat vacuous landscapes and street scenes, plus some early, more adventurous work in Cubist and Fauve style.

The practicals

The Magic of France (0208 7410208) has two-night breaks to Nice from £205. The price includes accommodation at the three-star Hotel Gounod, near the Promenade des Anglais, and scheduled flights with British Airways, price applicable until April 13. Extra nights for £26 per person per night. Two nights at the Hotel Aiglon cost around £70pp, including a meal in Le Riaumont garden restaurant.

fields.headline: Tales from the tabs
fields.trailText: Man Utd want Anderton and Sullivan; Middlesbrough want Trezeguet; Arsenal want Oliseh. All this and much more.
fields.body:
UNITED GO FOR DARREN SWOOP

Manchester United have finalised big money offers to take out-of-contract Darren Anderton and Wimbledon's Neil Sullivan to Old Trafford this summer.

ROBBO'S DES TREZ: BORO GO FOR FRENCHIE

Bryan Robson is chasing French star David Trezeguet: Boro's move for Teddy Sheringham collapsed last week, making the Monaco man Robbo's top target.

AND THE REST

Arsenal are chasing Juventus' Nigerian icon Sunday Oliseh - Arsène Wenger has made initial approaches and Juve are ready to sell; Paolo Maldini has received offers from Arsenal and Chelsea as he prepares to move to England this summer; Manchester United target Ruud van Nistelrooy has agreed to leave PSV for Roma in a massive £17 million switch - the striker was also being tracked by Chelsea , Leeds and Arsenal ; Everton's Don Hutchison has issued a fresh denial that he's set for a move to the North East: 'It's a disgrace that someone can quote me as saying I want to leave when I haven't even said it'; Liverpool have turned their attention from Emile Heskey to Belgian striker Luc Nilis; Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink is fishing for a return to England; Forest's David Prutton says he wants to stay at the City Ground despite interest from Chelsea; Middlesbrough are planning a deal for York City's highly-rated Christian Fox; Glenn Hoddle has rejected Norwegian trialist Alexander Aas at Southampton ; Aston Villa have taken striker Gustavo Bartelt on loan with a view to a permanent £4m move; Sunderland are chasing Swedish striker Marcus Allback; Spurs could be about to complete a £5m deal for Ipswich striker David Johnson after George Burley signed Hudderfield's Marcus Stewart to replace him; Brian Little has failed in a move to take Ruel Fox from Spurs to West Brom on loan - he'll concentrate instead on Forest's Marlon Harewood; Watford are ready to complete a deal for Reading's Darren Caskey; and Wimbledon have confirmed that Ben Thatcher is likely to join Liverpool for £5m this summer.

webTitle: May the G-force be with you

fields.headline: May the G-force be with you
fields.standfirst: Forget bungee-jumping, give white-water rafting a wide berth, the fastest show on earth is a rocket ride called Fly By Wire.  Patricia Davies goggles up in Queenstown
fields.trailText: Forget bungee-jumping, give white-water rafting a wide berth, the fastest show on earth is a rocket ride called Fly By Wire. Patricia Davies goggles up in Queenstown.
fields.body:
The driver who shuttles bleary-eyed adventure seekers from the luxurious calm of the Millbrook Resort and Country Club to The Station, the hub of all activity in the middle of action-packed Queenstown, was doubtful. "I've done most of the hundred or so rides available around here," he said, "but I'm not so sure I'd do this one."

A couple of hours later, clad in red overalls, gloves, goggles and helmet, strapped in and lying face down in a small, open-topped rocket that was too homespun for NASA and too straightforward for Heath Robinson, I wasn't so sure either.

"I must be bats," I thought, as my machine was winched up the mountainside to a height of 105m - that's more than 30 storeys high - and the position was a little bat-like, hanging head down above a peaceful valley that was an incongruous setting for something billed as "the world's fastest adventure ride", which can reach speeds of 171kmph.

I was well strapped in, although my body was trying to exit through my helmet and my head for heights had gone walkabout. "Beam me down, Scotty," I wanted to bawl but by then I was at the launch point and Mark, the man in charge of this madness, was giving me the thumbs up.

I pressed the red button that lit the blue touchpaper - well, released the winch and started the engine - and literally rocketed off across the valley for seven minutes of fun that was fast, furious and, in my case, haphazard because I had my hand on the throttle and was in charge of the steering - it's a bit like a bike, nothing too complicated, with a rocket but no rocket science.

Not that you're in any danger of crashing into anything. All the measurements have been carefully vetted by computer and, since the rocket is on a wire that is 11 times stronger than it needs to be and is secured by steel rock anchors set in concrete that is metres thick, there's no danger of coming unstuck. It's so safe that, as far as I remember, I wasn't even asked to sign a waiver saying that I was undertaking all this at my own risk. It was also so much fun that I'd do it all again, even the bat-like bit.

This piece of Bond-like nonsense is called Fly By Wire and was dreamt up by Neil Harrap. Literally. He woke up in the middle of the night, having dreamt that he was flying around a valley on a wire and set out to work out just how he could manage it. An aeronautical engineer designed the rocket and Neil, who has now sold the idea to the Americans, found his valley, at the back of Queenstown Hill, when he was off on a heliskiing jaunt.

Queenstown, a short, if sometimes bumpy flight, or a torturous six-hour drive, from Christchurch, is that sort of place. All action. If you sit outside the café, the traffic seems to consist entirely entirely of vans, four-wheel drives and buses, all ferrying people and equipment somewhere breathtaking to do something heartstopping.

At the height of the summer and winter seasons, visitors can outnumber locals by as many as three to one. It's hardly surprising, really. Queenstown is idyllically situated beside Lake Wakatipu in the Southern Alps of South Island and, if you wanted to, you could just enjoy the views, which couldn't fail to uplift the most jaded of souls.

The Dart River Jet Safari is spectacular in the extreme: a journey into Mount Aspiring National Park, surrounded by snow-covered mountains, with names such as Chaos and Pluto, glaciers and rainforest.

Jetboats are specially designed to operate in only inches of water and at times we seemed to be running on pebbles as our driver weaved his way along narrow channels and flashed past huge rocks. It was more than exhilarating enough for the eight debutants in our boat, but an experienced hand complained that the trip had lost its thrill. "The drivers are definitely more cautious," he said.

There is a reason for that. In early November, on a different ride on a different river, a Japanese honeymooner had been killed when the boat he was in collided with a rock face. The Maritime Safety Authority issued an edict that drivers should keep a metre away from the canyon rocks and adhere to a slightly more conservative driving line.

It's proably illegal to leave Queenstown without mentioning the "B" word. Bungee, in its mad, modern form, began here and spawned all sorts of daredevilment. AJ Hackett, the man responsible for the bungee craze, made it sound simple. "All that is needed is a sense of adventure and a willingness to try new things," he said and Queens-town makes it easy. You can go bungee jumping, hang-gliding, hot-air ballooning, river surfing, skiing, sky diving, kayaking, tramping, horse riding, parapenting, abseiling, almost anything. It's the town where your feet need never touch the ground.

The practicals

Queenstown Fly By Wire, Rees Street, Queens-town (0064 25 300 474; www.flybywire.co.nz) costs £40, which includes 4WD transport to the canyon. Millbrook Resort and Country Club, Malaghans Road, Arrowtown, Near Queenstown, tel: 0064 3 441 7000, fax: 0064 3 441 7016; www.millbrook.co.nz Accommodation options range from suites to cottages, with prices starting from £100.
