fields.headline: Sapphire and steel
fields.standfirst: Carol Shields marries sparkling variety with fierce control in Dressing Up for the Carnival
fields.trailText: Carol Shields marries sparkling variety with fierce control in Dressing Up for the Carnival
fields.body:
Dressing Up for the Carnival
Carol Shields
Fourth Estate, £15.99, 249pp

Carol Shields is frequently praised for her ability to celebrate the ordinary; nowhere was this more in evidence than in the critical response to her last novel, the Orange Prize-winning Larry's Party. Centred entirely on the minute detail of one man's life, the book's painstaking and often painful unfolding of his haphazard progress through life demonstrated her determination to transform banality into something remarkable, to commemorate the complexity and strange beauty of the everyday.

This attachment to ordinary life is not something that the author is above satirising in this superlative collection, going so far as to spell it out in one story, "Soup du Jour": "Everyone is coming out these days for the pleasures of ordinary existence. Sunsets. Dandelions. Fencing in the backyard and staying at home. 'The quotidian is where it's at,' Herb Rhinelander wrote last week in his nationwide syndicated column. 'People are getting their highs on the level rollercoaster of everydayness, dipping their daily bread in the soup of common delight and simple sensation.' "

In the topsy-turvy, thrill-fleeing world of this story, "adolescent girls stare into ditches where rainwater collects and mirrors the colours of passion, their young men study the labels of soup cans", and we learn that "there is no stone, shrub, chair, or door that does not offer arrows of implicit meaning or promises of epiphany".

But for Carol Shields there is more to an epiphany than looking at a sunset or a soup can. Dressing Up for the Carnival, far from being an inventory of the quotidian, is crammed full of oddity and downright peculiarity, stories of outlandish inventiveness jostling with pieces of sly, knowing comedy and tender, pathos-filled tales of loss and grief.

Often, Shields goes all out for an impression of whimsy and cuteness, before veering off wildly into unknown and unpredictable territory. "Invention" begins with the wholesome sentence "My grandmother, as everyone knows, was the inventor of the steering wheel muff", but this brief resumé soon yields to a whole litany of blatantly fabricated forebears, from the grammarian who invented the hyphen to the Greek shepherd boy who, finding himself overcome with boredom on an ancient hillside, happened across the daydream. The creator of this unlikely roll-call of achievement perversely laments his own lack of inventiveness, while at the same time mounting a spirited defence of those who must simply keep the records, "interpret, analyse, speculate".

Each of these 22 stories is a self-contained unit, and yet there is a sense in which the entire collection has been assembled in such a way as to set up mirrors, parallels and opposites. Unlike many other assortments of short fiction, there is no feeling of random gathering, nor of any stilted coercion of pieces made to dance to an arbitrary theme. The stories that echo one another do so subtly and quietly, similarities suggesting themselves in an unshowy manner.

In "Windows", two artists find themselves the subject of a new and unwelcome window tax that deprives them of natural light and compels one of them to undertake a mammoth project - painting a slab of plywood to recreate the peculiar effect of window glass, "a steaming liquid that has been frozen into a solid plane".

The process of creation is vexing, glassiness eluding her, until the moment at which it suddenly arrives, yielding "not real light, but the idea of light - infinitely more alluring than light itself". It is an artistic triumph that owes much to "illusion, accident, meticulous attention", and results in the creation of a simulacrum much more satisfying than its real counterpart, providing a window "that would rest in the folds of the mind as all that was ideal and desirable in the opening, beckoning, sensuous world".

That beckoning, sensuous world is held firmly at bay in another story, "Mirrors", in which a middle-aged couple deny themselves the pleasure and pain of mirrors at their country cottage, consigning themselves each year to a period of self-sightlessness. Shields undercuts the apparent high-mindedness of this sacrifice - its notion of renouncing vanity and superficiality - with a sad description of the narcissism and opacity of married life, in which the husband is moved to detect "something theatrical and childish about cultivated denial, something stubbornly wilful and self-cherishing". These are two people who know each other so well that they can assume each other's identity, yet who survive by the deliberate suppression of secrets.

Throughout, Shields extends a humane and sympathetic hand to her characters, many of them intent on eking out their lives, on creating something lasting or valuable in the face of loss and absence. This compassion survives the most brutal and unsparing comic treatment, as in the delightfully irreverent story "Ilk".

Here a literary theorist, injured by criticism of her "atemporal paradigms" in the spring issue of Ficto-Factions, trades theories of narrative with a colleague at a conference. As their talk of fictive modules and micro-discourses progresses, or fails to, she is fixated by the one strand of narrative that will never be broached: the suicide of her colleague's wife. What could the one-word note she left behind have said? That word - "the central modality... the narrational heart" - resists discovery, and leaves these two slightly ridiculous characters exactly where they began, fighting over the last shrimp on a tray of canapés.

But where Shields ridicules, she also repairs; she is a writer who pays extraordinary attention to the importance of reparation and recuperation. The fragility of her characters' lives, "their cycles of consolation and enhancement", provides her with a narrative toughness, an ability to catalogue without falling into cliché or cuteness.

Several of the stories are narrated by writers; one is run ragged in old age by the perverse attentions of a biographer, another tormented by the lack of a letter "I" on her keyboard. Yet another writer reflects on the unexpected nature of her literary success, while at the same time admitting that she knows perfectly well that "there was something just a little bit darling about my own book".

Shields could be accused, falsely, of being a little bit darling; but it would be more accurate to note that she is more than usually daring. There are few writers currently at work who display such steely control of their material, such seemingly effortless range and variety.

There is also a marked shortage elsewhere of such exceptionally well-crafted and beautifully turned prose, deployed here to brilliant effect with wit and economy. This is an important collection: it is to be hoped it outwits the neglect that often befalls short fiction and receives the attention it deserves.

fields.headline: Castles in the sand
fields.standfirst: Orson Welles filmed Othello here. Cat Stevens discovered Allah. Jimi Hendrix wrote songs and had fun.  John Cunningham finds society alive and well in a hassle-free Moroccan town
fields.trailText: Orson Welles filmed Othello here. Cat Stevens discovered Allah. Jimi Hendrix wrote songs and had fun. John Cunningham finds society alive and well in a hassle-free Moroccan town
fields.body:
Watchtowers, ramparts, a suicidal sea smashing itself below the fortress walls. Elsinore? No Essaouira. Orson Welles could have filmed Hamlet here. Perhaps sensibly, he went for Othello, altogether more suited to the medina and the mosques. But Essaouira is a chameleon town, quite capable of adapting to the wiles and guiles of Hollywood.

The more familiar in-your-face Morocco can be a turn off as well as an allure. But hassle-free Essaouira is literally set apart from the rest of the country. Three hours' drive north from Agadir or west from Marrakech, it's ideal as a 48-hour side trip if you're staying at either of the larger centres.

Access by road isn't as difficult as it used to be by sea. But the place has always been selective about those it admitted to its port and portals. Historically, traders were welcome; pirates not. Now, it's mostly individual tourists and couples who come to stay in its small hotels; the lack of huge hotels discourages packaged holiday invaders. The small-scale accommodation on offer ranges from the backpacking to the bijou.

You arrive dustily in a shared sky-blue Mercedes taxi, or humped and bumped along in a bus to a buggy debouching point just outside the town walls that does nothing to prepare you for the surprise lying within. Through the gate, a street spreads out. The market runs through it, and along it: fruit and veg and chickens in the first section; then, through a second portal, to bolts of cloth and cheap clothes - traditional robes and mostly western sports kit; then there's a side order of souks offering jewellery and silverware. Another portal opens on to a section of really useful things: pots and pans and bottled water. A final section takes you inside the town walls, past the clocktower and the palms. Little hotels and craft shops lurk here; alleyways hung with carpets on the warm town walls. Aladdin's caves of carvings and lamps beckon from dark shops. And beyond this, through a final arch, is the boat-building yard and fishing harbour, pincered and protected by the arms of the sea-wall, giving it the appropriate shape of a lobster's claw. Turn left, and you're at the start of the broad promenade that parallels the beach, which stretches for miles. But we'll come back to that.

What's special is the scale and neatness of the place. The market street you've just come along is shadily arcaded on either side and traffic-free except for porters' barrows and bikes. With its white walls and blue-shuttered windows, it's a sort of Moorish Toytown. Forget the labyrinthine bazaars of other Moroccan towns: the souks here seem to have been laid out on a grid by a logical Frenchman.

And indeed they were. An 18th-century local ruler, Sultan Sidi Mohammed had the good fortune to capture a French vessel. On board was one Theodore Cournut who was persuaded to use his architectural and engineering skills to rebuild parts of the town and to construct walls, with cannons mounted between the battlements, to deter marauders.

Essaouira is one of history's hand-me-downs: Phoenecian sailors were said to be here in the 7th century BC; the Portuguese had the port in their sights off and on from the 11th to the 16th century. There was a large and thriving Jewish community - you can still see now dilapidated mellah where they lived - but only a handful now remain. There was a mass exodus when Israel was founded.

Over the decades, Essaouira has managed to grind down the conflicts of the past, rather than be ground down by them. The walls, in the pinkish light of sunset, don't look terribly threatening now. Maybe they never were very fearsome, for the name Essaouira means "the little ramparts". In recent, less belligerent, times, the locals have put them to good use. The series of barrel- shaped cellars on the town-side are tenanted by an army of woodworkers who handcraft marquetry boxes and small pieces of furniture inlaid with different coloured woods and mother of pearl. The collective resonance of their tapping is part of the gentle soundtrack of Essaouira. In the port, it's the echo of adzes: the fishing boats, by which another portion of the community earns its bread, are built here. Amazingly, it's another hand-crafted activity; the timbers cut and planed by hand, without the whir of an electric saw to be heard.

Other activities are silent. Outside the walls, the sea may be booming and threshing, but in the sheltered lanes, looms are seamlessly and soundlessly weaving bright fabrics. A reminder, all this, that Essaouira is used to working for its living. That little boy ahead of you with a tray on his head is taking his mum's loaf to the baker's oven. Follow the thread from the bobbin held by a young girl and, yards later, it will lead you to a working loom.

From cockcrow to dusk, Essaouira works at weaving a sort of web that manages to involve everyone. And through the night, punctuated only by the calls to prayer from the mosques, fishing boasts slip in and out of the harbour.

If Lady Thatcher still believes there's no such thing as society, she ought to drop by - briefly. She'd learn that the single-cigarette sellers, the shoe-shine boys, the musicians who waggle their heads and beat gentle drums all have a role. So do the beggars, who ask modestly for "one dirham, monsieur" (£1 is worth between 15 and 16 dirhams). Gradually, the thought occurs that maybe it's not so much you being generous enough to give something to a beggar, but that the beggar is being gracious enough to recognise you as part of the scene.

Fanciful, perhaps, but even the hardest of haggling tourists here is thrown by a joke or a generous gesture by a local. There are waiters in the cafés in the Place Moulay el Hassan who'll bring you fresh orange juice, a milky coffee and a baguette with butter and apricot jam for around £1. From lunch to early evening, you can sit at the fish stalls between the Place and the port and have a plate of sardines grilled for you. With bread and a salad of chopped tomatoes and onions, it's 80 pence. A sole will cost around £2; seabass £3 or £4. The freshness factor - given the incredibly short distance between trawler and open-air grill - can't be higher anywhere.

Some of the joys of Essaouira are best experienced on an empty stomach, however. The Altantic besieging the fortress walls is only half the story. Turn towards the beach, and you have an ocean (relatively) becalmed. Not quite, for there is always a stiff breeze. It deters long-term sunbathers, but it is paradise for wind surfers. March and April are the months when Windy City, Africa, as the stickers on the backpacks say, most comes into its own. Then, the two or three écoles de voile on the beach are thronged. No motors, no towlines. Just perfect peace, even if you are doing no more than dawdling over a soft drink in a beachside caff.

Now it's mostly the French and German bourgeoisie who commune with the waves. A generation ago, hippies rather than dippies were most in evidence. Cat Stevens found Allah here, and Jimi Hendrix wrote Castles in the Sand, puffing, strumming and shagging for several golden summers. There are occasional faint echoes of that (if you're lucky enough to spot them). But you're far more likely to encounter the fine-upstanding rather than the horizontally inclined.

5 of the best

Places to eat
1 The fish stalls, just outside the gateway to the port. Plain grilled only - but the fish couldn't be fresher or cheaper.
2 Chez Sam . On the quayside. Piscatorial delights in a expensive nautical setting.
3 Restaurant Le Coquillage , just inside the port area. If Chez Sam is full, this will do nicely.
4 Restaurant Essalam, Place Prince Moulay Hassan. Go for the tajines - slow-cooked meat or fish stews.
5 Patisserie Driss, Place Prince Moulay Hassan. Driss is French bliss.

If you've any energy left over...
1 Go windsurfing. Try an é cole de voile by the beach.
2 Fly a kite. It's almost always windy.
3 Join in the football on the beach. Players of all standards welcome.
4 Try to find a new bar. There are not that many.
5 Keep right on to the end of the beach. It's inexhaustable - even if you're not.

The practicals
Simply Cities & Short Breaks (020-8541 2222) has three nights' B&B in Marrakech at the four-star Hotel Tichka Salamb from £454pp, including return scheduled flights from Gatwick and transfers (£377 for two nights). Essaouira is four hours by bus from Marrakech (about £1), or three hours in a communal taxi (£3 ). Villa Maroc, Rue Abdallah ben Yassin, costs from £30pp per night. Several budget places cost £10-£15pp.

Three hours' drive north from Agadir or west from Marrakech, it's ideal as a 48-hour side trip if you're staying at either of the larger centres. Access by road isn't as difficult as it used to be by sea. But the place has always been selective about those it admitted to its port and portals. Historically, traders were welcome; pirates not. Now, it's mostly individual tourists and couples who come to stay in its small hotels; the lack of huge hotels discourages packaged holiday invaders. The small-scale accommodation on offer ranges from the backpacking to the bijou. You arrive dustily in a shared sky-blue Mercedes taxi, or humped and bumped along in a bus to a buggy debouching point just outside the town walls that does nothing to prepare you for the surprise lying within. Through the gate, a street spreads out. The market runs through it, and along it: fruit and veg and chickens in the first section; then, through a second portal, to bolts of cloth and cheap clothes - traditional robes and mostly western sports kit; then there's a side order of souks offering jewellery and silverware. Another portal opens on to a section of really useful things: pots and pans and bottled water. A final section takes you inside the town walls, past the clocktower and the palms. Little hotels and craft shops lurk here; alleyways hung with carpets on the warm town walls. Aladdin's caves of carvings and lamps beckon from dark shops. And beyond this, through a final arch, is the boat-building yard and fishing harbour, pincered and protected by the arms of the sea-wall, giving it the appropriate shape of a lobster's claw. Turn left, and you're at the start of the broad promenade that parallels the beach, which stretches for miles. But we'll come back to that. What's special is the scale and neatness of the place. The market street you've just come along is shadily arcaded on either side and traffic-free except for porters' barrows and bikes. With its white walls and blue-shuttered windows, it's a sort of Moorish Toytown. Forget the labyrinthine bazaars of other Moroccan towns: the souks here seem to have been laid out on a grid by a logical Frenchman. And indeed they were. An 18th-century local ruler, Sultan Sidi Mohammed had the good fortune to capture a French vessel. On board was one Theodore Cournut who was persuaded to use his architectural and engineering skills to rebuild parts of the town and to construct walls, with cannons mounted between the battlements, to deter marauders. Essaouira is one of history's hand-me-downs: Phoenecian sailors were said to be here in the 7th century BC; the Portuguese had the port in their sights off and on from the 11th to the 16th century. There was a large and thriving Jewish community - you can still see now dilapidated mellah where they lived - but only a handful now remain. There was a mass exodus when Israel was founded. Over the decades, Essaouira has managed to grind down the conflicts of the past, rather than be ground down by them. The walls, in the pinkish light of sunset, don't look terribly threatening now. Maybe they never were very fearsome, for the name Essaouira means "the little ramparts". In recent, less belligerent, times, the locals have put them to good use. The series of barrel- shaped cellars on the town-side are tenanted by an army of woodworkers who handcraft marquetry boxes and small pieces of furniture inlaid with different coloured woods and mother of pearl. The collective resonance of their tapping is part of the gentle soundtrack of Essaouira. In the port, it's the echo of adzes: the fishing boats, by which another portion of the community earns its bread, are built here. Amazingly, it's another hand-crafted activity; the timbers cut and planed by hand, without the whir of an electric saw to be heard. Other activities are silent. Outside the walls, the sea may be booming and threshing, but in the sheltered lanes, looms are seamlessly and soundlessly weaving bright fabrics. A reminder, all this, that Essaouira is used to working for its living. That little boy ahead of you with a tray on his head is taking his mum's loaf to the baker's oven. Follow the thread from the bobbin held by a young girl and, yards later, it will lead you to a working loom. From cockcrow to dusk, Essaouira works at weaving a sort of web that manages to involve everyone. And through the night, punctuated only by the calls to prayer from the mosques, fishing boasts slip in and out of the harbour. If Lady Thatcher still believes there's no such thing as society, she ought to drop by - briefly. She'd learn that the single-cigarette sellers, the shoe-shine boys, the musicians who waggle their heads and beat gentle drums all have a role. So do the beggars, who ask modestly for "one dirham, monsieur" (£1 is worth between 15 and 16 dirhams). Gradually, the thought occurs that maybe it's not so much you being generous enough to give something to a beggar, but that the beggar is being gracious enough to recognise you as part of the scene. Fanciful, perhaps, but even the hardest of haggling tourists here is thrown by a joke or a generous gesture by a local. There are waiters in the cafés in the Place Moulay el Hassan who'll bring you fresh orange juice, a milky coffee and a baguette with butter and apricot jam for around £1. From lunch to early evening, you can sit at the fish stalls between the Place and the port and have a plate of sardines grilled for you. With bread and a salad of chopped tomatoes and onions, it's 80 pence. A sole will cost around £2; seabass £3 or £4. The freshness factor - given the incredibly short distance between trawler and open-air grill - can't be higher anywhere. Some of the joys of Essaouira are best experienced on an empty stomach, however. The Altantic besieging the fortress walls is only half the story. Turn towards the beach, and you have an ocean (relatively) becalmed. Not quite, for there is always a stiff breeze. It deters long-term sunbathers, but it is paradise for wind surfers. March and April are the months when Windy City, Africa, as the stickers on the backpacks say, most comes into its own. Then, the two or three écoles de voile on the beach are thronged. No motors, no towlines. Just perfect peace, even if you are doing no more than dawdling over a soft drink in a beachside caff. Now it's mostly the French and German bourgeoisie who commune with the waves. A generation ago, hippies rather than dippies were most in evidence. Cat Stevens found Allah here, and Jimi Hendrix wrote Castles in the Sand, puffing, strumming and shagging for several golden summers. There are occasional faint echoes of that (if you're lucky enough to spot them). But you're far more likely to encounter the fine-upstanding rather than the horizontally inclined. 5 of the best Places to eat 1 The fish stalls, just outside the gateway to the port. Plain grilled only - but the fish couldn't be fresher or cheaper. 2 Chez Sam . On the quayside. Piscatorial delights in a expensive nautical setting. 3 Restaurant Le Coquillage , just inside the port area. If Chez Sam is full, this will do nicely. 4 Restaurant Essalam, Place Prince Moulay Hassan. Go for the tajines - slow-cooked meat or fish stews. 5 Patisserie Driss, Place Prince Moulay Hassan. Driss is French bliss. If you've any energy left over... 1 Go windsurfing. Try an é cole de voile by the beach. 2 Fly a kite. It's almost always windy. 3 Join in the football on the beach. Players of all standards welcome. 4 Try to find a new bar. There are not that many. 5 Keep right on to the end of the beach. It's inexhaustable - even if you're not. The practicals Simply Cities & Short Breaks (020-8541 2222) has three nights' B&B in Marrakech at the four-star Hotel Tichka Salamb from £454pp, including return scheduled flights from Gatwick and transfers (£377 for two nights). Essaouira is four hours by bus from Marrakech (about £1), or three hours in a communal taxi (£3 ). Villa Maroc, Rue Abdallah ben Yassin, costs from £30pp per night. Several budget places cost £10-£15pp.

fields.headline: Grey days in west Wales
fields.standfirst: Rural Britain is unconvinced by Mr Blair
fields.trailText:
Tony Blair's attempt to reassure rural Britain that things are not as bad as they seem has not played
           well in Devon and Cornwall, and its distant ripples certainly did not persuade voters in Ceredigion, the
           area around Aberystwyth in Wales, to renew their trust in Labour. In Thursday's byelection Plaid Cymru
           held the seat, though with a much reduced vote. The Liberal Democrats, who held the seat before Plaid
           took it over, finished second, with 85% of the vote they got in May 1997. The big losers were Labour,
           relegated from second to fourth, with fewer than four in 10 of the votes they won at the general election.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's attempt to reassure rural Britain that things are not as bad as they seem has not played well in Devon and Cornwall, and its distant ripples certainly did not persuade voters in Ceredigion, the area around Aberystwyth in Wales, to renew their trust in Labour. In Thursday's byelection Plaid Cymru held the seat, though with a much reduced vote. The Liberal Democrats, who held the seat before Plaid took it over, finished second, with 85% of the vote they got in May 1997. The big losers were Labour, relegated from second to fourth, with fewer than four in 10 of the votes they won at the general election.

The turnout, though healthy compared to recent contests in England, was low by Welsh standards. It is not as if the arithmetic showed hordes of Labour voters bestowing their favours elsewhere. But the few reports of constituency opinion published outside Wales suggest a level of rural disaffection with Labour which needs to be taken seriously. This is one of the poorest counties in Wales, where many farmers are up against it and some have given up hope. Mr Blair allows that some farmers are in deep and genuine difficulty, and that the advantages rural dwellers enjoy over their rural counterparts, as claimed by Downing Street this week, do not apply everywhere. To people in parts of rural Britain who fall into the latter class, his message this week must have been deeply frustrating, like that of a man who says: yes, it is true, your house is on fire - but just look at that wonderful view of Helvellyn.

That is the rural factor. There is a Welsh factor too. Much of Wales, urban and rural alike, is growing aggrieved as it reads of a boom in the south-east of England which demands higher interest rates, while witnessing none of this boom itself. That south-east Wales, too, is benefiting from massive investment, if anything, makes things worse. The Labour leader of Blaenau Gwent council, in the industrial south Wales valleys, roundly denounced the government this week, saying it lacked the guts to combat the deprivation in his area. Alun Michael, the Welsh first minister, faces a no confidence motion on Tuesday arising from the government's failure to match European funds. Nationally, the polls still indicate that the country is happy with Labour, but increasingly, local suppurations suggest patches of strong dissent. Ceredigion, given an opening to express these feelings, has taken its chance.

webTitle: Tories ban Archer for five years

fields.headline: Tories ban Archer for five years
fields.trailText: February 5 2000: Jeffrey Archer was expelled from the Conservative party for five years last night after an internal investigation found that he not only concealed a fake libel alibi for 13 years but continued to cover it up for 15 crucial days when the truth finally emerged last November.
fields.body:
Jeffrey Archer was expelled from the Conservative party for five years last night after an internal investigation found that he not only concealed a fake libel alibi for 13 years but continued to cover it up for 15 crucial days when the truth finally emerged last November.

Lord Archer's failure to disclose that he had asked a friend to lie for him ahead of his 1987 Daily Star libel case - in which he won £500,000 - was unequivocally condemned for bringing his party into "disrepute" by the Tory ethics committee appointed by William Hague to clean up sleaze in the party ranks.

Despite the severity of the report's language, some Tory eyebrows were raised last night over the limited sentence. The committee, chaired by a QC, announced that the long-threatened expulsion of the 59-year-old former mayoral candidate and former deputy chairman of the party would only be for five years - not life - because of his "long and energetic service".

He has long been its most popular fund-raiser, whose talents may be needed again, a factor which MPs admitted. Lord Archer himself admitted the facts but may still appeal on the grounds that he never used the fake alibi or that he had faced a "kangaroo court" - a claim Hague aides deny.

Last night, in a statement, Lord Archer, a member of the Conservative party for 35 years, said: "I am naturally disappointed with the committee's decision, which I consider to be grossly unfair. I shall be consulting my advisers early next week as to whether or not to appeal."

The cabinet office minister, Ian McCartney, expressed astonishment that Lord Archer will be "entitled to make another comeback" in five years. "This sorry saga is more proof of William Hague's poor judgment and weak leadership."

In its damning report, issued after MPs were safely away from Westminster for the weekend, the four-person committee rejected Lord Archer's excuse for not revealing the alibi he concocted in 1987 because it was "stale".

But it also accused him of trying to conceal the truth even when the person who he had asked to give him the alibi, the writer Ted Francis, started to spill the beans on November 4 last year.

"The fabrication of false evidence would not be a matter that any ordinary man would be likely to forget," says the report. It was itself "dishonest and disreputable" conduct.

"The admission which was made by Lord Archer [on November 19 1999] ... was not prompted by any pang of conscience, but by the prospect of his imminent disgrace by the public disclosure of conduct which had never before been revealed," the committee's five-page report stated.

He had been asked in an interview with party chairman, Michael Ancram MP, on June 22 whether there were any more skeletons in his cupboard. "But for the assurance that he gave, he would not have passed the particular vetting stage which ultimately led to his selection," says the report.

It is particularly hard on the excuse which Lord Archer and his lawyers gave the committee of two grandees and two barristers - under Elizabeth Appleby QC - last month. "It was not conduct which could be dismissed, as his legal advisers sought to do, merely because it was old and stale.

The critical point, overlooked by Lord Archer's advisers, is that conduct whenever engaged in, which has been concealed, becomes new conduct when discovered and revealed publicly.

"It is the element of concealment which also makes what Lord Archer had done in order to promote his personal ambitions more reprehensible," the committee concluded.

One of the members of the ethics and integrity committee which sat in judgment, Sir Archie Hamilton, MP for Epsom and Ewell and chairman of the Tory backbench 1922 committee, last night paid tribute to the peer's "tireless" campaigning and fund-raising.

"I think we had to take a balanced judgment. And it would I think have been more than five years if we hadn't taken into account the amazing contribution Jeffrey Archer has actually made to the Tory party," he said.

The report makes no such reference to Lord Archer's previous form as a man prone to high risk and what his wife, Mary, once called "inaccurate precis." He was forced to resign as an MP in 1974 over a near bankruptcy, and as party deputy chairman over the Star's claims that he the paid off a prostitute, Monica Coughlan. He was also accused of insider trading over Anglia TV shares.

Last night's report was produced independently of Mr Hague, who did not know Lord Archer had even been interviewed. "It proves William will not tolerate sleaze," said a spokesman. Mr Ancram said: "I am grateful to the committee for their determination and the way they have conducted this referral."

fields.headline: The other Canaries
fields.trailText:
Some sing more quietly than others?
La Gomera, El Hierro and La Palma positively whisper.
fields.body:
Some sing more quietly than others?
La Gomera, El Hierro and La Palma positively whisper.

No beaches to shout about?
Not really - their coastlines are mainly sheer cliffs, their hearts clogged with spectacular volcanic scenery.

The parts that other tourists don't reach?
Exactly. Banana-filled valleys, prolific palms and Alto de Garajonay National Park only add to La Gomera's exoticism.

Is it user-friendly?
Certainly, although the terraces slope so steeply that farmers have been known to pole vault between crops.

And fall off the edge of the world?
That's more likely on El Hierro. Until 1884, when the meridian was moved to Greenwich, zero degrees longitude was set at Punte Orchilla, the western tip of the island.

Could I escape the pressures of the commercial world?
Whether you stay at tiny Tamaduste resort, the Parador at Las Playas or at Las Puntas.

Would I arrive by sea?
Regular ferries dock on all three islands, and Iberia Airlines pops over daily to El Hierro and La Palma, all from Tenerife.

Where silence is a dirty word?
Not in the town of Garachico. Its streets and squares are still as history made them.

Is there a bolthole?
None more intimate and stylishly Spanish than the San Roque, where a week's B&B with Harlequin Travel (01708 850300) costs from £816.

Is La Palma another green and hairy Atlantic blimp?
With stunning scenery. Escape the crowds with Travellers' Way (01527 836791).

How unlike Gran Canaria.
Just 20 minutes from Playa del Ingles, you could stay at Molino de Fataga, a working farm with a pool, gardens, country cooking and camel safaris.

How much would that cost?
From £376 for a week with car in September with Corona Holidays (0181-530 2500).

Would it be hot?
Any time, though pools need a helping hand in winter.

Even in the mountains?
Ask Vintage Travel (01954 261431). This upmarket villa specialist offers eight houses in the remote interior of Gran Canaria.

fields.headline: NatWest investor backs RBS bid
fields.trailText: An influential shareholder in NatWest yesterday publicly backed Royal Bank of Scotland's £23bn bid and urged his fellow investors to follow quickly to prevent the beleaguered bank escaping either of the Scottish bidders.
fields.body:
An influential shareholder in NatWest yesterday publicly backed Royal Bank of Scotland's £23bn bid and urged his fellow investors to follow quickly to prevent the beleaguered bank escaping either of the Scottish bidders.

The plea was made by Glasgow-based Britannic Asset Management, which controls just under 1% - worth £158m.

Peter Reid, chief investment officer at Britannic, said: "If a bandwagon is going to start, it's got to start early. It might be too late and that would increase the risk of NatWest independence."

Britannic also owns 4% of Bank of Scotland, which he said would continue to deliver good value to shareholders as an individual entity.

The intervention came amid new concerns, from its predators, about the way NatWest has been axing staff as part of its defence strategy, which involves 15,000 job cuts, against the competing bids by the Royal Bank and Bank of Scotland.

"What really strikes us is that the good people as often as the bad people [are being let go]. It's indiscriminate," said Johnny Cameron, managing director of corporate banking at Royal Bank of Scotland.

He said concerns about backing the Royal's bid because of potential risks, overlooked the risks which NatWest itself might be taking.

NatWest admitted that it had "reassessed" its acquisition finance department but denied it had installed a blanket 50% cut to consultancies across the group.

All three banks face a tortuous weekend during which major investors in NatWest are expected to decide whether to back either of the Scottish bids or give the bank's new management another chance.

The most important shareholders, such as Prudential, Mercury Asset Management, Schroders and Phillips & Drew, have yet to reveal their decisions although P&D said yesterday it would make its decision public early next week.

Major shareholders are being urged to take action to stem concerns that NatWest could escape either bidders by a split in the vote, preventing either reaching the 50% barrier.

The City continued to struggle to understand the movement in all three bank's shares although noted share dealings by CGU, the insurance company which is backing Royal Bank's bid. The insurer was seen to be buying Royal Bank's shares and selling Bank of Scotland.

fields.headline: Cheap thrills
fields.standfirst: Graham Duffill on how to book a bargain flight and still get maximum time on the slopes
fields.trailText: Graham Duffill on how to book a bargain flight and still get maximum time on the slopes.
fields.body:
The four big low-budget airlines - Go, easyJet, Buzz and Ryanair - fly to all the major Alpine destinations and also cover an impressive array of fringe airports.

The "from" fares only apply to a limited number of seats, so there is an advantage in booking early and travelling midweek. Shop around, as the proportion of seats sold at the lowest fare varies according to the airline and route. Ryanair, which began the no-frill budget flights in 1991, guarantees to sell 70% of its seats at its bottom two fares. Buzz sells 20% at the lowest fare. The others are more opaque about the proportion available.

If you want to have some flexibility in your travel times, your fare will also be more expensive, but a fully-flexible last-minute booking at peak times is still unlikely to cost you much over £200.

Avoiding weekends may be the only easy way to get baseline fares for this season, but it does not easily fit in with traditional low-priced ski-resort accommodation, where it's all-change every Saturday. French apartment specialist Erna Low (020-7584 2841) says it is possible to go across weeks in off-peak periods at short notice, but not during the peak times of February and March.

There is also the transfer to consider - a £50 coach or train fare, £120 car hire or £200 taxi? Coaches save money but waste valuable slope-time. If you book a car in advance by pre-paid voucher through an agent such as Momentum Travel (020-7371 9111), it should work out at not much over £120 for a week. If shared, it becomes a price that's hard to beat.

Short ski breaks, Thursday to Tuesday, can give you five days' skiing, and you can claim you have hardly been away from work. But study the timetable for which routes allow most slope time.

The sensible way to shop around is through the airlines' websites. Go and easyJet sell 63% of their seats over the internet. If you book by phone, there is inevitably a short wait while the recorded message tells you to book by internet followed by a long wait for someone to reply.

Lyon

Car: There are 40 ski resorts within 2€ hours drive of Lyon Satolas airport. The road to the Tarentaise Valley, home to Val d'Isère and Tignes, was much improved for the 1992 Albertville Olympics. Head south-west via Grenoble to the Valle des Oisans for Alpe d'Huez and Les Deux Alpes, and north via Annecy for the Aravis Valley with its linked resorts of Morzine and Avoriaz.

Bus: Satobus (+33 4 72 35 94 96) run coaches to 40 resorts from the central hall, Level 1 at Lyon Satolas. There are two departures a day weekdays and up to four on a Saturday. Some routes require changing coach, and transfers vary between three hours to five hours.

Train: The TGV goes leaves Lyon Satolas at 11.50am, arriving at Chambéry at 12.55am. From there, connecting trains go to Albertville and Moutier, or you can take the bus. Trains run from Lyon Part-Dieu to Albertville every two hours and the journey takes 2€ hours. Most require changing trains at Chambéry.

Milan

Car: There are more than 10 resorts within 3€ hours' drive. Malpensa airport is 48km north-west of the city, making western resorts like Cervinia, Courmayeur and La Thuile easy to reach. Take the motorway towards Gattinara and Santhia. For north-east resorts like Livigno, Bormio, Madonna di Campiglio and Madesimo, turn towards Milan, then Bergamo.

Train: The Malpensa Express from the airport to the Cadorna train station leaves every 30 minutes and takes 40 minutes. None of the ski resorts have train stations, but you can get quite close and then carry on by bus. For Courmayeur and La Thuile, take the train to Aosta. For Cervinia, go to Chatillon. For Livigno and Bormio, go to Tirano. For Madonna di Campiglio, go to Trento or Mezzolombardo.

Bus: Buses leave every 30 minutes from the airport to Stazione Centrale (main bus station). Buy your tickets at the Shuttle Bus office in the Terminal (single ticket L13,000/£4) and the journey takes about 50 minutes.

Munich

Car: The easiest way to access the northern Tirolean resorts and some of those in Salzburgland, with more than 50 resorts within 3€ hours' drive. Drive towards the city on the A92 until you join the motorway. For resorts east of Innsbruck, like Kitzbühel, Söll, Mayrhofen, Zell am See, turn towards Rosenheim and Kufstein on the A8 motorway. For resorts west and north of Innsbruck, like Seefeld in Austria and Garmisch Partenkirchen in Germany, take the motorway A95.

Austrian motorways are subject to toll - a vignette can be bought at the border. Check with the car-hire company if it is included. Take snow chains if you are travelling to higher resorts like Obergurgl or to the Arlberg.

Train: From the airport to the Hauptbahnhof and the Ostbahnhof. The more direct service to the ski resorts to the east of Innsbruck is via the Ostbahnhof. S-Bahn trains depart every 20 minutes and take 40 minutes. Tickets costs DM14/£4.40 (single). Very frequent services from Innsbruck to resorts like Kitzbühel, Innsbruck and Seefeld.

Bus: Take the Lufthansa Bus from the airport to the Hauptbahnhof. Buses leave every 20 minutes and take 45 minutes. Tickets cost DM15 (single) or DM25 (return).

Venice

Driving: Cortina is 160km from the airport. There is 95km of motorway on the A27 to Belluno, where it turns into a two-lane road. Parking is difficult in the resort's traffic-free centre, and hotels often charge extra for a parking space.

Rail and bus: Take the bus from the airport to the railway station at Mestre. The train to Calalzo takes 2€ hours and you have to change here to the bus for Cortina which takes a further hour.

Zurich

Car: Zurich is the gateway to Swiss ski resorts and the Austrian Vorarlberg. From here to Lech is just 2€ hours.

Train: Trains run direct from the airport. The Swiss "Fly Luggage" system takes your luggage straight from check-in in the UK to your hotel.

easyJet

www.easyjet.com
0870 6000 000

easyJet is big on Geneva which is perfect for skiers. Head round Lake Lausanne and you can be in Villars in 1 1/4 hours, Verbier in 1 1/2. Head south-east into France and Flaine is just over an hour, Chamonix and Argentiers 1 1/2 . Flights leave Luton at 6.30am, coming back as late as 9.10pm, so you can spend the day skiing. There are also Geneva flights from Gatwick, Stansted and Liverpool.

There are three flights a day to Zurich from Luton, from 8.30am. Although the latest return departs at 4.55pm, if you live in the south-east, you could risk the morning dash from slope to desk on the 6.55am return getting in at 7.50am.

For Andorra, there is a twice-daily service to Barcelona, another route shared with Go from Luton and Liverpool.

easyJet's website has a ski page with links and useful information.

Go
www.go-fly.com
0845 60 54321

British Airway's low-cost arm has the most comprehensive coverage of the Alps, with Stansted flights to Lyon, Zurich, Munich, Milan and Venice. Its best route is Munich, with four flights a day and good timings for maximum slope time - out as early as 6.50am, starting back at 8.55pm.

Milan has four flights and similar timings but, while the Tyrolean slopes are reachable in little over an hour from Munich, it takes about three to reach the slopes from Milan.

Venice flights leave at 8.35am, returning 9.30pm on Saturdays, with Cortina d'Ampezzo and the Dolo mites two hours' drive away.

There are also stacks of flights to Malaga for the Sierra Nevada.

Lyon and Zurich are slightly disappointing, an awkward mid-afternoon return from Lyon and just one flight a day to Zurich, leaving Stansted mid- afternoon.

Go's website is the clearest and most user-friendly of the lot. It has special pages for skiers with tables of drive-times to resorts, links to resort guides and an online request service for accommodation.

Ryanair

www.ryanair.com
0870 156 9569

Ryanair also flies to Lyon, but not Lyon Satolas like the others, but to St Etienne a smaller, and cheaper alternative.

Sadly, St Etienne is on the wrong side of Lyon for heading into the mountains. It probably adds an hour to the journey time from Satolas.

There is one flight a day, out from Stansted at 10.40am, meaning you won't ski that day. Flights return at 1.50pm, so you won't ski that day either.

Turin flights are more skier-friendly, leaving at 7.30am and returning up to 8.55pm. Turin is also nearer the slopes than Milan or Venice - the Milky Way is just over an hour's drive and Courmayeur, in the Valle D'Aosta, is three hours away.

Flights to Venice leave at 7am with a late 9pm return.

Buzz
www.buzzaway.com
0870 240 7070

KLM's low-cost creation has the best times to Lyon, leaving Stansted at 7.15am, 12.25pm and 6.25pm, returning at 10.30am, 3.45pm and 9.40pm.

Milan flights leave at 6.40am returning at 8.45pm.

webTitle: Has the British film censor lost all sense of proportion?

fields.headline: Has the British film censor lost all sense of proportion?
fields.trailText:
Dear Antony,
I believe censorship in various forms is an important element in the education of children, and the responsibility we all share as parents and teachers alike cannot be shirked or taken lightly, which is why I am so appalled at the BBFC's decision to grant The End of the Affair an 18 certificate.
fields.body:
Dear Antony,
I believe censorship in various forms is an important element in the education of children, and the responsibility we all share as parents and teachers alike cannot be shirked or taken lightly, which is why I am so appalled at the BBFC's decision to grant The End of the Affair an 18 certificate.

As a faithful adaptation of Graham Greene's most critically acclaimed novel, I expected an authorisation of 15, as I was aware of two scenes illustrating the intimate physical passion that ignited the fictional affair between Bendrix and Sarah that are not suitable for young children. The final amount of nudity after the editing process was minimal. The film received a fitting 15 certificate in Ireland and an R rating in the US which allows anyone under the age of 17 to attend a screening if accompanied by an adult.

The movie was never conceived with teenagers specifically in mind. And as Greene is one of the most respected and widely read authors of the 20th century, I wouldn't be surprised to find the novel appearing on an A-level syllabus sometime soon. Prohibiting 16-year-olds in Britain from seeing it is doubly frustrating as the novel and movie are mirrors of the social, cultural and psychological upheavals that English people, and in particular Greene himself, underwent between 1939 and 1946 in London. I believe that the censor is not working on behalf of responsible parents but against them.

Yours sincerely,
Stephen Woolley,
Producer, The End of the Affair

Dear Mr Woolley,
As a headmaster and teacher, I am delighted we agree that censorship in various forms is important. I would underline the importance of Catholicism in Greene's life and writing.

We must make a distinction between the written word and celluloid. The former enables the individual to create his or her own picture, while the film imposes a picture upon the person observing it. Film producers impose their own images into the minds of other people. In so doing, the film takes away the freedom of the young to make their own pictures.

People live in accordance with their own mental images and it is only when a child has reached an intellectual, emotional maturity that he is able to cope selectively with the pictures before him. The portrayal of intimate and physical passion can be an explosive matter, and it is possible to distort an issue through it. Greene's novels are never explicit, rather allowing the reader to imagine and cope with the affairs of the characters at their own pace.

Not all parents are responsible, and certainly not all people under 18 are capable of benefitting from the film's scenes, which may mirror the social culture and psychological upheaval of the English people - but so does the written word. I believe the BBFC's decision sensibly reflects caution. The risk of damage to the young must always be minimalised. I believe the censor is being responsible.

Yours sincerely,
Dom Antony Sutch

Dear Antony,
I'm afraid you must have no knowledge of the BBFC's recent certification decisions. They have certainly betrayed your faith in their caution. The two "objectionable" scenes would be regarded as tame after 9pm on terrestrial TV.

The End of the Affair deserves a 12 certificate and awarding a 15 would be exercising sufficient caution. Your letter allies your support of the 12 certificate awarded to The World Is Not Enough, a catalogue of violence, mayhem and extremely sadistic sex featuring the famous fictional public school graduate, James Bond. In addition, the censor granted a 15 certificate to a movie entitled 8 1/2 Women, which has possibly garnered the most outrageous collection of poor reviews attacking its sexist and misogynistic treatment of women.

The censor and his cohorts have created a climate whereby violence, titillation and sadism conducted upon women is deemed to be healthy for all genders over 15, and where mutually consenting adults making love is deemed unfit for that same audience. Under the James Ferman administration, both Shakespeare in Love and Wings of the Dove were passed as 15 certificates despite the similar sexual content.

I am in absolute agreement that care must be taken when visualising a novel. The End of the Affair is of course the most sexually explicit of Greene's novels and the sexuality in the novel and the movie, unlike most modern films, is placed absolutely within a moral and social context.

Yours sincerely,
Stephen Woolley

Dear Stephen,
I totally agree with you that the BBFC certification of the films you have mentioned (apart from The End of the Affair) is incomprehensible. Rather than reduce The End of the Affair's certification, films such as The World is not Enough should be certificated higher.

Peter Greenaway's 8 1/2 Women should be heavily censored. He spoke at Downside school and intellectually justified much of his work. He was speaking to a highly intelligent and perceptive group. I fear for those who need to be protected. There are certain youngsters who could see The End of the Affair at 15 without any difficulty, but we must look to those who would be disturbed.

Another point is that sexual explicitness in a beautifully moulded, crafted and thoughtful films such as yours can have a more devastating effect than one suffused with sexual explicitness and violence. In one sense the beauty and thoughtfulness of your film has hoisted you with your own petard.

We haven't yet mentioned the moral dimension. Certain religious denominations see sexual promiscuity, adultery, and fornication as morally wrong. I believe a child should have sufficient moral education before being exposed to what would be considered immoral acts. Do we dismiss the moral sensibilities of these religions as irrelevant and intolerant, or do we as a civilised society allow decorum and thus the certification?

Yours,
Antony

Dear Antony,
Let me stress that I am not against censorship and I could never envisage dismissing the moral sensibilities of any religion, but nor do I believe we live in a utopian society. I am forced to face the hard realities of the real world whenever I buy a newspaper, or switch on the news. We have the highest rate of teenage pregnancies in Europe and yet we are the most censorious nation in Europe.

My idea of an improved society is one where teenage boys have not only the mechanics of sexual education explained, but also, as reflected in The End of the Affair, the moral responsibility that comes with making love.

I'm confused by your constant reference to "children" being disturbed. In a sense, the young adults you are protecting have access to far more disturbing material by simply accessing the internet, wandering into their local newsagents or visiting a video store. At an age when fatherhood, owning a driving licence and making untold riches playing soccer for a Premiership team are legalised and encouraged, how disturbed can a teenage boy be by the contents of our film?

In Britain we seem to have a nasty habit of attempting to control young adults by restricting the choices they have, and suppressing often completely healthy desires. No teenager who chooses to see The End of the Affair should be discouraged. I'm not sure, Antony, if you have seen The End of the Affair, but at a screening recently of 500 adults, I asked if anyone in the audience felt that 15, 16 or 17-year-olds should be prohibited from seeing the film: not a single hand was raised. People depriving young adults of their freedom of choice, tend to be more in the category of the disturbed than the young adults themselves.

Yours sincerely,
Stephen Woolley

Dear Stephen,
Perhaps I am hoping for a utopian world. I have been disturbed by films in the past, even over the age of 18, and am therefore possibly over-sensitive to protection.

I concede that I would be prepared to show The End of the Affair to the boys here at 15 plus, partly because I know their moral maturity and partly because Ralph Fiennes's great-uncle is a fellow monk here. Yet I am concerned for the category of young adults whose lives have been messed up by an indifferent and over-tolerant society (your "real world" victims).

I am no prig nor control freak and, indeed, believe the human body is a beauteous creation, but I have also witnessed too often the sad and destructive results of those jolted into experiences before they were capable of absorbing them. Film is the most powerful medium and often in 90 minutes the viewer experiences a lifetime of emotions.

Without the personal apparatus to cope with such emotions, one is harming oneself and damaging development. Indeed, one is tarnishing what should be, in due season, a glorious appreciation and a genuine help to maturity.

Yours,
Dom Antony Sutch

As Lawrence Goldman, a historian, pointed out to us Ruskinians gathered at Lancaster University last month, the "aristocracy of labour" - skilled working men - of the 1850s and 60s were far from being socialists. Ruskin's ideas on wealth and welfare were far too radical for men who believed not just in a fair day's pay for a fair day's output of skill, but also in the very tooth-and-claw laws of political economy that Ruskin decried.

So embarrassed was the future Liberal prime minister William Gladstone at a grand meeting of the Social Science Association he chaired before a distinguished audience in London in 1858, that he walked out. Embarrassed by what? By Ruskin's full-blooded assault on "the natural law of wages". Ruskin, however, although his ideas verged on being dangerous at the time was - because of his eloquence, breeding, wealth, fame and intellect - treated on such occasions as a pet dragon. It was best to let him roar, and then either ignore or attempt to belittle him. It was not until the 1880s and 90s that Ruskin's writings reached a mass audience. By then, the British economy had been battered by cyclical trade depressions and the onset of large-scale unemployment. Large parts of the countryside had suffered economic collapse; there was mass migration from rural hovels to city slums; and finance capital had expanded massively (away from the nose-to-grindstone manufacturing that working men knew and understood), as explained by Jose Harris in her essay, Ruskin And Social Reform. His books, published by George Allen, a disciple whom Ruskin had set up in business (latterly at Ruskin House, Museum Street, Bloomsbury), sold in their hundreds of thousands. The tragedy is that at the very point at which Ruskin had become hugely popular, the man himself had retreated to Brantwood and into a near silent madness.

From 1889 he was all but out of sight, except through the carefully-posed photographs of the white-bearded prophet of the Lakes - the Old Man Of Coniston personified - sent out by his cousin Joan and her husband, the second-rate painter Arthur Severn, to journals and Ruskin societies that had been founded worldwide by liberal intellectuals and the working men who had come to see him as a prophet. As early as 1854 he was lecturing at FD Maurice's Working Men's College in Red Lion Square, Bloomsbury, and this led eventually to the establishment of Ruskin College, Oxford, where working men of future generations, sponsored by the trades union movement, gained diplomas and degrees. John Prescott, deputy prime minister in Tony Blair's New Labour government, is a late-flowering beneficiary of Ruskin's interest in adult education. Ruskin worked, too, with Octavia Hill, encouraging the advance of her Working Ladies' Guild established in 1853. He donated £10,000 to Hill's "improved working class housing" schemes. As Slade Professor at Oxford in the 1870s and again in the 80s (Robert Hewison takes up the post this year), when he took rooms at Corpus Christi, he publicly denounced the "great 800-year-old Picnic Party of the Upper Classes". He spoke of public service and public welfare and intelligent, artistic undergraduates were drawn to him like pilgrims to their chosen saint.

Young aesthetes, including Oscar Wilde, helped Ruskin labour to build a model road to benefit the village of Hinksey outside Oxford. In London, the professor paid three men to sweep the streets in exemplary fashion at Seven Dials in Covent Garden. In Paddington, he established an "ethical tea house". And in 1871 he endowed his new St George's Fund with 10% of his income (very few of his friends who promised to do the same came up with the cash) to fund good causes, including the, admittedly rather disastrous, buying up of redundant land for the yeoman craftsman of the idyllic Ruskinian future to sew, till and reap.

These good deeds may seem risible - Ruskin described them as "mere raft-making amidst irrecoverable wreck" - but he wanted to demonstrate that theory must be matched by action. Significantly, a number of young Oxford Ruskinians rose to become senior civil servants who encouraged governments to push through, bit by bit, the social welfare legislation that Ruskin had first set out coherently as a programme in Unto This Last. The keenest of all Ruskinites was John Howard Whitehouse, a companion of Ruskin's Guild of St George and editor of its journal. Whitehouse was elected a Liberal MP in 1910 and worked as one of Lloyd George's principal private secretaries during the passage of the National Insurance Act - pure Ruskin - of 1911. He later founded Bembridge School on the Isle of Wight (since closed), modelled on Ruskinian principles. Later still, he bought Brantwood, thus saving it for posterity after the death of Joan Severn in the 30s, and amassed an unrivalled collection of Ruskiniana that is today housed in the Ruskin Library, Lancaster, and at Brantwood itself.

A later contributor to "St George" until its demise in 1911 was William Beveridge, to whom we owe the famous Education Act of 1944, which led, as Ruskin had once dreamed of, to universal, state-funded education - now increasingly abandoned by the very middle classes who have so benefited from it. As for his influence on architecture and design, this was very much for better or worse. His love of Venice led to a spate of rash, pseudo-Venetian building in Britain in the 1860s and 70s; Ruskin detested it. More importantly, his belief that architecture and morality were inseparable, that the walls of an "honest" building were to be raised up from a plan that reflected the function of that building, was to have a profound effect on architects of the Arts & Crafts movement, on the Bauhaus, on Le Corbusier and on practitioners of the Modern Movement. Today, many architects, not least Richard MacCormac, designer of the Ruskin Library, are clearly affected by Ruskin. (He had ungraciously adopted this idea from Augustus Welby Northmore Pugin, 1812-52, father of the archaeologically-correct Gothic Revival. Pugin was a Catholic, whom Ruskin described as one of the "smallest or littlest architects", which simply wasn't true).

At the turn of the century, Ruskin was the main inspiration behind the superb Arts & Crafts Queen Anne housing developments designed by young socialist architects of the London County Council. His was the principal inspiration for Frank Pick (1878-1941), the man who gave the London Passenger Transport Board, created in 1933, its world famous and hugely influential modern and democratic design image. This list could be as long as those in Ruskin's paragraphs in Modern Painters. As for painters, he was both wise and foolish. In 1877, he famously libelled James Whistler, accusing the cocky young American of "flinging a pot of paint in the public's face" with his Nocturne In Black And Gold. Odd, given Ruskin's worship of Turner. He was found against, and ordered to pay Whistler a farthing (the smallest coin). Clearly the judge sympathised with Ruskin, but libel was libel. And as a critic? Ruskin was in many ways the founder and exemplar of the school of descriptive criticism that so characterises the best British writing on art and architecture - think of John Summerson and Ian Nairn. His way of thinking so very different from the art world structuralists for whom criticism was reduced to a pseudo-science, as if books on art and architecture could be written that were 100% rational and objective.

Ruskin argued with his eye and his feeling for what paintings and buildings told him. He remembered to look as well as to read. Since the 40s, so many art world academics appear, as the sculptor Canova once said of his critics, to "see with their ears". Ruskin would not have been employed by the Courtauld in the second half of the century.

Ruskin - angry, roaring, holistic, libellous, a damaged archangel - has influenced all our daily lives. He is far from being simply an odd man who worshipped Turner and had difficulties with women. If only his biographies were filled with salacious sex scenes, he would be much read and studied. Who, after all, in our hyper-materialistic, burger-chomping New Britain, is interested in the idea of raising the sights of working men and women to the stars when they can have McDonald's, Channel 5 and the Greenwich Dome instead of beauty, imagination and responsible work?

He wanted to think about, know, debate and discuss everything that was knowable, debatable or discussable, and would lead to people being as happy as he never really was - except among his rocks and stones, and with Bramble, his favourite dog, asleep at his feet in his study at Brantwood. No wonder his mind gave up the ghost. "I's a wide world," he said to his friend Charles Norton in 1866, "and there's a great deal in it, and one head is but a poor little room to study in after all." But what a study, and what a room. Ruskin lives. Give me a cigarette.

Large parts of the countryside had suffered economic collapse; there was mass migration from rural hovels to city slums; and finance capital had expanded massively (away from the nose-to-grindstone manufacturing that working men knew and understood), as explained by Jose Harris in her essay, Ruskin And Social Reform. His books, published by George Allen, a disciple whom Ruskin had set up in business (latterly at Ruskin House, Museum Street, Bloomsbury), sold in their hundreds of thousands. The tragedy is that at the very point at which Ruskin had become hugely popular, the man himself had retreated to Brantwood and into a near silent madness. From 1889 he was all but out of sight, except through the carefully-posed photographs of the white-bearded prophet of the Lakes - the Old Man Of Coniston personified - sent out by his cousin Joan and her husband, the second-rate painter Arthur Severn, to journals and Ruskin societies that had been founded worldwide by liberal intellectuals and the working men who had come to see him as a prophet. As early as 1854 he was lecturing at FD Maurice's Working Men's College in Red Lion Square, Bloomsbury, and this led eventually to the establishment of Ruskin College, Oxford, where working men of future generations, sponsored by the trades union movement, gained diplomas and degrees. John Prescott, deputy prime minister in Tony Blair's New Labour government, is a late-flowering beneficiary of Ruskin's interest in adult education. Ruskin worked, too, with Octavia Hill, encouraging the advance of her Working Ladies' Guild established in 1853. He donated £10,000 to Hill's "improved working class housing" schemes. As Slade Professor at Oxford in the 1870s and again in the 80s (Robert Hewison takes up the post this year), when he took rooms at Corpus Christi, he publicly denounced the "great 800-year-old Picnic Party of the Upper Classes". He spoke of public service and public welfare and intelligent, artistic undergraduates were drawn to him like pilgrims to their chosen saint. Young aesthetes, including Oscar Wilde, helped Ruskin labour to build a model road to benefit the village of Hinksey outside Oxford. In London, the professor paid three men to sweep the streets in exemplary fashion at Seven Dials in Covent Garden. In Paddington, he established an "ethical tea house". And in 1871 he endowed his new St George's Fund with 10% of his income (very few of his friends who promised to do the same came up with the cash) to fund good causes, including the, admittedly rather disastrous, buying up of redundant land for the yeoman craftsman of the idyllic Ruskinian future to sew, till and reap. These good deeds may seem risible - Ruskin described them as "mere raft-making amidst irrecoverable wreck" - but he wanted to demonstrate that theory must be matched by action. Significantly, a number of young Oxford Ruskinians rose to become senior civil servants who encouraged governments to push through, bit by bit, the social welfare legislation that Ruskin had first set out coherently as a programme in Unto This Last. The keenest of all Ruskinites was John Howard Whitehouse, a companion of Ruskin's Guild of St George and editor of its journal. Whitehouse was elected a Liberal MP in 1910 and worked as one of Lloyd George's principal private secretaries during the passage of the National Insurance Act - pure Ruskin - of 1911. He later founded Bembridge School on the Isle of Wight (since closed), modelled on Ruskinian principles. Later still, he bought Brantwood, thus saving it for posterity after the death of Joan Severn in the 30s, and amassed an unrivalled collection of Ruskiniana that is today housed in the Ruskin Library, Lancaster, and at Brantwood itself. A later contributor to "St George" until its demise in 1911 was William Beveridge, to whom we owe the famous Education Act of 1944, which led, as Ruskin had once dreamed of, to universal, state-funded education - now increasingly abandoned by the very middle classes who have so benefited from it. As for his influence on architecture and design, this was very much for better or worse. His love of Venice led to a spate of rash, pseudo-Venetian building in Britain in the 1860s and 70s; Ruskin detested it. More importantly, his belief that architecture and morality were inseparable, that the walls of an "honest" building were to be raised up from a plan that reflected the function of that building, was to have a profound effect on architects of the Arts & Crafts movement, on the Bauhaus, on Le Corbusier and on practitioners of the Modern Movement. Today, many architects, not least Richard MacCormac, designer of the Ruskin Library, are clearly affected by Ruskin. (He had ungraciously adopted this idea from Augustus Welby Northmore Pugin, 1812-52, father of the archaeologically-correct Gothic Revival. Pugin was a Catholic, whom Ruskin described as one of the "smallest or littlest architects", which simply wasn't true). At the turn of the century, Ruskin was the main inspiration behind the superb Arts & Crafts Queen Anne housing developments designed by young socialist architects of the London County Council. His was the principal inspiration for Frank Pick (1878-1941), the man who gave the London Passenger Transport Board, created in 1933, its world famous and hugely influential modern and democratic design image. This list could be as long as those in Ruskin's paragraphs in Modern Painters. As for painters, he was both wise and foolish. In 1877, he famously libelled James Whistler, accusing the cocky young American of "flinging a pot of paint in the public's face" with his Nocturne In Black And Gold. Odd, given Ruskin's worship of Turner. He was found against, and ordered to pay Whistler a farthing (the smallest coin). Clearly the judge sympathised with Ruskin, but libel was libel. And as a critic? Ruskin was in many ways the founder and exemplar of the school of descriptive criticism that so characterises the best British writing on art and architecture - think of John Summerson and Ian Nairn. His way of thinking so very different from the art world structuralists for whom criticism was reduced to a pseudo-science, as if books on art and architecture could be written that were 100% rational and objective. Ruskin argued with his eye and his feeling for what paintings and buildings told him. He remembered to look as well as to read. Since the 40s, so many art world academics appear, as the sculptor Canova once said of his critics, to "see with their ears". Ruskin would not have been employed by the Courtauld in the second half of the century. Ruskin - angry, roaring, holistic, libellous, a damaged archangel - has influenced all our daily lives. He is far from being simply an odd man who worshipped Turner and had difficulties with women. If only his biographies were filled with salacious sex scenes, he would be much read and studied. Who, after all, in our hyper-materialistic, burger-chomping New Britain, is interested in the idea of raising the sights of working men and women to the stars when they can have McDonald's, Channel 5 and the Greenwich Dome instead of beauty, imagination and responsible work? He wanted to think about, know, debate and discuss everything that was knowable, debatable or discussable, and would lead to people being as happy as he never really was - except among his rocks and stones, and with Bramble, his favourite dog, asleep at his feet in his study at Brantwood. No wonder his mind gave up the ghost. "I's a wide world," he said to his friend Charles Norton in 1866, "and there's a great deal in it, and one head is but a poor little room to study in after all." But what a study, and what a room. Ruskin lives. Give me a cigarette.

webTitle: BBC in row over toxic risk to staff

fields.headline: BBC in row over toxic risk to staff
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC is locked in a battle with the department of trade and industry and the ministry of defence over plans to send protective suits to staff facing chemical attack in Chechnya.
fields.body:
The BBC is locked in a battle with the department of trade and industry and the ministry of defence over plans to send protective suits to staff facing chemical attack in Chechnya.

Corporation chiefs have been trying since December 10 to send 10 so-called Noddy suits to the reporters and crew stationed near Chechnya to protect them from the primitive chemical weapons believed to be in use by Russian troops and Chechen rebels.

Journalists including special correspondent Ben Brown, Europe correspondent Orla Guerin and the BBC's Moscow team have been operating from a Russian army base in Mozdok, North Ossetia. BBC news executives believe their staff are at risk of toxic infection and burns from the chlorine-based chemical weapons, which can be lethal.

But the DTI and MoD have frustrated the BBC's plans by insisting the corporation apply for an export licence for the suits. The application is now caught between the foreign office, the MoD and the DTI. The Russian customs service has already given clearance for the equipment to be imported.

The BBC first identified the risk to its staff in early December, after reports of chemical hazards in Mozdok, and agreed to equip and train journalists. Although there is no embargo to prevent the suits being shipped, the DTI insisted on an export licence because the equipment is linked with defence against nuclear, chemical and biological hazards.

Leaked documents seen by the Guardian show a paper trail through numerous government departments as the DTI requested further information and called several meetings with the foreign office and MoD, despite the urgency stressed by the BBC.

Senior BBC news executives are angry at what one termed the "hair-tearing frustration of Whitehall bureaucracy gone mad".

A spokesman for the DTI said the application was still under consideration and blamed difficult security issues.

A BBC spokesman said: "The safety of our correspondents in the field is our top priority. We are not sure why this application is taking so long to process."

webTitle: I lost my heart in... Murter

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Murter
fields.trailText: My mum's from Croatia and, years ago, her mum bought an old stone house on an island called Murter, on the Adriatic coast betweeen Sibenik and Zadar. It's on an ancient stone street going up a hill, and we go there every summer.
fields.body:
My mum's from Croatia and, years ago, her mum bought an old stone house on an island called Murter, on the Adriatic coast betweeen Sibenik and Zadar. It's on an ancient stone street going up a hill, and we go there every summer.

The island is small and hilly, and has several beaches. I easily eat 100-150 figs on my way back from the beach (it's only about a mile), and I usually need to wash them down with about half a pint of Slivovica - a Croatian plum brandy.

On top of the island, up on the hill behind the house, is an old stone church. It's almost a pilgrimage to get to it, but you can see for hundreds of miles from up there.

Out towards Italy, there are several uninhabited islands with national park status. They're an incredible sight from the island on a cloudless night during a full moon.

A few years ago, my brother and I ressurected an inflatable dinghy with an outboard motor, and we used to go around the islands on this absurd little boat. It was a short-lived adventure because it developed a puncture and conked out. But when I've made a million, I think I'll buy the biggest boat I can and drive it around those islands.

 Adrian Chiles presents Working Lunch on BBC2 at 12.30pm on weekdays and Chiles on Saturday on Radio 5 Live, from 9am till 11am.

webTitle: Introduction: Has the British film censor lost all sense of proportion?

fields.headline: Introduction: Has the British film censor lost all sense of proportion?
fields.body: When The End of the Affair hits our screens on Friday, it is not the stars of the film, the director or even the fact that it is one of Graham Greene's most emotional works that will be the main talking point. It is the film's 18 certificate. There has been heated debate between its makers and the British Board of Film Classification over the "wisdom" of such categorisation. In America, children are deemed mature enough to see it if accompanied by an adult, while in Ireland the film has a 15 certificate only. So why will most British teenagers not be allowed to see it? Has film censorship here become inconsistent and out of touch, or is it rightfully protective of those whose interest it is there to guard? Stephen Woolley, producer of the film, whose credits include The Crying Game and Scandal, and Dom Antony Sutch, headmaster of Downside school, one of the bastions of Catholic education in the UK, debate the question in this week's Saturday Review debate. Read it and tell us what you think.
