fields.headline: Nest Eigg
fields.standfirst: Will Hodgkinson  on the islanders who have become lairds of their own domain
fields.trailText: Will Hodgkinson on the islanders who have become lairds of their own domain.
fields.body:
Much has changed on the isle of Eigg since my last visit. Fourteen years ago, this tiny Hebridean island, 8km long and 5km wide, had been under the ownership of an eccentric millionaire whose patriarchal attitude towards land administration had won him few friends among the islanders. They held even less admiration for the next landlord, a German businessman who visited the island twice and did nothing to pull it out of a spiral of environmental and social decline.

Then in June 1997, the 78 inhabitants of Eigg made history by buying the island themselves. Having successfully raised £800,000 with the help of the Scottish Wildlife Trust and the Highland Council, the Eiggites are now masters of their own affairs, working as crofters, preserving the environmental balance and running the island's tourist industry. They have even built a tea-room, shop and community centre by the harbour, something the old Eigg never came close to having.

Eigg will always have a dose of discord threatening its tranquillity, however. While the neighbouring island of Muck - less than half the size of Eigg and with a population of 20 - has an air of calm and respectability with its quaint tea-rooms and working farms, Eigg is more anarchic. The islanders find it hard to remember how much they're meant to charge you for the rental of their cottages and one can only imagine how they feel when they hand over money to the people of Muck for organic vegetables they could surely grow themselves.

But despite their laissez-faire attitude, the Eiggites have succeeded in making the island far more welcoming to visitors than it once was. The bothies, - sturdy stone houses with one room and no electricity that are available for weekly rental - had fallen into decline pre-June 1997. Now all the bothies boast that most basic of luxuries, as well as new roofs, hot water through Calor gas heaters, and huge fireplaces that make these old stone structures the cosiest places you could hope to be in.

It is the foreboding pitchstone ridge that is the Sgirr that dominates the island's landscape. At first appearance, this jagged rock looks impossible to conquer, but a two-hour walk along its length takes you past its sheer faces to a point at its back, where a hard but manageable scramble over rocks leads to the grassy verge at the top of the Sgirr, 1,000ft above sea level and with an incredible view that takes in the neighbouring islands of Rum, Muck and Canna.

Eigg has a wild, uncontrollable nature, reflected in the diversity of its landscape. Much of it is heather moorland traversed by wet seepages, rocky crags, and scores of timid sheep, but there are also open fields and lichen-encrusted forests, and this, along with a temperate climate, accounts for the variety of the wildlife found here. There are golden eagles that nest within the crevices of the Sgirr, corncrakes in the forest and seals and otters along the shores.

The wildness of the island is reflected in the turbulent history of its human population, which dates back to the early 7th century when the Pictish saint St Donnan brought a Christian population to Eigg and founded a monastery, only to be slaughtered along with 52 others by the warrior women of the Pagan queen of Moidart. In the early 16th century, the entire population - 395 members of the Celtic MacDonald clan - were suffocated by the MacLeod clan, who lit a fire at the mouth the cave where the MacDonalds were hiding. In 1588, there was another massacre, when Maclean of Duart raided and pillaged the small isles of the Hebrides with the help of sailors from the Spanish Armada.

The events of recent decades, with the islanders negotiating development grants and becoming embroiled in legal manoeuvres, are somewhat pedestrian in comparison. Now that the Eiggites are in charge of their island's administration, a new confidence is coming to Eigg, but there's no danger of the islanders becoming too businesslike. When I enquired of the Lodge, the beautiful 1920s country house that has served as home to a series of landlords and now stands empty, I was told: "Oh, that old thing. We really must get round to doing something about it sooner or later."

The practicals
For details of accomodation on Eigg, or general information, call Mairi Kirk on 01687 482416. Eigg is reached from the mainland by ferry from Mallaig or Arisaig, which can be reached by coach or train from Fort William. Caledonian Macbraine runs a scheduled ferry from Eigg five times a week. Murdo Grant runs the Shearwater ferry daily, except Thursdays, from Arisaig to Eigg, as well as cruises to Muck and Rum with time ashore (01687 450224).
Eigg website: EiggTrust/homepage.htm

fields.headline: Tip of the week
fields.trailText: • Keep your hopes afloat: Don't let 'them' get you down says Robert Ballard , the man who found the Titanic and the Bismarck. In an interview with Fast Company magazine he says "At every point in your journey, you'll confront all types of obstacles. One of the most difficult to overcome is human -on both an individual and bureaucratic level. The trick is never to give up. Keep clashing against the bureaucracies that are in your way, and eventually they'll give. If you're relentless, one day you'll bang against their door and they'll be out to lunch or on a coffee break - and you can slip right through."

According to the latest Valentine's Day survey (this one's from Mills & Boon), Cupid strikes most commonly at work with 29% of respondents claiming to have fallen in love at first sight.

 Love in the first degree: Watch out next week for a stranger in the office. Baby-faced and carrying a bow and arrow, he'll be so 'dressed-down' that he'll be naked. According to the latest Valentine's Day survey (this one's from Mills & Boon), Cupid strikes most commonly at work with 29% of respondents claiming to have fallen in love at first sight.

 Opportunity nuked: Job applicants are so scarce in some fields that many employers in the US are using a new hiring technique called an 'exploding offer'. The National Association of Colleges and Employers says some graduates are given only a few days to accept a job offer before it's withdrawn, which means they usually aren't able to do a thorough job search.

 Office bugs: Armies of brainless robots could replace us as office workers say robotic experts at Edmonton Research Park in Alberta who studied ants to discover how they achieve complex tasks without communicating with each other. The scientists say they can now mimick the same sort of distributed intelligence in a gang of worker robots.

fields.headline: Cool companies: No 26. 3M
fields.trailText: No - it doesn't stand for money, money, money. Nor is it the latest online music business selling MP3 files through the net. It is, in fact, an innovative US multinational, founded in1902 when five businessmen formed the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company.
fields.body:
No - it doesn't stand for money, money, money. Nor is it the latest online music business selling MP3 files through the net. It is, in fact, an innovative US multinational, founded in1902 when five businessmen formed the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company.

This famous five originally intended to mine a mineral deposit - but it turned out to be useless for their purposes and the businessmen were forced instead to use the mineral to manufacture sandpaper.

Perhaps their willingness to change and adapt was a portent of things to come since 3M has gone on to become a highly-diversified Fortune 500 company with operations in more than 60 countries.

The company's first major success was its introduction of waterproof sandpaper which was developed in the early1920s for the emerging car industry.

Then 3M began to focus its growth into many other markets. A major milestone occurred in 1925 when Richard Drew, a young lab assistant, invented masking tape to help car manufacturers produce the two-tone paint jobs popular at the time. This was the company's first step towards diversification and the first of the family of Scotch brand pressure-sensitive tapes which today numbers more than 900.

The company's research and development portfolio features 100 different technologies, which include abrasives, adhesives, non-woven fibres, films, precision coatings, fluorochemicals, ceramics, optics and microstructured surfaces. For example, non-woven technology spawned an array of seemingly unrelated products such as cleaning sponges, insulation material and face masks. Its better-known products include Scotch brand adhesive tapes and the ubiquitous yellow Post-It Notes.

Its UK and Ireland operation is one of the largest subsidiaries outside the US, employing around 4,000 people. Its customer technical centre in Bracknell welcomes more than 3,000 clients each year looking for technology-based solutions to business or manufacturing problems.

webTitle: Honesty is the best interview policy

fields.headline: Honesty is the best interview policy
fields.standfirst: But dare you tell them about your Achilles' heel?
fields.trailText: Think how different things would be if some of the great and the good were made to truthfully answer that perennial leg-trap of an interview question: "What is your greatest weakness?"
fields.body:
Think how different things would be if some of the great and the good were made to truthfully answer that perennial leg-trap of an interview question: "What is your greatest weakness?"

Would Margaret Thatcher have taken a chance on Michael Heseltine if he'd have answered "naked and all consuming ambition"? Would the American public have voted in as president a man who answered "unrestrained sexual urges towards impressionable young women"? And would the shareholders have had as much confidence in Virgin if its boss admitted early on he had a weakness for trotting off on pointless, expensive and dangerous hot air balloon rides?

But, unfortunately, these people don't get asked the question. We do - so it's best to be prepared.

Jot down a list of your strengths at work. Now list your weaknesses. If you're anything like me (modest, self-deprecating ... no, really) they'll be around the same length or even longer. How do we begin telling the interviewer?

We seem programmed to think of the negatives about ourselves, says occupational psychologist Clive Hunter. "It is almost that we try to tell ourselves our weaknesses before others do as a defence mechanism. It might also be a strangely British trait," he suggests.

Once written, my list includes such career-flattening traits as bossiness, chronic impatience, unrealistic standards and an inability to concentrate on tedious work. But it's not something I'd tell an interviewer.

Yet "what do you believe is your biggest weakness" rates as one of the most deadly grenades in the interviewer's arsenal of deflating and below-the-belt questions.

"Look back at that list of pluses and minuses," advises Margaret Shaw, managing director of Abacus Recruitment. "Now think of the job you want and pick the relevant traits and you can begin to play around with the meaning of 'weakness'."

Shaw agrees with most careers experts' advice: the answer is to take one of our strengths and turn it into a 'weakness'. For example, if you want them to believe in your attention to detail, argue that a weakness is your inability to let a piece of work go until it is correct and presented to your standards.

"In this way," she says, "you can always lead the firm back to one of your four or five key attributes."

Conversely, pick a weakness and miraculously make a virtue out of it. Playing the guinea-pig, I laid my personality defects on the line with Clive Hunter.

"OK, well 'bossiness' can easily be translated into strong leadership," he mused. "'Impatience'..hmm.. 'need to meet deadlines'. 'Unrealistic standards'? Well, you'd just have to look at it as 'very high standards'. 'Getting bored' should be read as 'needing challenges'."

He thinks for a minute. "How about telling them that you have very high standards for yourself and any teams you are in, so consequently feel the need to provide strong leadership when you feel that those standards aren't being met?"

Miraculously three items on my sin-list are moved smoothly over to my roll-call of virtues. Hey, this is great! But the careers counsellors caution us not to get too carried away and forget that a little humble honesty goes a long way with a cynical interviewer.

And be aware that a carefully-crafted 'virtuous weakness' could be exposed as the least of your worries by some of the computerised psychological profiling tests being used by the majority of large organisations.

"I'd been through an important interview with one high street retailer and thought I'd handled the 'name your weakness' question really well," confessed Paul, now a buyer for the Selfridges group. "I had given this firm some flannel about being over-enthusiastic. But when the personality and aptitude test came back, it highlighted my ambivalence at completing administrative or financial tasks. And that's an important part of my job.

"If I had the chance to do that interview again," says Paul, "I'd have said I was really strong on the creative aspects of my job, but that I knew I had to concentrate on getting the admin done too. They appreciate a bit of honesty if they can see you've genuinely thought about how to improve yourself."

Get it? You are perfect, but tell them in a way that's palatable. If you are still unsure about what weaknesses to unveil, the experts advise sticking to the classic: you work too hard, of course.

webTitle: Billions on road for year of the dragon

fields.headline: Billions on road for year of the dragon
fields.standfirst: China's migrant workers flock home for festivities as Jakarta's besieged minority celebrates again after years of repression
fields.trailText: A billion Chinese people sat down last night for their traditional New Year's Eve family dinner with  jiaozi  - meat dumplings - to welcome in the year of the dragon.
fields.body:
A billion Chinese people sat down last night for their traditional New Year's Eve family dinner with jiaozi - meat dumplings - to welcome in the year of the dragon.

Several hundred million had travelled long distances to reach home on packed trains, buses and special planes. Stories of travel hardships are notorious every year: they include collapsing carriages and the occasional death from suffocation. Passengers were also warned against forged tickets on sale at the stations, and against organised gangs of pickpockets.

Surveys show that four out of five Chinese will make the effort to go home. Most are migrant workers returning to rural areas.

State media reported yesterday that 33m travelled by rail between January 21 and 31 - the first wave of an estimated 129m rail passengers during the holiday.

Of a projected 1.6bn trips taken in the 40-day period surrounding the holiday, an estimated 1.4bn will be undertaken by road and 6.8m by air, Xinhua news agency reported. This represents a 3.5% rise on the number of journeys undertaken last year.

Beijing's 11 prisons yesterday gave 250 inmates three days' leave with their families as a reward for good behaviour.

Those who cannot return feel the deprivation bitterly. Ah Ping, 19, from the rural southern province of Guangxi, has worked as a waitress in Guangzhou City for six months.

She left her first job after a customer groped her and she was sacked for not being "cooperative". Her new boss says she must work because it is his busy season.

"It's the first time I've been away", she said. "It's such fun in the village when the 'big dog' [a local lion dancer] comes round to wish us a happy new year."

A happier holiday is in sight for 42 abducted children in Guizhou who have become media celebrities after being rescued by the police last month. They were victims of an organised trade to supply cheap labour in Guangdong province. More than half have been reunited with their parents and the others will spend the Spring Festival - as it is usually called - with volunteer families.

Though officially the lunar new year holiday only lasts four days, most Chinese manage to extend it. Government bureaucrats slow to a halt in the week before the festival, and little business is done for two weeks afterwards.

The Chinese leaders go on "comfort missions" in the run-up to the festival to visit army units and assure them they playing a valuable role.

This year local officials have been urged to pay particular attention to the old and the poor, who have been left behind in China's consumerist boom. A warning has also been issued against having banquets at public expense - but no one expects it to be taken very seriously.

New year bonuses range between 500 and 2,000 renminbi (£37-£148) in Beijing and other cities, fuelling shopping sprees for many. Families on average spend about 10% of their annual incomes on the holiday, according to a report in the China Daily yesterday.

Food is the main purchase particularly in southern China which has a reputation for extensive eating. "Eating is sim ply the most preferred way of spending the New Year for the people of Guangzhou," the popular Yangcheng Evening News wrote this week.

The combination of the year of the dragon with the new millennium is seen as particularly favourable. Despite strict planned parenthood controls, China may see a sharp rise in "auspicious" births.

In rural China there will be the traditional temple fairs - though temples were de stroyed in the cultural revolution, most villages now have at least one new temple.

Attempts in the past to ban fireworks and firecrackers have failed: five thousand firemen will remain at their posts in Shanghai to deal with an expected one hundred fires daily.

Five people were killed in the rural southern province of Guangxi this week when a young boy's firecracker burned down a block of firework shops.

fields.headline: In fashion, it's autumn already
fields.standfirst: Catwalk shows are costly but essential
fields.trailText: In the real world, it's not even spring yet - but in fashion, autumn is here already. New York fashion week begins in earnest tomorrow when sportswear king Tommy Hilfiger presents his designs for autumn/winter 2000/2001. Over the next four weeks, New York, London, Milan and Paris will take turns to host fashion weeks, where designers will present the clothes that will fill stores and magazines worldwide by autumn.
fields.body:
In the real world, it's not even spring yet - but in fashion, autumn is here already. New York fashion week begins in earnest tomorrow when sportswear king Tommy Hilfiger presents his designs for autumn/winter 2000/2001. Over the next four weeks, New York, London, Milan and Paris will take turns to host fashion weeks, where designers will present the clothes that will fill stores and magazines worldwide by autumn.

Nonsensical, attention-seeking and utterly without relevance to the real world: a cynic might argue that the idiosyncratic timing tells you all you need to know about the fashion industry. But behind the frippery is a multimillion pound business, and the timing is necessary for the fashion wheel to have time to turn.

Once the shows finish, department store buyers will choose, order and take delivery of clothes from all over the world. Glossy magazines will photograph the outfits on the world's most beautiful women and feature them in their summer issues to whet our appetites, so that by September the image-conscious consumer will not dare set foot in public without a whole new wardrobe.

The biannual ready-to-wear merry-go-round is the most important element of the fashion season. Haute couture, which takes place twice a year in Paris, grabs headlines for its fantastical designs and £20,000-plus price tags, and the European men's fashion weeks attract some coverage. But the ready-to-wear shows make or break designers' careers and dictate the reference points for fashion in magazines, on television and in film. By influencing high street retailers, ready-to-wear determines what the woman in the street is wearing six months later.

Staging fashion shows is an expensive business. London fashion week is organised by the British Fashion Council, but is made possible by sponsorship. VS Sassoon (formerly Vidal Sassoon) is the main sponsor, donating £2.2m over five years towards the official tents, security and other costs, while a number of smaller sponsors give money or help in kind (Harrods provides a courtesy bus between shows for press and buyers).

But each designer still has to find money for their own show costs, including hiring the venue, lighting and equipment, and paying models and make-up artists. The amount varies enormously. Simon Ward, of the British Fashion Council, said: "It would be very difficult to put on a show for less than £5,000. The average show probably costs £20,000-£30,000 - and for major international players, you are talking six figures."

Demanding sponsors

When you consider that the model of the moment, Brazilian Gisele Bundchen, can command a fee of $30,000 (£18,750) a show, it is easy to see how costs can become astronomical. For the wealthiest designers such as Donatella Versace, who likes to wow the audience with an army of supermodels, or Tommy Hilfiger, who had rock band Bush play live at his last show for a rumoured fee of $300,000 (£187,500), the sky is the limit.

But for most designers in London, finding the money for even a modest show without compromising for a demanding sponsor is difficult. Up and coming designer Andrew Groves said: "This is my sixth show and each one has almost not happened because of money."

Some designers shun catwalk shows, deeming them too expensive and overexposed. Bella Freud has made short films featuring her recent collections instead. But for most, catwalk shows remain an effective method of selling. "On the catwalk, you can put across the message of what you're about. A show can conjure a certain image in people's minds," said British designer Maria Grachvogel.

A show is also vital to generate publicity. When Stella McCartney persuaded Kate Moss to appear in her graduation show, she grabbed media attention and catapulted herself on to the world stage.

Celebrity endorsements

For major fashion houses, catwalk shows function as advertising. Few women may buy an outfit worn on Armani or Chanel catwalks, but many will be seduced by the image to buy the perfume, sunglasses, jeans or lipstick that bears the same name.

But what happens on the catwalk is only half the story. The majority of the audience is made up of press and buyers - usually seated on opposite sides of the catwalk - with seats allocated according to a strict hierarchy that would put a military academy to shame. Increasingly, even the most powerful editors and buying directors are ousted from the front row by celebrities.

Designers will use all the free frocks at their disposal to lure those who get the cameras flashing to their show - a full house of Spice Girls put relative newcomer Julien MacDonald on the front pages last season - and in a celebrity-obsessed world, the tacit endorsement of Whitney Houston or Salma Hayek (who both attended the Dolce & Gabbana show in Milan) is priceless.

The fashion world is currently abuzz with rumours and intrigue. Who, if anyone, will Gucci supremo Tom Ford appoint to plum jobs at his Milan headquarters and at newly acquired Yves Saint Laurent, now that Stella McCartney is alleged to have turned down the Gucci job because of her objection to working with fur? Will Tommy Hilfiger succeed in buying out Calvin Klein?

This ready-to-wear season looks set to be particularly intriguing.

fields.headline: Why Fairbrother must go
fields.trailText: The current round of discussions and arguments proposing solutions to the decline of English cricket concentrates on the games being played rather than the personnel actually playing them.
fields.body:
The current round of discussions and arguments proposing solutions to the decline of English cricket concentrates on the games being played rather than the personnel actually playing them.

I would like to look at one category of player, a category that is probably doing more harm to the English game and its future than any other single factor.

Every county has at least one older player - and often more - who in their time have served their county well, but who are now past their prime; they are still holding a place in their county side on merit, but will never improve, and never challenge for a Test place. In short, they are preventing the development of the young players who represent the future.

Neil Fairbrother at Lancashire is a good example. He may be as fine a one-day batsman as this country has seen in the last decade, and not an incompetent first-class batsman either. And, while Fairbrother is unarguably past his prime, it is quite likely that this season he will play a major role in helping Lancashire win at least one of the one-day trophies (and just miss the Championship). He is paid by Lancashire, and his presence is demanded by their members. And, yes, he is fully entitled to earn his living as a county cricketer. But is his continuing presence in the Lancashire side, along with all his generation of players around the counties, in the best interest of the England team?

If he and many of the other veterans are to be retired to make way for callow youths who are not yet as good as them, how do we do it? Employment Protection Laws apply to cricketers. How do we get the best from them in developing the callow talent?

County clubs cannot afford to carry excess staff, whether young or old. If a young player watches his career prospects blighted by an older man who is seeing out his time, he may well look for employment elsewhere, and just play at weekends for fun. Jack Simmons and David Hughes, again at Lancashire, played on until they were nearly 50: how many up-and-coming spinners' careers were blighted as a result? England might even have found their own matchwinning spinner if this pair had retired earlier.

Don't simply look for an easy solution by driving away crowd-pulling overseas players: look at our elder statesmen instead. Only then will our youngsters get the chances they need.

Brian Robinson lives in Essex

He is paid by Lancashire, and his presence is demanded by their members. And, yes, he is fully entitled to earn his living as a county cricketer. But is his continuing presence in the Lancashire side, along with all his generation of players around the counties, in the best interest of the England team? If he and many of the other veterans are to be retired to make way for callow youths who are not yet as good as them, how do we do it? Employment Protection Laws apply to cricketers. How do we get the best from them in developing the callow talent? County clubs cannot afford to carry excess staff, whether young or old. If a young player watches his career prospects blighted by an older man who is seeing out his time, he may well look for employment elsewhere, and just play at weekends for fun. Jack Simmons and David Hughes, again at Lancashire, played on until they were nearly 50: how many up-and-coming spinners' careers were blighted as a result? England might even have found their own matchwinning spinner if this pair had retired earlier. Don't simply look for an easy solution by driving away crowd-pulling overseas players: look at our elder statesmen instead. Only then will our youngsters get the chances they need. Brian Robinson lives in Essex

webTitle: Outrage at gran's account of Elian meeting

fields.headline: Outrage at gran's account of Elian meeting
fields.standfirst: More about the Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: US-based relatives of Elian Gonzalez, the boy at the centre of a tug of war with Havana, are outraged by his Cuban grandmother's account of how she playfully bit the 6-year-old's tongue and unzipped his trousers during their recent reunion.
fields.body:
US-based relatives of Elian Gonzalez, the boy at the centre of a tug of war with Havana, are outraged by his Cuban grandmother's account of how she playfully bit the 6-year-old's tongue and unzipped his trousers during their recent reunion.

"The family is shocked and disturbed," said Armando Gutierrez, a spokesman for the relatives, yesterday. "That is not a Cuban custom."

In an interview on Cuban television, the boy's paternal grandmother, Mariela Quintana, said she had "played jokes" with the boy during a meeting in Florida last month.

Ms Quintana said the boy was reserved at the start of the meeting, so she joked that he might have lost his tongue.

"I took his tongue out of his mouth," she said, gesturing with her hand as if she was pulling her own tongue from her mouth. "I bit it."

"I even opened up his zipper," she said, making an unzipping gesture. "I told him, 'Let me see, let me see ... if it has grown."'

In Cuba, few people found her behaviour strange, but a the channel which broadcast the interview in Miami was flooded with calls from outraged viewers.

"Everyone we have talked to, everyone who saw the tape, thought this was inappropriate behaviour for grandmothers," said Maria Lewis, managing editor at Telemundo's WSCV-TV.

Uva de Aragon, the assistant director of the Cuban research institute at Florida international university, said Ms Quintana's behaviour might seem odd to people in the US but was probably innocent. "The way the woman said it on national television shows it wasn't something perverted. She was joking with a little kid, trying to get him to respond, the same as if she were tickling him."

She said that most Hispanic cultures have a different concept of personal space.

Elian, who fled Cuba with his mother, was rescued after clinging to an inner tube for two days, the sole survivor of a shipwreck. His father in Cuba is pressing for his return.

webTitle: TransTec auditor to testify in DTI inquiry

fields.headline: TransTec auditor to testify in DTI inquiry
fields.trailText: A former auditor of TransTec, the collapsed engineering group founded by the former treasury minister, Geoffrey Robinson, is to testify to department of trade and industry officials investigating allegations of falsified applications for government grants, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
A former auditor of TransTec, the collapsed engineering group founded by the former treasury minister, Geoffrey Robinson, is to testify to department of trade and industry officials investigating allegations of falsified applications for government grants, the Guardian has learned.

The accountant - who has not been named - is expected to support the allegations, at least in part.

Meanwhile, creditors of the crashed group, owed about £200m, are to meet in Birmingham on Monday to discuss possible courses of action to protect their position.

The gathering will include both creditors and "creditors of creditors" - some of whom are on the brink of bankruptcy themselves as a result of TransTec's collapse.

This presages the full-blown creditors' meeting to be called by the end of March by receivers Arthur Andersen, who, while positive about the future of those who work for most of TransTec's operating units, are thought to find the outlook for creditors far less certain.

Some TransTec creditors are "feeling bruised", an Andersens spokesman said.

Elsewhere, further details have emerged about one of TransTec's major shareholders, the offshore Ducroire company, which has a 6.1% holding. Ducroire has shifted its offices from Madrid to Grand Canary and gives its chief activity as "development and selling of real estate".

Ducroire is controlled by a Dutch company, First Britannia Mezzanine, one of whose directors is Keith Harris, the former chief executive of HSBC investment bank.

First Britannia is run from a London company, Mezzanine Management, 50% of whose shares are registered to seven companies, all based in a for mer presbytery in Alderney in the Channel Islands.

At the peak of TransTec's stock market value, the Ducroire shares were worth some £13.5m.

The two independent inspectors who were appointed last month by the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, to report on TransTec's collapse in December are looking into the tangled ownership structure of some shares.

Meanwhile, the internal department of trade and industry team examining the allegations relating to government grants is to hear from one of the accountants who conducted external audits on TransTec in the late 1980s.

The auditor is no longer working for the same company and does not wish to speak to the media.

On Wednesday, the DTI heard from Max Ayriss, the former TransTec accountant who first alleged that grants from the department of trade and industry for technical innovation had been obtained by the company between 1986 and 1988 - in part by submitting invoices which produced inflated totals for spending on DTI-approved objectives.

Mr Robinson has denied absolutely Mr Ayriss's claims.

Mr Ayriss said, however, that the meeting had been "constructive and positive".

TransTec collapsed after it emerged the company had, some time after Mr Robinson's departure for government office, concealed a £12m claim against it from car group Ford, and had also hidden the fact it had repaid £8m.

 The United States-based scientific and environmental services group, EA Engineering, said last night that it would be restating its profit figures after "accounting irregularities" had come to light.

Earnings per share would be reduced by about 14 cents, said the Maryland company.

webTitle: Hostels to fortune . . .money saving sites on the net

fields.headline: Hostels to fortune . . .money saving sites on the net
fields.trailText: Whether you're still at the planning stages, or you've bought your ticket and are ready for the off, or even if you're already halfway around the world, the net is a good source for money-saving tips.
fields.body:
Whether you're still at the planning stages, or you've bought your ticket and are ready for the off, or even if you're already halfway around the world, the net is a good source for money-saving tips.

Most destinations are covered by The International Student Travel Confederation, which gives basic information about currency, telephone codes and time differences. More to the point, it can tell you which hostels in, say, Cape Town are offering discounts to student travellers holding an International Student Identity Card (ISIC). Information about how to get this card is also on this site. Another good source of budget accommodation is Hostelling International, which is essentially a database of hostels worldwide, allowing you to search for a hostel in your chosen destination, read about budget travel in that country and book your bed up to six months in advance. Hostels.com offers a similar service with its Worldwide Hostel Database and has links to online bookshops, bargain tickets shops, offers the chance to win a trip abroad and has some editorial content.

For more detailed reading about your destination, it's worth knowing that both Lonely Planet and Rough Guides reproduce a lot of their guide books online. Not only will you save money accessing the pages you want, but you won't need to carry a heavy tome around with you either. The Lonely Planet site has a noticeboard (the Thorn Tree) for travellers' tips. It doesn't look great, but a search under your particular destination may well throw up some useful advice from someone who's been there and done that.

The online magazine Gap Year is a hugely informative site run by travel writers. It publishes first-hand accounts of students' experiences, has a search engine to enable you to find a placement, gives the lowdown on choosing an organisation to travel with, as well as advice on visas, health matters and money. It also has a chat room - a good place to start if you want to hear more about other people's experiences - a message board and the staff are keen to respond to any concerns you may have.

Most charities and working-abroad organisations now have websites. Bunac has a specific group of programmes for gap-year students. Other sites to investigate are the Jet Programme for teaching English in Japan, Raleigh International, and Kibbutz Representatives.

It goes without saying that it's worth setting up an e-mail account, and most search engines now have a "free e-mail" flag on their homepage. Hotmail has updated itself since its security scare last year; Yahoo! and Compuserve are both popular programmes.

The Gap Year site mentioned above also has its own web-based e-mail. You may find there's already someone out there with your name, though, so if you're fussy about your e-mail address, you could try a few sites to see if you can get the address you want.

fields.headline: Flu provokes a family crisis
fields.trailText: The Sydney Flu has swept through the Mole family like a viral hurricane and has left us traumatised and weakened. The bathroom cabinet cannot hold all the prescription drugs...
fields.body:
Friday, January 28, 2000
Wisteria Walk, Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leicestershire

The Sydney Flu has swept through the Mole family like a viral hurricane and has left us traumatised and weakened. The bathroom cabinet cannot hold all the prescription drugs, so a pine shelf has been cleared of its bath oils and pressed into service.

Each of us Moles developed complications. Dr Grey was at our house so often I'm surprised he didn't bring his toiletry bag and slippers. One day, after being summoned urgently to my bedside, he rang the Lancet on his mobile and asked if they'd be interested in a 1,000 words on "GP rage".

Saturday, January 29

I received the following letter this morning.

Dear Adrian,

Remember me? I am your mother, Pauline Mole. Currently residing in bed five, ward 20, Glengorse District Hospital. I am recovering from pneumonia and pleurisy and have been here for three long weeks (on oxygen). I am very hurt that you haven't been to see me, sent me flowers or written a card. Your neglect is impeding my recovery. I can't sleep for wondering where I went wrong.

Love from your mother.

PS. I have stopped smoking. It is too difficult to manage in an oxygen mask.

Dear Mum,

Is it really three weeks? It has gone by in a flash. I'm pleased to hear that you have stopped smoking. I have collected up the ashtrays (all 31 of them) and thrown them into the wheelie-bin so as to lessen the temptation when you get home. The reason I haven't visited you is because I am still weak from the Sydney Flu. Dr Grey was called to my bedside four times, twice in the middle of the night. You should count yourself lucky that you were given a hospital bed, even though it was 60 miles away.

I intended to send you a bouquet of flowers but, quite honestly, I was horrified at the prices they were asking. The minimum charge for a bouquet is £15! Then there is a delivery charge of £2.50. It is sheer exploitation. I concede that I could have sent you a get-well card, but a trip to the shops is out of the question until I regain the strength in my legs. Your husband, Ivan, has kept me informed about your progress. You have been in my thoughts and I am hurt and annoyed to be charged with neglecting you.

Your son, Adrian.

I gave this note to Ivan to give to my mother. He is a fool for love, he drives 60 miles a day to visit her. At 10pm, Ivan got back from the hospital. He was ecstatic. "Your mother woke up this morning and asked for her make-up bag," he said. He confided in me that when she'd first been admitted he passed her hospital bed twice without recognising her. He'd never seen her without lipstick or mascara before. He gave me a reply from my mother.

Dear Adrian,

So, I'm not worth £17.50? When I think of the money and attention that I've lavished on you over 32 years, it makes me sick. I will probably be discharged in a couple of days. I want you gone from Wisteria Walk by then. You must take your boys and go and live with your father and Tania. There are four empty bedrooms at The Lawns.

Mother.

Sunday, January 30

Just returned from The Lawns after explaining my housing dilemma to my father and his new wife, Tania. They were not exactly keen to take me and my boys in. "We use those bedrooms," said my father. "I keep my golf clubs in one, and Tania over-winters the geraniums in another.

"That still leaves two empty rooms," I pointed out.

"Sadly, no," said Tania. "I'm in the process of turning one of those rooms into a meditation space."

"And the last remaining room?" I enquired with a cynical sneer. My father turned away, but Tania stared me out.

"The fourth room is to be used to store my collection of Millennium Dome memorabilia," she said. As I stumbled away from The Lawns, I dashed tears from my eyes. All hope is gone. The council estate beckons.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: Catherine Chidgey's new novel is bathed equally with humour and nostalgia, plus She's Come Undone, Sébastian Roch and Remembrance Day
fields.body:
In A Fishbone Church
Catherine Chidgey
Picador, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Clifford is the patriarch of the Stilton family and an obsessive diarist. His watchwords, "You have to keep an eye on things all the time, otherwise you lose them", become the leitmotif of this beguiling story about the connections which hold three generations of the same family together. Chidgey writes of shelves where diaries are kept, freezers used to store the birds Clifford and his son, Gene, shoot, and the cupboards which hold a trousseau assembled by Gene's mother in law. The rest of the Stilton glue is provided by the Catholic church and the ritual growing up of the children. Chidgey's novel is bathed equally with humour and nostalgia.

She's Come Undone
Wally Lamb
Scribner, £7.99
Buy it at BOL

Lamb is the first author to have enjoyed the Oprah effect - a leap into the US bestseller charts after his first novel was "Oprah's Choice". So what does Lamb's tale have that gives it daytime appeal? From the mid-50s, when Dolores Price is discovering TV and friendship, to the mid-80s, after 100-odd pounds of weight have been gained and shed, lovers found and lost, and dreams turned to dull reality, she is the all-American post-war girl. Along the way there are plenty of tears, heartache and the usual coming-of-age stuff. This is an epic of Oprah's age, with an engaging heroine whose life story is well-made, but in the grander scheme, essentially insignificant.

Sébastian Roch
Octave Mirbeau
Dedalus, £9.99
Buy it at BOL

In the catalogue of novels about lives distorted by unhappy schooldays, Mirbeau's contribution must be one of the bitterest. He follows the young, carefree Sébastian from a small French town to the bleak Breton coast. There the Jesuit fathers, in whom his snobbish father has placed so much trust, heap misery upon misery. The ironmonger's son is mocked by France's adolescent aristocracy and turns for comfort to the perfidious priests. An angry novel, but poignant through Mirbeau's descriptions of landscape to which his hero sensitively responds. But the age allows no redemption for Roch except oblivion.

Remembrance Day
Henry Porter
Orion, £5.99
Buy it at BOL

Con Lindow is waiting for Eamonn, the brother he hasn't seen for two years, when a bus explodes on the street in front of him. Two Irish brothers caught up in a terrorist attack? Knacker of the Yard jumps to conclusions. Con, a harmless molecular biologist, dodges a host of baddies from London to Ireland to Boston before he can clear his name. Porter constructs a thriller with all the correct ingredients - a turf war between the Met and the spooks, policemen estranged from their wives, friends who come good and lovers who go bad - and he tosses in more evidence every time you think the mystery is solved.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.standfirst: News That Stays News brings a poem from every year of the 20th century
fields.trailText: News That Stays News brings a poem from every year of the 20th century.
fields.body:
News That Stays News: The 20th Century In Poems
Penguin, £8.99, 240 mn
Buy it at BOL

Here is a poem from every year of the century just closed. The point is to spread out an appraisal of the century by its most "critical and visionary observers". But outside the world wars and other political crises, there are many nondescript single years, for which it has been hard to muster verses. An interesting sequence, nevertheless, and best enjoyed as a conveyor belt of poems with occasional real goodies, read by Timothy West, Eileen Atkins, Andrew Sachs and Alex Jennings.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: Elizabeth Barber crawls through the dust of ages, plus Detective Agency and The Elegant Universe
fields.body:
The Mummies of Urumchi
Elizabeth Barber
Pan, £7.99
Buy it at BOL

We're total fans of Prof Barber from her previous work on prehistoric textiles (radical revisions of tech and cultural history): here she goes as expedition consultant after the discovery of well-preserved bodies, circa 1,000BC, in Chinese Turkestan. She's so honest an expert, describing how she crawled through the dust of ages and naptha anti-moth fumes in museum cases, the better to understand that the wool and felt clothes the buried wore to their graves were related to those of Celtic cultures through Europe - another confirmation of the non-Chinese origin of the mummies' clan. Time present, time past, practical expertise and a touching tenderness for the long-dead.

Detective Agency
Priscilla Walton and Manina Jones
University of California, £10.50
Buy it at BOL

Thought this might be OK. Pop-culture study of female private eyes and cops "rewriting the hard-boiled tradition". Trouble is (and trouble is our business), they talk too much. And about intertexuality and metatextual references. Cross-examine 'em on dicks we care about, V I Warshawski or Jane Tennison, and get the picture: they like the idea of what these new dames represent a whole lot more than they actually enjoy the company of said dames. All culture, no pop. Bet they phone each other up the morning after a new Prime Suspect and rap about political discourse and revised stereotypical subtext.

The Elegant Universe
Brian Greene
Vintage, £7.99
Buy it at BOL

String theory - the 11-dimensional universe which is the mighty and harmonious symphony played by the vibrations of the universe's tiniest loops of energy. Bit pompous, but otherwise think that description is about right, though we're quantum-mechanics-impaired. We've been concentrating hard, trying to follow Greene metaphor by metaphor into these new worlds beyond worlds, but his metaphors are so plonking: based, like archaic maths problems, on his limited human social vision, all fast cars and garden hoses. He should have collaborated with a poet who could feel for the words which invoke, as much as explain, the infinite.

fields.headline: The deadly dandy
fields.standfirst: Andrew Motion on the extraordinary story of the forgotten artist, forger and poisoner who embodied the Romantic age and inspired his new novel
fields.trailText: Andrew Motion on the extraordinary story of the forgotten artist, forger and poisoner who embodied the Romantic age and inspired his new novel
fields.body:
Who was Thomas Griffiths Wainewright? He often asked the same question himself, and in the end decided "Nobody". In a sense he was right: today he's not much more than a shadow flickering through the footnotes to Romantic studies. In his own time, though, he was a remarkable Somebody: a renowned painter and author, and a flamboyant man-about-town, who was also a forger and a murderer. His story sheds an eerie light on the famous names around him: Keats and Hazlitt, Lamb and Clare, Fuseli and Blake. Its combination of high culture and low crime dramatises their fascination with the Self, and with the link between vice and virtue. As a victim and as a villain, let alone as an artist and critic, Wainewright caught the spirit of his age.

He was born the year before Keats (1794) in Chiswick. His mother died in childbirth, and when his father disappeared shortly afterwards, he was taken in by his maternal grandfather, Ralph Griffiths. Griffiths was an impressive fellow: the founder, and then for 50 years the editor, of England's first modern literary magazine, the Monthly Review. This made him a reasonable living, but most of his money came from another source. He was the original publisher of Fanny Hill and the proceeds bought a grand mansion on Chiswick High Road: Linden House.

Wainewright was raised in Linden House and educated in Greenwich by the famous Classicist Charles Burney (brother of Fanny, and son of the well-known musician), where he discovered a flair for drawing. When the time came for him to enter the wide world, he was apprenticed to established painters: John Linnell (Blake's friend) first, then Thomas Phillips, the society portraitist who is probably best remembered today for his portrait of Byron wearing Albanian national costume.

Wainewright didn't get on brilliantly well with Phillips. He thought he was too flattering to his sitters. Which is why, when he painted Byron himself (the picture now hangs in Newstead Abbey) he went out of his way to make him look frankly voluptuous. Indeed, the whole business of painting soon lost its appeal for Waine-wright, so he chucked it in and joined the army. By this time, he had shaken off the stern influence of his grandfather and become the most ostentatious kind of dandy: fancy moustaches, frock coat, spurs.

This was largely why the 16th Foot appealed to him: they had a uniform which put Beau Brummell in the shade. But not even this was enough to keep him in the military for long. After a year he gave up the army as well , came back to London, had a nervous breakdown, cured himself by reading Wordsworth's poems, got married and went back to painting, exhibiting at the Royal Academy and elsewhere. This was when he met Blake and others in his circle, and also became close friends with Fuseli, to whose dungeon-apartments under Somerset House he often took his wife's two half-sisters to pose for the "god of his worship".

His life was glamorous, but expensive. He collected prints; he rented smart rooms in Great Marlborough Street; he gave lavish dinners for the London Magazine set: all things which couldn't easily be financed by the little money he earned as a painter and journalist, or by the interest he received from the small trust fund which had been set up for him by his grandfather. By the early 1820s he was reduced to forging the deeds governing this trust (which he knew was a capital offence), in order to continue on his merry way.

When that money was spent, he devised a more desperate remedy. In the late 1820s and early '30s at least three of his nearest and dearest died in highly suspicious circumstances, and as a result of each death Wainewright made large financial gains. He never admitted to murder, but the circumstantial evidence against him is overwhelming, and he is known to have had several books on poison in his library. He was especially interested in strychnine, which had been developed only recently, and could not be reliably detected at autopsy.

What seems to have happened is this: first he killed his uncle and inherited the big house out at Chiswick; then he bumped off his mother-in-law to sever his links with her money-grubbing relations; and then he set up a complicated insurance scam with Helen Abercrombie, a half-sister of his wife. The original idea was to fake her death and run away to France with the loot, but things got too complicated. In the end, he poisoned Helen as well.

When Wainewright unwisely returned to London in the mid-1830s after five wretched years in France, he was immediately arrested, put in Newgate, where he was visited by Dickens, among others, and tried for forgery. (Not for murder, which was mentioned during his trial but could not be proved.) He was transported to Van Diemen's Land (Tasmania), the most brutal of all the penal colonies.

After a gruelling year on the chain gang, Wainewright got back his freedom by degrees: as a hospital orderly, then as someone who was allowed to practice painting again. Many of the local worthies sat for him (about 50 of these elegant portraits survive), but Wainewright never became part of respectable society, even after gaining his ticket-of-leave and, eventually, a conditional pardon. When he died in Hobart in 1847, his body was seized by the hospital and used to demonstrate methods of dissection. He has no grave.

It took two years of library-hopping, as well as a visit to Tasmania, to sort out the basic chronology of Wainewright's story. (Though a biography of him had been published in the 1930s, and another in Australia in the '50s). But when I was ready to start writing, it was obvious that certain vital elements had vanished for ever. As his friends learned of his disgrace, they destroyed all evidence of their connection with him: only a handful of his letters survive, and his petition for a ticket of leave. When he disappeared from public records he vanished from the face of the earth.

This meant that I was simply not in a position to write a complete orthodox biography, but by now I didn't want to, anyway. Initially, I'd supposed that whatever was experimental about my book would have to do with Wainewright's obscurity. During my research, I realised that I had good reasons for going on a formal adventure as well. I'd been pre- occupied for years by the problems which dog all biographers: how to combine objective views with subjective judg-ments; how to breathe life back into people who don't leave a mass of papers behind them. Maybe, I thought, by allowing Wainewright to tell his own story - by writing his Confessions (19th-century sense) - I could frame these questions in dramatic rather than just theoretical ways. And at the same time I could reveal things about his personality. I could make a virtue of unavoidable ignorance by presenting it as his own plausible evasion. I could suggest things about his devious nature by mingling extracts from his own writing, with others from contemporaries like Lamb and Hazlitt, and embed them all in my own ventriloquising invention.

This, I reckoned, would make Wainewright at once elusive and plausible - as he was. But I was still anxious to preserve a reliable kind of control over the material. In order that readers should know what they were dealing with, and to let hard facts emerge clearly, I decided to augment his text with notes which would supply background information, include mini-essays on relevant topics (from print collecting to poisoning), and wherever necessary correct the lies or misinformation in Wainewright's own account.

And this is how the book ended up: 21 chapters in which Wainewright tells his story from cradle to (almost) grave, and which purport to have been written in Van Diemen's Land the year before he died. They combine elements we normally associate with novels, prose poems, rants, ravings, self-justifications, the whole caboodle. And at the end of each chapter, there's a parcel of notes which contain the "orthodox biography".

The book is an experiment. But its mixture of different forms all share a common purpose. They are dedicated to rescuing Waine-wright from obscurity, to enjoying his achievements as an artist and critic, to exploring his career as a criminal, and to investigating his self. The voice that I have given him is a confection, but it is nothing more or less than the one I would have tried to characterise by more conventional means, had I decided to write a more familiar sort of biography. Exactly the same applies to my treatment of his personality.

fields.headline: Tingles among the tower blocks
fields.standfirst: Philip Ridley tells Lyn Gardner why he was the first magic realist
fields.trailText: Philip Ridley tells Lyn Gardner why he was the first magic realist
fields.body:
Towards the end of Vinegar Street, Philip Ridley's ninth book for children, the words appear to explode off the page. As Poppy Picklesticks, 12- year-old storm-bringer and fury, precipitates the final showdown against modern wicked-stepmother figure Mandy Nylon, the text begins to behave very oddly indeed. It skids and skedaddles across the page until finally the sentences combust, falling helter-skelter across the page like a giant firework.

Creating the artwork for these final pages took Ridley three months of cutting and pasting, and when he did eventually turn up at his publishers with the hefty manuscript under his arm, his editor was initally aghast. "But they have reproduced it very well in print," he says.

But then, Ridley always brings to his writing the same visual flair that he brings to his work as an artist, playwright and filmmaker. It is a short step from the ripe operatic visuals of Ridley's debut feature film The Reflecting Skin (1990), with its exploding frogs, to the exploding words of Vinegar Street. This is probably the first book to show on the page what a first kiss actually feels like. Like most of Ridley's work, it is the kind of book that kids love, and which makes parents feel slightly nervous.

As befits someone who trained as a painter, Ridley writes using joined-up images. His play, The Pitchfork Disney, includes what is almost certainly the longest monologue in contemporary drama. The entire 10-minute speech consists of nothing but a series of strung-out images. In Vinegar Street there is a similar connection between words, pictures and feelings. What better description of love than feeling as if your blood "tingled and fizzed like it was full of sherbet"? At a school recently, one 12-year-old girl confessed to Ridley that that was exactly how she felt when her friend, Adam, took off his shirt for PE.

Ridley writes about what he knows, the East End where he was born and where he still lives, in the same block of flats where he spent his childhood. But it is an East End viewed through a gothic lens: familiar and skewed, whether in his much-admired screenplay for The Krays (1990) or the dilapidated towerblock-turned-castle in his first book for children, Mercedes Ice (1989).

Even as a child he told stories, soothing his small brother to sleep with tales about the local launderette or corner shop that mixed the everyday with the exotic. "I think I must have been the first magic realist," says Ridley who spent much of his childhood bed-ridden by the asthma. By age 13 he had written and illustrated 10 novels. "I was the typical weedy kid. My nickname was 'Alien'. I had no friends, I was bullied and so I read and wrote all the time."

Not surprisingly, much of Ridley's work has a less than rosy take on childhood. From the nightmare of the child's-eye view in The Reflecting Skin, through The Pitchfork Disney, about a pair of young twins being molested by a serial killer, to the plays for young audiences, Fairytaleheart and Sparkleshark, Ridley's work explores the loneliness of the outcast.

But if childhood is not portrayed as golden age, Ridley displays a touching faith in the transforming power of the imagination and storytelling. In his 1997 novel Scribbleboy, shortly to be turned into a play and staged at the National Theatre, the grey concrete of a run-down neighbourhood is transformed by the fabulous graffiti of the hero.

In Fairytaleheart and Sparkleshark, troubled teenagers are healed through the act of storytelling, a theme further developed in Brokenville, an extraordinary, mythic piece set in a land devastated by an unknown catastrophe that was performed by and for Kosovan refugees early last year. And in Vinegar Street, it is the strength of Poppy's imagination that defeats makeover queen Mandy Nylon, purveyor of body fascism, and one of Ridley's most memorable creations. "She is," says Ridley "like Melinda Messenger on acid". Ridley believes so fervently in the imagination because it was the imagination that saved him. As he says simply: "Poppy is me and I am Poppy."

Like most people who are multi-talented, Ridley is often hailed in one breath for being a "Renaissance man" and condemned in the next for not sticking to one thing. "It has never occurred to me that what I do amounts to a career," he says happily, pointing out that he even fell into writing for children by accident.

"I'd written a couple of books for adults and I wrote what I thought was a novella. But when I showed it to my agent she said: 'Right then, a children's novel.' Since then, he has been shortlisted for both the Carnegie and the Whitbread, and he won the Smarties prize for Krindlekrax in 1991. But he thinks that distinctions between literature for children and adults are unnecessary. "It doesn't happen in film. Everyone will go and see Toy Story 2."

Yet, he says, writing for children is the backbone of his working life, and he will keep pushing back the boundaries. "I am always trying to push what the novel can do. I don't want to resort to the traps of whimsy and nostalgia you see in so much children's fiction, but to create something that's very now and in a language that connects with young people."

Ironically for someone whose books are influenced by - and paced like - films or computer games rather than traditional novels, Ridley still does all his writing longhand in an exercise book. But the results are anything but old-fashioned. Like Poppy Picklesticks, Ridley is a bit of a visionary, with a singular and very "spiffing, riff-raff imagination".

fields.headline: Only connect
fields.standfirst: He is the emminent Victorian we've largely forgotten, yet few thinkers deserve our thanks as much as John Ruskin. His vision was of a romantic, progressive society informed by respect for cultural achievement. He forged a link between art and politics, gothic arches and socilaism - and, during the early Labour governments, much of that vision became reality. His vision was of a romantic, progressive society informed by respect for cultural achievement. He forged a link between art and politics, gothic arches and socilaism - and, during the early Labour governments, much of that vision became reality. Now, perhaps more than ever, we need his guiding spirit
