fields.headline: A view from the bridge
fields.standfirst: She fled Pinochet's junta and began to write as a way of coping with exile and loss. She became a best-selling novelist but her masterpiece was a memoir of her daughter, who died at 26.  Maya Jaggi on a feminist pioneer of Latin American literature
fields.trailText: She fled Pinochet's junta and began to write as a way of coping with exile and loss. She became a best-selling novelist but her masterpiece was a memoir of her daughter, who died at 26. Maya Jaggi on a feminist pioneer of Latin American literature
fields.body:
Isabel Allende divides her life starkly into two: before and after the 1973 coup in Chile that brought General Augusto Pinochet to power and precipitated an exile from which she has never fully returned. "I never imagined such a thing was possible in Chile, which had such a solid, 160-year-old democracy - it was called the 'England' of Latin America," she says. "It was a revelation that there were concentration camps and torture centres all over the country. It had been there in the shadows, the brutality and violence, but for me, it was like waking into a nightmare."

The military coup toppled her "uncle" - strictly, her second cousin - and godfather Salvador Allende, the world's first freely elected Marxist president, who committed suicide - or was murdered - in the burning presidential palace in Santiago. (That his daughter, now a Socialist politician, is also called Isabel still results in juxtaposed portraits in the British press, a confusion that the author, who sometimes fancies she was switched with another infant at birth, might relish.)

Yet while her family, like a million other Chilean exiles, was scattered by the coup, she is convinced that had she not fled across the mountains, eventually making her way to Venezuela, where she stayed until 1987, she would not have become a writer. That vocation not only helped her break the junta's "chain of hatred" in her own soul, but later eased her recovery from the death, seven years ago, of her 28-year-old daughter Paula, who had lain comatose for 12 months with the rare genetic disorder, porphyria. For Allende, writing has in part been a tenacious reflex to loss, whether of exile or bereavement.

Now 57, she wrote her first novel when she was almost 40, in Venezuela. The House Of The Spirits (1982), tracing four generations of Chilean women up to the aftermath of the coup, became an international bestseller. With its English translation in 1985, she became the first of many women writing in Latin America to join the fraternity enjoying worldwide acclaim since the so-called Latin literary boom of the 1960s and 70s - most notably the 1982 Nobel laureate Gabriel García Márquez, Carlos Fuentes and Mario Vargas Llosa.

Her books - five novels, a collection of stories and two non-fiction works - have sold millions in 27 languages across the world. They have inspired plays and films, including, in 1993, Bille August's The House Of The Spirits, starring Jeremy Irons and Meryl Streep, and in 1994 Betty Kaplan's Of Love And Shadows, starring Antonio Banderas. There was even a musical in Iceland based on The House Of The Spirits.

Her appeal to her compatriots lies partly in the Allende name and her vocal opposition to the junta. But the allure of her writing is far wider. Ilan Stavans, professor of Spanish at Amherst College in Massachusetts, says: "She came late to the banquet but achieved an international reputation that exceeded many men. She brings feelings to the fore in a way male writers don't, with a panoramic view of politics and history that illuminates the connection with individual lives."

Yet her critical reception has been mixed. While Fay Weldon called The House Of The Spirits the "perfect novel - now that's written the rest of us can all go home", others lament that the early "spell" has been broken, complaining of shallow romance and potboilers, of sentiment that tips into sentimentality. Some bemoan a north American influence on her fiction since she moved to the United States in 1987.

"There's an ambivalence towards her even among Latin American critics," Prof Stavans says. "She revived a tradition of melodrama and the light women's novel - la novela rosa , as serialised in newspapers across the Spanish-speaking world - and turned it around in a more sophisticated way to bring to mind 'magical realism'. She's called derivative by those who saw The House Of The Spirits as a revamp of [Márquez's] One Hundred Years Of Solitude from the point of view of women. But what infuriates them is the bridge she forms between popular culture and the highbrow, and that she's so successful."

Alberto Manguel, who edited Other Fires, an anthology of work by Latin American women writers less fortunate in attracting English translators (for which Allende wrote a warm preface), says: "She is fascinated by melodrama, the romanticised, the sentimental. But she's much more interesting stylistically, and is able to tell these stories without forgetting political angles. She asserts the right of her women characters to live their own lives and speak in their own language - which can verge on purple prose, though there's no such thing in Spanish." Of her popularity in the English-speaking world, he adds: "Her fiction does correspond to the stereotypical vision of what Latin America might be: the passionate, dark-eyed heroine; the cool, male, governor - you are in the world of El Zorro. But that overlap is not a fault in the writing."

Poised and very funny, though more serious in private, Allende appears to mirror her books' vivacious if volatile mix of hard realism and playfully-edged romanticism. She was shortlisted for the Literary Review's Bad Sex Award for Daughter Of Fortune, her first novel in eight years, and read out the "offending" passages at the Queen Elizabeth Hall in London during her recent visit - she hadn't been to Britain for a decade - with amusement and aplomb, her tone underlining their deflating irony.

A California bookseller and friend, Elaine Petrocelli, calls her "very forthright and transparent. There aren't two Isabels; there's only one." But while Allende declares dramatically that all the women in her family run headlong after men - as she did in emigrating from Venezuela to California ("The second move was by choice; I fell in lust with a guy") - she has been adamant about earning her own living since she was 17.

Daughter Of Fortune began, she says, as a book about passion and ended up being about freedom. Set amid the Californian goldrush of the mid 19th century, its main characters are Chileans and Chinese who followed the trail for reasons of their own. Yet the lover whom the heroine Eliza follows from Chile fades from the plot, leaving only traces of a mythic Latino bandit. Eliza, disguised as a boy, grows too fond of her new-found liberty to relinquish it even for the most seductive man.

"When Eliza is sleeping outdoors, surrounded by snakes, bears, Indians, bandits, for the first time in her life she's not afraid, not restrained in a corset," says Allende. "It's an epiphany I had: the self-sufficiency she has now she can't give up. I belonged to the first generation of organised feminists in Chile, though by no means the first - my grandmother struggled for the vote. Going out into a man's world, like Eliza, to do things their mothers would never have dreamt of doing, to conquer that space, is what my generation of women did."

Isabel Allende was born during the second world war in Lima, Peru. Her father Tomás Allende (Salvador's cousin) was a Chilean diplomat who absconded in an "unsolved mystery" from both his job and his family when Isabel was three. She now thinks he may have been bisexual and embroiled in a scandal. She never saw him again (her mother cut his face out of all family photographs) until called upon to identify his body after he suffered a heart attack in the street. She was unable to recall what he had looked like. Allende sees herself as marked by his disappearance.

"Until very recently, I didn't trust men," she says. "I thought they weren't reliable; if you wanted something done, you had to do it yourself - including raising the kids. I never allowed anyone else to pay the bills because I understood that economic independence created the rest; I started working early and I've worked all my life. I never surrendered to a relationship with a man the way I did to my children and my mother."

She returned to Chile with her mother to live with her maternal grandparents and two uncles in Santiago. While the grandly conservative Catholic household left the poor-relation Isabel prone to rebellion and mixing with the Amerindian servants, its anglophilia later found ironic expression in the English expatriates of Daughter Of Fortune. "My grandfather was Basque and my grandmother Castilian, but everything from England was good - including the soap. I was born in the middle of the second world war, and practically everyone in the country had pro-German sympathies; the Chilean armed forces were trained by the Prussians. But my grandparents were knitting socks for the British troops."

After she was 10, and her mother remarried another diplomat, Allende lived in Bolivia and Lebanon, attending a Beirut school run by British Quakers, before being sent home at 15 (her grandfather enrolled her in an English finishing school), and starting work two years later. She had a spell translating Barbara Cartland into Spanish ("I couldn't resist making improvements"), then became a successful journalist, working for a magazine, Paula, that campaigned for divorce and abortion in the staunchly Catholic country, and penning "humorous" feminist columns, including one called "Civilise Your Caveman". In the 1960s - sporting long, dyed-blonde hair and driving a car painted with giant flowers - she had her own TV chat show.

"I was a lousy journalist," she insists. "I had no problem exaggerating or making up quotes. My colleagues thought they were being objective, but I never thought they were and I didn't even pretend." Flattered by a lunch invitation from Chile's Nobel poet laureate Pablo Neruda, she supposed she had been summoned to interview him. "He laughed and said he would never allow himself to be interviewed by me; that I was the worst journalist and I only ever wrote about myself. But he was amused by my columns."

At 19, Allende married an Anglo-Chilean engineering student with whom she lived for 25 years and had two children. She says she served him "like a geisha". "It was the way a Latin American woman served a man, but I exaggerated, because all my life is about exaggeration. I had three jobs. We had a car; he'd take it, and I'd go on the bus with the grocery, then come running home to serve him a drink. I thought I was a feminist, but I was raising the children alone; my husband never changed a diaper. I never applied the theory to my practical life."

Though not "political" like her Allende cousins, she chaffed against not only male prerogatives ("I'd wanted to be a man since I was five") but an impervious hierarchy that was partly racial: the more Indian the blood, the lower the class. "I'm fascinated with how you can break a system, defy and challenge it. As a woman, that's determined my life," she says. "I was brought up seeing the injustice of a class system; the poor didn't have a chance. The people who had control for generations had impunity. It was very hard to change society when I was growing up, though it happened with Salvador Allende."

While she regrets not having done more for her uncle's short-lived regime, the military coup when she was 31 awoke her to "the amount of evil that was possible". "I was a very frivolous person; involved in women's issues and feminism but not politics. In my humorous columns or TV programme I was always looking for the ironic and funny; I failed to see the tragedy brewing in my country." But in the first 48 hours after the coup, her "perpetual innocence, extended adolescence" were shattered. "My husband, who was in the construction business, had to take food to workers stranded by the curfew. We went out slowly in the car, with a white flag, and were stopped 10 or 20 times. Driving through the streets, I could see corpses, and books being burned, and people dragged into trucks, running with blood."

Partly because she was an Allende and a familiar face on television, she found herself called on to help the resistance. "Through friends in the church, I smuggled information and hid people in my house before they could be taken to the border or, when that became unsafe, to asylum in embassies." The experience is most closely reflected in her second novel, Of Love And Shadows, in which a fashion journalist is drawn into the resistance after falling for a photographer. Though Allende had initially refused safe passage offered by the Mexican embassy, after 14 months of the terror she fled. "By then I'd been fired from my job, and I was on a list. I couldn't take the fear for my family any more." Her husband joined her in Caracas when it became clear she could not return.

Despite hardship, Venezuela was liberating. "I'd come from a country where we dress in grey and pretend we're British, to a place enjoying the oil boom, where there was an erotic charge in the streets." The House Of The Spirits was begun on January 8 (Allende has since started all her books on the same date) as a letter to her dying grandfather, the model for its landowner and conservative senator Esteban Trueba, who backs the coup but becomes sickened by its brutality. His wife Clara was modelled on Allende's grandmother, a disciple of Madame Blavatsky who experimented with telepathy ("she didn't trust the mail"). She abandoned fantasy in Of Love And Shadows, which chronicled the real discovery of bodies of some of the "disappeared" in a disused mineshaft in 1978, and was written "out of anger". Yet in Eva Luna, about an Amerindian Sheherazade turned scriptwriter, and "a celebration of being a woman and a storyteller", she restored it with elements of kitsch borrowed from Latin soap opera, the telenovela .

Allende's marriage faltered as she was succeeding as a writer. She went off on an affair with a musician in Madrid, but after three months she returned to Caracas. She divorced in 1987. Within months, she had met her second husband while on a book tour in California. He became the model for Gregory Reeves in her California-set novel The Infinite Plan, about a post-Vietnam generation "defeated by the American dream".

While Allende was promoting the book in Spain her daughter Paula fell ill with porphyria, a hormonal disorder that is rarely fatal, but which left her in a coma. After six months in intensive care, she seemed strong enough to breathe without life support. For the six months till she died we tried everything: acupuncture, herbs, psychics, magnets, Shamanism, anything that might make her comfortable and that was not invasive. She'd already had enough pain."

Alternative medicine is explored in Daughter Of Fortune, through the character of the Chinese physician Tao Chi'en, with whom Eliza slowly falls in love. But the book was halted by Paula's illness and death in December 1992. "I thought I was never going to write again," Allende says. "I had to pull myself out of a writer's block and very dark depression. I just went to hell; it's a moment of grief you can't avoid and can't make better. I tried Prozac; it didn't work - I'd rather be in pain. Nothing helps except time, but you start drawing from an inside strength, a resilience you didn't know you had."

While her daughter was ill, Allende wrote an extended letter to her, in the diminishing hope that she would one day read it. The letter grew into her memoir Paula, which she calls "the most important book I will ever write, which has the greatest truth. Writing is exorcism. It deals with the demons of the past, sorts out the confusion. Life happens so fast there's no time to see the connections or consequences; there's too much noise everywhere. But in my work, there is no noise. Everything has a ripple effect in a book; in the years of introspection, I grow. For me, it's like meditation or prayer."

While her mother was aghast at the disclosure of "family secrets", Allende even added snatches of love letters between Paula and her husband of only a year, Ernesto. He consented to Isabel's taking Paula home to California because she was better able to care for her, with nurses. "Ernesto called me on the phone, crying, saying 'Paula was different, you only knew her as a mother'. He sent me love letters they'd exchanged, revealing aspects of my daughter I didn't suspect. To me she was mainly intellectual, a brain. But she was emotionally immature, very dependent and - I was embarrassed - very passionate sexually."

Austere yet full of lyrical flights of memory, interspersed with bulletins from her daughter's bedside, Paula has been seen as Allende's masterpiece and brought her a new readership. For her, "it saved my life". Yet she was unable to return to fiction, convinced "that the world had lost its colour and that a universal greyness had spread inexorably over every surface".

She also had an experience mirrored in Eliza's asexual disguise. "I turned 50 when Paula fell sick. Grief and menopause shut me down sexually and emotionally. I look at pictures and see I aged 10 years. I couldn't laugh. To me, sensuality is related to humour, and if I can't laugh, I can't make love. Maybe I felt that my daughter had all the right to be healthy and have sex. It was so hard to think of myself making love when she couldn't."

It took three years for her to emerge from a tunnel of mourning. A playful meditation on aphrodisiacs - the "bridge between gluttony and lust, interspersed with recipes" - it helped her return to life and to fiction, though she reflects: "I've changed because I have a sort of detachment now; I know how little I can control in my life or of others' safety and happiness, though to learn to love without trying to control the environment is hard."

Her husband's daughter from a previous marriage - she had been a drug addict - also died around the time of Paula's death, a double blow that threatened to push them apart. She says: "Till recently a husband to me was an addendum who didn't share anything important - my work, insecurities, grief. While some see her as having opened doors in the US for other Latina writers - Laura Esquival, Cristina García, Sandra Cisneros - Allende senses changes in her own fiction. "I speak less Spanish and my writing is becoming less baroque; I use fewer adjectives." Her mother, now 79, remains her editor, referring to her daughter's works as "ours", and rooting out the Spanglish words creeping into her prose ("Her first comments are horrible, very negative"). She lives in Chile where Allende often visits her. They have kept up an almost daily correspondence for 35 years. "She's becoming smarter with age. I can't imagine what it will be like without her."

Allende has now found a "sisterhood" in other US writers, such as Amy Tan, Barbara Kingsolver, Alice Walker and Louise Erdrich. At last, she says she feels settled. "It was hard the first time [in Venezuela] because we didn't have the right state of mind. We were always looking south and never quite unpacked; I never expected the dictatorship to last 17 years."

Since the amnesty of 1988, Allende has visited Chile often, where she is top of the bestseller lists, and says that even if Pinochet is freed by Britain after 15 months house arrest, and never faces trial, "justice has been done; he's a pariah and an embarrassment, even to the right" - though she adds with a shrewd stab of irony: "I only hope he doesn't make a miraculous recovery and go back to sitting in the senate."

She asks emotionally why his medical record should be kept secret when women raped under his regime were stripped of this privacy. Yet she also insists she no longer hates Pinochet. "I realised 20 years ago that hatred is a very heavy burden. I'd still fight for what's truthful, but this is not about him but about grief that needs to be acknowledged for true reconciliation to take place."

Her writing has sought to recover a place lost not only through exile but through childhood separation from Chile as a diplomat's daughter. "In Chile I realise I'm a foreigner, even though I understand the codes and can speak with my own accent, and it's very sad for me to confront that," Allende says. "I'm a foreigner in the US, too, and always will be. But my roots are more in my books now than in a place; my home will be in my writing."

Life at a glance: Isabel Allende

Born: August 8 1942, Lima, Peru.

Education: Schools in Chile; Bolivia and Lebanon.

Married: 1962-87 Miguel Frias (one son, one daughter); 1988 William Gordon.

Domicile: Went into exile in Caracas, Venezuela, after 1973 Chilean coup. Emigrated to California, USA, in 1987.

Employment: Journalist, Paula Magazine, Santiago, 1967-74; Mampato Magazine 1969-74; Channel 7 humorous programmes 1970-74; freelance, El Nacional, Caracas 1976-83. Administrator, Marrocco School, Caracas. 1979-83.

Publications: Fiction - The House Of The Spirits 1985; Of Love And Shadows 1987; Eva Luna 1988; The Stories Of Eva Luna 1991 (short stories); The Infinite Plan 1993; Daughter Of Fortune1999. Non-fiction - Paula 1995 (memoir); Aphrodite: A Memoir Of The Senses 1999.

 Daughter Of Fortune is published by Flamingo at £16.99.
fields.bodyText: Isabel Allende divides her life starkly into two: before and after the 1973 coup in Chile that brought General Augusto Pinochet to power and precipitated an exile from which she has never fully returned. "I never imagined such a thing was possible in Chile, which had such a solid, 160-year-old democracy - it was called the 'England' of Latin America," she says. "It was a revelation that there were concentration camps and torture centres all over the country. It had been there in the shadows, the brutality and violence, but for me, it was like waking into a nightmare." The military coup toppled her "uncle" - strictly, her second cousin - and godfather Salvador Allende, the world's first freely elected Marxist president, who committed suicide - or was murdered - in the burning presidential palace in Santiago. (That his daughter, now a Socialist politician, is also called Isabel still results in juxtaposed portraits in the British press, a confusion that the author, who sometimes fancies she was switched with another infant at birth, might relish.) Yet while her family, like a million other Chilean exiles, was scattered by the coup, she is convinced that had she not fled across the mountains, eventually making her way to Venezuela, where she stayed until 1987, she would not have become a writer. That vocation not only helped her break the junta's "chain of hatred" in her own soul, but later eased her recovery from the death, seven years ago, of her 28-year-old daughter Paula, who had lain comatose for 12 months with the rare genetic disorder, porphyria. For Allende, writing has in part been a tenacious reflex to loss, whether of exile or bereavement. Now 57, she wrote her first novel when she was almost 40, in Venezuela. The House Of The Spirits (1982), tracing four generations of Chilean women up to the aftermath of the coup, became an international bestseller. With its English translation in 1985, she became the first of many women writing in Latin America to join the fraternity enjoying worldwide acclaim since the so-called Latin literary boom of the 1960s and 70s - most notably the 1982 Nobel laureate Gabriel García Márquez, Carlos Fuentes and Mario Vargas Llosa. Her books - five novels, a collection of stories and two non-fiction works - have sold millions in 27 languages across the world. They have inspired plays and films, including, in 1993, Bille August's The House Of The Spirits, starring Jeremy Irons and Meryl Streep, and in 1994 Betty Kaplan's Of Love And Shadows, starring Antonio Banderas. There was even a musical in Iceland based on The House Of The Spirits. Her appeal to her compatriots lies partly in the Allende name and her vocal opposition to the junta. But the allure of her writing is far wider. Ilan Stavans, professor of Spanish at Amherst College in Massachusetts, says: "She came late to the banquet but achieved an international reputation that exceeded many men. She brings feelings to the fore in a way male writers don't, with a panoramic view of politics and history that illuminates the connection with individual lives." Yet her critical reception has been mixed. While Fay Weldon called The House Of The Spirits the "perfect novel - now that's written the rest of us can all go home", others lament that the early "spell" has been broken, complaining of shallow romance and potboilers, of sentiment that tips into sentimentality. Some bemoan a north American influence on her fiction since she moved to the United States in 1987. "There's an ambivalence towards her even among Latin American critics," Prof Stavans says. "She revived a tradition of melodrama and the light women's novel - la novela rosa , as serialised in newspapers across the Spanish-speaking world - and turned it around in a more sophisticated way to bring to mind 'magical realism'. She's called derivative by those who saw The House Of The Spirits as a revamp of [Márquez's] One Hundred Years Of Solitude from the point of view of women. But what infuriates them is the bridge she forms between popular culture and the highbrow, and that she's so successful." Alberto Manguel, who edited Other Fires, an anthology of work by Latin American women writers less fortunate in attracting English translators (for which Allende wrote a warm preface), says: "She is fascinated by melodrama, the romanticised, the sentimental. But she's much more interesting stylistically, and is able to tell these stories without forgetting political angles. She asserts the right of her women characters to live their own lives and speak in their own language - which can verge on purple prose, though there's no such thing in Spanish." Of her popularity in the English-speaking world, he adds: "Her fiction does correspond to the stereotypical vision of what Latin America might be: the passionate, dark-eyed heroine; the cool, male, governor - you are in the world of El Zorro. But that overlap is not a fault in the writing." Poised and very funny, though more serious in private, Allende appears to mirror her books' vivacious if volatile mix of hard realism and playfully-edged romanticism. She was shortlisted for the Literary Review's Bad Sex Award for Daughter Of Fortune, her first novel in eight years, and read out the "offending" passages at the Queen Elizabeth Hall in London during her recent visit - she hadn't been to Britain for a decade - with amusement and aplomb, her tone underlining their deflating irony. A California bookseller and friend, Elaine Petrocelli, calls her "very forthright and transparent. There aren't two Isabels; there's only one." But while Allende declares dramatically that all the women in her family run headlong after men - as she did in emigrating from Venezuela to California ("The second move was by choice; I fell in lust with a guy") - she has been adamant about earning her own living since she was 17. Set amid the Californian goldrush of the mid 19th century, its main characters are Chileans and Chinese who followed the trail for reasons of their own. Yet the lover whom the heroine Eliza follows from Chile fades from the plot, leaving only traces of a mythic Latino bandit. Eliza, disguised as a boy, grows too fond of her new-found liberty to relinquish it even for the most seductive man. "When Eliza is sleeping outdoors, surrounded by snakes, bears, Indians, bandits, for the first time in her life she's not afraid, not restrained in a corset," says Allende. "It's an epiphany I had: the self-sufficiency she has now she can't give up. I belonged to the first generation of organised feminists in Chile, though by no means the first - my grandmother struggled for the vote. In Daughter Of Fortune she explores people's impulse to reinvent themselves in a new land while tracing incipient hostilities between Yanquis and Latinos after the war in 1846-8 that forced Mexico to cede to the US territory where gold had been found only days before. "I'm an immigrant myself. I live in an area with a large immigrant population - though I'm privileged: I'm legal and speak some English; I'm married to an American and can support myself." While some see her as having opened doors in the US for other Latina writers - Laura Esquival, Cristina García, Sandra Cisneros - Allende senses changes in her own fiction. "I speak less Spanish and my writing is becoming less baroque; I use fewer adjectives." Her mother, now 79, remains her editor, referring to her daughter's works as "ours", and rooting out the Spanglish words creeping into her prose ("Her first comments are horrible, very negative"). She lives in Chile where Allende often visits her. They have kept up an almost daily correspondence for 35 years. "She's becoming smarter with age. I can't imagine what it will be like without her." Allende has now found a "sisterhood" in other US writers, such as Amy Tan, Barbara Kingsolver, Alice Walker and Louise Erdrich. At last, she says she feels settled. "It was hard the first time [in Venezuela] because we didn't have the right state of mind. We were always looking south and never quite unpacked; I never expected the dictatorship to last 17 years." Since the amnesty of 1988, Allende has visited Chile often, where she is top of the bestseller lists, and says that even if Pinochet is freed by Britain after 15 months house arrest, and never faces trial, "justice has been done; he's a pariah and an embarrassment, even to the right" - though she adds with a shrewd stab of irony: "I only hope he doesn't make a miraculous recovery and go back to sitting in the senate." She asks emotionally why his medical record should be kept secret when women raped under his regime were stripped of this privacy. Yet she also insists she no longer hates Pinochet. "I realised 20 years ago that hatred is a very heavy burden. I'd still fight for what's truthful, but this is not about him but about grief that needs to be acknowledged for true reconciliation to take place." Her writing has sought to recover a place lost not only through exile but through childhood separation from Chile as a diplomat's daughter. "In Chile I realise I'm a foreigner, even though I understand the codes and can speak with my own accent, and it's very sad for me to confront that," Allende says. "I'm a foreigner in the US, too, and always will be. But my roots are more in my books now than in a place; my home will be in my writing." Domicile: Went into exile in Caracas, Venezuela, after 1973 Chilean coup. Emigrated to California, USA, in 1987. Employment: Journalist, Paula Magazine, Santiago, 1967-74; Mampato Magazine 1969-74; Channel 7 humorous programmes 1970-74; freelance, El Nacional, Caracas 1976-83. Administrator, Marrocco School, Caracas. 1979-83. Publications: Fiction - The House Of The Spirits 1985; Of Love And Shadows 1987; Eva Luna 1988; The Stories Of Eva Luna 1991 (short stories); The Infinite Plan 1993; Daughter Of Fortune1999. Non-fiction - Paula 1995 (memoir); Aphrodite: A Memoir Of The Senses 1999.  Daughter Of Fortune is published by Flamingo at £16.99.

fields.headline: Grey days in west Wales
fields.standfirst:
Rural Britain is unconvinced by Mr Blair

Devolution in Wales: special report

Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's attempt to reassure rural Britain that things are not as bad as they seem has not played well in Devon and Cornwall, and its distant ripples certainly did not persuade voters in Ceredigion, the area around Aberystwyth in Wales, to renew their trust in Labour.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's attempt to reassure rural Britain that things are not as bad as they seem has not played well in Devon and Cornwall, and its distant ripples certainly did not persuade voters in Ceredigion, the area around Aberystwyth in Wales, to renew their trust in Labour.

In Thursday's byelection Plaid Cymru held the seat, though with a much reduced vote. The Liberal Democrats, who held the seat before Plaid took it over, finished second, with 85% of the vote they got in May 1997. The big losers were Labour, relegated from second to fourth, with fewer than four in 10 of the votes they won at the general election.

The turnout, though healthy compared to recent contests in England, was low by Welsh standards. It is not as if the arithmetic showed hordes of Labour voters bestowing their favours elsewhere. But the few reports of constituency opinion published outside Wales suggest a level of rural disaffection with Labour which needs to be taken seriously. This is one of the poorest counties in Wales, where many farmers are up against it and some have given up hope. Mr Blair allows that some farmers are in deep and genuine difficulty, and that the advantages rural dwellers enjoy over their rural counterparts, as claimed by Downing Street this week, do not apply everywhere. To people in parts of rural Britain who fall into the latter class, his message this week must have been deeply frustrating, like that of a man who says: yes, it is true, your house is on fire - but just look at that wonderful view of Helvellyn.

That is the rural factor. There is a Welsh factor too. Much of Wales, urban and rural alike, is growing aggrieved as it reads of a boom in the south-east of England which demands higher interest rates, while witnessing none of this boom itself. That south-east Wales, too, is benefiting from massive investment, if anything, makes things worse. The Labour leader of Blaenau Gwent council, in the industrial South Wales valleys, roundly denounced the government this week, saying it lacked the guts to combat the deprivation in his area. Alun Michael, the Welsh first minister, faces a no confidence motion on Tuesday arising from the government's failure to match European funds. Nationally, the polls still indicate that the country is happy with Labour, but increasingly, local suppurations suggest patches of strong dissent. Ceredigion, given an opening to express these feelings, has taken its chance.

webTitle: Jews outraged at plan to visit ruins of death camp

fields.headline: Jews outraged at plan to visit ruins of death camp
fields.standfirst:
Italy: Rabbi condemns rightwing stunt to boost Haider
The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Jörg Haider has thrown Italian politics into disarray and outraged Jews after apparently asking to pay homage at the ruins of a Nazi extermination camp in northern Italy.
fields.body:
Jörg Haider has thrown Italian politics into disarray and outraged Jews after apparently asking to pay homage at the ruins of a Nazi extermination camp in northern Italy.

The leader of Austria's far right Freedom party wants to offer an olive branch to opponents by acknowledging and apologising for Nazi crimes, said Roberto Antonione, an ally and president of Italy's Friuli-Venezia-Giulia region.

Mr Haider may travel this month to Risiera di San Sabba, where the Nazis murdered 5,000 people and disposed of their bodies in a crematorium.

"I see it as an important occasion, not only for relations with a good neighbour but as sending a conciliatory signal and a clear message of peace with the community of Friuli-Venezia-Giulia," Mr Haider wrote to Mr Antonione.

However, Umberto Piperno, the chief rabbi for Trieste, the region's capital, said the presence of a man who has praised the Waffen SS and Hitler's em ployment policies was unacceptable.

Mr Piperno denied reports that he had invited Mr Haider to visit the site. Local media had misquoted him and right-wing politicians had manipulated the confusion to entice Mr Haider, he said.

"What I said is that Haider should tell his supporters and the youth of Austria about Nazi crimes such as the ones committed at the extermination camp at the Risiera di San Sabba. I never said he should visit Trieste, and certainly not San Sabba, where his presence would be unacceptable."

An apology for war crimes would no longer be welcome, Mr Piperno said. "No, not now."

No confirmation of the visit has come from Mr Haider, but Mr Antonione insisted that the Freedom party leader had faxed a letter expressing a "sincere interest" in coming.

The controversy fuelled an increasingly bitter row in Italy about how to respond to the new Austrian government.

The centre-left government of the prime minister, Massimo D'Alema, has taken a hardline stance against Austria, but opposition groups have split.

Police broke up a protest in support of Mr Haider in front of Mr D'Alema's office in Rome on Thursday.

Silvio Berlusconi, the media magnate and leader of the centre-right opposition, has attempted to put clear blue water between himself and Mr Haider, who shares his hostility to immigration.

Mr Berlusconi has condemned Mr Haider but has been unable to control his fractious coalition's enthusiasm, especially that of the leader of the Northern League, Umberto Bossi. To Mr Berlusconi's mortification, senior members of his own Forza Italia party have joined the league in praising Mr Haider. So far he has resisted pressure to disown them.

There is a growing belief in Italy's German-speaking Alto Adige region that the European Union has bullied the Austrians for exercising their democratic right. Small rightwing parties in the region are euphoric. They are sure Mr Haider, who has made vague statements encouraging their separatist impulses, will emerge stronger.

The region has intermittently clashed with the Italian state on language and autonomy since being ceded from Austria in the treaty of Versailles after the first world war.

Even moderates within the German-speaking majority in the region have been angered by the EU's sanctions and threats. Mr Haider is no demon, they say.

fields.headline: Vienna warned to stay neutral
fields.standfirst:
Russia: Mild response betrays unease at west's stance
The Austrian far right in power: special report
Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Russia yesterday warned Austria against veering from neutrality. But with the Kremlin constantly telling the world to mind its own business over the war in Chechnya, and resentful of Nato flouting Yugoslav sovereignty in Kosovo, it was wary of being seen to interfere in Austria's domestic affairs.
fields.body:
Russia yesterday warned Austria against veering from neutrality. But with the Kremlin constantly telling the world to mind its own business over the war in Chechnya, and resentful of Nato flouting Yugoslav sovereignty in Kosovo, it was wary of being seen to interfere in Austria's domestic affairs.

"The Russian side hopes Austria will continue to contribute constructively to the development of good, neighbourly relations in Europe on the basis of its adherence to its policy of neutrality" - the condition for Russian troops' withdrawal in 1955 - the foreign ministry said.

Igor Ivanov, the foreign minister, discussed the Austrian crisis with the visiting French foreign minister, Hubert Vedrine, and said afterwards that "Russia sincerely trusts Austrian democracy and [the new Austrian chancellor] Wolfgang Schüssel personally."

The Russian foreign ministry statement was guarded: "We are closely following developments in Austria and take note of the assessment of a number of states about the possible consequences of the process of forming the new government."

The Russian media are presenting the European Union's pressure on Vienna as the logical follow-up to the war against Yugoslavia and western attempts to interfere in Chechnya. The newspaper Vremya-MN said: "No one is talking about bombing Vienna yet, but the precedent has been set for meddling in the internal affairs of Austria, an EU member and democratic state."

Non-interference in internal affairs of sovereign states is an article of faith for Russia's acting president, Vladimir Putin, who said yesterday that Russia could not but respond to "changes in Nato strategy". He said Nato had granted itself the right to act militarily outside its zone of operations without a UN mandate.

He was speaking at a session of Russia's national security council devoted to adopting a new military doctrine that is much more adversarial to the west than its 1993 antecedent. It dovetails with his recently approved national security strategy, which eases the conditions under which Russia would press the nuclear trigger.

fields.headline: Cut and thrust
fields.standfirst:
The David Irving libel trial: special report

David Irving V Penguin & Lipstadt
fields.trailText: Rampton: Mr Irving, you have made a suggestion to the effect that [SS officer Hans Almayer] gave a fallacious account because he was tortured or threatened with torture by the Brits. You have absolutely no basis for that whatsoever.
fields.body:
Rampton: Mr Irving, you have made a suggestion to the effect that [SS officer Hans Almayer] gave a fallacious account because he was tortured or threatened with torture by the Brits. You have absolutely no basis for that whatsoever.

Irving: Mr Rampton, when the time comes to cross-examine your expert witnesses, I shall be putting to them documents which show very clearly what methods were used to extract information from witnesses, including some of the most brutal and horrifying descriptions of what happened to the witnesses in the Malmedy trial. I shall invite them to state whether they consider this kind of evidence is dependable.

Rampton: Mr Irving, I am tempted myself to resort to such methods to get a straight answer to my question, I have to say. You have no evidential _

Irving: It included, for example, crushing the testicles of 165 out of 167 witnesses. Is that what you are proposing to do to me?

Rampton: We cannot fit that many witnesses into your witness box up there,

Mr Irving, I am afraid _

Rampton: Would you like a rest? You seem very énervé , if I can use the French word.

Irving: I can carry on if you can.

Mr Justice Gray: Mr Irving, it occurred to me actually whilst watching the film that you said you were up till four or five this morning. I am very concerned that it is a huge physical strain on you and I would be perfectly happy if you said you had had enough.

Irving: I can go as many rounds with Mr Rampton as he wishes.

Rampton: You do not have to worry going rounds with me, Mr Irving. I have been doing this for 35 years.

webTitle: Haider won votes but not hearts of electorate

fields.headline: Haider won votes but not hearts of electorate
fields.standfirst:
Many see the leader only as a thorn in flesh of corrupt system
The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: It is barely credible. The land of the Sound of Music has become a pariah state. How has it happened ?
fields.byline: John Hooper  and  Kate Connolly  in Vienna
fields.body:
It is barely credible. The land of the Sound of Music has become a pariah state. How has it happened ?

This is one view: "Austria is not just the country of the famous white Lipizzaner horses, Mozart, the Vienna boys' choir and cream cakes. Underneath the glossy surface lurk serious power politics fortified by intrigue, corruption and abuse of privilege ...

"The Second Republic has been characterised by the domination of two main political parties. On one hand the conservative People's party, known as the "blacks", and on the other the Socialist party, known as the "reds" ...

"Their influence has gone far beyond the government and has overshadowed the entire socio-economic fabric of Austria. Not only banks and insurance companies are red or black, but hospitals and even sports and automobile clubs. Party membership is astonishingly high, since the 'party book' is the passport to a job, a flat and promotion."

The writer is Jörg Haider, whose far-right Freedom party yesterday became the dominant partner in a coalition government with the "blacks" at the end of the most tumultous week in Austria's recent history. The passage comes from his book, The Freedom I Mean, published five years ago.

His success is in large part a product of dissatisfaction with cronyism and corruption among people who do not necessarily share his views on other questions. Pollsters estimate that half the people who gave him a 27% share of the vote in last October's general election were former supporters of the left.

"Roughly a third of Freedom party voters would not vote for Haider as chancellor," said Professor Wolfgang Bachmeyer of the OGM opinion research institute. "They want to keep him as a thorn in the flesh of the old system".

Mr Haider is a prankster as well as a populist. When he was campaigning against Austria's entry into the European Union, he held up a yoghurt pot in front of the television cameras and, grinning ear to ear, told viewers that joining the EU would mean letting Brussels put lice in their food. He was apparently referring to cochineal, which is made from the dried shells of certain South American bugs.

In one sense his rise to power is symptomatic of a wider phenomenon: the backlash against the dubious political carve-ups which were allowed to survive in the front line states of the cold war. It is what lies behind the crises in christian democracy, both that of today in Germany and that of the early 90s in Italy, which led to formation of a government including Gianfranco Fini's "post-fascists".

What a lot of Austrians want to know is why European governments, which did little more than tut-tut then are reacting with such draconian measures now. The answer they like most is that 8m Aus trian are easier to ignore than 58m Italians.

But there are other factors. Where Mr Fini's aim has been to make himself progressively more respectable, Mr Haider's aim remains the reverse.

He has even begun to scare some of his backers. The rise of the Freedom party owed a lot to support from the tabloid Kronen Zeitung, which reaches almost half the newspaper-reading public.

"Some of the older columnists lent him their support because he offered something new and they wanted to give him a chance. But he lost their support because he got too big for his boots," said Dieter Kindermann, the paper's political correspondent.

"Listen to Mr Haider railing in a beer tent," said Hans Rauscher, political columnist for the left-leaning daily Der Standard. "If a German politician said these things he would have gone by now. Here it is tolerated. It is even made light of."

Like Italy, Austria has never fully come to grips with its past. Just as Italians used the sacrifices of their partisans to create the myth of a country at odds with its leaders, so Austrians used the 1938 annexation by Germany to mould a legend of their own - that they were the victims and not the willing instruments of Nazi aggression.

The contemporary relevance of all this is now coming to the surface in the form of a socially tolerated dislike of immigrants.

"Xenophobia has grown in Austria rapidly in recent years, especially since the borders with the former communist countries have opened," said Prof Bachmeyer. "It results from the observation of just about everybody in this country, especially in the east, that the manpower coming in from the east is very tough price competition and, if not more skilled, then more motivated".

Yet as he readily acknowledges, Austria's economy is booming and unemployment is low. Indeed, some industries like tourism cannot find the labour they need.

But then irrational racism in central Europe is scarcely a preserve of the Austrians. And the EU's drastic reaction this week could belie the growing concern in other European capitals about the challenge to their values presented by the looming incorporation into the EU of the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland, where naked racism is rife.

What worries Prof Bachmeyer is whether the reaction will prove counter-productive. It threatens to undermine Austria's prosperity, thus sharpening the very anti-immigrant sentiment it was meant to reprove. What is more, his polls confirm that it has altered political sentiment in the way that yesterday's clashes and protests in Vienna seem to suggest.

The international pressure, Prof Bachmeyer said, "is creating two things: polarisation and solidarity within the polarised groups.

"The middle is shrinking and moving to the extremes, and that is the worst thing that can happen to a democracy."

What worries Prof Bachmeyer is whether the reaction will prove counter-productive. It threatens to undermine Austria's prosperity, thus sharpening the very anti-immigrant sentiment it was meant to reprove. What is more, his polls confirm that it has altered political sentiment in the way that yesterday's clashes and protests in Vienna seem to suggest. The international pressure, Prof Bachmeyer said, "is creating two things: polarisation and solidarity within the polarised groups. "The middle is shrinking and moving to the extremes, and that is the worst thing that can happen to a democracy."

fields.headline: Riots as Austria's crisis deepens
fields.standfirst:
Hard right takes power in Vienna to angry demonstrations
The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Austria's hard right coalition came to power yesterday amid violent protests in Vienna, as governments in several countries began to make good their threats of a boycott.
fields.byline: John Hooper and  Kate Connolly  in Vienna
fields.body:
Austria's hard right coalition came to power yesterday amid violent protests in Vienna, as governments in several countries began to make good their threats of a boycott.

Last night, police in riot gear clashed with protesters for the second time in hours. Twenty-five police were injured.

President Thomas Klestil appealed for calm in a country which has rarely seen such anger. He called on the world to "give the new government a chance and judge it by what it does". But he warned the chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel, and his coalition partner, the populist Freedom party leader Jörg Haider, that if it strayed from guidelines he had made it underwrite "it would have a serious impact at home and abroad".

The US joined European nations in limiting contact with the new administration, but the secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, said further judgement would be made "on deeds not words". Her colleague, the defence secretary, William Cohen, sounded a more ominous note. On a tour of Germany, he said the new government "might be a step back into a very dark past".

Mr Klestil delivered his warning after Mr Haider, who will hold the government's fate in his hands, had questioned the need for the commitment he and the new chancellor had signed. It pledged Austria to respect basic human rights and to re-examine its Nazi past. "It is an affront to the public that such matters of course have to be signed," Mr Haider said.

The high emotions were highlighted at a ceremony at which the outgoing Social Democrat chancellor bade farewell. Viktor Klima appeared to be on the verge of tears and several of his staff openly wept.

Outside the imperial palace, while ministers were taking their oaths of office, demonstrators were baton-charged. They later stormed the social affairs ministry, demanding to see the new Freedom party minister.

There was little evidence, however, that the more moderate elements in the government had grasped the reasons for the fury. The foreign minister, Benita Ferrero-Waldner, said: "There is nothing in Austria which justifies this, apart from a couple of unpleasant comments by Mr Haider."

Contrary to early reports that the Freedom party had secured most seats in cabinet, agriculture went to the conservatives, giving them an equal share . However, Mr Haider's supporters will control the key spending departments.

Mr Haider, who is not in the government but can bring it down when he likes, has praised Hitler's "orderly employment policies" and lauded Waffen SS veterans. He has since apologised for the remarks "which were attributed to me"; yesterday, though, he was in defiant mood. "I have no intention of wandering around world apologising for all kinds of things," he said.

The most extreme reprisal came from Israel, whose ambassador, Nathan Meron, left Austria yesterday on the orders of the prime minister, Ehud Barak. Finland suspended relations andBelgium put its ties on a lower footing. France's defence minister postponed a meeting with his Austrian counterpart and his depart ment struck the first economic blow by cancelling an order for six Austrian ambulances.

Austria's president meanwhile took every opportunity to stress his dismay. He barely looked at Mr Schüssel as he swore him in and kept eye contact with the new ministers to a minimum, giving the briefest of handshakes.

In a letter to the Los Angeles-based Simon Wiesenthal centre, which tracks down Nazi war criminals, Mr Klestil insisted he had no choice but to appoint the coalition, whose members had won a majority in the lower house.

Mr Haider said his party had achieved an historic change "despite the attempted influence from abroad and violence on the streets". He expected the protests to calm down soon.

webTitle: US joins campaign to isolate new leaders

fields.headline: US joins campaign to isolate new leaders
fields.standfirst:
Countries unite in pressure, amid unease at the prospect of a revival of fascism in Europe
The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: The United States yesterday joined the international outcry against Austria's new far right government, expressing disapproval by calling its ambassador back to Washington for consultations.
fields.body:
The United States yesterday joined the international outcry against Austria's new far right government, expressing disapproval by calling its ambassador back to Washington for consultations.

The secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, announcing that contacts with Vienna would be limited, said that there should be no place in a European government for a political party that "doesn't distance itself clearly from the atrocities of the Nazi era and the politics of hate".

Ms Albright said the US ambassador, Kathryn Hall, would register Washington's deep concern at the inclusion of six members of the far right Freedom party in the new coalition government. The ambassador would return to Vienna after consultations, she said.

General Wesley Clark, the supreme commander of Nato forces in Europe, scrapped plans to visit Austria. Although a spokesman claimed that his decision had nothing to do with recent events in Vienna, the message was clear.

Vienna has been plunged into isolation as governments around the world, alarmed at the prospect of a revival of fascism in Europe, announced immediate sanctions.

Israel, deeply offended by past comments by the Freedom party's leader, Jörg Haider, withdrew its ambassador. He was on a flight back to Tel Aviv even before the new government was sworn in.

"Israel cannot remain silent in the face of the rise of extremist rightwing parties, in particular in countries which played a role in events which brought about the eradication of a third of the Jewish people in the Holocaust," a government statement said.

EU members downgraded normal diplomatic contacts and will not support Austrian candidates for international posts. They will hold bilateral meetings only at a low level.

But there was much anguish about what exactly the right response was. The EU has been careful to limit bilateral relations while continuing to engage with Austria on multi lateral business. Even this, however, has its dangers. There is concern that outside hostility to Mr Haider might broaden his support at home. There are also fears that Austria in turn might disrupt discussions or block EU decisions in sensitive areas where unanimity is required.

Franz Fischler, the Austrian commissioner for agriculture, said in a poignant personal statement that he shared the EU's concerns about the situation, but added: "It is not the commission's place to isolate a member country. On the contrary, our duty is to prevent my country cutting itself adrift from the rest of Europe. That is why the commission must, and will, maintain its working relationship with Austria."

Within the EU, some countries went beyond the bounds of the basic sanctions. In Belgium, the defence ministry cancelled a £600,000 order for ambulances from an Austrian firm. Schools cancelled ski trips to Austria's alpine resorts and the authorities in Liège refused to lend a Gauguin painting to an Austrian museum.

Guy Verhofstadt, the Belgian prime minister, said more action should be taken, "but we want to do it together with our European partners".

In Germany, the foreign minster, Joschka Fischer, told journalists that "forces hostile to Europe and to foreigners," were now part of the government in Austria. However, an opinion poll this week found that 79% of Germans were opposed to the sanctions.

Britain's foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said sanctions would be applied at once, despite Thursday's pledge by the Freedom party and the Austrian chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel's conservative People's party to respect democracy and EU values. They would be judged, he said, on whether they fulfilled that commitment.

And there was a powerful, if general, message of support from Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy supremo, speaking on the issue for the first time. "Europe has given a very good example of how there can be no compromise over its principles and values," he said.

fields.headline: Riots as Freedom triumphs reign
fields.standfirst:
Austrians from all walks of life rail against new coalition
The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: The Angelus bells chiming throughout Vienna at midday yesterday were drowned out by the screams and whistles of the thousands of demonstrators who gathered in front of Vienna's imperial palace in an angry and violent protest against Austria's new government.
fields.body:
The Angelus bells chiming throughout Vienna at midday yesterday were drowned out by the screams and whistles of the thousands of demonstrators who gathered in front of Vienna's imperial palace in an angry and violent protest against Austria's new government.

In the red room of the palace, President Thomas Klestil was swearing in the administration - a coalition of the far-right and conservatives - in a ceremony that took place behind closed doors.

"He doesn't want it to turn into an international affair," one of his aides revealed.

Outside at the strike of 12, demonstrators from a cross-section of society banged pot lids together, blew whistles and jangled keys. The demonstration took place just yards from Helden Square where in 1938 Hitler addressed 250,000 Viennese after the Anschluss, or annexation, of Austria to Germany.

Some demonstrators yesterday held banners reading: "1938 reasons to be against Haider", and "Time to Stand Up". Others had banners bearing yellow Stars of David, symbols of Judaism.

Margarete Gal, 76, said she was shocked by the recent changes in Austria. "Now I feel frightened, but I'm trying not to be. We need to fight this neo-fascism and stand up against it. There's no room for fear."

The retired nursery school teacher recalled standing on Helden Square more than six decades ago as Hitler's troops marched in. Her parents handed out leaflets against the Anschluss. Her father, a Spanish Jew, later spent four years in Auschwitz.

"This is a different time, but a similar tendency is there," she said. "[Freedom party leader Jörg] Haider is not as dangerous as Hitler, although his parents were Nazis and the social minister he's chosen comes from the town of Braunau [Hitler's birthplace], so we can't be too careful."

Wolfgang Reder, a 53-year-old gay architect, was holding a rainbow flag and said he feared that gay rights would suffer under the new government. "My father was a Nazi and he destroyed my family," he said. "I have a good reason to be here today."

His friends, 30-year-old Ingo Kruegler, a costume designer, and 31-year-old Wolfgang Kimmel, a former spokesman for the Liberal party until it lost its parliamentary seats in last October's election, said the atmosphere in Vienna was tense. They both said they were stunned that Mr Haider had reached power.

They also expressed their concerns at moves to curb the freedom and diversity of the Austrian media, which they said had already begun.

Hundreds of police in riot gear were bussed in as protesters attempted to break through the security barrier outside the meeting. Truncheons were used against the crowd as they threw blue paint (the colour of Haider's Freedom party), stones, eggs and fruit at police officers. Black flags hung from the trees and many of the protesters were dressed in black from head to toe.

Fire engines arrived after some protesters were spotted with petrol bombs. A senior police officer said that the protests had become more aggressive in the past few days. Two police officers had been injured by flying glass, he said.

Traditionally, when an Austrian government is sworn in, the new chancellor and cabinet walk the short distance from the imperial palace to the chancellery for their first cabinet meeting. But yesterday, Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel and and his government took the rarely used underground passageways instead, in order to avoid the angry crowds.

Inside the chancellery, they posed for a group photograph in the congress chamber. Aides closed the windows and pulled down the green blinds to block out the protest going on below the window.

Mr Haider was noticeable for his absence. The Freedom party leader, who has chosen not to take a place in the cabinet, had returned to the southern province of Carinthia where he is governor.

Later, the new cabinet, the mean age of which is lower than any other in Austrian history, gathered round a green felt table under a picture of a youthful-looking Emperor Franz Josef. A planned press conference was replaced instead by a short statement delivered by Mr Schüssel.

"We know that we will be observed closely," he said. "But we kindly ask you to judge us based on what we do. Austria needs a competent government."

Outside, women's groups were also present in significant numbers. Irine, a 46-year-old single mother, said the entry of the Freedom party into government was "a catastrophe for Austria, especially for women. Haider wants women back in the kitchen so that he can reduce the unemployment rate," she said.

She and her fellow protesters later marched on from Ballhaus Square and over the Ring road, storming the offices of the ministry for social affairs on the Stubenring.

Violent clashes broke out be tween civil servants and demonstrators.

Representatives from the teaching profession turned out to protest against the government's plan to reduce the numbers of foreign children in the classroom to a maximum of 33%. "This is severely racist," said 34-year-old Lotte Kreissler, an English teacher at an evening school. "What about the children who were born here and speak German perfectly, even though they don't have citizenship?"

Members of the youth wing of the Social Democratic party (SJ) said that the new changes had polarised Austria, but that they would also give their movement a much-needed boost. "The people will bring the conservatives and Freedom party government to its knees," said Robert Pichler, the SJ's head. "Schüssel should enjoy every single day he spends in office because there won't be many of them."

fields.headline: Oxygen pumps up to £240m
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: BSkyB's managing director, Elizabeth Murdoch, and Manchester United's chief executive, Martin Edwards, head a list of nine individuals who were last night celebrating making paper millions from the first day of trading in the shares of internet incubator fund Oxygen Holdings.
fields.body:
BSkyB's managing director, Elizabeth Murdoch, and Manchester United's chief executive, Martin Edwards, head a list of nine individuals who were last night celebrating making paper millions from the first day of trading in the shares of internet incubator fund Oxygen Holdings.

Shares in Oxygen soared to 65p by mid-morning yesterday, a 3,250% increase on the 2p placement price. It valued the Aim-listed company at around £240m. The shares eventually closed at 57.5p.

Oxygen aims to invest in early stage internet companies. So far it has spent around £1m on stakeholdings in five start-ups, investing around £200,000 each time.

The jump in the share price was driven by strong demand among private investors desperate to buy the very small amount of stock Oxygen made available to outside parties.

By the end of trading Ms Murdoch, daughter of News Corporation owner Rupert Murdoch and a member of Oxygen's investment committee, found the 3m share options she has been granted notionally worth £1.7m.

However, she is unable to exercise her options for at least three years. Mr Edwards' 3.7% stake was worth £8m.

Oxygen is chaired by Michael Edelson and advisers to the company said the performance of Mr Edelson's last vehicle, Knutsford, had partly prompted the dash for shares.

Knutsford made stock market news last year when Archie Norman, Nigel Wray, Julian Richer and Nick Leslau announced they were going to use it as a base from which to bid for a large retail company.

The shares soared from 5p to 240p on the news but have since slipped back to 140p after a failed takeover bid and negative comment.

A spokesman for Oxygen said: "The company is obviously delighted by today's performance but it hasn't affected in any way what they intend to do or the amount of money available to them."

She added that dozens of students drop out of university each year to run businesses, and Oxygen's aim was to provide them with the capital and expertise to allow them to complete their studies.

The Edelson family were the largest beneficiaries of yesterday's rise, with the combined holdings of Mr Edelson and his two daughters Emma, 26, and Laura, 22, worth £39m. Emma, a Cambridge graduate, is to co-ordinate Oxygen's attempts to search out investments from campuses across the country.

She and three colleagues, all 26 or under, will submit the best ideas to the investment committee and Oxygen's other directors Keith Harris and Matthew Freud.

Mr Freud, Ms Murdoch's partner and a PR executive who acts for singer Geri Halliwell, has shares in Oxygen worth £11m while former corporate financier Mr Harris has the largest individual stake of £22m. Former footballers Alan Hansen and Steve Bruce are also stock owners. Three other investors also found their stakes worth over £1m.

fields.headline: The 'dishonest, reprehensible' fall of Archer
fields.standfirst: The fall of Archer: special reportTories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The following is an edited version of the report by the Conservative ethics and integrity committee which last night led to Lord Archer's suspension from the party for five years
fields.body:
The following is an edited version of the report by the Conservative ethics and integrity committee which last night led to Lord Archer's suspension from the party for five years

1. On November 22 1999 the party leader William Hague referred to the committee the complaint that Lord Archer had brought the party into disrepute.

The complaint was based on the assurance given by Lord Archer to the party chairman on June 22 1999 that there were "no new, substantial and damaging allegations" which could be made against him which would merit referral to the committee.

2. The committee was asked to consider Lord Archer's apparent admission that he had fabricated a false alibi for possible use in court: the evidence provided by Ted Francis in the form of a letter to Lord Archer's solicitors for possible use in Lord Archer's libel action against the Daily Star in 1987.

3. The context in which the reference was made by the leader is the resignation of Lord Archer as the party's mayoral candidate on November 18 1999.

4. The ethics and integrity committee has concluded:

(1) Lord Archer has engaged in conduct which brought the party into disrepute.

(2) The appropriate sanction which should be imposed is expulsion from the party for five years.

In reaching these conclusions the committee has take into account the evidence which Lord Archer gave and the submissions made on his behalf.

On January 28 2000 the committee invited representations from Lord Archer's legal advisers. These were received on February 1 2000.

The committee has carefully considered these representations, but does not consider that there is any basis for changing its conclusions.

5. Since Lord Archer has admitted to the committee that he did procure the fabrication of a false alibi by Mr Ted Francis, that particular issue, namely, whether Lord Archer "apparently" fabricated a false alibi has been resolved.

6. The significance to the committee of this admission was its timing, and the weight to be given to the submission made by Lord Archer's legal advisers, that conduct which occurred so long ago was stale and should not be entertained by the committee under its own rules of procedure.

7. First, timing. The admission which was made by Lord Archer was made in November 1999. It was not prompted by any pang of conscience, but by the prospect of his imminent disgrace by the public disclosure of conduct which had never before been revealed.

But for the assurance that he gave, he would not have passed the particular vetting stage which ultimately led to his selection.

8. Secondly, the submission that the conduct complained of was too old or stale. The critical difference to be drawn is between conduct which has been in the public domain and conduct which has not.

The fabrication of a false alibi was conduct which had been concealed by Lord Archer. It had not been in the public domain. It consequently was not conduct which was stale or old.

9. The conduct which Lord Archer had engaged in was conduct which, once revealed, was new and damaging to the party. It was not conduct which could be dismissed merely because it was stale.

The critical point, overlooked by Lord Archer's advisers, is that conduct whenever engaged in, which has been concealed, becomes new conduct when revealed publicly. It is the element of concealment which also makes what Lord Archer had done in order to promote his personal ambitions the more reprehensible.

10. On June 22 1999 Lord Archer assured the party chairman that no new, substantial and damaging allegations could be made against him which would merit referral to the committee.

11. The committee is satisfied that the categoric assur ance given by Lord Archer to the party chairman was untrue. The committee is also satisfied that Lord Archer knew or must have known when he gave the categoric assurance which he did, that if it was disclosed the party would be brought into disrepute.

12. The fabrication of a false alibi for possible use in court was conduct engaged in by Lord Archer, which was dishonest and disreputable and would be regarded as such by the party. It would be so regarded by any right-minded person. It is immaterial that the evidence was not used.

13. The committee notes that Lord Archer, on November 4 1999, when he was alerted by Mr Ted Francis to the possibility that his conduct would be made public, did not make a clean breast of it.

Instead he took steps to ensure that this would remain hidden. He only resigned on November 19 1999 when he knew that disclosure was inevitable.

14. The committee is in no doubt that the revelation that Lord Archer had procured the fabrication of a false alibi, his admission that he had done so and his resignation as the party's mayoral candidate brought the party into disrepute.

15. On November 4, 9 and 12 1999 there were a number of conversations between Lord Archer and Mr Ted Francis on the subject of the false alibi. The transcripts of those conversations, which were published in the News of the World on November 28 1999, were accepted by Lord Archer as an accurate record of what was said.

Lord Archer revealed, in the committee's view, a vivid recollection of those events. The fabrication of false evidence would not be a matter which an ordinary man would be likely to forget.

Lord Archer proved to be no exception, although he sought to deny any recollection of what he had done when he gave his assurance to the party chairman on 22 June 1999 that he had nothing to hide.

16. The principal explanation proffered by Lord Archer for the fabrication of a false alibi was to protect the identity of a lady companion. On behalf of Lord Archer it was suggested that while this conduct was not excusable, it was understandable because of the intrusion by the press into every aspect of Lord Archer's life. This was not accepted by the committee.

17. The matters which were urged on the committee on behalf of Lord Archer as ameliorating the consequences of his conduct to the party served merely to emphasise the prominence which Lord Archer had achieved in the party and, consequently, to highlight the extent to which Lord Archer had brought the party into disrepute.

18. The committee has had in mind the principle of proportionality, namely that in the exercise of its powers, the committee should reflect the nature and blameworthiness of the conduct which brought the party into disrepute by imposing appropriate sanction.

The committee had taken full account of all the matters which have been urged on it on Lord Archer's behalf. But for Lord Archer's long record of service, the committee would have been prepared to impose a longer period of expulsion.

The determination of the committee, having addressed the leader's reference dated November 22 1999, is that Lord Archer did engage in conduct which brought the party into disrepute and that he should be expelled from the party for five years.

webTitle: Tories ban Archer for five years

fields.headline: Tories ban Archer for five years
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special reportThe fall of Archer: special report
fields.trailText: Jeffrey Archer was expelled from the Conservative party for five years last night after an internal investigation found that he not only concealed a fake libel alibi for 13 years but continued to cover it up for 15 crucial days when the truth finally emerged last November.
fields.body:
Jeffrey Archer was expelled from the Conservative party for five years last night after an internal investigation found that he not only concealed a fake libel alibi for 13 years but continued to cover it up for 15 crucial days when the truth finally emerged last November.

Lord Archer's failure to disclose that he had asked a friend to lie for him ahead of his 1987 Daily Star libel case - in which he won £500,000 - was unequivocally condemned for bringing his party into "disrepute" by the Tory ethics committee appointed by William Hague to clean up sleaze in the party ranks.

Despite the severity of the report's language, some Tory eyebrows were raised last night over the limited sentence. The committee, chaired by a QC, announced that the long-threatened expulsion of the 59-year-old former mayoral candidate and former deputy chairman of the party would only be for five years - not life - because of his "long and energetic service".

He has long been its most popular fund-raiser, whose talents may be needed again, a factor which MPs admitted. Lord Archer himself admitted the facts but may still appeal on the grounds that he never used the fake alibi or that he had faced a "kangaroo court" - a claim Hague aides deny.

Last night, in a statement, Lord Archer, a member of the Conservative party for 35 years, said: "I am naturally disappointed with the committee's decision, which I consider to be grossly unfair. I shall be consulting my advisers early next week as to whether or not to appeal."

The cabinet office minister, Ian McCartney, expressed astonishment that Lord Archer will be "entitled to make another comeback" in five years. "This sorry saga is more proof of William Hague's poor judgment and weak leadership."

In its damning report, issued after MPs were safely away from Westminster for the weekend, the four-person committee rejected Lord Archer's excuse for not revealing the alibi he concocted in 1987 because it was "stale".

But it also accused him of trying to conceal the truth even when the person who he had asked to give him the alibi, the writer Ted Francis, started to spill the beans on November 4 last year.

"The fabrication of false evidence would not be a matter that any ordinary man would be likely to forget," says the report. It was itself "dishonest and disreputable" conduct.

"The admission which was made by Lord Archer [on November 19 1999] ... was not prompted by any pang of conscience, but by the prospect of his imminent disgrace by the public disclosure of conduct which had never before been revealed," the committee's five-page report stated.

He had been asked in an interview with party chairman, Michael Ancram MP, on June 22 whether there were any more skeletons in his cupboard. "But for the assurance that he gave, he would not have passed the particular vetting stage which ultimately led to his selection," says the report.

It is particularly hard on the excuse which Lord Archer and his lawyers gave the committee of two grandees and two barristers - under Elizabeth Appleby QC - last month. "It was not conduct which could be dismissed, as his legal advisers sought to do, merely because it was old and stale.

The critical point, overlooked by Lord Archer's advisers, is that conduct whenever engaged in, which has been concealed, becomes new conduct when discovered and revealed publicly.

"It is the element of concealment which also makes what Lord Archer had done in order to promote his personal ambitions more reprehensible," the committee concluded.

One of the members of the ethics and integrity committee which sat in judgment, Sir Archie Hamilton, MP for Epsom and Ewell and chairman of the Tory backbench 1922 committee, last night paid tribute to the peer's "tireless" campaigning and fund-raising.

"I think we had to take a balanced judgment. And it would I think have been more than five years if we hadn't taken into account the amazing contribution Jeffrey Archer has actually made to the Tory party," he said.

The report makes no such reference to Lord Archer's previous form as a man prone to high risk and what his wife, Mary, once called "inaccurate precis." He was forced to resign as an MP in 1974 over a near bankruptcy, and as party deputy chairman over the Star's claims that he the paid off a prostitute, Monica Coughlan. He was also accused of insider trading over Anglia TV shares.

Last night's report was produced independently of Mr Hague, who did not know Lord Archer had even been interviewed. "It proves William will not tolerate sleaze," said a spokesman. Mr Ancram said: "I am grateful to the committee for their determination and the way they have conducted this referral."
