fields.headline: Now Vodafone wants net alliances
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Chris Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, is planning a series of new alliances with American and European internet and data services providers after sealing the 181bn euro (£110bn) merger with Mannesmann to create the world's largest telecom company.
fields.body:
Chris Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, is planning a series of new alliances with American and European internet and data services providers after sealing the 181bn euro (£110bn) merger with Mannesmann to create the world's largest telecom company.

The world's biggest corporate deal, creating a group worth £225bn, yesterday unleashed a wave of buying into European telecoms as investors bet on a wholesale shake-up of the corporate landscape as a result of the deal. Germany's Dax index rose to a record high, with Deutsche Telekom and Siemens reaching their own highs - a trend echoed elsewhere on the continent.

Mr Gent, buoyed by endorsements from both Tony Blair and Gerhard Schröder, the German chancellor, who clashed at the outset of Vodafone's hostile bid, set out the enlarged group's stall as "the partner of choice" throughout the world.

He hopes by the middle of next week to declare unconditional the offer - approved belatedly by Mannesmann's supervisory board yesterday - of 58.96 Vodafone shares for every Mannesmann share, giving the German company 49.5% of the combined group.

He said in a London conference call that, by agreeing to demerge or even sell off Orange, Vodafone hoped to get swift regulatory approval for the friendly merger by early next month at the latest.

Mr Gent insisted that the enlarged group, to be known as Vodafone AirTouch, would not pose a serious competition issue given the presence of Deutsche Telekom, France Telecom, BT and other mobile operators.

But German sources, still smarting from Mannesmann's loss of independence, questioned whether Brussels would simply give approval without launching a full-scale investigation lasting up to four months - given the repeated references to dominance.

A few analysts also questioned whether Vodafone had paid over the odds to secure a European partner for its global ambitions, with aides of Klaus Esser, Mannesmann's chief executive, pointing out that he had forced up the price from 155 euro in October to Vodafone's effective offer of 353 euro.

"That's three euros more than the 350 euros Klaus put as the value of the group, a statement that brought him ridicule as a man off his head," a source said. "And he's got a company worth 30% less than Vodafone owning nearly half the new group."

Mr Gent paid handsome tribute to his opponent, not least for his sense of humour. "There should be smiles in Germany given the tremendous shareholder value created, not least by Klaus Esser in the robust defence of his own company. Our discussions were always professional and courteous."

But Mr Esser, who is to become a non-executive deputy chairman after overseeing the £2.5bn float of Mannesmann's engineering and automotive unit in late June, is increasingly seen in his homeland as the man who sold out corporate Germany to Anglo-Saxon capitalism. It emerged clearly yesterday that Mr Esser, who is likely to seek new pastures, lost the battle for independence when he failed to cement a planned 60-40 merger with French media group Vivendi, which backed Vodafone instead.

Mr Gent and his advisers believe the turning point came, however, when Hutchison Whampoa, led by flamboyant Li Ka-shing, began to vote its 11% stake in the Mannesmann group towards Vodafone. "The unequivocal message from shareholders was that, however good the Mannesmann team, the business would be better with us," said Mr Gent.

Disputing this, Mannesmann insiders said British institutions in particular simply had "an unquestioning love affair with the notion that bigger is better and global is the only way". Mr Esser blamed speculative moves by arbitrageurs.

Mr Gent, who signed off on the deal in Düsseldorf on Thursday after a last-minute impasse had threatened it, said he now hoped for a swift integration of Mannesmann's business and personnel within the wider group's operations.

webTitle: Hopes of net buying boom discounted

fields.headline: Hopes of net buying boom discounted
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Hopes of an imminent boom in e-commerce were discouraged yesterday by a big survey which found that seasoned surfers have no plans to buy more electronically.
fields.body:
Hopes of an imminent boom in e-commerce were discouraged yesterday by a big survey which found that seasoned surfers have no plans to buy more electronically.

The survey - of more than 38,000 British internet users - says most expect to increase their spending "slightly or not at all" in the next six months.

The Bookseller magazine, which commissioned it, concludes that "internet shopping is not about to enter a period of rapid growth among those already familiar with the web".

The study is based on questionnaires advertised on search engines and popular websites. Some 30% had bought goods on the net. Books were their most popular buys, followed by CDs and computer software. They made 15% of their book purchases on the net in the past year.

Amazon.co.uk had a big lead over its bookselling rivals, with 56% of sales. Its US parent company Amazon.com held second place. Its nearest UK rival, launched last year by the German group Bertelsmann, had only 9%, with WH Smith at 5%, Waterstone at 2% and Blackwell at 1%.

An earlier report, by Verdict Research, forecast that internet book sales could rise to 15% of the market. They now stand at 3%.

webTitle: Dome chiefs predict late surge after slow start

fields.headline: Dome chiefs predict late surge after slow start
fields.standfirst: The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: Ticket sales for the Dome during the first month fell far below break-even levels, the organisers admitted yesterday, with only half the expected number of visitors attending.
fields.body:
Ticket sales for the Dome during the first month fell far below break-even levels, the organisers admitted yesterday, with only half the expected number of visitors attending.

The disclosure prompted calls from opposition MPs for a Commons debate on the running of the troubled attraction. The Liberal Democrat spokesman, Norman Baker, demanded immediate action "to prevent this turning into a complete white elephant".

The attack came as an extra £60m of lottery money was pumped into the New Millennium Experience Company, to solve its cash flow problems after three of the main sponsors - Sky, Boots and Mars - refused to sign their contracts for what are claimed to be "minor technical and legal reasons". Advance ticket sales are also sluggish.

Although the Dome's bosses claimed there was no crisis, they appeared to backtrack on previous attendance targets, saying that 10m visitors, and not 12m as originally thought, were needed to break even.

But David Faber, a Conservative member of the Commons culture select committee, which will investigate the Dome later this year, said they had "simply switched the goalposts".

An average of 11,820 people a day visited the Dome in January, less than a third of its capacity. But the managing director, Liam Kane, insisted the figures were "pretty good" and that "any leisure attraction in the UK would cut off its right hand" for that kind of turnout in its first month. "We always knew it would be slow to begin with. But we are beginning to see a build-up of momentum. The dome is like a supertanker revving up. We are expecting numbers to pick up very quickly from April to September, with a very strong drive in the last quarter."

A Mori poll, commissioned for the New Millennium Experience Company, showed four out of five visitors to the dome were satisfied by their day.

fields.bodyText: Ticket sales for the Dome during the first month fell far below break-even levels, the organisers admitted yesterday, with only half the expected number of visitors attending. The disclosure prompted calls from opposition MPs for a Commons debate on the running of the troubled attraction. The Liberal Democrat spokesman, Norman Baker, demanded immediate action "to prevent this turning into a complete white elephant". The attack came as an extra £60m of lottery money was pumped into the New Millennium Experience Company, to solve its cash flow problems after three of the main sponsors - Sky, Boots and Mars - refused to sign their contracts for what are claimed to be "minor technical and legal reasons". Advance ticket sales are also sluggish. Although the Dome's bosses claimed there was no crisis, they appeared to backtrack on previous attendance targets, saying that 10m visitors, and not 12m as originally thought, were needed to break even. But David Faber, a Conservative member of the Commons culture select committee, which will investigate the Dome later this year, said they had "simply switched the goalposts". An average of 11,820 people a day visited the Dome in January, less than a third of its capacity. But the managing director, Liam Kane, insisted the figures were "pretty good" and that "any leisure attraction in the UK would cut off its right hand" for that kind of turnout in its first month. "We always knew it would be slow to begin with. But we are beginning to see a build-up of momentum. The dome is like a supertanker revving up. We are expecting numbers to pick up very quickly from April to September, with a very strong drive in the last quarter." A Mori poll, commissioned for the New Millennium Experience Company, showed four out of five visitors to the dome were satisfied by their day. webTitle: Carnage on the road out of Grozny

fields.headline: Carnage on the road out of Grozny
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Tears fell from the Chechen fighter's eyes as he remembered escaping from a Russian minefield by walking on the bodies of friends.
fields.body:
Tears fell from the Chechen fighter's eyes as he remembered escaping from a Russian minefield by walking on the bodies of friends.

His hands shaking with grief, Umar Tashayev was unable to talk, instead writing on a scrap of paper about what happened when a rebel column blundered into the minefield as it tried to escape from Grozny this week after months of fighting in the Chechen capital.

"I saw dreadful things during fighting in Grozny, but that massacre was beyond comparison," he wrote of Monday's breakout of some 2,000 rebels from Grozny.

Khamzat Tisayev, wounded in the foot, said some fighters sacrificed themselves to clear a path, running ahead to deliberately set off mines. "The boys marched on mines and shouted to us: 'Meet you in paradise!'"

The carnage, which left some 600, including several prominent warlords, dead or badly wounded, was the bloodiest loss for the rebels since Russian forces moved into Chechnya in September.

The Russians claim they lured the rebels into a trap by pretending to sell them safe passage out of Grozny for $100,000, and finished most of them off with artillery barrages.

The limited rebel escape was a setback for the Russian military, who had based their strategy on wiping out the insurgents in Grozny and ending the war. The remaining rebels are determined to fight on.

Before venturing out of Grozny, rebel commanders sent a party ahead. It never returned, but Aslanbek Ismailov, who was in charge of Grozny defences, decided to leave anyway. He and other leaders decided to lead the column.

Lyoma Dadayev, a fighter who survived the march, said one commander, Shamil Basayev, turned to his men and said: "Women often tell us, 'You let our sons be killed while you stay alive.' Well, we shall go first."

Ismailov died in the first explosions.

After the first mines exploded, Russian artillery shells and rockets screamed into the rebel column, killing scores. The rebels pressed on, leaving their dead and wounded behind, contrary to custom. Some still shudder at the memory.

"I was pulling my comrade on a sledge, and then was hit in my leg by a fragment," Mr Dadayev said. "I had to leave him behind, because otherwise I would have died too."

Mr Tashayev wrote: "Our wounded comrades pleaded with us not to leave them, but we had to keep going."

It was late on Monday morning when rebels, clad in winter camouflage, reached Alkhan-Kala, south-west of Grozny.

They laid scores of wounded on the snow near the hospital, which was too small to take all the casualties. The hospital had no water or heat and very little medicine or medical instruments.

Baiyev, the hospital chief, conducted amputations with a hacksaw and no painkillers or antiseptics.

Villagers quickly took most of the wounded to their homes, where the fighters lay without any medicine to ease the pain of their wounds. A smell of rotting flesh filled a room in house where two rebels were lying, their feet amputated.

"These people don't know that they have gangrene and are doomed," Dr Malika Sabiyeva whispered, turning away from the wounded men. "We don't know what to do, we have nothing to help them."

webTitle: Nurse critically ill after hospital attack

fields.headline: Nurse critically ill after hospital attack
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: A nurse was in a critical condition last night after being attacked in the grounds of the Bristol hospital where she works.
fields.body:
A nurse was in a critical condition last night after being attacked in the grounds of the Bristol hospital where she works.

The assault, which has left the woman in intensive care with serious head injuries, stunned staff at Southmead hospital, where managers yesterday promised an immediate review of security.

Two security guards, who chased the woman's attacker after a hospital porter heard her screams, suffered facial injuries as they struggled to detain the man.

The 39-year-old mother of three was assaulted shortly before 6.30am after leaving her car in a hospital car park before starting her shift.

The woman, a senior healthcare assistant who has worked at the hospital for about 10 years, was last night taken off a ventilator, but was still critical. She has not been named at the request of her family.

As police cordoned off the area, hospital managers pledged to increase security for the 2,500 nursing staff at the 1,000-bed NHS hospital.

"We take security very seriously and we will be increasing it further," Julie Burgess, director of nursing at North Bristol NHS trust, said.

Ms Burgess said that although the hospital had not experienced such a serious incident for about 10 years, the attack was a reflection of life in the health service where vio lence against staff seemed to be on the increase.

Nursing staff were stunned by the attack and reluctant to talk.

One nurse who had worked with the victim said although such attacks were not a general problem they had taken place before. "There are a lot of very unhappy nurses around."

A radiographer who asked not to be named said staff were very upset by the assault.

"Security here is not good enough. It's all very well to say that they are going to tighten it but it does not make me feel any safer."

Police were yesterday questioning a 20-year-old Southmead man about the assault. Ms Burgess said it was not known whether the attacker was known to the nurse, but he was not believed to be a current in-patient.

Jill Rhys Jones, steward for the public services union Unison at Southmead, said security at the hospital had improved considerably since five years ago. But it was still not as good as it could be. "Anyone who works in the health service knows that staff are at risk from patients, relatives and people who have had too much to drink. It can be a violent place to work. The mood among staff is sombre."

Hospital officials praised the two security guards who struggled with the attacker for three minutes until police arrived.

A GP stabbed by a patient in his surgery during an argument over medication was "comfortable" in hospital last night.

The attack on Ian Brooman, 52, led Michael Fallon, Tory MP for Sevenoaks, to call for more security for public servants.

Two fellow doctors came to Dr Brooman's aid when the patient stabbed him in the back at his Swanley surgery on Thursday afternoon.

Detective Chief Inspector Stella Mercer, leading the investigation, said, "If it was not for swift medical intervention by his colleagues, then Dr Brooman's injuries could have been far worse."

He was assaulted by a patient after refusing to prescribe extra medication. Police arrested a man at the surgery, which Dr Brooman, a Territorial Army commanding officer, runs with five partners. Matthew Richards, 29, of Swanley, was charged with attempted murder and is due to appear at Maidstone magistrates court today .

fields.headline: Finger wagging
fields.standfirst: "It's like the whole world, led by the media, has become one big interfering mother-in-law, forever coming forward, putting their oar in"
fields.trailText: "It's like the whole world, led by the media, has become one big interfering mother-in-law, forever coming forward, putting their oar in"
fields.body:
My friend's pregnant again. Fifth time in six years, all by the same man, and she's already chosen her next abortionist. Last time, it took 50 minutes from anaesthetic to home-time, and she felt so chirpy afterwards that she walked home and called me as she passed an Italian deli to see if I wanted anything. She is also half of the most devoted couple I know: six years, never a cross word that's not easily solved with a pen and thesaurus, and marriage on the cards. They go on holiday one hell of a lot - and I'm speaking as someone who took five last year. They've been together longer than anyone I know. Why? "Because we don't have children. I know it sounds odd, but it's like every abortion brings us closer."

"Don't you ever feel sort of weird, not even when you see really adorable babies in prams? Don't you ever feel sorry you had the last abortion, say?" Predictably, having turned 40 and buried my mother, I can't think of anything I'd like more than another baby. Women!

"No, but I'll tell you one thing for sure: there isn't a day that passes that I don't see at least one child who makes me thank God I've had four abortions, and vow to have four more, if I have to. When did all children start acting as if they're auditioning for The Exorcist?"

"What about X?" X is her boyfriend, a mature dreamboat with no apparent horn-buds or cloven hooves. "Doesn't he ever feel regretful?"

"Don't be silly! I told you, X has three grown-up children from his first marriage. He said they're the reason it broke up. He was mad about his wife, then the children ruined everything. He says he's not in a hurry to lose another woman he loves that way." Her pretty face clouded. "I was feeling a bit wavery, actually. Then we went to Barbados. There were loads of families there. It was horrible, all these couples sitting there for hours, not speaking a word to each other, and the kids, like little jailers, demanding things non-stop. It was incredible to think that these people had originally been drawn together through attraction and sex. X just smiled at me sort of sadly and said, 'See?' When we came back, it was my New Year's resolution to start reading newspapers, not magazines."

She shuddered. "And I remembered that thing Sharon Stone said when reporters wouldn't stop asking if she was pregnant: 'Climb out of my uterus, will ya?'" My friend shook her head. "It seems to me that when you have a relationship it's private; it's your business. But the moment you're pregnant, suddenly everybody thinks it's their business. It's public. And everyone knows that public relationships never last."

She's got a point. It's like the whole world, led by the media, has become one big interfering mother-in-law, forever coming forward and putting their oar in. We have all but abolished socialised childcare and the nanny state, but the organs of right-wing opinion have decided that women's bodies, once they have conceived, are nevertheless public property.

The fact that having children is a real laugh - I still think back to the infanthood of my second son as the happiest days of my life - has been totally lost in the static of censure. Everyone's got an opinion, especially those who don't have a womb. I wouldn't trust any of them, especially that alleged "feminist", Dr Michel Odent, who recently suggested that men should stay out of the delivery room. Yeah, so male doctors feel free to deprive the putative mother of the pain-killing drugs that the Odent tendency consider so wicked! This is the same Odent, don't forget, who last year suggested that women should devote themselves utterly to their children for the first few years after birth, while encouraging their husbands to pursue sex with other women! Funny, I didn't know that that was being a feminist; I thought it was being a Frenchman.

Women who work damage their children, says Panorama. Women who have affairs damage their children, says the Guardian. Women who drink even one glass of wine damage their children, say the doctors. Women who use technology to defer childbirth until they are settled and solvent damage their children, says the Mail in a fascinating about-face from a newspaper that previously prized social responsibility and self-reliance above all else, and spent decades demonising "natural" teenage single mothers. (The Mail is extremely keen on Bad Mothers, which must be why, after calling me "The Worst Mother In Britain" last year, it is now paying me £2 per word - must be those Wages Of Sin you hear about.)

On the other hand, says the equally strident evidence, simply by being born, children damage their mothers. Mothers are twice as likely to be depressed as non-mothers, and were recently discovered to be far less optimistic about the future. In a final, ironic twist, it appears that Mother Nature - since time immemorial the final authority to which the Family Values brigade resort - actually programmes women sexually to shut down on their husbands four years after the first child has been produced, and to stray elsewhere. If that doesn't happen, a third child will finish a marriage more often than not, anyway. DNA testing, meanwhile, has revealed that one in 10 children is sending the card to the wrong man on Father's Day.

But if the organs of the silent majority - Panorama, the Mail and the rest - really want women to start enthusiastically replenishing and caring for the nation's stock once more, I suggest they call a moratorium on the Bad Mother issue. Otherwise, the number of very young women asking to be sterilised will continue to rise and rise. The fact that having a baby in the house is, under the right circumstances, about as much fun as you can have while someone's throwing up on you, is being lost in the maelstrom of wagging fingers.

You won't get girls to behave like adults - to reproduce - simply by treating them like children, scolding them and lecturing them, over and over, until they decide to shut down out of sheer mulish stubbornness. Having a baby, at the end of the day, remains a young woman's own personal decision. No newspaper or government, no matter how mad and reactionary, would ever dare suggest a programme of mass rape, or even financial reward, as the monumentally sexist French did just after the war in order to replenish the stock.

If we don't stop making young women of child- bearing age feel that motherhood is a permanent test that they will never measure up to, these women will simply stop reproducing. There are, after all, so many other things for women to do these days. In seeking to guide the cream of child-bearing women into the ways of righteousness, we will instead have killed the goose that lays that shiniest of golden eggs: the future.

fields.headline: A right good moan
fields.standfirst: "Moaning is what makes people feel free even when they are not. It nurtures individualism. It bestows dignity on the humblest wage slave"
fields.trailText: "Moaning is what makes people feel free even when they are not. It nurtures individualism. It bestows dignity on the humblest wage slave"
fields.body:
Some of the things Greg Dyke said in his first pep talk as director general of the BBC were music to the ears of those many members of staff who are disenchanted with Sir John Birt's management reforms. Dyke promised to cut down the number of the BBC's outside consultants by up to a half, to abolish various layers of management and administration, to eliminate the pointless internal bazaar in which producers are required to haggle with each other over the rental of things such as props and costumes, and to spend a much larger proportion of the corporation's £2.8 billion income on making programmes. While Dyke insisted he would not be unpicking the Birtist reforms, he sounded very much as if that is just what he will be doing. The only part of Sir John's legacy that he seems genuinely to admire is the BBC's website, BBC Online, which he describes as "well ahead of the field".

But the part of his talk that rightly made the headlines was his ultimatum to staff to stop moaning or leave. "Please don't stay at the BBC and moan," he said. "It damages the morale of the BBC internally and the reputation of the BBC outside. If you genuinely don't like the BBC, or don't think you'll like what it's going to be, please take control of your own life and go somewhere else." I was surprised to read that this was greeted with warm applause by his audience, for moaning has always been a British national pastime and should be enshrined in a Bill of Rights if we ever have one. How would most of us get through life if we weren't allowed to moan about the weather, about the traffic, about the railways, about the postal service, about the inland revenue, about everything in fact, and especially about the people who give us our living?

As someone who has spent most of his life moaning, I feel most strongly about this. Moaning is what makes people feel free even when they are not. It nurtures individualism. It bestows dignity on the humblest wage slave. I am told that the employees of the Microsoft Corporation assemble once a year in a stadium somewhere and chant "I love this company". This, apparently, makes them feel good. But what distinguishes the British from most Americans and Japanese is that we shudder at such displays of corporate loyalty. Most of us are loyal in what we do - trying to serve the interests of our company and performing to the best of our ability at work - but we reserve the right to complain in private as much as we want. So we should. It is what makes us proper, independent people.

It is possible, I admit, that journalists moan too much. They are egotists by nature and resent any attempts to clip their wings or cut them down to size. So they often complain unfairly about their editors, even about editors they admire. But I know of no evidence to suggest that moaning journalists are any less hard-working or any less good at their jobs than the non-moaning ones. It may even be the other way round. And I would venture to suggest that the sharp decline in the opportunities to moan caused by the disbandment of the old Fleet Street community, whose members used to gather regularly in pubs to slag off their bosses to each other, has had a dampening effect on general journalistic vitality.

Greg Dyke, of course, is a supporter of New Labour, and he seems to be at one with Tony Blair in his belief that the country will only be successful if we all pull together in common cause. Their first error is to confuse moaning with a reluctance to do this, and their second error is to believe that they have a right to dictate what the cause should be. Blair made the great mistake of trying to depict early critics of the Millennium Dome as moaning ninnies without courage or vision. He wanted them to be thought of as petty and envious. But the moaners were right, and the prime minister was wrong. They ignored his threats, stuck to their guns, and have been thoroughly vindicated. The Dome is one of the great triumphs of British moaning.

The other silly thing about Dyke's attack on moaning at the BBC is that he should imagine he has any power to stop it. fields.bodyText: Some of the things Greg Dyke said in his first pep talk as director general of the BBC were music to the ears of those many members of staff who are disenchanted with Sir John Birt's management reforms. Dyke promised to cut down the number of the BBC's outside consultants by up to a half, to abolish various layers of management and administration, to eliminate the pointless internal bazaar in which producers are required to haggle with each other over the rental of things such as props and costumes, and to spend a much larger proportion of the corporation's £2.8 billion income on making programmes. While Dyke insisted he would not be unpicking the Birtist reforms, he sounded very much as if that is just what he will be doing. The only part of Sir John's legacy that he seems genuinely to admire is the BBC's website, BBC Online, which he describes as "well ahead of the field". But the part of his talk that rightly made the headlines was his ultimatum to staff to stop moaning or leave. "Please don't stay at the BBC and moan," he said. "It damages the morale of the BBC internally and the reputation of the BBC outside. If you genuinely don't like the BBC, or don't think you'll like what it's going to be, please take control of your own life and go somewhere else." I was surprised to read that this was greeted with warm applause by his audience, for moaning has always been a British national pastime and should be enshrined in a Bill of Rights if we ever have one. How would most of us get through life if we weren't allowed to moan about the weather, about the traffic, about the railways, about the postal service, about the inland revenue, about everything in fact, and especially about the people who give us our living? As someone who has spent most of his life moaning, I feel most strongly about this. Moaning is what makes people feel free even when they are not. It nurtures individualism. It bestows dignity on the humblest wage slave. I am told that the employees of the Microsoft Corporation assemble once a year in a stadium somewhere and chant "I love this company". This, apparently, makes them feel good. But what distinguishes the British from most Americans and Japanese is that we shudder at such displays of corporate loyalty. Most of us are loyal in what we do - trying to serve the interests of our company and performing to the best of our ability at work - but we reserve the right to complain in private as much as we want. So we should. It is what makes us proper, independent people. It is possible, I admit, that journalists moan too much. They are egotists by nature and resent any attempts to clip their wings or cut them down to size. So they often complain unfairly about their editors, even about editors they admire. But I know of no evidence to suggest that moaning journalists are any less hard-working or any less good at their jobs than the non-moaning ones. It may even be the other way round. And I would venture to suggest that the sharp decline in the opportunities to moan caused by the disbandment of the old Fleet Street community, whose members used to gather regularly in pubs to slag off their bosses to each other, has had a dampening effect on general journalistic vitality. Greg Dyke, of course, is a supporter of New Labour, and he seems to be at one with Tony Blair in his belief that the country will only be successful if we all pull together in common cause. Blair made the great mistake of trying to depict early critics of the Millennium Dome as moaning ninnies without courage or vision. He wanted them to be thought of as petty and envious. The more Dyke tries to stop them moaning, the more they are likely to want to take control of their own lives, as he puts it, and go somewhere else.

fields.headline: Father Dougal, superhero
fields.trailText: Channel surfing
fields.body:
It's hard not to feel for Father Ted Crilly. He sits in chair keeping his counsel of a quiet Friday evening. Father Jack is comatose. Father Dougal? He's gluing the pieces of the Kerplunk game back together after that accident with the bishop that we don't talk about. Then in bursts Mrs Doyle with the third pot of tea of the night. "No thank you Mrs Doyle. I've had 17 cups already." "Ah, go on now, have a drop." "Mrs Doyle, thank you. But no." "Ah, you will. You will. You will, you will, you will."

British sitcoms are like Mrs Doyle's pots of tea. They just keep coming. No matter that they were, quite frankly, not ordered, nor that they have long since lost their savour. Once, they seemed to work: you only have to look at The Fall and Rise of Reginald Perrin, Rising Damp or Porridge, currently being repeated, to realise that situation comedies once had interesting premises. My Hero (BBC1), the new Ardal O'Hanlon vehicle, doesn't.

My Hero suits the temper of an earlier era, when merely setting a comedy in Northolt would be funny enough. It involves a superhero called Thermoman who becomes a mild-mannered Irish health-shop proprietor when he takes off his pants and crash helmet. There are special effects, but not ones that George Lucas will lose sleep over. It's so gentle that it makes the Vicar of Dibley seem like a Throbbing Gristle gig.

I like the minor characters most of all. There's a grouchy receptionist who wears a crocheted sleeveless cardigan. "You've got a bad cough," she sneered to a prospective patient. "I've got a husband who's scarpered to Solihull, leaving me with the triplets. And you've got a bad cough." A note about Solihull may be helpful at this point. Nobody "scarpers" there. It's not like Shard End or Bloxwich. People, rather, "aspire to live" there as they would with Frinton or Sutton Coldfield.

There's a neighbour called Tyler, too, with a vast collection of acid flashbacks. "What were you on in the 60s?" said nice nurse Janet, the object of Theroman's ardour. "I was on Neptune for a couple of years, then I moved to Mars." Poor nice nurse Janet with her sensible hair and shoes. She is the still centre of this would-be hurricane of a comedy. She will never, I feel sure, say anything funny.

Through all this wanders Ardal O'Hanlon, as often as not wearing the same expression as he does when gluing bits of Kerplunk. There was a mock-heroic joke about him getting a rash from wearing tights that may well have to be returned to the Les Dawson estate. Mind you, I did like the way he kept emerging from the public conveniences he uses to transport himself across continents. He would arrive on the street rather quickly as though he didn't like what he'd seen in there. I know how he feels.

It'll be just dandy getting to know these characters, won't it? It will, it will, it will, it will.

webTitle: PM takes a walk on the west side

fields.headline: PM takes a walk on the west side
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday did his utmost to put Ireland out of his mind, and stuck with his plans to spend the day in Cornwall, England's poorest county.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday did his utmost to put Ireland out of his mind, and stuck with his plans to spend the day in Cornwall, England's poorest county.

He went to two farms, one shipyard, one radio station, one post office and one imitation rain forest (under construction), all in the centre of the county, not far from Lostwithiel.

Since Labour in Cornwall spends most of its elections not far from Lost Deposit, it is safe to assume he will not be repeating the exercise this side of a second term.

However, this visit enabled Mr Blair to acquire instant expertise on Cornish problems and priorities, with the impertinent ease normally associated with journalists.

"What I've seen in Cornwall is ..." he began at one stage - which would have been fair enough except then it was just after breakfast, and he had seen nothing at all except the inside of the hotel where he had slept and talked to Bertie Ahern.

Later, on a Radio Cornwall phone-in, Mr Blair was asked what he was going to do about Goss Moor. This is the stretch of A30 which is not yet dual carriageway and a notorious bottleneck.

One suspects, however, it is not quite so notorious that the prime minister could call it to mind at once. Masterfully, he said it was subject to consultation and then a question of funding. This covered all possible contingencies, whatever Goss Moor might be.

He turned down the opportunity of visiting the unemployment blackspot of Redruth. But he did pop into a village shop to publicise the day's policy announcement: the subsidised introduction of cash machines in rural post offices: 400 this summer, 3,000 in all.

One customer was far more affected by Mr Blair's arrival than by the announcement. "Your little heart goes," said Rhonda England after she met him. "It was interesting because not much happens in Polgooth."

All day Mr Blair was making things happen, in Polgooth, in Lanlivery, Stythians, Falmouth and St Blazey. The theme throughout was One Nation.

"They're coming from three directions, all preaching the politics of division.

"They're coming from the right trying to divide town against country, from the left with north and south, and from the nationalists with the UK."

He told a gathering of businessmen: "The issue is how we unite the country to deal with issues that are coming from outside which are beyond our control to change but within our control to manage."

He was speaking at the Eden project - the giant version of a tropical palm house now being constructed in a china clay pit, which is due to have six domes, not just one.

"What an incredible place. Is this not fantastic?" he drooled.

Well, it probably will be fantastic. At present it is a hole in the ground with scaffolding, and it will be 10 years before it can produce serious results. A bit like the Blair project.

He then went to an old barn converted into a restaurant by a local farmer who is now serving wild boar cutlets and offering one solution to rural problems: everyone can earn a precarious living giving each other dinner.

As in Devon on Thursday, farming protesters were once again asked in to talk over their problems with the prime minister.

Unlike the pig farmer he met in Exeter, these did not immediately roll over just because they had their stomachs tickled.

"I have buried two farmers who have committed suicide," said the vicar of Lanlivery, the Rev David Keighley, one of the protesters, "and that's two too many.

"I've got three family breakdowns I'm dealing with. The pressure on farmers is so intense, there's no time to lean over the garden gate and talk any more. It affects everything in the community.

"Mr Blair didn't offer us any solutions, but he did listen. I have now got more respect for the problems he faces."

However, the prime minister again declined to meet any animals, to the intense disappointment of the photographers.

A planned meet-the-sheep walkabout was cancelled, and the cows on the farm he visited at Stythians were ignored.

Indeed, by the end of two days in the west country, the prime ministerial black shoes were as shiny as when he set out.

webTitle: It's almost like living in a republic

fields.headline: It's almost like living in a republic
fields.standfirst:
Suddenly the royals only get into the papers if they're being sniped at

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The sniping at the Wessexes is intriguing in that it comes from the Daily Mail and that it concentrates on the money and privilege of the Windsors and their clan. The Mail has been the most monarchist of British publications. Yet the recent coverage of the couple would have fitted a republican publication.
fields.body:
In an interview before her wedding, Sophie Rhys-Jones promised that she would not attempt to become the new Diana. Her word has been kept for her by the press. This week she became the new Fergie: mugged by pundits for wearing an animal-fur hat while leaving a private plane to walk towards a Rolls-Royce waiting to take her to a freebie residence. The Daily Mail - which had led this criticism - yesterday devoted its front page to more or less accusing the Earl of Wessex of causing a building firm to go into receivership by haggling over a £600,000 bill for work at his country home.

The same day's papers revealed that princesses Eugenie and Beatrice are to be sent to school in Switzerland, where their mother may join them. Even 10 years ago, this decision would have brought appalled editorials. Now there seems to be a general sense that Switzerland's gain is ours too. These reports all tell the same underlying story: that, whatever the constitutional facts, we are living in a republic of the mind. Sending the offspring to chalet school is what exiled and deposed monarchies do.

The sniping at the Wessexes is doubly intriguing in that it comes from the Daily Mail and that it concentrates on the money and privilege of the Windsors and their clan. The Mail has been the most monarchist of British publications. Yet the recent coverage of the couple would have fitted a republican publication. And the specific charge against them - that they are arrogant and privileged and fail to live like ordinary people - is a fascinating back-flip. What, after all, would be the point of monarchy, except to have more money, less humility and a more rarefied existence than other people?

What's interesting about this week's pieces is that they had the effect of reading about a film star who you'd thought for some time was dead. In a way which seems astonishing even in comparison with 20 years ago, it is possible to go about your business for weeks or even months now in Britain without noticing there's a throne or a family on it. The only articles which bring them into the papers are carping ones. The Queen's golden jubilee in the year 2002 may be used to try to increase their visibility, but the royals could find themselves celebrating age and continuity in a culture increasingly devoted to youth and change.

There have been four factors in this eclipse. The first is that Tony Blair has co-opted many of the ceremonial roles once entrusted to the throne and particularly in the areas of openings, mournings and symbolic utterances. His unusual youth has even allowed him to be the first prime minister to challenge the royals in breeding babies for the media and nation to adore.

The loss of Diana - the show's one star - has also been significant, though not in the way predicted. It seemed briefly that the celebration of her might provide a platform for hostility to the monarchy. In fact, the reaction has been more like apathy. Finding the stage looking bare, many of the audience have simply torn up their tickets and left.

Devolution has also played a part, as its architects in Scotland and Wales always knew it would but Tony Blair felt obliged to deny. A shrinking kingdom diminishes the monarch. It could logically have no other effect.

And finally there is the problem - which Diana's death exacerbates - of the age and relative dullness of the central characters. The great and governing agony of the Prince of Wales's life is at a lesser level the difficulty for all monarchists. They are almost certainly in a long period - which may last for up to another 20 years - of waiting for something to happen. This is a problem which afflicts all systems which depend on posthumous succession in an age of sophisticated medical care.

None of this means that an actual republic is close. At a time when political skill is defined as caution, the question is not going to be asked. Even if it were, there are at least two living British generations who grew up with enough flag-waving and commemorative crockery to vote a loud No in any poll. Indeed, the moment in the mid-90s - with the divorces and the concession on tax and the refusal to use public funds to rebuild Windsor Castle - when there seemed to be a momentum towards republicanism has now passed. There are no front pages now as terrifying as that time, and will not be until one of the young princes is caught doing something anti-social or illegal.

The point is that Britain feels less and less like a monarchy. Such shifts are subjective and hard to define but, just as Scotland did seem to have a new atmosphere in the weeks after the opening of its new parliament, so England feels subtly different: in its newspapers and television stations and the conversations in its streets.

The feeling is similar to the spell in an American presidency when he can no longer run for re-election but his successor is being lengthily selected. A lame-duck presidency, they say. The American electorate suffers that inconvenience for at most two years. British voters may put up with this one for a hundred or so, but the atmosphere of valedictory ceremonial is now the same: a lame-duck monarchy.

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: With the CBI's position on the single currency as clear as mud, Rentokil boss Sir Clive Thompson - president of the employers' organisation - waded in with a clarification of his own on Tuesday.
fields.body:
With the CBI's position on the single currency as clear as mud, Rentokil boss Sir Clive Thompson - president of the employers' organisation - waded in with a clarification of his own on Tuesday. We can't remember much of what he said, however, because, in common with most of his audience, we didn't get much further than Sir Clive's reference to the prime minister's remarks on the subject when addressing "Davros" earlier this year. While we grappled with the idea of Mr Blair chewing the fat with the wheelchair-bound creator of the Daleks, Sir Clive droned on about, oh, convergence, or something. Spoilsports suggested Sir Clive had merely inserted a superfluous R in Davos, home of the toponymous international hot-air festival, but we don't believe it. Our paths cross again, doctor ...

 Back home, NatWest is bracing itself for St Valentine's day, on which auspicious date it finds out whether Bank of Scotland or Royal Bank of Scotland has won the hearts of shareholders or whether they are sticking with the action bank's existing management. Executive chairman Sir David Rowland has booked Gibson Hall, near his Lothbury HQ, for St Valentine's night, we hear, which shows either supreme confidence or a determination to blow a chunk of NatWest's money on a sorrows-drowning bash before the flinty Scots turn up. Meanwhile, Peter Burt, Bank of's chief executive, wined and dined journalists this week in the offices of financial advisers Credit Suisse First Boston. CSFB's offices are on level 32 of the old NatWest tower, which may or may not augur well for Bank of's suit.

 As banks fall into bed with each other (or not, as the case may be), Peninsular & Oriental is breaking itself in two, with the go-go ports and "logistics" business going one way and the sedate, leisurely cruise line another. Lord Sterling was imperious on Thursday when asked if he would expect the latter to find itself on the end of a bid from Carnival, the world's biggest line, headed by energetic executive chairman Micky Arison. No, no, was the disdainful response. "I know Micky," said his lordship, adding that the Carnival chief had already been told in no uncertain terms that he would not be a suitable owner for such a grand business.

 Lord Sterling was robust also when it was suggested the demerger would prove his swan song at P&O: "Following this I feel more like a cygnet than a swan." His lordship goes big on singing. Some time ago, as he strolled through Covent Garden, Lord Sterling passed two busking opera singers. Impressed by their performance, he stopped to chat to the two young women and suggested they might like to sing on one of his ships. The ladies in question had heard this sort of chat before and paid little attention. Half an hour later, Lord Sterling was back to sign them up and they performed to great acclaim on P&O's millennium cruise.

 Fellow peers were this week entertained by the Underside's old pal, Professor Ian Angell, who holds the LSE's chair in alarm and despondency. The prophet of a new post-democratic "age of rage" was giving evidence on Wednesday to a house of lords EU sub-committee looking at the development of e-commerce. Initially, Prof Angell had been planning to insist on speaking only to hereditary peers and one or two of the more "sound" bishops, but thought better of it. Next Wednesday sees the launch of The New Barbarian Manifesto, the professor's latest book (Nietzsche, Ayn Rand and the mafia - good; democratic politicians and the inland revenue - bad) at the Economist bookshop in Portugal Street, London. "Guardian readers welcome," chuckled the professor.

 Finally, Vodafone chief Chris Gent may be having second thoughts about the "communications revolution". On Friday morning he flew into London from Düsseldorf fresh from his triumph in tying up the world's biggest deal, the £110bn merger with Germany's Mannesmann group. While we grappled with the idea of Mr Blair chewing the fat with the wheelchair-bound creator of the Daleks, Sir Clive droned on about, oh, convergence, or something. webTitle: If this is Life, will someone please pass the cyanide?

fields.headline: If this is Life, will someone please pass the cyanide?
fields.trailText: Wave riding
fields.body:
'You're listening to Life," said the jingle on Britain's newest national radio station, which launched last week. And in the nanosecond's pause before the voice added "digital radio", I anticipated the stereo sounds of fecund cells, generative organisms, the wholly messy bio-battle for survival itself. Instead, all I got was George Michael.

Life is Capital Radio's attempt to go national. It's a soft adult contemporary station (like every second commercial radio station in the country). Armed with this information, you could probably programme the station yourself. Indeed, soft adult contemporary lovers have most of the playlist piled up beside their hi-fi anyway - Whitney Houston, Rod Stewart, Robbie Williams. They might as well just switch on their own CD players since, for a whole hour on Wednesday mid-morning, there wasn't a single word of speech except for some absurd celebrity greetings ("Hi, Phil Collins here"). There is some speech in between Abba and Madonna on Paul Phear's Breakfast Show, but this only makes you realise why the other shows have dispensed with it.

As for the scrolling text (which appears in a data window on the digital radio set), it may be early days, but at present no information is given about the tracks being played. All it keeps repeating is "Life - digital radio where the music sounds better all day long". All day long? More than 15 minutes of soft adult contemporary, and you'd gag on its lushness. This is music to buy T-shirts to, a radio station for wine bars. "Let there be Life", inevitably thrummed a jingle. If this is it, pass the cyanide.

By contrast, on Saturday night on Radio 4 there was a programme made up largely of old clips which was so compelling that I couldn't get out of the car; when I did, I chuckled all the way up the front steps. Julian May's Boy, Oh Boy: He's Going Down played examples of speech radio where the traditional formality was displaced by reporters or contributors overwhelmed by mirth, passion or drink.

The title came from Herb Morrison's memorable live reporting of the Hindenburg airship bursting into flames. Morrison's voice vaults an octave, turns lachrymose, and he almost breaks down as, watching the dying, he sobs, "Oh humanities" - the kind of poetic demotic which arises in extremis.

Presenter Sean Street traced the influence of that broadcast on Orson Welles, who played it to his crew when he was making The War of the Worlds. There was an ironic coda. Three years after the panic brought about by The War of the Worlds' depiction of an invasion by Martians, it happened to be Welles, live on air, when the announcement of the bombing of Pearl Harbour had to be made. No one believed him.

One couldn't help noticing that most of the clips were on the oldish side. Today's presenters have been so made over in the current style - bland fluency, with a few punning quips - that the Hindenburg would need to land on their heads to jolt them from their professional tracks.

Finally, a BBC news story (you heard it first here). Having disbanded its history unit in the mid-90s, the BBC has now appointed a successor to its former historian Asa Briggs. Jean Seaton, broadcasting sociologist and historian, is to document the BBC in the Thatcher years, and there isn't a more rigorous yet engaged chronicler of the siege of public service broadcasting around. At last the BBC's history will no longer be history.

fields.headline: A token too far
fields.standfirst:
So the Irish peace process is in crisis. But it's not the peace, just the process

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Today, the IRA is snowed under with exhortations to decommission some weapons. One wonders when one sees and hears these pronouncements exactly who is meant to be impressed by them. Should we British not remember that an amount of discord has resulted from our history of telling Irish people what to do?
fields.body:
One of the events of August's West Belfast Festival is the Black Mountain Walk. Local historian Terry Enright, whose son was shot by loyalists a couple of years back, guides a mixture of tourists, festival performers and Belfast folk up a path that, no matter how trampled, has never come to resemble a path.

There are anecdotes, folk tales, history and good-natured wisecracking. Some of the jokes flying about are obscure if you've never been to prison or held an AK47. But the only slight sign of tension I have seen during the walk resulted from the fact that the Hare Krishna people's only song was starting to grate after two hours' hard walking, and they were pleasantly asked to give it a rest. You might think they got off lightly, but they had shared their satsumas.

The tour's climax is a look down the sheer drop at the back of the mountain. Before flashes of geography O-level enter your brain, I should tell you that it has nothing to do with glaciers, plate tectonics, oxbow lakes or rain gauges. An enormous quarry is eating the mountain to produce the white stuff that's painted on roads. Its owner has a licence to mine the whole beautiful thing out of existence.

The first time I saw this destruction, I asked an IRA veteran, "Can't somebody shoot him?" My companion looked at me in a kindly and amused way and replied, "We don't do businessmen anymore - that was the 70s".

Perhaps I should stress that this man was retired from the struggle, despite the British illusion that these people do it for a living and are addicted to the gun. Some commentators like to imagine that living in constant fear of arrest or death is a way of life that's hard to give up. I suppose that being on the run gives you an excuse for not doing much around the house, but most of us find in our 30s that we quite like staying in at night. I have not done extensive (any) research into this, nor would I presume, as the newsmen say, to "enter the mindset of the IRA", because it doesn't do to stare at people too intently in Belfast pubs, and apart from anything else, it's rude. But it seems to me that, if being an urban guerrilla were that much fun, there wouldn't be so many of them who are now doing other things.

But despite the fact that this veteran had hung up his gun, he could have mentioned my suggestion to someone on the army council if he had thought that the musings of an English media tart might be put on the agenda at their next meeting.

Today, the IRA is snowed under with exhortations to decommission some weapons. One wonders when one sees and hears these pronouncements exactly who is meant to be impressed by them. Fair enough, we are all paid to fill space, but should we British not remember that an amount of discord has resulted from our history of telling Irish people what to do?

Of course, many people are calling for decommissioning, not just British commentators and politicians. People want peace. But peace and the peace process are not necessarily the same thing. The peace process, we hear, is in crisis. Not the peace, just the process. But this does not mean that a war process is beginning.

The IRA leadership has held together and has prevented a significant split, partly because of internal discipline and partly because there has been no decommissioning. Would we all be cheering if there were a gesture of decommissioning this afternoon and, tomorrow, another Omagh?

An alarming number of people say that there has to be a split sooner or later. Many of them would like this because it would mean IRA volunteers killing one another. It seems unlikely that there would be no ramifications for anyone else.

Yes, these are worrying days, but at the moment the thing that is under threat is the agreement, not the peace. Very few republicans want war. Very many are unhappy with the agreement because it represents the best deal unionists could possibly have won. It's not a great read, but it does, remarkably, recognise the grandiose piece of ballot-rigging that is partition. In fact, our government has renounced our right to decolonise if we so wish, which makes a mockery of our history. What on earth's the point of over-running places if we then have to stay there when we're fed up with them?

If unionists get the token gesture they demand, they will soon dismiss it as tokenism. If anything had been handed in at any stage it would have been said that it was no guarantee that the IRA are serious about peace. Now Peter Mandelson recognises that they are serious about peace but says they have to be serious about decommissioning. However did this ludicrous precondition come to dog the whole process? Oh yes, the British government has allowed it to - funny how we keep messing things up for Ireland.

fields.headline: Darling, I'm on the wheel
fields.trailText: Of football, fishcakes, ferris wheels and ...erm... alliteration.
fields.body:
That tobacco manufacturers have undermined government efforts to stop black marketeering in cigarettes was "as clear as a pikestaff", the Liberal Democrat MP Peter Brand declared this week. What on earth is wrong with these people? Can't they even marshal a decent cliche? No wonder they are where they are on the polls. Everyone knows that a pikestaff is an object which things are as plain as - not as clear as, which does not even alliterate. Indeed, pikestaffs today have few uses outside simile.

I suggest young Mr Kennedy calls his forces together and gives them a bit of schooling. "Repeat after me," he should say "as bright as?...as cool as?...as dead as?..." and so on right up to Z for "as zealous as..." Anyone failing to answer respectively "a button", " a cucumber", " a doornail" and "a Zwinglian" should be instantly deselected.

A pedant writes: I do not myself recall having heard the expression "as zealous as a Zwinglian" until now.

Smallweed ripostes with insufferable complacency: In that case, you are a more rounded and whole human being than you were before you read this paragraph.

A bevy of distinguished journalists went up on the millennium wheel on Tuesday. Most of them, had a good time - not least the Daily Telegraph's William Deedes, 86 and perhaps, one begins to think, immortal. "Whew!" his piece began cheekily. But then Deedes went on meticulously to describe what the capsules were like, the speed at which the wheel turned, and the astonishing views.

Not so Hunter Davies, pressed into service as wheel correspondent for the Independent. "My wife refused to come," he began his account of this historic occasion, explaining that he'd been forced to go on his own. Then there were chats with people he met on the trip, Deedes included, and a jubilant reference to sharing his capsule with Bob Ayling of BA, no less, and David Marks, the wheel's co-architect. Then a bit of by-play with Julia Somerville about people they'd like to sleep with.

And that view? This was Hunt's description: " 'Earth has not anything to show more fair/Dull would he be of soul who could pass by/A sight so touching in its majesty.' So he mused in 1802. Well put, William. It could easily apply to the wheel." At the very top, Hunt reports, he took out his mobile phone and rang his wife. "Darling" he said adapting the old commuter cliche with a wit and inventiveness one could never match in a thousand years, "I'm on the wheel!" You have to hand it to Hunter, don't you!! Such a whizzo sense of what matters compared with bumbling old Bill!!! I mean who is the teeniest bit interested in the view up and down the Thames when they could be hearing all about dear old Hunt and his dear old mobe?

Hunter Davies is 64.

Life's little byways: no 242 in an occasional Smallweed series. Did you know EM Forster should have been HM Forster? I prefer EM myself, since it makes him sound less like royalty. His father, whose name was Edward, went to the registrar intending to call the child Henry Morgan Forster, but when asked to state the child's name, he forgot what he and his wife had agreed and gave his own name instead.

Did you also know that Edward Lear was one of 20 children and that his father, Jeremiah, was slung into jail because of his debts? One day, when walking into London, Jeremiah saw a board with the name Jeremiah Lear inscribed upon it, so he marched straight in and introduced himself: Jeremiah Lear, meet Jeremiah Lear. The two men and their families then became the firmest of friends.

Winsford 4, Guiseley 2. Yes, at last the first victory of the season, and this after our boys had gone two down in six minutes. True, Tuesday's game with Stalybridge Celtic ended in another defeat, but the hoodoo (or was it the voodoo) is broken. Meanwhile, the Metropolitan Police rugby union team, which, as you may remember, Smallweed failed to endorse, was thrashed again on Saturday and has now been beaten 17 times out of 17. There is clearly a pattern there, though Smallweed is far too modest to spell out what it is.

Meanwhile, a second campaign has also been brought to a happy conclusion. A reader suggests that next time I travel from Winsford to Guiseley I should stop off in his home town of Halifax, where any fish shop - but particularly Clare Road fisheries, on the way to the Shay, home of Halifax Town AFC - will sell you a fish teacake. The teacake, he writes lasciviously, is generously buttered, and a fillet of haddock is added, followed by salt and a shower of vinegar. "Result: pure ecstasy as the hot fish melts the butter. Lick fingers afterwards and continue towards the Shay."

There is also, it seems, such a thing as a herring sandwich, as mentioned in Ronald Firbank's novel Valmouth. Mrs Thoroughfare is discovered at Hare Hatch House: "'Hail Mary...!' she breathed, ignoring a decanter of sherry and a plate of herring sandwiches - a contrivance akin to genius in drawing attention to an offertory box nearby."

But let me not be distracted by thoroughfares from the matter of Winifred Robinson, whose occasional appearances on the Today programme I lauded last week. Smallweed is clearly not alone in this passion. A former resident of Todmorden says that when she appeared on the local news from Manchester, people used to discuss whether she resembled Bette Davis. The verdict: she did, but Winifred was better looking. A BBC employee, no less, predicts that Greg Dyke may come to be judged on how often she is allowed to appear on our airwaves. I noticed on Thursday that Jim Naughtie seemed to have quite a nasty cough. Perhaps they will need to draft in a temporary replacement.

fields.headline: Hanging on to hope
fields.trailText: One of the elements of hope that arose from the Good Friday agreement was a plan by a number of primary schools in the UK and Republic of Ireland for cooperation and exchange. Our two schools are writing a proposal for joint events during the coming academic year.
fields.body:
 One of the elements of hope that arose from the Good Friday agreement was a plan by a number of primary schools in the UK and Republic of Ireland for cooperation and exchange. Our two schools are writing a proposal for joint events during the coming academic year. Supported by European funding, there is enthusiasm and excitement that our pupils, staff and the wider school community may contribute in a small way to building confidence between our two countries. How sad it would be if, at this crucial stage in the political developments that arose from the detail of the agreement (Irish buy last chance for peace, February 4), the process were now to falter and the real opportunities for a brighter future for the younger people in our countries were lost.

Fulfen school, Burntwood, Staffs
Scoil Mhuire, Dublin

The peaceful political efforts of elected representatives such as McGuinness and Adams show this is not now the case. Sinn Fein is no longer in any controlling power over the IRA and to exclude elected politicians from the peace process because of an anachronistic association would be undemocratic and foolishly dangerous. Instead of demanding decommissioning, a way forward is to insist on the total severance of Sinn Fein from the IRA. A formal statement from Sinn Fein ought to allow the assembly to continue.
Ian Flintoff
London
IanFlintoff@aol.com

Something of this sort might be a way of breaking the log-jam that threatens to frustrate the wishes of people throughout Ireland and Britain.
Kevin McGrath
Harlow, Essex

fields.headline: Saints and sinners
fields.trailText: Your Consumer section (February 4) prints the much repeated Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders' argument that high car prices are partly due to the strength of sterling. Any economics textbook will demonstrate that a highly valued currency means lower import prices.
fields.body:
Your Consumer section (February 4) prints the much repeated Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders' argument that high car prices are partly due to the strength of sterling. Any economics textbook will demonstrate that a highly valued currency means lower import prices. Sterling has gained about 15% against Euroland currencies (the source of most imported cars) in the past year. Perhaps the SMMT would care to explain?
Peter Cullen
Chippenham, Wilts

 Julie Burchill says (Letters, February 4) she doesn't broadcast because she lives in Brighton. Is there, perhaps, a location which would render her also unable to write?
Bill Robertson
Kendal, Cumbria

 You must be pleased at Julie Burchill's letter. If she'd included her points in her column, it would have cost you £200 at £2 a word. Do hyphenated words attract a premium?
Tony Fry
Southampton

 Dr Stevenson's British wayside pulpit sighting (Letters, February 4) is certainly not the earliest, because I saw "Jesus Saves! Moses Invests" in 1970 at Sussex University, and I doubt that was original.
Tony Vinicombe
Hove, East Sussex

 Surely the original version was "Jesus Saves! St John puts in the rebound." Ian St John was Liverpool centre forward in the mid/late 60s. This pre-dates "the definitive Vancouver graffito of 1972".
Roger Titford
Hungerford

 In 1942 in Blackpool a tin tabernacle advised young airmen "Drink is your worst enemy" but round the corner they were told to "Make your worst enemy your best friend". I have happily pursued this advice for 58 years.
Douglas Hogg
Kingston upon Thames, Surrey

fields.headline: Row over Lockerbie TV rights
fields.standfirst: Libya and the Lockerbie trial: special report
fields.trailText: The trial of the Lockerbie bombing suspects is to be broadcast to victims' families in the UK and America via closed circuit TV.
fields.body:
The trial of the Lockerbie bombing suspects is to be broadcast to victims' families in the UK and America via closed circuit TV.

Pictures from the court, in the Netherlands, will be relayed to Dumfries, London, Washington and New York to allow families of those killed in the 1988 outrage to follow proceedings when they start in May.

Plans for CCTV links were announced last year but required court approval, which has now been given by the trial judge, Lord Sutherland.

A live TV feed has already been arranged for journalists in the court complex.

The Scottish Executive said yesterday that the decision to allow families to see CCTV pictures of the trial was reached after a request by the US office for victims of crime (OVC), which is representing the needs of the relatives.

But the decision has provoked a row with broadcasters, who have been barred from filming the trial. Some claim that the US government has effectively bought the TV rights to the trial.

"A substantial amount of money is being paid by the US to the British government, who are funding this trial," claimed one broadcast source yesterday.

However, a spokeswoman for the OVC in Washington said: "We are sharing some funds in order to set up the CCTV sites. It would be wrong to suggest we had bought the TV rights. Everything we do goes towards helping the victims' families."

A spokesman for the Scottish Executive said the OVC was funding the CCTV sites, not the cameras in the court. He said there was no financial deal with the Scottish courts.

A number of networks are interested in showing the trial. Next week, a group of leading broadcasters, led by the BBC, will attempt to get their cameras allowed into the court.

Under 1925 legislation, cameras are prohibited from British courts, but guidelines drawn up in 1992 by Lord Hope, then head of the Scottish judiciary, permitted a procedure for allowing cameras into Scottish courts.

The BBC's Scottish legal expert, Alistair Bonnington, said yesterday: "If it is being filmed then we must be allowed to film as well."

But a Scottish Executive spokesman said CCTV feeds, which enhanced the working of the court, and the televising of the trial were two completely different issues.

Earlier this week, the two accused, Abdel-basset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, formally pleaded not guilty to the charges against them. The two men were handed over by Libya in April 1999.

Lockerbie Trial Briefing
Lockerbie Accident Investigation
League of Arab States: Libya

fields.headline: False memory syndrome
fields.trailText: One of the recurrent themes in the Haider outcry (Leader February 4) is Austria's difficulty in remembering its past. It was Allied policy to maintain Austria's "first victim" status, for decades.
fields.body:
One of the recurrent themes in the Haider outcry (Leader February 4) is Austria's difficulty in remembering its past. It was Allied policy to maintain Austria's "first victim" status, for decades. Thus, two generations have been brought up with little or no education about Austria's real role in National Socialism in the 30s. In September 1999, with colleagues in Austria and Germany, we held the first ever public Holocaust conference, for survivors and descendants of survivors and perpetrators, in Vienna. It was clear that the lack of education and post-war amnesia in Austria is as much to do with the rest of Europe as Austria herself.

The process of understanding and working through a murderous past is a long and difficult one, requiring sustained confrontation from outside a country, as well as inside. It is naive and superficial to imagine a country will change, unless it has been forced to. Germany, for example, although without question totally culpable, also became the convenient perpetrator dumping-ground on behalf of most of Europe.

As we now wake up to the consequences of this, we run the risk of colluding, again, in the creation of an Austrian "second victim" myth.
Katherine Klinger
Second Generation Trust secgentrust@compuserve.com

 Mr Haider is no more a Nazi supporter than Mr Blair can be accused of being a communist supporter. All the allegations are smears, slander and deliberate distortions from those who think they may lose their nepotistic privileges. He is a postmodern politician who wishes to move his country beyond the tyranny of tradition, just as Mr Blair is looking for a "Third Way". Mr Haider has a social conscience and believes accumulated wealth should be shared out more fairly. He believes state bureaucracy needs curtailing and nepotism should be eliminated

Mr Haider believes, like Britain, that unlimited immigration is not possible to sustain without serious social consequences. He is no more a racist than Mr Straw, but concerned to contain immigration at levels a small country like Austria can cope with.
F Pock
Chester

 If history has taught us anything, it is that the best way to ensure the electoral success of xenophobic, fascist parties is to make them appear victimised. The gargantuan efforts of our foreign secretary to whip up anti-Austrian feeling across the EU is not only offensive to the vast majority of Austrians who do not support Jörg Haider's views, it is also highly irresponsible. That our government may end up encouraging people to vote for Haider scares me.
Cllr Keith Mitchell
Conservative group leader
Oxfordshire county council

 EU politicians should keep their noses out of other country's affairs. The reason for the upsurge in extremist parties throughout Europe is because the power elite is so corrupt that the people cannot see any other option. Outside threats from a bully are guaranteed to unite people. The peoples of the UK should also be thankful that there is a national party which is neither an EU grovelling party nor a bunch of extremist bigots, to whom they can now turn for a different outlook within politics - the UK Independence Party.
J W Smith
UKIP, Ayrshire

 Western powers have been happy to go along with the likes of Franco and the Greek colonels, not to mention Mrs Thatcher's old buddy General Pinochet. Why the outcry over Haider? After all, it's not as if the man is a communist.
Norman Jarvis
Torquay

fields.headline: Levi remembered
fields.trailText: I was grieved to read of the death of Peter Levi, and further saddened by Peter Forbes' flippant and ungenerous obituary (February 3), which seemed more concerned with malicious trivialities than with evaluating the legacy of a complex and talented writer.
fields.body:
I was grieved to read of the death of Peter Levi, and further saddened by Peter Forbes' flippant and ungenerous obituary (February 3), which seemed more concerned with malicious trivialities than with evaluating the legacy of a complex and talented writer. To concentrate exclusively on Levi's alleged "dandyish insouciance", to say nothing of those gothic-arch eyebrows, is rather like dismissing Eliot because of his taste in hats and theology.

Whatever one might think of his personal style, Peter Levi will be remembered above all for his poetry; for his passionate and erudite travel books; and for his encyclopedically annotated translation of Pausanias. Those who knew him will also remember his generosity, high spirits and, yes, dandyish insouciance, with gratitude and regret.
John Stathatos
London

fields.headline: Not really faking it
fields.trailText: Catherine Bennett is entitled to her view that reconstructions have no place in television current affairs (Beware of cheap imitation, February 3). However, her comparison of the recent Panorama on Harold Shipman with Carlton's The Connection was unfair, as was the G2 cover line "Haven't got the footage? Then fake it".
fields.body:
Catherine Bennett is entitled to her view that reconstructions have no place in television current affairs (Beware of cheap imitation, February 3). However, her comparison of the recent Panorama on Harold Shipman with Carlton's The Connection was unfair, as was the G2 cover line "Haven't got the footage? Then fake it". The Connection deceived the viewer into thinking that something had happened when it had not. Panorama's reconstructions were factually correct, clearly labelled and the relatives of Shipman's victims were consulted before and after the broadcast. None of them were unhappy with the use. There was no faking involved.
Andy Bell
Panorama, BBC

 Catherine Bennett picked a fair fight with last Monday's Panorama, and then spoiled it by hitting below the belt. It is always worth debating the tastefulness and effectiveness of reconstructions in TV programmes, but it wrecked her case to suggest that the BBC programme shared moral culpability with the makers of the discredited Carlton documentary, The Connection.

The great glory of series like Panorama is that they make available to a tabloid-sized audience the qualities of broadsheet journalism. If the cost of keeping the viewers with you is to offend Catherine's sensibilities, it seems a small price to pay.
Steve Boulton
Former editor, World In Action

steveboulton@email.msn.com

fields.headline: Bad affair
fields.trailText: I saw the The End of the Affair at the Guardian preview. It is a sensitive depiction of a passionate love affair and deserves to be seen by a wide audience, but it has been granted an 18-certificate by the British Board of Film Classification. How peculiar.
fields.body:
I saw the The End of the Affair at the Guardian preview. It is a sensitive depiction of a passionate love affair and deserves to be seen by a wide audience, but it has been granted an 18-certificate by the British Board of Film Classification. How peculiar - it is legitimate for people to have sex, get married, have children but not see a beautiful film like this until they are 18. It is also likely that older people, including many Graham Greene fans, will be put off because they think the sex will be explicit, which it isn't.

We are told (Corrections, February 4) that the BBFC is asking the nation whether we want age classifications relaxed. Yes, as soon as possible.
Annie Watson
London

fields.headline: Wolfit's acting was dandy
fields.trailText: Would Simon Hoggart please stop perpetuating the myth that Donald Wolfit could only overact and not act (Commons sketch, February 3). Wolfit's Lear was unarguably one of the greatest of the century.
fields.body:
Would Simon Hoggart please stop perpetuating the myth that Donald Wolfit could only overact and not act (Commons sketch, February 3). Wolfit's Lear was unarguably one of the greatest of the century. I suspect that Hoggart did not see it; I did and I have never seen its equal. Please read the reviews of his Lear and the astonishing reviews of his performances in Tamburlaine the Great and The Clandestine Marriage at the Old Vic - two other performances which I have never forgotten. Read James Agate on the young Wolfit at Stratford in the 1930s.

Wolfit's defect was not that he could not act; it was that he was self-centred, arrogant, opinionated, selfish, and rode roughshod over others. I can see what Hoggart has in mind, but it has nothing to do with Wolfit's acting ability.
Prof Les Allen
Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk
