fields.headline: Walk tall
fields.trailText: All of you who are happy to live with your disability, good luck, but there are many of us like Christopher Reeve (Anger as Superman appears to walk, February 3) who look forward to being physically as we were before.
fields.body:
All of you who are happy to live with your disability, good luck, but there are many of us like Christopher Reeve (Anger as Superman appears to walk, February 3) who look forward to being physically as we were before. I have been inspired by Christopher Reeve and the courage he has shown appearing in public to promote spinal research. If the TV ad helped raise money for this research and even if it raises false hope in me, I could happily live with that. When I was seeking treatment for my disability, I was continually given false hope by well-meaning individuals, but I understand that out of the good of their hearts they were trying to help me and ultimately did me no harm.
Maureen Cook
Epsom
Surrey

webTitle: You've never had it so good

fields.headline: You've never had it so good
fields.trailText: Is the UK heading back to full employment? BT grabbed the headlines this week with the grim news that it is to slash 3,000 managerial jobs, yet the other headline which will scream out later this year is when unemployment  falls below one million.
fields.body:
Elateral, a fast-growing software company in Farnham, Surrey, advertised for a secretary/personal assistant in January in the local newspaper. The company received only four replies, and when it came to interview them the following week, three had already obtained jobs elsewhere. When Elateral tried to re-advertise, the local paper said no - its pages were so stuffed with job adverts it didn't have space for more.

Is the UK heading back to full employment? BT grabbed the headlines this week with the grim news that it is to slash 3,000 managerial jobs, M&S is culling UK suppliers, threatening thousands of jobs losses, and British Airways is in a programme to cut 6,000 jobs. Yet the other headline which will scream out later this year is when unemployment (judged by the claimant count measure) falls below one million.

Several City economists, such as Dresdner, Salomon and Charterhouse, see unemployment falling below 1m by the fourth quarter of this year and as low as 800,000 next year. The UK may be a job-destroying economy, they say, but it is also undeniably a highly-successful job-creating economy too.

Evidence of a remarkable surge of jobs, even since the beginning of this year, is building up. Job advertising in the national broadsheet newspapers, after dipping at the start of 1999, rebounded in September, and is now climbing at a rate of 10-15% per month according to Media Monitoring Services. And that's not counting the growth in jobs advertised on internet sites such as the Guardian's own jobsunlimited.co.uk.

The number of vacancies posted up in Job Centres across the UK has shot to record levels, with many low-paid jobs almost impossible to fill. On average, adverts for jobs in what the employment service calls "protective service occupations", or what the rest of us call security guards, sit on Job Centre display boards in the south east for seven-and-a-half weeks before they get filled. Demand far outstrips supply.

It's not just a south east phenomenon. In the north of England, employers have to wait nearly seven weeks to find a candidate for a clerical job, twice as long as employers in the south, according to the employment service. A survey of Jobs Centres by Jobs & Money this week found positions such as bus drivers and chefs that have been left unfilled for more than six months.

Across the country the greatest demand is for "health associate professionals" such as nurses and midwives. Job centres in the south west - where the problem is worst - report average waits of almost 12 weeks before jobs cards can be taken off the board.

Essex county council hit the headlines last month when it was revealed that it is hiring social workers from South Africa to fill empty posts. Schools in West London are bussing in supply teachers daily from South Wales and hospitals are recruiting nurses from the Phillipines.

Much of this is directly attributable to low pay - unqualified social care staff typically pick up around £5 an hour, compared with £6.25 an hour sitting at a Tesco's till. Even four-year qualified social workers start on not much more than £17,000, while low-pay in nursing has landed the NHS in a near permanent recruitment crisis.

Yet staff shortages are not just a feature of low-paid jobs. An analysis of the last three months' job adverts in the national broadsheet press reveals that the fastest growing area is finance and accountancy.

Paul Taylor is a manager of the financial division of HW Group, one of the UK's top three temping agencies by market share. He says there are now 40,000 professional temps working in the City of which 65% are in the banking industry. Around one in seven are antipodean, says Mr Taylor, and without them he says the City would grind to a halt.

fields.headline: Chocolate at 20 paces
fields.standfirst: Once it would have been custard
fields.trailText: Beating even a sow called Cherie, paraded in Parliament Square, the image which caught the photographers' eye in this week of farmers' protest was the chocolate all over the face of the agriculture minister, Nick Brown.
fields.body:
Beating even a sow called Cherie, paraded in Parliament Square, the image which caught the photographers' eye in this week of farmers' protest was the chocolate all over the face of the agriculture minister, Nick Brown.

It was put there at the National Farmers' Union conference by a woman who raced up to the platform and squashed an eclair in his face. She was angry, she later claimed, at the minister's failure to stand by the beef industry or offer more money to farmers.

Though even Ann Widdecombe has yet to get round to saying so, this episode is symbolic of our country's decline. The thrusting of pastries into the faces of statesman has been practised in Britain for generations. But until quite recently the weapon of choice was almost always indigenous. And among indigenous weapons, the custard pie was king. The chocolate eclair in action on Wednesday may have been built in Britain, but eclairs are undoubtedly French. One can see the case for rejecting various home- inspired delicacies which this woman might have wielded: an Eccles cake fired from close in might have done too much damage, while the kind of rock cake which lurks for a week or more on the shelf of a tearoom could have been lethal. But no such objection is possible to, say, a cream slice with a trickle of jam dribbling out of one end.

The assailant defended her choice on the grounds that she happened to have an eclair in her bag. But that too is a sign of how cosmopolitan the pastry market is becoming, with old favourites squeezed to the margin. A mere 50 years ago, very few women would have come to an NFU conference with eclairs in their bags. Yet today, there's a choice in every supermarket of pastries reflecting the cultures of nations all over the globe. Some Greek and Turkish concoctions might almost have been designed for plastering adversaries. Mr Brown may think himself lucky that he only faced an eclair. It might have been a baklava.

fields.headline: Money down the drain
fields.trailText: Householders kept awake at night by the scratching and gnawing of uninvited guests often feel like they're in the middle of an invasion. Though the temptation to pull the covers over your head is overwhelming, ignoring pests can result in them causing damage costing hundreds of pounds to put right.
fields.body:
Householders kept awake at night by the scratching and gnawing of uninvited guests often feel like they're in the middle of an invasion. Though the temptation to pull the covers over your head is overwhelming, ignoring pests can result in them causing damage costing hundreds of pounds to put right.

Tackling infestations of mice, beetles, bees and wasps also costs, as increasing numbers of local authorities charge for services they used to offer for free or have ceased to provide altogether.

Last month the English house condition survey, carried out for the Ministry of Agriculture, revealed that almost two in every hundred homes had mice under the floorboards and at the backs of cupboards, and one in every 200 had rats.

The city comes off worse than the country when it comes to rats living alongside humans in the house. Infestations inside were more common in urban, rather than rural or suburban, areas. Communities of rats seem to thrive better outside buildings where 1.7% of homes had a problem.

No one knows whether in festation is on the rise - work has only recently begun on collecting comparable statistics. But rodents are the most common pest problem faced by householders. The danger of spreading disease means councils are legally obliged to keep the lid on the rat and mice population: relaxing the safeguards currently in place could lead to a major infestation.

A report by the Institute of Environmental Health for England and Wales, revealed the number of authorities providing a comprehensive infestation service is continuing to fall, as expected - from 74 in 1993/94 to 64 in 1997/98. Instead, many contract out services to a commercial pest control firm.

The Prevention of Damage by Pests Act was introduced during the war to protect food stocks in the countryside. Under the act local authorities have a duty to keep their districts free of rats and mice by carrying out inspections, destroying rodents on council-owned land and forcing other owner-occupiers to kill rodents too.

Rats, like humans, need food and a safe (for them) place to live and reproduce successfully. In the countryside they lurk in barns and underneath hedgerows. In cities, they use the sewers as a kind of rat Tube to get around.

Properties most at risk from high levels of rats and mice are those that are neglected or left vacant with untidy or dirty gardens. Homes with high levels of damp, in need of repair or with inadequate kitchens also suffer. Rodents also target householders who keep pets or livestock in their gardens.

The tell-tale signs include droppings, footprints and tail trails, gnawing marks and noises in wall cavities. They can get through half-inch wide gaps and are also good swimmers. More unusual pests include squirrels that can chew through cables and wires and make their home in a loft or shed.

Many pests are seasonal says Richard Strand, chief executive of the industry body the British Pest Control Association. The beginning of the summer is marked by the appearance of wasps, which can be a major problem from the end of June to the end of September. From April to the end of October we might be invaded by ants - in July, their activity peaks with the appearance of flying ants.

Bees and wasps need to be in an enclosed area before they can be treated, although not all need to be destroyed. Honey bees, living in a clump on a wall or tree, may be removed by a bee-keeper. Other bees and wasps can form nests around the home, even in chimneys.

The creatures can be destroyed but unless the nest is removed (which is sometimes impracticable) other bees may move in. If a chimney is not used then it should be covered to prevent another settlement. If human fleas are the problem, the house needs to be sprayed.

Local authority environmental health or pest control departments should be the first point of contact for anyone worried about an infestation, says the Institute of Environmental Health. If the council can't help, staff should point householders towards a contractor. What's on offer from councils varies and depends on whether or not the service is subsidised. The London borough of Wandsworth council's pest control department recently took on extra staff to cope with rising demand. On domestic premises they will tackle infestations of mice, rats, bed bugs and fleas free of charge. There are charges for dealing with other insect problems. Officers will give advice to residents dealing with foxes, pigeons and squirrels.

Daventry District Council in Northamptonshire will treat rats and mice free of charge, but charges £30 for infestations of fleas, wasps and bees. Ants, swarming flies and mortar bees can be dealt with for £30 per hour.

Mr Strand's advice for householders is don't ignore anything other than the most trivial of problems, which people can usually treat themselves. A flick through the Yellow Pages reveals a wealth of pest control companies, but Mr Strand urges consumers to take care. Anyone can set themselves up as a pest control firm: "There is no statutory certification scheme for pesticides operatives," he points out.

Pests are at the heart of one well-known con practised by so-called ladder men - cowboys who prey on old or vulnerable people. They knock on the door of a carefully picked house, pretend to have spotted a swarm or other pest activity, gain access to the loft with the pretence of checking it out, returning with something purporting to be a nest. They then charge for removing the problem.

Customers should use members of the BPCA, says Mr Strand, many of which are contracted by local authorities to carry out work on their behalf. Though self-regulating, the members abide by a code of practice governing health and safety.

fields.headline: Investment trusts go a-wooing
fields.standfirst: They're 'wunnerful', croons the singer in the advert. Paul Farrow examines the evidence
fields.trailText: As long as the Association of Investment Trust Companies has anything to do with it, the advertising strapline "its wonderful" will soon be embedded in your memory forever. It has just kicked off the second phase of a multi-million pound advertising campaign, called "its", in a bid to woo investors to investment trusts.
fields.body:
As long as the Association of Investment Trust Companies has anything to do with it, the advertising strapline "its wonderful" will soon be embedded in your memory forever. It has just kicked off the second phase of a multi-million pound advertising campaign, called "its", in a bid to woo investors to investment trusts.

The promotional push coincides with the end of the Isa season - a time awash with investors scrambling to make the most of their tax-free savings allowance before April 5. So are these savings vehicles "wunnerful", as the Italian singer Paolo Conte croons?

The "its" campaign is supposed to make us love investment trusts - and understand them better. Big gains over the past year should help this process.

The advocates of investment-trust Isas say they are a cost-effective, diversified way for investors to dabble in the stock market while spreading the risk. They should be viewed as long-term investments.

Unlike unit trusts, which divide a pooled fund of stocks and shares into equal units and then issue them to investors, investment trusts are listed on the London stock exchange and invest in other companies' shares.

But investment trusts are also close-ended, so managers are not forced to take in more money - which could force them into buying at top prices. And investors who want to take their money out must sell their shares on the stock market, so the fund managers are not forced to sell shares when they might not want to.

It is this crucial difference between a unit trust and an investment trust that creates the infamous "discount". The supply and demand effect of buying and selling a trust's shares means there is often a difference between the share price and the value of the trust's underlying assets.

When the share price is lower than the value of the trust's assets, it is said to be trading at a discount, and when it is higher - this is rare - it is said to be trading at a premium.

Michael Owen, a director at independent financial adviser Plan Invest, says: "Investment trusts can be more complex for first-time clients who are unlikely to have a grip on discounts. They do not understand that sometimes the market can go up and the trust does not because its discount widens."

Investment trusts trading at wide discounts may be tempting. A trust trading at a 20% discount on the face of it looks a bargain because it is giving you the opportunity to buy £1 worth of shares for 80p. But experts warn investors to find out why a trust appears cheap and it may be because holders are not happy with the trust and are selling their shares.

The AITC director general Daniel Godfrey says: "There are no general rules when buying an investment trust. The levels of discounts should not be the main reason for buying one." One of the purposes of the "its" campaign is to cut discounts.

But the performance of some investment trusts may also be tempting for would-be investors. For example, an outlay of £1,000 in an average UK growth investment trust a year ago would be worth £1,304 compared with the average UK growth unit trust, which is worth £1,142.

There are more than 300 investment trusts available, ranging from the low-risk to high, to those offering income or growth and some called split-caps that offer an often complicated choice between the two.

Investment trust analysts at Deutsche Bank are tipping the big well-known investment trusts such as Foreign & Colonial and Witan as the ones to watch. They invest in a wide range of shares.

It is a view shared by Mr Owen. He also believes many investment-trust Isas offer great value because they often levy lower charges than unit trusts, yet deliver at least comparable performance.

The AITC director general Daniel Godfrey says: "There are no general rules when buying an investment trust. The levels of discounts should not be the main reason for buying one." One of the purposes of the "its" campaign is to cut discounts. But the performance of some investment trusts may also be tempting for would-be investors. For example, an outlay of £1,000 in an average UK growth investment trust a year ago would be worth £1,304 compared with the average UK growth unit trust, which is worth £1,142. There are more than 300 investment trusts available, ranging from the low-risk to high, to those offering income or growth and some called split-caps that offer an often complicated choice between the two. Investment trust analysts at Deutsche Bank are tipping the big well-known investment trusts such as Foreign & Colonial and Witan as the ones to watch. They invest in a wide range of shares. It is a view shared by Mr Owen. He also believes many investment-trust Isas offer great value because they often levy lower charges than unit trusts, yet deliver at least comparable performance.

fields.headline: Funds selling like hot cakes
fields.standfirst: In a 12-page special report Jobs & Money looks at the successful rise of the individual savings account - the Isa. Ignore the doubters and knockers who still remain and take the plunge with the help of our expert guides
fields.trailText: The individual savings accounts - Isas - can seem confusing, and they offer less of a tax break for investors in equities than the personal equity plans they replaced,  writes Tony Levene .
fields.body:
The individual savings accounts - Isas - can seem confusing, and they offer less of a tax break for investors in equities than the personal equity plans they replaced, writes Tony Levene .

So it is not surprising that when Isas were launched last April they were hit by waves of criticism. "They won't sell because the tax savings are so slim," some said. "Purchasers will stay away, as they won't get their heads around the maxis and minis," said others.

But the knockers and doubters are having to eat their words. A combination of bright stock markets and rising interest rates have seen funds flow into both shares and cash Isas - the insurance Isa was always going to be small beer with only a handful of policies on sale.

The plans are selling well. And with just two months to go before the April 5 deadline for this year's Isa plans, the indications are that they could end up selling like hot cakes. But because other investors are piling in does not mean they are right for you. This Isa special report - the first of three we will publish before the end of the tax year - will guide you through the technicalities of tax-free savings and investments, point you to better opportunities and warn of potential pitfalls.

Latest figures from the inland revenue covering the first six months of the Isa scheme's life show that £12.7bn was invested in the tax-free plans. And half of that was cash Isa savings in building societies and banks. The government's hopes were that many who had never saved before would be attracted into putting some money away.

Convincing non-savers was always going to be difficult, and the evidence is that it is savers with larger sums who have rushed to take advantage of tax freedom.

The building societies gained a large market share - 953,000 accounts with an average subscription of £2,370 per account. The banks, which now include former building societies such as the Halifax and Woolwich, opened 1.5m accounts worth typically £2,400. Sales of equity-based Isas totalled £6.2bn in the six months to October. And they're looking even better now.

Figures out this week from the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds show that sales of Isas in December reached the same level as those of Peps in December 1998. There are now 2.7m stocks and share Isa owners - and more are expected. Axa Sun Life forecasts that Isa sales will soar in the last months of the tax year once the "hangover" effect of the old Peps and Tessas disappears.

It says the slow start was only to be expected as savers got to grips with the system. Many are waiting for end-of-tax-year bargains; some are visible already.

 Legal & General is waiving both the initial charge and annual management charge on a range of 13 actively managed funds and five tracker trusts until the end of this calendar year if the investment has not been sold by December 31.

 Murray Johnstone is waiving the initial account opening charge on its Investment Trust Isa - a £70 saving if the maximum £7,000 is invested.

 Norwich Union is promising superior returns or a refund of the 1% annual charge on four of its most popular funds: UK Growth, UK Index Tracking, European Equity and Higher Income Plus. A customer will collect a refund of the annual fee if any of these Cat-marked trusts fails to beat the average of comparable funds over the next year.

Much of the attraction of equity funds has been their unexpectedly sparkling performance in 1999. The new year has started with a few more wobbles, but any one putting away £5,000 a year into shares should - on past performance - be sitting on £200,000 by 2020 after allowing for inflation, according to figures from Standard Life, based on the whole of the last century.

These show there is a four out of five chance of equity money beating cash or government stocks over five years. With Isas there are no tax deductions, so what you see is what you get. The Edinburgh-based investment group calculates that the average 20th century investor would have turned £5,000 into £200,000 in 18.7 years - often faster. The past is no promise of the future. But what the Standard Life findings show is that even buying at bad moments only increases the time needed to make a fortune by a few years.

webTitle: Taking a shine to Victorian pottery

fields.headline: Taking a shine to Victorian pottery
fields.standfirst: William de Morgan re-discovered lustre glazes and at Christie's next month his work will fetch high prices, says Stewart Dalby
fields.trailText: William de Morgan was something of a renaissance man. His first novel, Joseph Vance, was hailed as the greatest of the day when it was published in 1906. By the time of his death in 1917 he was ranked alongside Hardy and Kipling. But his reputation as a writer faded and he is now best remembered as a ceramicist.
fields.body:
William de Morgan was something of a renaissance man. His first novel, Joseph Vance, was hailed as the greatest of the day when it was published in 1906. By the time of his death in 1917 he was ranked alongside Hardy and Kipling. But his reputation as a writer faded and he is now best remembered as a ceramicist.

Born in 1839, he chose to study art against the wishes of his strong-minded spiritualist parents. Realising that he had no talent for painting, he pursued an interest in pottery. In 1872 he set up a ceramics firm along the lines of that of William Morris in nearby south London. He had worked for William Morris in the 1860s and, like him, evolved a distinct repertoire of stylised foliage, birds and beasts. He has been overshadowed by Morris, but some critics consider him a better technical innovator. His most famous legacy was the re-invention of lustre (metallic, copper and ruby) glazes.

Lustre glazes date back to pre-Islamic Egypt and were used to great effect by the Hispano-Moresque and Italian Renaissance potters of the 15th and 16th centuries. The process fell into disuse and was rediscovered in 1869 or 1870.

According to his own account, de Morgan was working on stained glass windows when he was struck by the iridescence caused by the presence of silver in the outline paint after the glass had been fired. He set out to reproduce that effect on ceramic tiles and supply the hand-made tiles to a growing middle-class market. From tiles he progressed to vessels.

Christie's South Kensington is holding its first lustre ceramics sale on Friday March 4. The striking feature of the auction is that, unlike most ceramics sales which usually concentrate on one potter like, say, Clarice Cliff, or one well-known factory like Royal Doulton, this sale has items from many ceramics companies and designers from William de Morgan to the potter Alan Caiger-Smith, born in Buenos Aires in 1930.

From de Morgan there is a charger painted in ruby lustre depicting a galleon under full sail, circa 1890. This is expected to realise between £2,000 and £3,000.

During the same period Gordon Forsyth at Pilkington produced a whole range of coloured lustres for himself and artists including Richard Joyce. The Liverpool artist Walter Crane (1845-1915) also designed a small range of vases and plates in these new glazes. A charger entitled Night and Morning, designed by Crane and executed by Joyce, is estimated at £2,000-£3,000.

At Wedgwood, in contrast to the basalt jasperware designs traditionally associated with the house, Daisy Makeig-Jones (1881-1945) created a range of mystical lustre ceramics depicting elves, goblins and ghostly figures in twisted and gnarled forest kingdoms. A Malfrey pot and cover decorated in a candlemas pattern is one of the most expensive items in the sale, estimated at £10,000 to £15,000.

In the 20s and 30s Carlton Ware and Crown Devon combined the Art Deco images which were popular at the time with lustre techniques in a wide range of patterns. And after the discovery and opening of Tutankhamun's tomb by Howard Carter, Carlton Ware developed designs in matt blue, black and orange lustres depicting the king's charioteers, funeral boats and other images found in the tomb. A tomb jar and cover with a death mask finial on a blue lustre background is estimated at £4,000 to £6,000.

Christie's is holding this inaugural sale because it is a rare opportunity to appeal to different markets. Michael Jeffrey, the expert at Christie's says: "A Wedgwood collection became available at the same time as an extensive Carlton Ware one. Wedgwood is very popular in America and Carlton Ware in Australia. This is the first good opportunity to have crossover between collectors."

Finally, there are some pieces by Alan Caiger-Smith, who has been producing tin-glazed earthenware designs from his Aldermaston pottery in Devon for the past 30 years.

Prices start at around £200. But although some of the prices I have quoted seem expensive they could go higher yet. Michael Jeffrey says: "Demand is very strong. A Carlton Ware vase which typically would have cost £1,500 five years ago would now realise £4,000."

For further information telephone (020)-7321-3121.

webTitle: You can catch up if you hurry

fields.headline: You can catch up if you hurry
fields.standfirst: Penalty demands for late returns are already going out but knowing the ropes can help to avoid the worst. David Brodie advises on tactics
fields.trailText: It is estimated that 900,000 taxpayers missed this week's tax return deadline and will soon receive £100 penalty demands, but you may avoid a penalty if you know the rules,  writes David Brodie.
fields.body:
Although the official filing date was January 31, the Revenue says it will not charge a penalty if your form was received by post or handed in on February 1, or if it was found in a tax office letterbox at 7.30 am on February 2. Even if you file after that, there are three other grounds for not paying a £100 penalty.

Firstly, you may be one of the 400,000 taxpayers who were sent their forms after October 31, 1999. As the law allows you a minimum of three months to complete any return, there is no late-filing penalty if you comply within three months after the "date of issue" on the front page.

Secondly, a late-filing penalty should never exceed the tax still outstanding on the filing date. So if on January 31 you were owed a refund for 1998/99, you are safe from a penalty even if your return is late. And if you owed some tax, but less than £100, the penalty is reduced to that figure. However, the inspector cannot know your tax position until he receives the form, so you will be pursued for a £100 penalty until the return is filed and your tax liability agreed. So do get the form back as soon as possible.

Finally, you can object to a penalty if you have a reasonable excuse for delay, and you filed within 14 days of the excuse coming to an end. The law does not define "reasonable excuse", but the Revenue has listed some examples in its free booklet Self Assessment - Penalties for late tax returns (SA/BK6).

What the taxman thinks is a good excuse

 You did not receive a form

 Your completed return was lost or delayed in the post

 Loss of tax records

 Serious illness - yourself, close relative or partner

 Bereavement

What the taxman does not generally accept

 Tax return too difficult

 Pressure of work

 Failure by accountant to do the job on time

 Lack of information

 Absence of reminders from the Revenue

If you think you have a reasonable excuse, you should write to your tax office appealing against the penalty and giving the reasons for your delay.

The Revenue dislikes lengthy disputes over relatively small fines and so accepts most appeals without argument.

If the inspector rejects your excuse, he will ask you to withdraw your appeal and explain that it must otherwise be considered by the commissioners, an independent tribunal. Do not be put off! If you show determination by requesting a tribunal hearing, he may back down and cancel the penalty. And if your appeal does go to a hearing, the commissioners may well allow your appeal.

Another point to consider is whether you have paid all your tax for 1998/99. Any outstanding liability is now attracting interest at 7.5% and there is also a 'surcharge' - 5% of unpaid tax - if it is not cleared by February 28. If you owe tax for more than one year and cannot settle all of it immediately, ask for any payment to be set against the 1998/99 liability so as to reduce the surcharge. And if you cannot pay all your 1998/99 tax by February 28, ask the collector for extra time to pay the balance. If instalments are agreed before the end of this month, any surcharge should be waived.

With all the publicity about tax returns, TaxAid has received calls from several people who were worried that they had not been sent a form.

In most cases nothing needed to be done. The Revenue requires tax returns from only one in three taxpayers, typically the self-employed, company directors and higher earning employees. If you earn just an average wage or pension, which is fully taxed under pay as you earn, no return is normally required. But if in 1998/99 you had other income which was not taxed, and you did not get a form, you should send the Revenue details and arrange payment of any tax as soon as possible.

David Brodie is Director of TaxAid, the charity which provides free tax advice to people who cannot afford professional fees. Phone 0171-624-3768 between 10 am and 12 noon, Mondays to Thursdays.

webTitle: Simple rules to follow on the road to riches

fields.headline: Simple rules to follow on the road to riches
fields.standfirst: Tony Levene provides a step-by-step route map to guide investors through the savings minefield
fields.trailText: Early in April individual savings accounts will be a year old. But, as with any new baby, there can be teething troubles and complications. This quick guide should steer you through most of the problems.
fields.body:
Early in April individual savings accounts will be a year old. But, as with any new baby, there can be teething troubles and complications. This quick guide should steer you through most of the problems.

What is an Isa?

It stands for individual savings account.

What is special about it?

Savers do not pay any tax on their dividends from shares or bonds or from their interest on savings accounts. It was created by the present government to encourage savings. And if they make gains on shares, there is no capital gains tax to pay, although losses on Isas cannot be offset against gains elsewhere.

How much is the tax saving worth?

Basic-rate taxpayers would receive £80 for each £100 of interest in a taxed account and top-rate payers get £60. In an Isa, they get the whole £100. These figures also apply to bond Isas.

With shares, basic-rate taxpayers receive a special 10% tax credit and top-rate payers do even better.

Can any individual have one?

Yes - providing they are residents of the UK and aged 18 or over. Married couples can have an Isa each.

How much can I invest?

Up to £7,000 in this tax year - to April 5 2000 - and up to £5,000 in the nine subsequent tax years in which the government has promised that the scheme will run.

Do I have to invest all my money in one go?

Not necessarily. Most, though not all, product providers allow you to save monthly or to make payments when you can afford them. You cannot carry over unused Isa allowance from one tax year to the next.

Where can I place my savings?

There are literally thousands of variations of Isas. But there are three basic headings or "components":

 stocks and shares

 cash

 insurance

What are minis and maxis?

A mini is where you can choose different product providers for different components. So you could buy one, two or three mini Isas. A maxi is where you buy one, two or three components from one product provider. You cannot hold a maxi Isa in the same tax year as a mini Isa.

How much can I put into a maxi Isa?

Every investor has an overall ceiling this year of £7,000 -£5,000 in subsequent years whether they go via the maxi or the mini route. You can invest up to your limit in a maxi Isa how you wish, providing that you do not exceed £3,000 in the cash section (£1,000 in subsequent years) and £1,000 in the insurance component.

Whatever is left over can then be invested in stocks and shares. If, for instance, you were to put £500 in cash and £600 in insurance, you could then invest up to £5,900 in stocks and shares.

What are the plus points of the maxi route?

The maxi is for those who want to put the bulk of their annual allowance into equities or bonds - some Isa firms allow you to mix different types of stock and share investment.

Many stock and share opportunities are only available with the maxi label. Discount brokers often give better deals to maxi investors who are prepared to put in the maximum amount.

How much can I put into a mini Isa?

You have the same overall £7,000 limit (£5,000 after this first year) but each component has its own ceiling as well. You can invest up to £3,000 in stocks and shares, £3,000 (£1,000 after this year) in cash, and £1,000 into insurance. But you cannot carry over an unused amount from one component to another. This could cut your overall tax free saving possibilities. Saving £1 into a mini cash Isa puts you automatically on the mini-only route and limits your stocks and shares to £3,000

What are the advantages of the mini route?

Choice is the main plus point. Most of the cash Isa providers only offer a mini version.

How long do I have to keep my money in for?

There is no minimum period, although the insurance Isa works best when kept for at least three years and equity Isas could fall in price.

If you are dissatisfied with the Isa provider, you can switch to another within the same component category. If you make a withdrawal, you cannot replace the money later, so Isas are better suited to long-term saving than for those who need ready access.

Whatever is left over can then be invested in stocks and shares. If, for instance, you were to put £500 in cash and £600 in insurance, you could then invest up to £5,900 in stocks and shares. What are the plus points of the maxi route? The maxi is for those who want to put the bulk of their annual allowance into equities or bonds - some Isa firms allow you to mix different types of stock and share investment. Many stock and share opportunities are only available with the maxi label. Discount brokers often give better deals to maxi investors who are prepared to put in the maximum amount. How much can I put into a mini Isa? You have the same overall £7,000 limit (£5,000 after this first year) but each component has its own ceiling as well. You can invest up to £3,000 in stocks and shares, £3,000 (£1,000 after this year) in cash, and £1,000 into insurance. But you cannot carry over an unused amount from one component to another. This could cut your overall tax free saving possibilities. Saving £1 into a mini cash Isa puts you automatically on the mini-only route and limits your stocks and shares to £3,000 What are the advantages of the mini route? Choice is the main plus point. Most of the cash Isa providers only offer a mini version. How long do I have to keep my money in for? There is no minimum period, although the insurance Isa works best when kept for at least three years and equity Isas could fall in price. If you are dissatisfied with the Isa provider, you can switch to another within the same component category. If you make a withdrawal, you cannot replace the money later, so Isas are better suited to long-term saving than for those who need ready access.

fields.standfirst: Liz Loxton guides you through the maze of discount brokers in search of that pot of gold
fields.trailText: With the deadline for taking full advantage of the upper £7,000 limit on Isa investment coming into view, investors are looking around for the best deals.
fields.body:
With the deadline for taking full advantage of the upper £7,000 limit on Isa investment coming into view, investors are looking around for the best deals.

Those who can narrow - or even eradicate - upfront or "initial" charges have a standing start when it comes to performance. This has led to a huge demand for the services of discount brokers. They keep costs down largely by operating streamlined telephone services. The other side of the coin is that generally they keep advice to a minimum.

Hargreaves Lansdown has access to more than 1,000 different funds with initial charges from 5.25% down to 0.25% on a handful of index tracker funds. It operates by offering a discount on the fund provider's initial charge. On regular savings Isas, HL discounts the initial charge on the monthly premium by a couple of percentage points.

Tel: 0117 988 9880
hargreaveslansdown.co.uk

This means that on its 30-plus recommended funds, clients pay no initial charge, saving between 3% and 5%. Best then aims to rebate up to 0.5% of the annual management fee. Adviser line: 0171 321 0100

Financial Discounts Direct discounts both the initial charge and the annual management fee. The level of discount depends on the provider. If a customer invests the maximum £7,000 in an Invesco Isa, for example, Financial will rebate the initial charge.

Tel: 01420 549090
financial-discounts.co.uk

It has a same-day turnaround commitment, forwards rebates electronically and provides an annual report on its investors' portfolios with all funds audited on the same date. ITQ is an execution-only service with initial discounts of some 3% to 5% of the fund's value.

fields.headline: Put your trust in Europe
fields.standfirst: Financial advisers are backing non-UK funds to produce better returns, writes Tom Bawden
fields.trailText: The average European unit trust soared by 28% in the last quarter of 1999, double the increase seen in funds dedicated to the UK, according to Standard & Poor's Micropal.
fields.body:
The average European unit trust soared by 28% in the last quarter of 1999, double the increase seen in funds dedicated to the UK, according to Standard & Poor's Micropal.

But earlier lacklustre share performances and a plummeting euro meant that overall, people investing in European funds made 10% less on average than if they had stuck to UK shares.

The euro has dropped by around 15% against sterling since it was launched and that comes off any profits you make in European stocks.

Yet most financial advisers swear by Europe. They say the slow start to 1999 was just a blip. The prolonged fight over Vodafone AirTouch's £107.5bn takeover of German telecommunications giant Mannesmann could prove a watershed. If successful, it will be the first time a foreign company has acquired a German one against its will - and it could prompt a raft of cross-border mergers that will push up share prices.

The proposal to abolish Germany's 50% capital gains tax - a major deterrent to equity sales - would free up capital that could be redirected into promising companies.

Europe is now going through the privatisation mania last seen in Britain in the 80s. Public offerings such as Deutsche Telekom and the Dutch post office are widening share choice and more Europeans than ever are taking out private pensions.

Colin Lunnon, senior research analyst at advisory broker Killick & Co, says: "Pension funds have more money to play with now bond yields are declining, which means they are shifting their investments from bonds to equities. They are pushing at corporations and governments to foster an environment which will maximise share prices."

If you factor in a low inflation rate of around 2.5%, predicted growth of 3% and a predicted rise in the euro, Europe does indeed seem like a good place for funds.

Funds investing in European stocks are governed by the same rules and subject to the same risks as those dedicated to the UK. Virtually all are "Isable", which means they can be wrapped in a tax-free individual savings account.

Brokers advise taking out a unit trust that covers a spread of shares. They tip the media, telecoms and technology sectors, where Europe boasts world-beaters such as Nokia and Ericsson in phones, and Novartis and Glaxo Wellcome in pharmaceuticals. They believe these groups are still undervalued compared with their US competitors.

Colin Lunnon at Killick & Co recommends the Invesco GT European Growth fund while Mark Dampier of Hargreaves Lansdown tips the Gartmore European Selected Opportunities fund. B> Leading performers

webTitle: Fishing for funds? Cast the net wide

fields.headline: Fishing for funds? Cast the net wide
fields.standfirst: Patrick Sherwen trawls through the methods of finding the right financial product online
fields.trailText: When looking for a financial product on the internet there are three possible routes to take. You could:
fields.body:
When looking for a financial product on the internet there are three possible routes to take. You could:

1. Stick in the name of your favourite financial services firm in the address field, and see what it has to offer;
2. Type the name of the product into a search engine;
3. Turn to the directory of an online money page.

The first option is fine if you have extensively surveyed the market. The second option may turn up the goods but can lead to sites for companies with no business in Britain.

The third has the benefit of offering some kind of filter. although this is by no means a guarantee of quality - the onus is still on the investors to shop around for a good deal.

A convenient place to start is Find www.find.co.uk, an online financial directory. Bringing the homepage up on screen produces a "Find an Isa" icon which will take the user straight to the list of equity Isa managers.The main thing to remember when buying a stocks and shares Isa is that, although the tax advantage may be tempting, like any other investment the most important factors are the investment performance and the risk profile. The Find site takes some pain out of this by presenting the net user with a list of firms that offer funds through Isas.

At the lower risk end of the spectrum, but with strong performance against its sector (UK All Companies) is ABN Amro's UK Growth unit trust managed by Nigel Thomas, manager of the best-performing fund in the sector, Solus UK Special Situations. Click on the link for ABN Amro and once through the warnings - the user is presented with a simple list of products. Whichever is selected leads to electronic documents that can be printed or downloaded. These include factsheets on each fund and an application form. This must be posted, along with a cheque, in the conventional way.

Among the more exciting, and by the same token more risky, funds available over the net through an Isa is the Framlington NetNet fund. Since this fund's portfolio is based on internet and internet-related stocks, it is disappointing it is not directly on sale online, though it does have its own website. It has an online brochure and application form can be printed off and posted.

To do everything electronically, you need to turn to groups such as M&G and Johnson Fry, some of whose funds can be bought directly on the net. There are no forms to fill in and you can transfer your money through cyberspace from your bank account via a debit card. But you cannot use a credit card.

When it comes to cash Isas, the first thing to look for is a high interest rate. Skipton building society offers a superior top rate - at 7.2% on £3,000 minimum - to those without stepped rates www.skipton.co.uk A site menu takes the user straight to an information page on the mini-cash Isa. But the next stage is not immediately clear - the "Request a pack" icon could be more prominent, and when you find it it simply requests a brochure by mail and offers no online application facility.

Philanthropists may be attracted by the 0.5% donation each cash Isa investor can make to the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, which is deducted from their interest payments.

The best rate available over the net for a £1 investment, which also happens to be the best on the market, is from Coventry Building Society at 7.25%, but this is only available to existing customers.

All comers are welcome though at Julian Hodge Bank, Leeds & Holbeck and Smile, which all offer 6.75% APR through their websites. You can locate all these on Find.

fields.headline: EU tightens aid screw
fields.standfirst: Brussels links £8.5bn package for poorest countries to clamp down on immigration
fields.trailText: The European Union has forced 71 of the world's poorest countries to accept draconian new immigration rules in exchange for renewing an £8.5bn aid and trade package.
fields.body:
The European Union has forced 71 of the world's poorest countries to accept draconian new immigration rules in exchange for renewing an £8.5bn aid and trade package.

The countries, mostly former colonies in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, will be required to take back any illegal immigrants who reach the EU from their shores, even if they are not resident in that country. It is the first time that trade has been linked to the EU's tough immigration regime.

Negotiations over the replacement for the Lomé agreement, which offers aid and preferential market access to the African, Caribbean and Pacific countries began in 1998. The sticking points have been over the regional free trade agreements which are to replace the special access ACP countries enjoy under Lomé, and the immigration clause which the EU threw in at the last minute.

EU development commissioner Poul Nielson said yesterday that the pact was "the biggest financial and political framework for north-south cooperation in the world".

But development agencies said it was a flawed deal which would force the ACP countries to expose their infant industries to competition from established EU companies. The ACP countries export a range of basic commodities and food to Europe under the existing agreement.

The new agreement, say the agencies, is worth less in real terms than the present pact which expires at the end of this month, and it requires the ACP countries to open their markets to European companies in exchange for continuing preferential access to EU markets.

"This is definitely not a generous deal," said Phil Bloomer, an aid and trade expert at Oxfam. "This is the minimum necessary for the ACP countries to walk away from the table with dignity."

But the commission denied that the EU was "pandering" to certain views in Europe. "We have a genuine breakthrough in returning illegals back to their countries of origin, it is an enormous step forward," Mr Nielson said.

The new agreement will see a radical overhaul of the existing aid-and-trade package, signed in 1975 in Lomé, Togo. The Lomé provisions offer non-reciprocal special access to ACP countries' goods which the EU has claimed need to be transferred into two-way free trade agreements in order to comply with World Trade Organisation rules.

Under the new deal, the ACP countries will be required gradually to lower their tariff barriers affecting goods from the EU.

However, trade experts said this could have a disastrous impact on small producers in the ACP countries and it would have been possible for the EU to win an extension of the WTO waiver for existing Lomé provisions.

"This was a threat to make the ACP countries agree to free trade agreements," Mr Bloomer said. Other western countries with one-way special trade arrangements with developing countries had obtained WTO waivers.

A greater commitment to fight fraud is also part of the new package. The EU wants the ACP countries to crack down on corruption and financial mismanagement in exchange for aid.

"The new deal will see a radical reform, with increased efficiencies. Aid will be based on need and performance," said Bernard Petit, a senior EU commission official.

webTitle: How you can savour the dot.com flavour

fields.headline: How you can savour the dot.com flavour
fields.trailText: After the strict, mainly UK investment stance of Peps, Isas have freed the investor to look at worldwide markets for growth opportunities, bringing more exotic possibilities than the average UK or European blue chip fund.
fields.body:
After the strict, mainly UK investment stance of Peps, Isas have freed the investor to look at worldwide markets for growth opportunities, bringing more exotic possibilities than the average UK or European blue chip fund.

This coincides nicely with the mouth-watering opportunities apparently awaiting us all in the technology sector. But investors must ask themselves whether the new technology is a flash in the pan, or, as the experts say, the driver of an investment revolution that warrants the often giddy share price levels associated with a dot.com.

Technology and specialist funds have left their mark on the unit trust industry. In the early 80s, the commodity sector had a final flush before gold lost its glitter. Then we had one-country European funds, The late 90s have seen the rise of the internet, and biotechnology developments. For Craig Walton, group marketing director at specialist fund manager Framlington, there are worldwide trends in favour of specialist funds. Technology, he says, may be moving fast but it has an incalculable distance to go. Traffic on the internet doubles every 100 days. These particular fund flavours of the month are "huge global trends, not passing fads".

If convinced, don't plunge into what may be a market ripe for a "correction" - polite market jargon for a fall. The following are some points to consider:

Isn't it already too late to invest in these funds? No one is suggesting that specialist funds will keep growing at their present rate. After 100% growth in 1999, few expect a repeat, though the market could average 20% long-term
. The ride will be volatile, so smaller Isa investors should spread risk by making small regular savings.
Look for an Isa from a group that offers a range of trusts, including specialists. You can spread your Isa cash among blue chips, hot stocks and bonds.
If all your holdings are in the UK and Europe, it is unlikely you will have a high weighting in technology, since the leading world market for these stocks is the US. International diversification is essential.
Specialist funds are more likely than most to be volatile. So expect to hold on to them for the long term - and be prepared for a rollercoaster ride.

fields.headline: How to...Drive a lorry
fields.trailText: Guy Browning
fields.body:
Most people never get to see lorry drivers. Generally, when you overtake a lorry, all you can see of the driver is their forearm. The reason why this part of their body is always visible is because they drive with their stomach, which they rest on the steering wheel.

In order to keep their stomachs roadworthy, lorry drivers stop at transport cafes and eat meals that come straight from the pages of Department of Health warning leaflets. Lorry drivers also like to use the chain of mobile eateries called Hot Snacks Mile Ahead, which consist of a man in a lay-by experimenting with advanced forms of E. coli , BSE and the Black Death.

To pass the time, lorry drivers like to play chicken with their wing mirrors, and pass each other at 60mph on country lanes with a good inch to spare between them.

Lorries have a lot more gears than cars, which is why they won't thank you for stopping unnecessarily (to a lorry driver, 'stopping unnecessarily' means anywhere between here and Portugal). Being on the road all the time, lorries tend to get very dirty. This is where the lorry driver's sense of humour comes out: white-van man will write 'Clean me' on the back of his vehicle; a lorry driver, on the other hand, will put 'Your skid stops here'. Lorry drivers see themselves as knights of the road, and indulge in elaborate courtly rituals when they pass each other. These involve a combination of flashing headlights and hazards. It doesn't mean, however, that the 40-ton Scania Turbo Intercooler flashing eight sets of lights at you is complimenting you on your driving.

On the back of some lorries, there is a little sign that says 'How's My Driving?' with a phone number underneath. Handling a colossal lorry is hard enough without do-gooders in Citroëns complaining about your driving, so if you do call this line, don't be surprised if 40 tons of loose cattle feed are deposited on your front lawn shortly afterwards.

There's a limit to how free- spirited lorry drivers can be, thanks to the tachograph, or 'spy in the cab'. This is like having your mother sitting in the passenger seat, her eyes permanently glued to the speedometer, wincing every time you touch the speed limit. After eight hours of driving on the limit, lorry drivers then have to reverse an 80ft articulated lorry into a goods entrance the size of your garage.

In other words, if you like eating well, driving at 90mph and have trouble parallel parking, this job is not for you.

The reason why this part of their body is always visible is because they drive with their stomach, which they rest on the steering wheel. In order to keep their stomachs roadworthy, lorry drivers stop at transport cafes and eat meals that come straight from the pages of Department of Health warning leaflets. Lorry drivers also like to use the chain of mobile eateries called Hot Snacks Mile Ahead, which consist of a man in a lay-by experimenting with advanced forms of E. coli , BSE and the Black Death. To pass the time, lorry drivers like to play chicken with their wing mirrors, and pass each other at 60mph on country lanes with a good inch to spare between them. Lorries have a lot more gears than cars, which is why they won't thank you for stopping unnecessarily (to a lorry driver, 'stopping unnecessarily' means anywhere between here and Portugal). Being on the road all the time, lorries tend to get very dirty. This is where the lorry driver's sense of humour comes out: white-van man will write 'Clean me' on the back of his vehicle; a lorry driver, on the other hand, will put 'Your skid stops here'. Lorry drivers see themselves as knights of the road, and indulge in elaborate courtly rituals when they pass each other. These involve a combination of flashing headlights and hazards. It doesn't mean, however, that the 40-ton Scania Turbo Intercooler flashing eight sets of lights at you is complimenting you on your driving. On the back of some lorries, there is a little sign that says 'How's My Driving?' with a phone number underneath. Handling a colossal lorry is hard enough without do-gooders in Citroëns complaining about your driving, so if you do call this line, don't be surprised if 40 tons of loose cattle feed are deposited on your front lawn shortly afterwards. There's a limit to how free- spirited lorry drivers can be, thanks to the tachograph, or 'spy in the cab'. This is like having your mother sitting in the passenger seat, her eyes permanently glued to the speedometer, wincing every time you touch the speed limit. After eight hours of driving on the limit, lorry drivers then have to reverse an 80ft articulated lorry into a goods entrance the size of your garage. In other words, if you like eating well, driving at 90mph and have trouble parallel parking, this job is not for you.

fields.headline: Moonstruck
fields.standfirst:
Today, Nasa is ridiculed for its multiple failures, and the astronauts who carved its reputation 30 years ago have faded from popular memory. But, for the photographer Steve Pyke, those once great space missions have become ever more intriguing. Report by Sean O'Hagan

Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Today, Nasa is ridiculed for its multiple failures, and the astronauts who carved its reputation 30 years ago have faded from popular memory. But, for the photographer Steve Pyke, those once great space missions have become ever more intriguing. Report by Sean O'Hagan
fields.body:
On July 20, 1969, the collective imagination of the planet was captured by the grainy black-and-white images of Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin walking on the moon. On a family holiday in Bettystown, County Louth, my childish thoughts were focused not on the two indistinct figures beamed back from the planet's surface, but on the other guy; the one left behind in the spaceship circling above them, waiting in limbo for what must have seemed like an eternity for the safe return of his comrades.

Michael Collins, the astronaut in question, occupied a special place in my adolescent imagination because he had the same name as the charismatic Irish civil-war hero, later immortalised on celluloid in Neil Jordan's film. The other Michael Collins, though, missed out on the great symbolic moment, yet his role in the unfolding drama seemed to me the most heroic, certainly the most lonely, of all. "Collins moved through a continual succession of sun-drenched lunar day, soft earthlight, and unyielding blackness," writes Andrew Chaikin, in his extraordinarily detailed and evocative book about the Apollo missions, Man On The Moon. "For 48 minutes out of each orbit, from Loss of Signal to Acquisition of Signal, he knew a solitude unprecedented in human history."

Collins was alone in the Columbia spacecraft for 22 hours. In the event, he did not even get to hear the most famous words uttered in the 20th century. As Neil Armstrong stepped on to the lunar surface - "That's one small step for man..." then, that Shakespearian pause, "...one giant leap for mankind" - the Columbia had just slipped behind the far side of the moon and he had lost the moon-earth-moon link-up engineered by mission control for his benefit. By the time he reappeared, Armstrong and Aldrin were planting the American flag on the Sea of Tranquillity, but a technical fault kept him cut off. While an estimated 600 million people on planet earth watched and listened, transfixed, the man closest to those momentous events could, literally and symbolically, only imagine them.

Reading Chaikin's book brought home to me the full responsibility and risk of the Apollo adventures: Apollo 1 caught fire and its crew - Grissom, White and Chaffee - had perished barely two years before the successful moon landing. It was a tragedy that had been all but expunged from America's collective memory, but one that must have haunted the astronauts who followed in their footsteps. If disaster had struck Apollo 11 - say, if the Eagle, the landing craft, had malfunctioned during its take-off from the moon, or if it had later failed to dock with the Columbia craft - Collins would have had to do the unthinkable: leave his partners behind and journey back to earth alone. For the rest of his life, he would have had to carry an impossibly heavy burden: the loss of his friends and fellow adventurers, and the death of the greatest of all American dreams. It would have been a disaster with implications we can barely imagine.

Did he allow the unthinkable to cross his mind as he floated silently in space some 60 miles above the surface of the moon? Apparently not. Soon after the event, Collins published his diary of that time in limbo, fragments of which read like a work of almost metaphysical intensity, yet contain no traces of uncertainty regarding the precariousness of his mission: "I am alone, now, truly alone, and absolutely isolated from any known life," he wrote. "I am it. If a count were taken, the score would be three billion plus two over on the other side of the moon, and one plus God knows what on this side. I feel this powerfully - not as fear or loneliness - but as awareness, anticipation, satisfaction, confidence, almost exultation. I like."

That, in essence, was what Tom Wolfe would later call the Right Stuff: self-belief, certitude and - "I am it" - pure ego.

The photographer Steve Pyke grew up, like me, transfixed by America's great adventure in space. As the years passed and appreciation of that great adventure seemed to diminish in the collective consciousness, his curiosity about it - and the men who undertook it - grew. "It has," he says, "taken me 30 years to absorb what they did and to make sense of it, not just as a scientific achievement but as the last truly heroic human adventure. It was a singular moment when a few individuals carried the whole world's hopes and aspirations. I just wanted to meet these guys, as much as anything, because they were myth- makers, adventurers, pioneers. I think you can feel that off them, their sense of destiny, the sense that they were, and remain, part of an elect. It's a palpable energy - an aura, almost. They come into a room and the atmosphere changes. But there's also something else, something more elusive and almost sad. What they achieved was truly awe-inspiring, and, in a way, they have had to live in the shadow of that moment ever since. That's a heavy weight to carry."

Pyke never got to meet Collins, who declined to be photographed for personal reasons - he had just lost his son - nor Armstrong, who now fiercely protects his privacy and has retreated to a remote home in native rural Ohio, but he did photograph and talk to the other Apollo 11 astronaut, Aldrin, as well as 10 other men who had been in outer space. He asked each of them what space meant to them and, unsurprisingly, garnered some interesting answers.

"I was ordered to Washington DC in 1959 to listen to overtures about going into space in a capsule on top of a rocket," replied Wally Schirra, whose career spanned both the Gemini and Apollo missions. "I was not interested, and I lost interest completely when it was added that they would launch monkeys and chimpanzees first. Later, I realised that, as a fighter pilot, if I wanted to go higher, faster and farther, this was the way. I left earth three times and found no other place to go. Please take care of Spaceship Earth."

To Pyke's surprise, he found that many of the space pioneers had, like Yuri Gagarin before them, been treated shabbily by the government that was, simultaneously, holding them up as the ultimate exemplars of the American dream. "Armstrong was sent out on extraordinary meet-and-greet itineraries, doing maybe 15 interviews a day as well as speeches, but nobody really looked after him. He was booked into scuzzy hotels, often he didn't have time to eat all day."

If Armstrong took his destiny in hand and retreated voluntarily from the glare of celebrity, Buzz Aldrin had an altogether more difficult time: he struggled with both manic depression and alcoholism before finding a new role as, according to Chaikin, "a one-man think tank, designing everything from new launch vehicles to scenarios for returning to the moon". Charlie Duke, the tenth man to walk on the moon, went the other way and set up his own church in Texas. In all there have been six successful missions to the moon, and 12 men have walked on it.

"They all have extraordinary egos," says Pyke, "but that goes with the turf, I guess. Whatever, to me they are heroic men in the real sense of the word. They took extraordinary risks and what they did was, literally and metaphorically, out of this world. I've photographed enough celebrities to see first-hand how devalued and diminished the notion of heroism has become, but these guys were the real thing and they made me feel like a star-struck kid."

Pyke also photographed the Nasa back-up teams and, in the process, uncovered a plethora of old technical instruments - some were gathering dust in cupboards, but all have acquired an almost talismanic quality not because of their often extraordinary functions but because of where they have been. There is the Apollo 11 sample box, for transporting moon rock, the hammer that astronaut Al Bean used to chip those samples from lunar craters and ridges, and a strange, vice-like tool that turned out to be Tom Stafford's water dispenser.

Pyke also discovered that each astronaut was allowed to take into space a PPK - Personal Preference Kit - in which he could carry objects of his choice up to a certain weight. "Many of them brought cheap rings and medals, rolls of dimes, books of stamps, things they could give away to their friends and family when they returned: small things invested with huge meaning because they'd been to the moon and back."

Rusty Schweickart, known to his compatriots as "the hippy astronaut" because he preferred to listen to the Grateful Dead in space rather than the regulation country-and-western recordings, brought a collection of quotations by John and Robert Kennedy, the Dalai Lama, Walt Whitman and Elizabeth Barrett Browning. He secretly attached them to the inside of his spacesuit, and they were there with him when he walked out of Apollo 9 into space.

Schweickart also experienced something that no other astronaut, before or since, has: because of a technical hitch that occurred just as he stepped outside the craft, he had to wait for five minutes while it was corrected. Instead of working at his tasks quickly and intensely, as he had been trained to, he suddenly had breathing space, time to try and take in where he was, what he was doing. He held on to the rail of Apollo 9 and - for five long minutes - glided through the vastness and silence of space. Below him he could see America drift by, and even, after a while, make out southern California, where he lived. It was a life-changing moment, and, like the rest of them, Schweickart has, to some degree, lived in the shadow of that moment ever since.

In a whole other way, so have we. What strikes me, in retrospect, about the great lunar adventure is how quickly we - the human race - processed it and, more troublingly, lost interest in it. "The whole Apollo mission was born of a time of great idealism and optimism," says Pyke, "even though it was located within the political drama of the cold war. The country had a charismatic president, John F Kennedy, who voiced the dream, and also used it to bolster his own self image. But they went ahead and did it. That's the essential thing which maybe we have lost. By the time it came to pass, that reservoir of idealism had been used up, by the war in Vietnam, by the turmoil at home. By the time of Apollo 13, there were no more live broadcasts, unless there was trouble or impending tragedy. People were saying, 'We've been to the moon - so what?' The stuff that was happening on earth had diminished our sense of wonder to that degree."

Now, with the 20th century over, perhaps we can look back and sense how much history was being made back in the 60s, that most criticised decade. Some people still maintain that the Apollo adventure was simply a collective American ego trip in the context of the cold war; that it was an empty gesture, which, ultimately, did not benefit mankind in any real way. But for me and, I suspect, Steve Pyke, not to mention nearly everyone else who came of age at the time, that black-and-white view is both reductive and cynical when set against the lingering sense of wonder that neither time nor experience has diminished.

The last word goes to Frank Borman, who journeyed into space on Apollo 8: "My experience on Apollo 8 helped me to see how isolated and fragile our earth really is. It was also beautiful. It was the only object in the entire universe that was neither black nor white."

fields.headline: Eating out
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort can't resist a Greek bearing the most wonderful gifts in east London
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort can't resist a Greek bearing the most wonderful gifts in east London
fields.body:
Let me be clear about one thing right away. I like The Real Greek; really, really like it. I like the look of the place. I like the feel of the place. I like the food - tremendously so. I like the unrepentantly all-Greek wine list. I like the service. I like the open-plan kitchen, the well-worn wooden floor, the comfort of the chairs, the cream-and-brown paintwork, and the frame to the big picture window looking out on to the calm of Hoxton Market. I like the way it balances between novelty chic and old-fashioned comfort. I like its prices. I even quite like Hoxton.

I think that just about wraps things up, so you might want to ring up now and book right away, or pass on to something else. Oh, all right then: a word of explanation might be in order.

Hoxton is one of those coming bits of London with which taxi drivers have a lot of trouble. Either they don't want to go there or, once they get you there, they are inclined to drop you off at one Hoxton Market, when you really want to go to the other Hoxton Market. Hoxton is unique, I think, in the British Isles, in having two markets, only one of which is really a market in the sense of selling things, but both of which appear to exist only to confuse taxi drivers and to confound the unwary. That was certainly the impression that Celimene got when she tried to make her way to The Real Greek. She was reduced to being talked in on her mobile from the Holiday Inn around the corner (down the road from Old Street underground station, for those of us more used to public transport).

The moving spirit behind The Real Greek is Theodore Kyriakou, who has a bit of form behind him. He first came to general notice when he opened the splendid Livebait in Waterloo, which built up a formidable reputation for rather outré treatments of fish, before selling on to the Chez Gerard group (since when the standards have rather slipped). Theodore is Greek in antecedents. No surprise there. Hitherto, Greek cooking has not been terribly well served by most of its practitioners here. No, hitherto Greece figured just above Malta and Baffin Island at the bottom of my own personal league table of culinary cultures.

No longer. Kyriakou has dipped into the treasure chest of Greek regional and domestic cooking, subjected his discoveries to the transforming power of his eye and technical skill, and come up with a sequence of aces. The menu is divided into four parts. Mezedes, which are not unlike the mezze of North Africa, being a series of nibbles, here grouped in combinations of three or four elements: tuna cured with eastern spices, lady's thighs meatballs, and bean stew cooked in the oven is one example; kalamata olives, purée of yellow split peas from Santorini, salami from Lefkes and mature feta cheese is another. You can take a selection of these, if you fancy, or just one grouping as a first course.

Then there are small dishes - real first courses, if you like: Cretan-style octopus stifado with kritharaki-rice pasta and grated kefalotiri, or spinach and feta pie from Epirus. Then the main courses: roast neck of lamb, smoked pork and spicy beef sausages with a bean casserole or roast fillet of fish Spetsai-style with a warm salad of cauliflower and broccoli with ricotta dressing. And for pudding, how about rose-petal meringue roulade filled with blackberry-scented manouri to mop up whatever hunger you have left?

I had, in fact, ordered by the time Celimene poled up and, out of a desire to keep things simple, I think, she ordered exactly the same as I had - that is, a mixed mezede of barbecued squid with olive oil and lemon juice, and home-salted fillet of cod with mashed-potato-and-garlic aïoli and roast beetroot, followed by beef shin cooked in its own consommé, with vegetables and potatoes in a mustard mayonnaise, olive oil and lemon juice dressing - striking out on her own only when it came to the pudding, which we will come to all in good time.

The mixed mezede was a delight. The squid had that delicious hint of caramel and taut tenderness that comes only when you hit very fresh fish with exactly the right degree of fierce heat. The fat finger of salted cod was encased in a crisp, light batter, a kind of Greek tempura. The potato-laden aïoli was heady with lemon juice, while a slab of golden beetroot and two smaller slices of the ordinary red variety added a note of earthy sweetness. This food wasn't the higher reaches of invention. It wasn't pushing back the boundaries of taste, or even laying down a challenge to the eater. It was just beautifully judged and a joy to eat.

The same could be said of the shin of beef arrangement. The consommé was as clear and cleanly flavoured as the most exacting old-school chef could wish for, and generous hunks of beef shin floated in it, along with the veg. Beef shin is one of the cheaper cuts but, when braised long and slow, it takes on a gentle fibrous softness, a luscious floppiness, that I find quite irresistible. You may stumble across the odd bit of thew or gristle, sure, but these are easily put to one side.

Celimene was well into her stride by this time, and we were well into a bottle of Satirikon from the Peloponnese. Greek wine is a foreign country to me, but the staff were more than ready to offer guidance. The Satirikon, which I'd ordered mainly on account of its name, managed to be both pretty alcoholic and quite refreshing at the same time. Or maybe it was the alcohol that was refreshing.

At this point, Celimene and I parted company: she to karidopita, a roll of filo pastry stuffed with pistachios, almonds and walnuts, with yoghurt; I to loukoumades, or honey-soaked doughnuts served with a pear-and-apple compte and yoghurt. To judge by the speed with which Celimene wolfed down her Greek-style nut brittle, you'd have thought she hadn't eaten anything else. I lingered as far as I was able over each tiny honey-soaked baba, cleared the mouth with a little compte and then limbered up with a spoonful of yoghurt before dipping back again. This was serious pudding time.

It was time to pay up and head out into Hoxton again, too. The bill came to £86.95, of which £52.30 was food and the rest made up of the usual other matters (the Satirikon came out at £21.65). This is comfortably above what you would expect to pay at your average Greek taverna. But then, The Real Greek is as far removed from those establishments as Ivana Trump is from the realms of reality, and it's worth every penny
