Theodore is Greek in antecedents. No surprise there. Hitherto, Greek cooking has not been terribly well served by most of its practitioners here. No, hitherto Greece figured just above Malta and Baffin Island at the bottom of my own personal league table of culinary cultures. No longer. Kyriakou has dipped into the treasure chest of Greek regional and domestic cooking, subjected his discoveries to the transforming power of his eye and technical skill, and come up with a sequence of aces. The menu is divided into four parts. Mezedes, which are not unlike the mezze of North Africa, being a series of nibbles, here grouped in combinations of three or four elements: tuna cured with eastern spices, lady's thighs meatballs, and bean stew cooked in the oven is one example; kalamata olives, purée of yellow split peas from Santorini, salami from Lefkes and mature feta cheese is another. You can take a selection of these, if you fancy, or just one grouping as a first course. Then there are small dishes - real first courses, if you like: Cretan-style octopus stifado with kritharaki-rice pasta and grated kefalotiri, or spinach and feta pie from Epirus. Then the main courses: roast neck of lamb, smoked pork and spicy beef sausages with a bean casserole or roast fillet of fish Spetsai-style with a warm salad of cauliflower and broccoli with ricotta dressing. And for pudding, how about rose-petal meringue roulade filled with blackberry-scented manouri to mop up whatever hunger you have left? I had, in fact, ordered by the time Celimene poled up and, out of a desire to keep things simple, I think, she ordered exactly the same as I had - that is, a mixed mezede of barbecued squid with olive oil and lemon juice, and home-salted fillet of cod with mashed-potato-and-garlic aïoli and roast beetroot, followed by beef shin cooked in its own consommé, with vegetables and potatoes in a mustard mayonnaise, olive oil and lemon juice dressing - striking out on her own only when it came to the pudding, which we will come to all in good time. The mixed mezede was a delight. The squid had that delicious hint of caramel and taut tenderness that comes only when you hit very fresh fish with exactly the right degree of fierce heat. The fat finger of salted cod was encased in a crisp, light batter, a kind of Greek tempura. The potato-laden aïoli was heady with lemon juice, while a slab of golden beetroot and two smaller slices of the ordinary red variety added a note of earthy sweetness. This food wasn't the higher reaches of invention. It wasn't pushing back the boundaries of taste, or even laying down a challenge to the eater. It was just beautifully judged and a joy to eat. The same could be said of the shin of beef arrangement. The consommé was as clear and cleanly flavoured as the most exacting old-school chef could wish for, and generous hunks of beef shin floated in it, along with the veg. Beef shin is one of the cheaper cuts but, when braised long and slow, it takes on a gentle fibrous softness, a luscious floppiness, that I find quite irresistible. You may stumble across the odd bit of thew or gristle, sure, but these are easily put to one side. Celimene was well into her stride by this time, and we were well into a bottle of Satirikon from the Peloponnese. Greek wine is a foreign country to me, but the staff were more than ready to offer guidance. The Satirikon, which I'd ordered mainly on account of its name, managed to be both pretty alcoholic and quite refreshing at the same time. Or maybe it was the alcohol that was refreshing. At this point, Celimene and I parted company: she to karidopita, a roll of filo pastry stuffed with pistachios, almonds and walnuts, with yoghurt; I to loukoumades, or honey-soaked doughnuts served with a pear-and-apple compte and yoghurt. To judge by the speed with which Celimene wolfed down her Greek-style nut brittle, you'd have thought she hadn't eaten anything else. I lingered as far as I was able over each tiny honey-soaked baba, cleared the mouth with a little compte and then limbered up with a spoonful of yoghurt before dipping back again. This was serious pudding time. It was time to pay up and head out into Hoxton again, too. The bill came to £86.95, of which £52.30 was food and the rest made up of the usual other matters (the Satirikon came out at £21.65). This is comfortably above what you would expect to pay at your average Greek taverna. But then, The Real Greek is as far removed from those establishments as Ivana Trump is from the realms of reality, and it's worth every penny

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Long on flavour - oxtail
fields.trailText: Long on flavour - oxtail
fields.body:
The subject
Bovine coccygeal vertebrae. Winter-warmer sans pareil - and proof that cheap need not mean nasty.

The basics
Think of flies, and you'll understand oxtail: incessant swish-swishing at the loathsome insects builds up powerful muscle; on the plate, this translates into tough, flavourful meat. But there's more to oxtail than muscle. There are the vertebrae, cushioned on both ends by a pad of collagen, about which more in a mo'.

The details
Since tails taper, pieces of oxtail range in size from thumb-like to fist-like. The biggest piece, where tail meets sacrum, is scrappy and irregular. Some tails are fat-free, others need a serious trim. Normally, you'll be sold a whole tail, or a selection of pieces in different sizes. No matter. They're all good. And the cooking's as easy as falling off a log - but a lot more rewarding. Brown in hot oil. Put in a heavy pot with plenty of fluid and whatever flavourings take your fancy.

Bring to a boil, then lower the heat to a simmer (low oven by choice) and go to sleep. After a long time, the braised meat is tender and the collagen is lip-gluing gelatin. Yum. Oxtail is almost impossible to overcook, and likes being reheated and frozen. It also likes garlic, wine (any colour), bacon, tinned tomatoes, any dried herb, onions, citrus peel, Chinese things. Reserve plate-space for: something starchy to soak up the braising liquid.

Reserve contempt for: recipes that want the oxtail boned. OTT recipe: Paul Heathcote's Char-Grilled Cutlet of Beef with Braised Oxtail Casserole, Horseradish Potatoes, Mustard Cream and Ale Sauce (see his Rhubarb And Black Pudding, Fourth Estate). Sensible recipe: Marcella Hazan's Oxtail alla Vaccinara (see her The Essentials of Italian Cooking, Macmillan).

The easy way out
You've already got it.

Where to buy
The butcher's your best bet - most supermarkets don't bother. Expect to pay £1-2 a pound.

fields.headline: Kid's stuff
fields.trailText: Mediterranean vegetables and mint pesto
fields.body:
Mediterranean vegetables and mint pesto
The perfect accompaniment to the polenta cakes in last week's column.

For the vegetables
150g mixed peppers
50g courgettes
60g aubergines
75g red onions
60g sun-dried tomatoes
15g garlic, finely chopped
15ml olive oil
30ml passata (sieved tomato)

For the mint pesto
25g pistachios, shelled and skinned
60g fresh mint leaves
50ml groundnut oil
1 garlic clove, peeled

Preheat the oven to 220C/425F/gas mark 7. Brush the peppers with oil, and bake for 15-20 minutes, until the skin is black and blistered. Place in a covered bowl to cool, then peel. Cut the pepper, courgette, aubergine, onion and tomato into 1.5cm chunks. Next, make the mint pesto. Place the ingredients in a food processor, and blend roughly. Set aside.

To finish, sauté the vegetables and garlic in olive oil until tender. Remove from the heat, and toss in a little pesto. Mix in half the passata, season, and keep warm. To serve, shallow-fry the polenta cakes in butter until golden, then place in the centre of each plate. Spoon over the veg, drizzle the remaining pesto and passata around.

 Kids' stuff recipes devised and cooked at Petit Cordon Bleu. Call 020-7935 3503 for details of children's classes.

fields.headline: The Questionnaire: Ivor Cutler
fields.standfirst: Ivor Cutler was born in Glasgow in 1923. After teaching for 31 years, he became a poet, humorist, composer, author and singer whom both Bertrand Russell and John Lennon cited as their hero. He has released two albums and performed at the Edinburgh Festival last year. He lives in London.

After teaching for 31 years, he became a poet, humorist, composer, author and singer whom both Bertrand Russell and John Lennon cited as their hero. He has released two albums and performed at the Edinburgh Festival last year. He lives in London.
fields.body:
What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Turning into an albatross in the South Atlantic.

What is your greatest fear?
Boredom.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
Worrying that I've got a big head and don't realise it.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Bigotry.

Where would you like to live?
I don't see the point - I'd have to take myself along.

What makes you depressed?
The growing realisation that Homo sapiens is a marred species.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
My inability to cut a dash.

What is your most unappealing habit?
My inability to accept a gift graciously, as it puts a weight on me.

What is your favourite word?
Pragmatic.

Do you believe in capital punishment?
If it's painless euthanasia, I'd volunteer.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?
Myself, assuming that you can't properly love others until you love yourself.

What do you consider the most overrated virtue?
Any which you are able to practise because you've enough money to do so.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
If 'I love you' means 'You make me feel lovable', then I've always meant it.

Which words or phrases do you most overuse?
Crumbs!

How do you relax?
A bit at a time.

What would your motto be?
I'm not as clever as I really am.

What keeps you awake at night?
Draughts.

How would you like to die?
Holding my breath while reading a book of jokes.

Do you believe in life after death?
What the hell would I want to live for? I've done that.

How would you like to be remembered?
Lying in deep snow, licking an ice-cream cone.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Creativity communicates best via the unconscious, bypassing the intellect.

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Web friends
fields.body:
Sometimes, it's hard to be on my own, although I'm lucky to have so many friends. Patrick does my hair, Marika waxes my legs, Augusta cleans my loft, Jenny is my therapist and Baggio my personal trainer. The only problem is finding birthday presents for all of them. I'm terrible about dates, so I like to keep something in the cupboard that I can give at any time, regardless of sex or age.

Tins of caviar are ideal, but I love the stuff so much that often I gobble up the lot and then I'm hysterical. To replenish my shelves, I explored the net: www.caviar.tic.cz, in Azerbaijan, has 2oz of Beluga at $65, www. freshcaviar.com, in the US, quotes $76, while at www. from.co.uk/ imperialcaviar the price is £63 ($100).

As usual, the worst deal is the one you can get here in the UK, but Azerbaijan... ! I placed my order in the US. I hate paying duty, though (I'm a free-trader), so I gave my friend Libby's address in New York. Libby buys thick art books from amazon.com, so I asked her to stuff one of amazon's big cardboard wrappings full of tins of caviar and then re-address it to me. With any luck, customs and excise should think they're books (duty-free). I hope it will work.

When I say that it's hard being on my own, don't think I'm looking for anyone special. Love is marvellous, of course, but all my mother's friends have ended up supporting their unemployed/able middle-aged husbands. If the queen and Cherie Blair have to be the financial props of their households, what hope is there for an ordinary girl like me? I have no intention of splitting my shares, Peps, Tessas and Isas straight down the middle, let alone the loft and the TVR. But if you feel lonely under your duvet, try www.dating.co.uk. You'll be amazed.

webTitle: How to get the best from your plants?

fields.headline: How to get the best from your plants?
fields.standfirst: Visiting a trial is an excellent start, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: Visiting a trial is an excellent start, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.body:
The floral trials that take place at Wisley are of a selection of commonly-grown plants for which exciting developments are foreseen. I consider myself lucky to be on the committee that judges them through the seasons, but they are there for any visitor to examine. However, judging makes you really look, assess and criticise - and the more you look, the more you see.

The trial of violas from seed a year ago was a real eye-opener; they had such an amazingly long season. From a July sowing, the plants started flowering in October and continued through to early summer. They made a terrific show, far greater than pansies would have done.

Violas are generally smaller-flowered than pansies, but exceedingly prolific. Large-flowered pansies, for example, have problems with holding their petals in place: they are inclined, one or more of them, to fold forward under their own weight, which spoils the flower's symmetry. Pansies often have "faces" (violas generally not), which can be an attractive feature at close range, as in a window box, but from a distance create a confused overall impression.

Of the violas in the trial, the Jewel series, bred in Japan, was the most impressive. 'Jewel Blue', 'Jewel Deep Blue' and 'Jewel Yellow' all won Awards of Merit. If you find these (or any other) hard to locate as seed or as plants, contact the RHS at Wisley for a source.

Bellis, the highly developed versions of our common daisy, B. perennis, was the other over- wintering outside trial. Sown in July or thereabouts, these were flowering from January on, but were, overall, a disappointment, being susceptible to rust disease, a newly-arrived affliction, and despite regular sprayings. Potentially, they make a fine carpet beneath tulips, however, and if you want to have a go, the two Award of Garden Merit winners were 'Romi Red' and 'Roggli Red'. I shall give them a miss for a while.

In the summer, there was a huge, brain-numbing trial of grandiflora petunias. The two main categories of petunia from seed are grandiflora and multiflora - the grandifloras are favourites in the US, having larger flowers and a more compact habit; and they are favoured by the hotter US summers, but are less weather-resistant in our climate. Physically, you can distinguish them from multifloras as their green calyx (behind the showy corolla) has short, narrow sepals, whereas the multifloras are broader and rounder. A number of entries in the trial were disqualified for being multifloras.

But on the whole, I find them preferable, as their less compact, more rangy habit better suits the looser, shirt-sleeves style of gardening that I enjoy, and they produce plenty of colour. Also, they do not react so direly to hail or heavy rain. If rain or hail occurs in late June or early July, while the petunias are young though already in flower, they can stage a better recovery than if the elements turn against them in August, as they (inevitably) did last year. The trial of grandifloras never made more than a partial recovery.

Among the most weather- resistant (and you can breed for this) was the Storm series: 'Storm Lavender', 'Storm Pink', 'Storm White' and so on. It was noticeable that white-flowered strains are the most susceptible to blemishes caused by weather. The whole trial - and this is a point often forgotten about petunias in general - was deliciously scented on the air, even by day, though it is even stronger at night and in the early morning.

A veil must be quickly drawn over the cosmos trial, for which the soil was far too rich, so that the plants grew huge and leafy but never made a proper display. It also emphasised that the sulphurous types - those with orange or deep-yellow flowers - are the first to go mouldy and never recover if the weather turns against them. I discovered, years ago, that they are useless on my heavy clay soil, which is a shame, because their colour intensity can be a wonderful feature. I would still recommend them to any gardener with a hot, sandy soil and full exposure to sun.

The trial of zonal pelargoniums - those popularly known as 'geraniums' - took place with the same varieties grown both as pot plants under glass and as bedding plants outside. They were all single-flowered types, with no more than five petals to a flower.

Single-flowered 'geraniums' do not make quite the intense display of which doubles are capable, but neither do they succumb to wet weather so badly. Even so, they greatly benefit from the small attention that a gardener can readily give them, of rubbing out and removing the clusters of dead blooms that accumulate at the centre of each flower truss, long before the entire truss has finished flowering. We are always tidying up, particularly those grown in ornamental pots, tubs and window boxes, but it is not an unacceptable chore.

I love the combination of magenta and carmine, or magenta and red, that you often find in a 'geranium' flower, as in 'Cardinalis', but my heart was really captured by 'Antik Violett Tikvio', a tall-growing magenta-and-violet variety. I liked its extra height. One wearies of everything being made compact. However, my fellow committee members were not too keen, so you might not be, either.

Be sure to visit the trial of heuchera in early summer. It was already most interesting in 1999.

Spadework
Celia Woolfrey

Tom Tom Club
My tomato crop was pants last year, so this year Organic Tomatoes: The Inside Story (Harris Associates, £15.99), by Terry Marshall, will be obligatory reading. Marshall's tomato plants produce fruit from May through to November, and the green fruit that ripens in the house lasts him until the following February (and no, he doesn't live in the Canary Islands, but in West Yorkshire). An intriguing part of his technique includes 'reading the leaves', so plants get the right feed and growing conditions as and when they need them. The book is available through the Organic Gardening Catalogue (01932 253666, or email chaseorg@aol.com).

Time to ...
Give birds a water supply and check that fish don't get frozen into ponds. A nifty method for the latter is to put a plastic ball on the surface, as the ball floats around in the least breeze and its movement stops the water freezing. What should be avoided is smashing the ice with a hammer: the sound waves reverberate through the water and can be enough of a shock to kill the fish.

Plant of the week
The name Asian buttercup doesn't convey the plushness of Ranunculus asiaticus . This is probably because it has been substantially bred from its weedy, wildflower origins - modern cultivars such as 'Accolade' have something pleasingly kitsch about them. The only drawback is that R. asiaticus isn't hardy: it will grow well enough outdoors in warm areas, but if in doubt, grow in pots and bring inside in winter, or grow under glass for cut flowers. Plant between now and spring. Weekend readers can buy a ranunculus collection for £15.99, inc UK p&p: the collection consists of five x 15 asiaticus bulbs, comprising 15 yellow, 15 white, 15 red, 15 pink and 15 orange. To order, send a cheque or postal order, made payable to Thompson and Morgan (Young Plants) Ltd, to: The Guardian Shop, Plant of the Week, Dept GUC24, PO Box 89, St Leonards-on-Sea, East Sussex TN38 9ZX,or call 0870 8701361 with credit-card details. Last orders: March 10. Allow 28 days for delivery.

Round Force
Garden designer Stephen Woodhams mounds up stone spheres to make a kind of stone fruit bowl for the garden; others place them on the edge of a brick path or in the middle of low-growing plants for instant effect. These ones, made from terracotta, are frostproof, cost £59.95 for a set of three (20cm, 25cm and 30cm diameter), and are available by mail order from home elements. Call 0800 3285351 for details.

The trial of zonal pelargoniums - those popularly known as 'geraniums' - took place with the same varieties grown both as pot plants under glass and as bedding plants outside. They were all single-flowered types, with no more than five petals to a flower. Single-flowered 'geraniums' do not make quite the intense display of which doubles are capable, but neither do they succumb to wet weather so badly. Even so, they greatly benefit from the small attention that a gardener can readily give them, of rubbing out and removing the clusters of dead blooms that accumulate at the centre of each flower truss, long before the entire truss has finished flowering. We are always tidying up, particularly those grown in ornamental pots, tubs and window boxes, but it is not an unacceptable chore. I love the combination of magenta and carmine, or magenta and red, that you often find in a 'geranium' flower, as in 'Cardinalis', but my heart was really captured by 'Antik Violett Tikvio', a tall-growing magenta-and-violet variety. I liked its extra height. One wearies of everything being made compact. However, my fellow committee members were not too keen, so you might not be, either. Be sure to visit the trial of heuchera in early summer. It was already most interesting in 1999. Spadework Celia Woolfrey Tom Tom Club My tomato crop was pants last year, so this year Organic Tomatoes: The Inside Story (Harris Associates, £15.99), by Terry Marshall, will be obligatory reading. Marshall's tomato plants produce fruit from May through to November, and the green fruit that ripens in the house lasts him until the following February (and no, he doesn't live in the Canary Islands, but in West Yorkshire). An intriguing part of his technique includes 'reading the leaves', so plants get the right feed and growing conditions as and when they need them. The book is available through the Organic Gardening Catalogue (01932 253666, or email chaseorg@aol.com). Time to ... Give birds a water supply and check that fish don't get frozen into ponds. A nifty method for the latter is to put a plastic ball on the surface, as the ball floats around in the least breeze and its movement stops the water freezing. What should be avoided is smashing the ice with a hammer: the sound waves reverberate through the water and can be enough of a shock to kill the fish. Plant of the week The name Asian buttercup doesn't convey the plushness of Ranunculus asiaticus . This is probably because it has been substantially bred from its weedy, wildflower origins - modern cultivars such as 'Accolade' have something pleasingly kitsch about them. The only drawback is that R. asiaticus isn't hardy: it will grow well enough outdoors in warm areas, but if in doubt, grow in pots and bring inside in winter, or grow under glass for cut flowers. Plant between now and spring. Weekend readers can buy a ranunculus collection for £15.99, inc UK p&p: the collection consists of five x 15 asiaticus bulbs, comprising 15 yellow, 15 white, 15 red, 15 pink and 15 orange. To order, send a cheque or postal order, made payable to Thompson and Morgan (Young Plants) Ltd, to: The Guardian Shop, Plant of the Week, Dept GUC24, PO Box 89, St Leonards-on-Sea, East Sussex TN38 9ZX,or call 0870 8701361 with credit-card details. Last orders: March 10. Allow 28 days for delivery. Round Force Garden designer Stephen Woodhams mounds up stone spheres to make a kind of stone fruit bowl for the garden; others place them on the edge of a brick path or in the middle of low-growing plants for instant effect. These ones, made from terracotta, are frostproof, cost £59.95 for a set of three (20cm, 25cm and 30cm diameter), and are available by mail order from home elements. Call 0800 3285351 for details.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Fruity reds and the pedant's reputation.
fields.body:
It is, I daresay, not often that a wine scribe has a hand in the birth of a wine which, some years later, pops up on shelf. But with the Co-Op's Chateau Reynella Basket Press Cabernet Merlot 1996 I can make claim to just such a relationship, however slight. I pitched up at said winery in Australia at harvest time, and graciously reinserted a fallen bunch of grapes (they are pressed in whole bunches) back in the press. Anything to help.

As the old screw came down and squeezed the fruit so tenderly, I could see my bunch yielding its juice, the skins retaining their rich tannins for leaching into the must as it settled (excuse me while I dry an eye). Later, I sat under a eucalypt of tremendous girth and read Patrick White. Such a wine, so unique, cannot come cheap, but £10.99 is not outrageous (though, not so long ago, you could have bought a whole CWS branch - or at least one of the smaller ones - for this sum). For, what its method of manufacture produces is one of Australia's most civilised cabernet merlots, with that marvellous contradiction, paradox even, of delicacy yet potency, sveltness yet character. It rates 16.5 points (out of 20).

There are cheaper Co-Op reds, of course. At the Co-Op superstores, there is Mountain Vines Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon & Maratheftiko 1997 (15 points, £4.49), from Cyprus, and everywhere but convenience stores there is Portada Vinho Regional Estremadura 1996 (15 points, £3.99), from Portugal. The Cypriot wine is fairly classy and individual, and its eager fruit is saved from a sloppy posture by the alert, savoury tannins to give it back-bone. The Portuguese wine has layers of fresh jam interleaved with tannins and well-integrated acidity, and is thoroughly food-friendly.

At Booths, the northern phenomenon, there is La Piazza Nero d'Avola 1998 (15 points, £3.49), from Italy, which parades a curious amalgam of fat fruit and thin acidity, with a hint of muscularity from the tannins. There is a Portuguese wine at this retailer, too (and, rumour has it, at Budgens, also): Alta Mesa 1998, a deliciously fresh and cherry-ripe glugging wine that rates 15 points and costs an outrageous £2.89. Two bargains at Morrisons are Vina Albali Tempranillo 1998 (14.5 points, £3.35), from Spain, with its lovely rounded, plummy fruit, and Domaine Boyar Bulgarian Gamza 1998 (14 points, £2.79), which demonstrates that this country and the gamza grape can produce cheap, utterly fulfilling, juicy reds of the kind that beaujolais used to specialise in 40 years ago.

Tesco has been shopping in Portugal, too, and returned with Vinha Nove Tras-os-Montes 1998 (15.5 points, £3.69). It is dry yet fruity (raisins, plums, cherries and a hint of fig), with assertive tannins and, at this price, an overall structure of surprising detail and daring inventiveness. Tesco also has Villa Pigna Rosso Piceno 1997 (14 points, £3.99), from Italy - though light, I found its sprinkling of tannins most useful when I had a glass with a fresh pea risotto (never use frozen in a risotto). Tesco also has, from Spain, Finca Lasendal 1998, a red of delightfully soft, rich, textured ripeness and earthiness. It rates 15.5 points and costs £3.99.

One last thing before I go: several readers have written concerning wines that I recommended five years ago and claimed at the time would be interesting candidates for ageing for the new millennium. Leaving aside the consideration that we are not yet in the 21st century (fling pedant at my head, if you must), these wines should be ready to drink by now. However, I cannot respond to requests on how I find them - I did not lay them down myself, since my bike takes up so much room in my coal-hole, where I keep my pitifully meagre racks. But those readers who did buy any of these bottles can - and I would be most entertained to hear what they have to report. I appreciate that what little reputation I have might evaporate overnight if too many have failed the test of time but, like the readers who bought them, I wait in eager expectation.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.
Email: weekend@guardian.co.uk
Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
I am not sure we should be blaming those innocuous OK! and Hello! articles for the rise in stalking. (Stalkers, January 29). There is more likely to be a connection with the prevalence of pornography in all its guises and the steadfast refusal of society to acknowledge the effect it has on all of us. By making women loathe their bodies and feel afraid and vulnerable, pornography is itself a kind of mass stalking, and effectively turns us all into stalkers. The confusion is compounded by the media's insistence that pornography is a healthy exercise of civil liberties.
Anna Fisher
London SW17

The interview with Noel Gallagher assumed that Oasis lost the plot. The reality is that they didn't have the choice. As soon as Travis asked 'and what's a Wonderwall, anyway?' it was obvious that Oasis had no idea either, and the plot was lost - to Travis.
D Mercer & S Wright
Accrington, Lancashire

On the subject of teenage vandalism, Alexander Chancellor (January 29) failed to develop an important point made in his own article. The children throwing rocks at fire engines were 'imagining they were being chased... It had been a pretty safe kind of thrill'. Whatever else has changed in the past few decades, one thing is certain; it gets more and more difficult to take risks legally. What young males (in particular) look for is excitement and a perception of danger. Providing swimming-pools and ice rinks that the kids can't afford to use is not the answer. Even if they do go to a pool, are they allowed to behave irresponsibly on the slide, or to dive-bomb each other? No way; it's said to be too dangerous. Small wonder that many turn to ad-hoc, antisocial methods of providing their own entertainment and excitement; they're allowed few other ways of testing the world or themselves. There's no easy solution, but part of the answer lies in allowing kids to experience a level of danger they - not we - can believe in, rather than treating them as miniature versions of our cautious selves. Young people will always seek risk; we should aim to manage, not eliminate it.
Graham Trott, aged 51,
North Walsham, Norfolk

Don Jones (Dear Weekend, January 29) needs to get out more. His letter implies that he is horrified by people who have moral reasons for rejecting certain foods and incensed if offered a type of cuisine that he is not used to. I imagine he is a bundle of laughs during social occasions, demanding hot dogs from Jewish friends and ordering egg and chips in Chinese restaurants. Chill out Don, the odd meatless meal isn't going to kill you.
Adele Barnett London SW19

I would consider it unsufferably rude not to offer my non-vegetarian friends a meat dish when they come to dinner. Perhaps Don Jones should consider changing his friends. He should also desist from generalising about vegetarians. We are not all ill-mannered boors, you know. Tony Green Hebden Bridge, West Yorkshire It was interesting to read that Julie Burchill used to be the cleverest woman in England. I used to play centre-forward for Brazil, and my dad was the first man on the moon. We must get together sometime for a chat.
John Rigby Oldham, Lancashire

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum
fields.standfirst: "Strange how things one hated when young in time acquire a peculiar sweetness"
fields.trailText: "Strange how things one hated when young in time acquire a peculiar sweetness"
fields.body:
We are at Centerparcs for the weekend, courtesy of Great-Aunt Elspeth. This sorts out the Wets from the Dry. Ex-Spouse regards exposure to water in any form as torture. I love it. I can float on my back and gaze up at palm trees without the least frisson of post-colonial guilt. The brick paths, the villas discreetly stashed away among evergreens, the bicycling - why, it's almost like living in a Dutch suburb. The only thing missing is a chic little clinic with an Indonesian nurse dispensing sexual therapy, marijuana and euthanasia.

"It's a Designer Village!" sneers ex-Spouse. "A cross between Neighbours and Little Red Riding Hood." Secretly hope synthetic suburban wolf will slink out of the pinewoods and bite his arse.

"We're on the pull!" says Harriet after lunch, and cycles off with her friend, Kate, to the Subtropical Swimming Paradise. They're old enough to rampage around the steaming pools in their bikinis without being in danger. Any boys young enough to be at Centerparcs with their parents are clearly going to take a lot of pulling, rather like unripe Bramley apples on a particularly overprotective tree.

"There's rugby on TV this afternoon," announces ex-Spouse defiantly, "so I shall just slump in front of it, okay, just as if I was on planet earth?" Agree readily. I might feed the two coots who haunt our patio, or I might just go for a brisk walk through the pinewoods.

A weekend is not quite long enough, however. The stink of Homework Yet Undone hangs in the air, though Harriet and Kate have promised to hunker down this evening at 6pm sharp. Their homework is to design a biscuit. We never had design when I was a girl; we just muddled along with things being useful and ugly. But everything's designed these days. The February issue of House & Garden contains pictures of a notebook designed to look like a sandwich, furry hot-water bottles and photograph albums covered with fleece, presumably to keep your pin-ups cosy in winter.

So why not design a biscuit? For centuries, they've just been flat and brown. How boring! Biscuits should take comfort from the example of soap. For Christmas, somebody gave me a bar of transparent golden soap, in which a palm tree brooded over a sandy shore, like a Jamaican sunset in amber. I have seen heaven in a bar of soap.

Why not literary biscuits? Not like Brontë biscuits - just flat and brown - but biscuits with poems on. A pink biscuit with O Rose Thou Art Sick on it in icing sugar, and a cute, jammy worm poking its head out at the top.

Walking through the pine forest, my imagination reeling with exciting biscuits, I wonder why I never went into commerce. Biscuits to match your bathroom! Biscuits to reflect your star sign! I trudge on, but begin to feel cold. Darkness falls, and I realise I am lost - biscuits that bleep when you're near home. Wander through endless pitch-black lanes. Biscuits with a powerful searchlight. A biscuit that is also a mobile phone. The future's orange creams.

A tall figure looms ahead. Wonder if Centerparcs is is really crime-free, or if I am about to become an unexpected statistic. Tall figure passes without murdering, though no doubt tempted. Locate villa and rush in hoping for John Inverdale and Jonah Lomu, preferably filled with chocolate and scattered with chopped nuts. Ex-Spouse reports that rugby was dull. Suits you, sir. Best idea of all: biscuit, from photograph supplied by long-suffering wives and ex-wives, bearing the likeness of their rotten husbands. Beyond Relate? Masticate! Bite his head off with your morning coffee.

Girls return. "I've thought of lots of biscuit ideas for you!" I cry foolishly.

"Oh, we've just realised that we don't have to give it in till Wednesday," says Harriet, "and this is a leisure break, so we're not going to do any homework at all." Homework is wasted on the young.

Strange how all the things that one hated when young - mashed swede, homework, gardening, the singing of hymns - in time acquire a peculiar sweetness. Wonder if the opposite will happen to my relationship with ex-Spouse, which was quite tender 20 years ago and is now as dry and old as a ship's biscuit.

fields.headline: Famous then, February 5 1984, Mo Moreland
fields.trailText: On February 5, 1984, Mo Moreland, star of the tap-dancing troupe the Roly Polys, revealed that her rise to fame after appearing on the Les Dawson Show had forced her husband, Roy, out of work. The couple had been performing together as The Mighty Atom And Roy, but Moreland's sudden success meant she was no longer able to commit as much time to their double act.
fields.body:
On February 5, 1984, Mo Moreland, star of the tap-dancing troupe the Roly Polys, revealed that her rise to fame after appearing on the Les Dawson Show had forced her husband, Roy, out of work. The couple had been performing together as The Mighty Atom And Roy, but Moreland's sudden success meant she was no longer able to commit as much time to their double act.

Soon after, the couple bought a hotel in Blackpool, which they ran for five years, while Moreland continued her career. 'Hotels need to have personalities behind them,' says Moreland, 'and running one suits the entertainer-type really well.' Although they had planned to run the hotel into their retirement, Moreland could see no end to her tap-dancing days and they sold up. 'I'll only retire when my legs give up,' she says today, 'or when my diary tells me it's time.' Still with the Roly Polys (pictured below with Des O'Connor), she has just finished a pantomime, and is about to embark on a tour.

Moreland also does charity work - she sits on the committees of Cheerful Sparrows, which helps the socially disadvantaged, and Talking Newspapers, for which she records celebrity interviews for Blackpool's Evening Gazette. She is also president of the People's Dispensary for Sick Animals. Jane Crinnion

fields.headline: Doctor   on call
fields.standfirst: The challenge: A young family is laid low by illness. Christmas, New Year and a birthday have come and gone but, with all the will in the world, festive meals and celebrations were the last things on their minds. To complicate matters, mum is breast-feeding, so has to be careful about what she eats. Morale is low, and the larder has cobwebs. But wait... is that   a Kitchen Doctor at the door?
fields.trailText:

Christmas, New Year and a birthday have come and gone but, with all the will in the world, festive meals and celebrations were the last things on their minds. To complicate matters, mum is breast-feeding, so has to be careful about what she eats. Morale is low, and the larder has cobwebs. But wait... is that 
a Kitchen Doctor at the door?
fields.body:
So, you're driving due south through London on a wet Wednesday in winter. The lunchtime traffic has sludged into a grimy crawl. A few miles on, London loses the will to be London; roads ease up, green spaces become greener and, suddenly, end of journey. Balham. Or, more specifically, a locale dubbed Nappy Valley, Balham. Apparently, the capital boasts several Nappy Valleys, each gouged out in a geological trauma of the double-income mortgage kind, a geo-economic eruption that threw up a rubble of gurgling babies, overflowing skips, mountain-biking dads, Gap-fixated mums and Smeg-infested kitchens.

This Nappy Valley is usually a contented place. But, seven weeks ago one family there became encased in misery. Just as Father Christmas was leafing through the south- London pages of his A-to-Z, Chris and Eva Niemyt and their progeny - three-year-old Theo and Louis, just three-and-a-half months - were singled out for special treatment by Dame Flu and her evil cohorts. Big festive family meal? Forget it. Biggish eating on New Year's Eve and Day? Nope. Celebration feast for Chris's birthday at the start of January? Think again. Boiled egg? Just about.

Pretty grim. So many excellent excuses to stuff one's face, so little energy to do it. By mid-January, the backlog of blow-out meals was proving unbearable. Which is where Kitchen Doctor Rosie Sykes came in. For, on the wet Wednesday in question, the Niemyts had had enough and called in the KD to cook a belated multi-celebration meal. Now, Rosie Sykes KD - veteran of troubled larders and lauded eateries throughout the realm - is an accommodating and energetic operator.

Within minutes of taking the call, she had set out on her mercy dash, via nearby Northcote Road, home of Northcote Fisheries and Dandelion Natural Foods. By midday, she had set up a makeshift intensive-care unit in the Niemyts' kitchen and her finely-honed blade was making the first incisions - across a wig-sized bunch of coriander and a fistful of spring onions. By 1pm, a medium-sized pan was doing its thing, containing dashi (Japanese soup stock based on bonito fish), the coriander stalks - "I don't believe in waste," explains the Doc - the spring onions, a bit of ginger, lime leaves, white wine and lemongrass.

This was to be the broth. Next, four red mullet were slashed with the knife and laid to rest in a marinade of basil, lemon, olive oil, salt and pepper. To call these mullet plain "red" is to do them a disservice. When fresh - and these were - they shimmer every hue from pale pink to deep, metallic burgundy. In the marinade, they sparkled like jewels.

At this point, as the first wisps of salivation-inducing broth vapour began to permeate Niemyt Villas, the pallid Niemyts themselves had more or less scarpered. Whether this was out of respect for the good Doctor and her work, or a desire not to spread their lurgy to the relatively healthy visitors, or simply an urge to hide in the pub until the hard work was done is not clear. Whatever, the result was that, but for a simmering hiss from the stove, sporadic chopping and the occasional snap of a photographer's shutter, the kitchen was becalmed. End of round one.

Before the next stage began, Doc Rosie set out the rationale behind her choice of dishes. "I tried to think of healthy foods, things with clean, simple flavours, but the meal has also to be something vaguely celebratory. Also, Eva is breastfeeding, so ingredients had to be carefully chosen soas not to get any nasty, strong flavours coming through in her breast milk."

Every corner of the house was by now suffused with a delicate fusion of smells, part oriental, part farmhouse-European. Barely an hour had passed between the lighting of the first gas ring and this higher state of culinary consciousness. Then, suddenly, the KD announced with gravitas, "the steamed pudding must get underway." So it did - ginger cake crumbs, butter, eggs, flour, sugar and all. An hour later, however, the whole process seemed as if it might just be in some peril. Seizing a blender by the throat, Doc Rosie, never one to fluster, observed calmy, "Um, things are betting a bit, um, mayhemmy now."

Every few seconds, ingredients moved from one container to another, back and forth, mixing, multiplying, dividing as if trying to evade capture. The pace took off. Blender whirred aggressively, eggs cracked, pots bubbled, dysfunctional carrots jostled with streetwise courgettes, brown sugar squared up to chopped cucumber, the clock ticked, the sink overflowed with used pots and plates, the Japanese seaweed for the salad. The seaweed! The mash! The mash! The seaweed! The foil, the noodles, the prawns, the trade deficit, the phone! The doorbell! The horror. The horror! The garlic! And all the while two representatives of the Guardian hovered over proceedings like a pair of vultures.

But only one Rosie to choreograph this chaos into a memorable meal? Did she do it? Fast forward to 4.30pm, and there's Chris, Eva, Louis, Theo and a series of exquisite, subtly aromatic, beautifully presented dishes, as sophisticated as they are simple. As flu remedies go, this one's hard to beat. All recipes serve four.

Japanese seaweed salad and clear tiger-prawn broth
Dashi is a Japanese soup stock base, made from bonito. You can get it, and the seaweed, from Asian stores and some high-street supermarkets (health-food shops also sell dried seaweed).

For the broth
1 packet dashi, dissolved in 750ml water
6 spring onions
16 tiger prawns, preferably uncooked, shells on
1 thumb-sized piece fresh ginger
3 tbsp soy sauce
Chinese five-spice powder
6 lime leaves
Paprika
1 stalk lemongrass
1 bunch coriander, preferably with roots on

For the seaweed salad
200g mixed dried seaweed:
kombu, wakame, arame or nori
150g glass noodles
1 bunch chives
1 cucumber
55g mangetout
1 tbsp vegetable oil
For the dressing
4 tbsp soy sauce
2 tbsp sesame oil
2 tbsp rice vinegar
1 tbsp sugar

First, prepare the broth. Peel and slice the ginger, roughly chop the lemongrass, and put both into a pan, along with the soy sauce, lime leaves and the crushed stalks of the coriander. Add the dashi water. Place on a low flame with a lid on, and allow to infuse for 45 minutes or so. Take off the heat and set aside, covered, until needed.

Peel the prawns and throw the shells into the still-warm, resting broth. Sprinkle the prawns with a little five-spice powder and paprika. Slice the spring onions. Wash a couple of leafy coriander branches and pick off the leaves.

Ten minutes before serving, strain the broth through a fine sieve and return the pan to the boil. Turn down the heat to a gentle simmer, season the prawns and throw them into the broth - if they are uncooked, they should only take a few minutes to change colour and be ready; if they are already cooked, just give them time to heat through thoroughly.

Pour the broth into warm serving bowls, garnish with spring onions and a few coriander leaves, and serve. It's a good idea to prepare the seaweed salad before you complete the final stages of making the broth. If you have kombu seaweed, wash and soak in water for around 30 minutes, drain and simmer gently in clean water until tender. This will take about an hour. For wakame, soak in cold water for 30 minutes. For arame, soak in cold water for 15 minutes. And for nori, simply cut into strips. Cover the glass noodles with boiling salted water and leave to soak for five to six minutes, until softened. Chop the chives, peel and deseed the cucumber, then cut into thin half-moons. Finely slice the mangetout, and saut* briefly in the oil.

Finally, whisk together the ingredients for the dressing. Toss the salad mixture in a large bowl, then stir in the dressing. Serve on a small plate beside the soup. (It can be served cold, but is best warmish or at room temperature)

Red mullet in parma ham, with garlic mash and roasted fennel and courgette

10 slices Parma ham (or other cured ham, such as Jamon Serrano)
4 red mullet, scaled, gutted, filleted and pin-boned (your fishmonger will do this)
4 tbsp olive oil
1 tbsp lemon juice
1 bunch fresh basil
1 shallot, finely chopped
4 tbsp white wine
4 tbsp fish stock

Cut a couple of slits into the skin of each mullet fillet. In a bowl, make a marinade with three tablespoons of the oil, lemon juice, a little roughly chopped basil, salt and black pepper. Lay in the fish, and leave to steep for about 10 minutes. While the fish is marinating, saut* the shallot in half a tablespoon of olive oil for a few minutes until translucent, then pour in the wine. Whack up the heat, and reduce the liquid to a quarter of its original volume. Now add the stock, and reduce the liquor again, this time by half.

Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/gas mark 6. Place a basil leaf on top of each fish fillet, then carefully wrap each one in a slice of ham. Heat an ovenproof frying pan until it is very hot, pour in half a tablespoon of olive oil and add the fish. Fry undisturbed until the ham has crisped up - this should take only a couple of minutes - then turn on to its other side and transfer the pan to the oven for about 10 minutes, or until the fish is cooked. At the same time, bring the winey fish stock back to the boil, gradually whisk in the marinade until you have a very light emulsion, and add a little more chopped basil.

Place the fish on a warm dish, and pour the sauce over and around. Serve with the following vegetable dishes:

For the garlic mash
450g floury potatoes
150ml double cream
10 cloves garlic
Salt and pepper

Peel and chop the potatoes into evenly-sized pieces, pop them into a large pan of well-salted water, along with five unpeeled cloves of garlic. Bring the whole lot to the boil and simmer gently until the potatoes are tender. In a separate pan, combine the cream, the remaining five cloves of garlic, peeled this time, some salt and pepper. Bring this mixture carefully to the boil. Once boiled, remove the pan from the heat and leave the garlic flavour to infuse into the cream for at least 15 minutes, and preferably for a half-hour or even longer.

Whizz up the cream mixture in a blender until it is completely smooth in texture, and then set to one side. Drain the cooked potatoes and garlic, squeezing the latter out of their skins, and then mash well together. When you are ready to serve, pour the garlic milk into a pan, add a couple of large tablespoonfuls of butter, bring to a simmer, season, then beat into the mash. Serve at once.

For the roasted fennel and courgette
4 fennel bulbs
4 courgettes
Olive oil
Salt and pepper

Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/ gas mark 6. Cut the fennel bulbs into eighths, and the courgette into batons of a similar size. Toss the veg in olive oil, season, and bake until tender and crispy on the outside - for around 40 minutes, or so.

Steamed ginger pudding with honey and honey custard
5 tbsp honey
150g crumbled fresh ginger cake
25g self-raising flour
100g soft brown sugar
100g crystallised ginger, with its syrup
125g butter
3 large eggs
1 level tsp bicarbonate of soda
2 tbsp milk or lemon juice

Melt 25g of the butter, brush a two-pint pudding basin with it. Pour the honey into the bottom of the basin. Combine the crumbled cake and flour in a mixing bowl. Put the remaining butter, and the ginger and syrup in a food processor, and pulse until the ginger is roughly chopped. Melt the resultant mixture in a small pan. In another bowl, whisk the eggs and sugar until frothy and slightly thickened. Stir the butter-and-ginger mixture into the crumb-and-flour bowl, then stir in the eggs. Dissolve the bicarb in the milk/ lemon juice, and amalgamate with the mixture in the bowl.

Pour into the pudding basin, cover with greaseproof paper, pleated in the middle to let the pudding to rise. Fasten with an elastic band and wrap again with foil. Secure this with string, using enough to make a handle. Place the package in a large pan, pour in boiling water to come halfway up the sides of the basin, cover, and simmer gently for an an hour and three quarters. Top up the water as necessary. The pudding is ready when it is firm to the touch.

For the honey custard
4 egg yolks
8 tbsp honey
150ml milk
100ml cream

Pour the milk and cream into a pan, bring to the boil and scald briefly. Beat together the egg yolks and honey, pour this into the milk-cream mixture and return to the heat. Cook, stirring constantly, until thickened. Pour through a sieve into a warmed jug

webTitle: Jail for corrupt detective turned informer

fields.headline: Jail for corrupt detective turned informer
fields.standfirst: Dealer's affair with member of elite crime squad led to web of corruption in which drugs seized by police were resold at huge profit
fields.trailText: A corrupt detective who turned supergrass to expose corruption in the elite south east regional crime squad was jailed yesterday after he admitted taking money from colleagues who were running a lucrative drugs scam.
fields.body:
A corrupt detective who turned supergrass to expose corruption in the elite south east regional crime squad was jailed yesterday after he admitted taking money from colleagues who were running a lucrative drugs scam.

Detective Constable Neil Putnam, 42, was sentenced to three years 11 months at the Old Bailey by Mr Justice Blofeld, who said the activities of corrupt police officers like him undermined the whole fabric of society.

The judge also jailed Evelyn Fleckney for 4 years for her involvement in the deals. The court heard that Fleckney, 43, was a drug dealer turned informant who had an affair with one of Putnam's colleagues, Robert Clark.

Orlando Pownall, prosecuting, described how Fleckney recycled drugs seized by Clark in police raids. She sold quantities of cannabis, heroin and cocaine to her contacts, and he distributed the proceeds among officers, including Putnam.

The judge told Putnam and Fleckney that their sentences had been reduced by two thirds because they had become important supergrasses who were helping the Complaints Investigation Branch in a corruption purge of the Metropolitan police. The court heard that their whistle-blowing was "unique" and that they were both in fear of their lives.

Putnam, who admitted 16 offences of drug possession and acts tending or intended to pervert the course of justice, could be released in two years.

Fleckney was jailed for 15 years for drug dealing in 1998. Yesterday she admitted 21 drug related offences. The sentences will run concurrently.

Mr Justice Blofeld told Putnam: "The public rely on the police. When they let them down it is a terrible thing. That is a breach of duty you must live with for the rest of your life."

Mr Pownall described how Fleckney became a police informant in 1990. DC Clark became her "handler" at SERCS, based in east Dulwich, south east London, the following year.

"Within a short time Clark abused his position and used information provided by Fleckney to steal drugs from those arrested," said Mr Pownall. "The drugs were given to Fleckney, who sold them using her contacts. The proceeds were given to Clark."

Fleckney said she had an affair with Clark and that she became pregnant by him twice. On both occasions she had an abortion, the court heard. The couple spent nights together in luxury hotels, went to the Canaries on holiday, and exchanged gifts. Putnam joined the squad in 1991 and became involved in the drugs scam during a police operation in the village of Fletching, Sussex. Fleckney tipped off Clark that a light plane was going to drop cannabis in a field.A surveillance operation was mounted and he took several blocks from the haul.

"Some days later Clark gave Putnam £300 in cash," said Mr Pownall. "This was the first occasion upon which Putnam and Fleckney had been involved in corruption. It was by no means the last." The ethos of the squad was "all for one and one for all" and Putnam wanted to be accepted by his colleagues, the court heard.

On another occasion Putnam received £2,000 from Clark following a drugs-bust at a public golf club. In the spring of 1995, Putnam was given £500 after Fleckney had "recycled" cocaine seized during a raid in a pub car park.

The court heard that Putnam decided to cooperate with the corruption investigation because he "could no longer tolerate the guilt and hypocrisy of his position."

The judge said Fleckney was "fascinated and deeply fond" of Clark. "The approach of the squad was they could do what they wanted. The supervision was not what it should have been."

The court heard that Putnam decided to cooperate with the corruption investigation because he "could no longer tolerate the guilt and hypocrisy of his position." The judge said Fleckney was "fascinated and deeply fond" of Clark. "The approach of the squad was they could do what they wanted. The supervision was not what it should have been."

fields.headline: National roundup
fields.trailText: 'Beam me up' Scotty to be dad at 80
fields.body:
'Beam me up' Scotty to be dad at 80

James Doohan, chief engineer in the cult 1960s science fiction series Star Trek whose most famous refrain was "I cannae do it, captain", has proved that at the age of 79 he most definitely can, after announcing that he is to be a father again.

Doohan and his wife, Wende, 43, who have two sons aged 23 and 21, are expecting their baby in April, a few weeks after the actor's 80th birthday.

The man known to legions of fans as "Scotty" will join a growing band of celebrity octogenarian parents, including Saul Bellow, the Nobel Prize-winning author, who became a father again at the age of 84.

Doohan, who has four children from previous marriages, said fathering children in old age ran in his family. His grandfather was 72 when his mother was born.

One of the original cast members of the hit TV series and the star of several Star Trek films, the former captain in the Canadian royal army said: "I thought it was incredible, but now I'm going to beat the family record."

Earl denies debt to builder

A friend of the Earl of Wessex yesterday dismissed reports that a building firm that carried out renovation work on his Surrey mansion had collapsed because he refused to pay a £600,000 bill.

A source close to the earl said CJ Sims, a London-based company employed to renovate Bagshot Park, had sent a bill "out of the blue" days before the firm was placed in the hands of receivers.

According to the friend, the extra bill totalled around 30% above the agreed £1.8m cost and had come as a surprise to the earl, who had paid the company after the contract was finished in August last year.

The friend said:"It is regrettable, but he is not the only debtor. He had paid his bill and was then sent a higher bill out of the blue. He was trying to settle it and the offer was rejected."

Receiver Keith Goodman, of accountants Leonard Curtis, said: "[The earl] owes a substantial amount of money in respect of which the company was negotiating with him prior to the receivership."

Government to pick up games bill

Ministers yesterday pledged that the government would meet the full cost of the opening and closing ceremonies of the Commonwealth Games to be held in Manchester in 2002.

Estimates for the cost of the ceremonies, which both government and games organisers insist will have an international impact, range from £2m to £20m.

Ministers have also acknowledged that the games will play a key part in celebrations of the Queen's golden jubilee. But Ian McCartney, cabinet office minister, and Frances Done, chief executive of Manchester 2002, denied that the government had decided to write Manchester a blank cheque.

"The government has not done that and I would not expect them to do so," said Ms Done. "But this is a really important national event and it has to be worthy of Britain. It will be a joint effort between the games' organisers and the government on what is finally delivered."

Mr McCartney added: "We want to make sure that they are planned in such a way that they give credit to the jubilee and to Great Britain."

The announcement came as a huge relief to Manchester city council. "We have a positive commitment," said the council leader, Richard Leese. "We are very pleased."

The city is committed to funding any deficit and underwriting any losses.

Work has started on a 50,000-seat stadium, costing £90m, in east Manchester beside the national cycling arena. It will provide a home for Manchester City football club after 2002. A £32m swimming pool is also being built near the city centre.

Jodrell Bank in search for Mars lander

Radio telescopes in Britain and Holland are being used to help in the hunt for Nasa's Mars polar lander which has failed to communicate with its base since reaching the red planet just before Christmas.

Scientists at the University of Manchester's Lovell telescope at Jodrell Bank in Cheshire and at the Wester bork complex in the Netherlands hope they will this afternoon be able to pick up a signal from the craft.

Its failure badly embarrassed US space officials.

The lander's main transmitter has remained silent, possibly as a result of a crash landing.

But Nasa has since tried to switch on the lander's low-power UHF transmitter, designed to communicate only with other over-flying spacecraft.

A telescope at Stanford university has listened for signals which might just be strong enough to reach earth.

"After a lot of processing of data, something was picked up two or three times in December and January," said Ian Morison, operations engineer at Jodrell Bank.

"Scientists there may have detected the lander but the telescope was operating right at the limit of its range."

Nasa hopes the bigger telescope at Jodrell Bank, which is 250ft in diameter, and the 14 Dutch telescopes, each 82ft in diameter, will give better results.

The lander's UHF transmitter was switched on for two 50-minute sessions yesterday, with any signal expected to take 16 minutes to make the 181m mile journey from Mars to earth.

"What we get depends on the strength of the signal," said Mr Morison.

"We won't be able to tell in real time, and many gigabytes of information will be transferred to a cluster of computers which will work in parallel."

Laughing gang kicked man's head

A group of men laughed as they kicked a man aged 49 unconscious during an apparently motiveless early-hours attack, police said yesterday.

Thomas Brannon-Brown, a mature student, was left with a fractured skull and brain injuries after being assaulted as he walked to his home in Cambridge at about 2.30am on Thursday.

He remains unconscious in an intensive care unit at Addenbrooke's hospital, Cambridge, where his condition is said to be stable.

Police believe as many as six men were involved in the attack, which was seen by a local resident.

Detective Inspector Neil Constable said: "It is sickening to learn that one witness had reported that the attackers were laughing throughout the incident."

Mr Brannon-Brown, who lives alone, was last seen leaving a fast-food restaurant nearby.

Police are appealing for anyone who saw the group to come forward.

Police hunt killer of MP's niece

Police were yesterday hunting for the murderer of an SDLP MP's niece whose naked body was found on a beach in Londonderry.

Julie Hamill, 28, was found stripped and strangled on Thursday morning at Portstewart. She had last been seen at a nightclub in Portrush, Co Antrim, where she lived.

Ms Hamill was a niece of the South Down MP Eddie McGrady and originally came from Downpatrick, Co Down.

The RUC said her body was found by a jogger. A postmortem showed she had been murdered. Detectives said they had discovered no motive for the killing, but said she had not been sexually assaulted. The woman's clothes have not been found.

fields.headline: Broker, trader, free trade enemy
fields.standfirst: Birgit Cunningham is a friend to the wealthy, a champion for the poor
fields.trailText: Birgit Cunningham is the woman who squashed a chocolate eclair into the face of Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, as a protest because farmers were going bankrupt; listening to her, it's hard to see how she could touch something so unhealthy as chocolate. "I'm a food nut really. I live on organic food. I have lots and lots of detoxes too. Someone offered me a crunchy bar the other day. I took three bites and I started to see flashing lights."
fields.body:
Birgit Cunningham is the woman who squashed a chocolate eclair into the face of Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, as a protest because farmers were going bankrupt; listening to her, it's hard to see how she could touch something so unhealthy as chocolate. "I'm a food nut really. I live on organic food. I have lots and lots of detoxes too. Someone offered me a crunchy bar the other day. I took three bites and I started to see flashing lights."

She is, she says, 34: she has worked as an art dealer, a stockbroker, in the film industry, and as a web designer. "I've also been a yacht broker: that's exclusive to you. I don't really need any more snobbish remarks about being a trust fund baby. I have this accent because of the school I went to; I have my flat [in the Old Brompton Road, west London] because I'm a website designer; and I have my contacts because I worked in Hollywood."

She certainly has the contacts. On the website for a picnic against GM foods that she organised is a picture of the Supporters Lunch: Elle MacPherson, Jemima Khan, Zac and Scheherazade Goldsmith, and Tara Palmer-Tomkinson pose with her alongside a couple of other billionaires' children and playthings like Lucas White and Normandie Keith. These are the kind of people who can only worry about the food chain because they own so much of it. The only person missing from the list, in fact, is Liz Hurley, whose flatmate Birgit Cunningham is supposed to have been, though Henry and Lili Dent Brocklehurst are there along with Jeffrey Archer.

These are not the people you would expect to see attacking world trade. But every celebrity, she says, has got their own causes, and you just have to keep track of who likes to support what. "That's something I learned in Hollywood. You just go up to people and ask them straight away to help you; usually they will because they are so relieved that you want to talk about environmental issues and it's not someone asking about their ex-husband. You just have to know what their interests and charities are. I keep all that on the computer. I've got quite a good Rolodex."

And then she converts these heirs to huge fortunes made in the grocery trade to her view that the food trade is intrinsically wicked. "We shouldn't be eating mango, really. I don't expect Claridges hotel to stop serving it. But it's just ridiculous to sit down to a meal with food from all over the world when there are farmers going out of business.

"Food is not the kind of commodity that should be traded globally. Nike shoes or electronics are totally different things. You can't do that to food."

Neither of us, I object, would be capable of having this conversation without imported coffee. "Oh, I know. I didn't sleep at all last night. But I only drink fair trade coffee. I don't go to Starbucks."

Perhaps her charm doesn't work so well down the telephone. She doesn't sound in the least bit stupid. The speed and force with which inquiries about her background are ignored is not that of someone saying the first thing that comes into her head. She's a bit light on concrete proposals. "Poor countries need water and education in how to grow their own crops. I think Susan Sarandon is right: she has a charity that gives poor families their own goat."

The conversation has by this time acquired a certain irony: the Guardian is defending globalisation and the Old Brompton Road is speaking up for agrarian self-sufficiency. But before the dance can continue, she heads it off: "I've been up all night. I'll have to stop; I'm feeling all faint and queasy."

fields.headline: A lofty ambition realised
fields.standfirst: Peter Jenkinson part-time showman and part-time labourer behind new Midlands art gallery
fields.trailText: Peter Jenkinson talks about public access to the arts with the jumpy enthusiasm of a man giving you a hot tip on a horse. He sucks his cigarette and grins with exhaustion. Behind him, in an unlikely pine and plate glass pub by the canal in Walsall, a phantom lift drifts up and down the window, reflected from the new art centre which he will open soon. "It's not as if we're giving access to people. Access is their right. That's why, as you go in, the first thing you come across is the children's gallery."
fields.body:
Peter Jenkinson talks about public access to the arts with the jumpy enthusiasm of a man giving you a hot tip on a horse. He sucks his cigarette and grins with exhaustion. Behind him, in an unlikely pine and plate glass pub by the canal in Walsall, a phantom lift drifts up and down the window, reflected from the new art centre which he will open soon. "It's not as if we're giving access to people. Access is their right. That's why, as you go in, the first thing you come across is the children's gallery."

The access they are getting is to one of the most remarkable buildings in Britain. The arts centre, which has been Jenkinson's work for the last 10 years, is an extraordinary feat of architectural redemption. Walsall on a drizzling February afternoon is dispiriting but from the high huge windows of the gallery it is transformed.

"Oh, the place is changing," he says. "There is a stall in Walsall market selling cappucino now, for 85p a cup; and there is a sign underneath, explaining that it's 'posh frothy coffee'." That's 85p more than it will cost to get into the gallery. "Free admission is the absolute foundation of what we are doing," he says, and grinning, clenches his fist at shoulder height. "Free! Yes! and if that ever changed I would resign like a shot, and so, I think, would most of my team."

"That's what really interests me: saying that we can do this. The building is literally about looking out above the horizon, not looking down by your feet. It makes reference to some very subtle political questions about the privatisation of public space."

"We wanted to get away from the usual compromises that you always have in Britain. We really wanted to get excellence. We wanted to continue the work to broaden audiences for the visual arts and to have proper access. That's why there's no route through that building.

"It is a building where you can eat your pudding first. The person who visits is at the centre. This arrogance of having a route is ridiculous - it's the idea we have to be led by the nose through public space."

The building was funded by lottery money - it cost less than a tenth of the Dome.

Jenkinson came to Walsall in 1989. "My first job was to work on plans for an art gallery. Then poll tax hit and the project was postponed. Here we are with the fourth attempt Walsall has made; and we've been working on it since 1992. It's been like a roller coaster of excitement."

At the heart of the gallery is a collection made by Jacob Epstein's widow, Kathleen Garman, and her American friend Sally Ryan. But Jenkinson talks little about the paintings. The gallery itself has become his passion. "It's a very complex business. I'm a part-time showman and a part-time labourer."

webTitle: Sunken fishing boat gives up her dead at last

fields.headline: Sunken fishing boat gives up her dead at last
fields.standfirst: Bereaved relatives' tears of relief as bodies of seven fishermen are brought to Isle of Man before return to Scotland for burial
fields.trailText: Bereaved relatives' tears of relief as bodies of seven fishermen are brought to Isle of Man before return to Scotland for burial
fields.body:
The Solway Harvester has finally given up her dead. Seven bodies were lifted from her broken hull yesterday and carried back to shore to those waiting for their return. Mothers, fathers, wives, girlfriends and children.

Divers found the remaining four members of the crew in the sleeping quarters and gutting deck of the sunken scallop dredger. They freed all seven, carrying them up to the surface from where they were taken to the Isle of Man. Skipper Craig Mills, 29; his brother Robin, 33; their cousin David, 17; and friends and colleagues, Martin Milligan, 26; John Murphy, 22; David Lyons, 18, and Wesley Jolly, 17.

The news was relayed to relatives waiting on the Isle of Man. "There were many tears and I joined them in those tears, there were tears of relief that all seven bodies had been found," said the Rev Alexander Currie, the minister for the small coastal villages around the Isle of Whithorn in Galloway where the men had lived.

"There were prayers in church last Sunday that all seven would be brought home and I thank God that those prayers were heard on their behalf.

"I have been with the families in their grief as a fellow traveller in this journey, it is not yet complete and will not be complete for years to come.

"Our desire was to bring the men home for a burial that would be appropriate to their memories."

The families had all steadfastly refused to contemplate the possibility that the men might not all be found and brought back together, he said.

It has been almost a month since they were lost. The Kirkcudbright registered scallop dredger was overwhelmed on January 11 in circumstances yet to be determined.

The boat was located 38 metres down, 10 miles off the Manx coast. Yesterday, with the weather worsening again, a team of six divers from the Isle of Man fire and rescue service volunteered to search for and retrieve any bodies.

The families, who had travelled to the Isle of Man earlier in the week, were kept protected and informed of every step by the Manx authorities, who shared in the emotion of the news.

"The feeling here is one of relief that the bodies of all seven victims of the tragedy were recovered," said the island's chief minister, Donald Gelling. "At this time our sympathy and thoughts are with the families. Everyone involved in the operation hopes that the news helps them in the grieving process. As far as the Isle of Man government is concerned we are extremely relieved that we have been able to get the bodies for the coroner for the inquest."

Mr Gelling and his authorities were praised for their respectful attention to the relatives and their insistence that they would do everything in their power to bring the men back.

"From day one they have bent over backwards to do everything they could," said Alasdair Morgan, the MSP for the Isle of Whithorn area, "from sending police to Whithorn in the immediate aftermath to effectively underwriting the costs of the opera tion." Last night, the news was spreading round the fishing communities of the South Machars.

"It was our big prayer that they would all be found," said Sarah Scoular, of the Steampacket Inn in Whithorn. "It would have been ghastly if someone had been missing. The community has been in limbo. The whole area has just been waiting, not knowing what was going to happen. With them found it will start a gradual progression. There will be funerals, somewhere to go to pay your respect."

Last night, the news was spreading round the fishing communities of the South Machars. "It was our big prayer that they would all be found," said Sarah Scoular, of the Steampacket Inn in Whithorn. "It would have been ghastly if someone had been missing. The community has been in limbo. The whole area has just been waiting, not knowing what was going to happen. With them found it will start a gradual progression. There will be funerals, somewhere to go to pay your respect."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Death crash student jailed
fields.body:
Death crash student jailed

A former public schoolboy with links to the royal family has been jailed for four-and-a-half years for killing a student while drink-driving in Oxford.

Student William Hobbs, 21, the son of Sir Michael Hobbs, a friend of the Duke of Edinburgh, was more than three times over the legal drink drive limit when he hit Sarah Westwood, 20, as she pushed her bicycle on April 25 last year.

He pleaded guilty at Oxford crown court to causing death by dangerous driving.

Police name murder girl

Police have named a teenager found stabbed to death in a Liverpool street.

Victoria O'Hara, 17, from the Walton area of the city, died from multiple stab wounds to the chest.

Her body was found on Wednesday morning near a builder's yard in the city's Kirkdale area. Detectives do not know why she was there, but believe she was murdered overnight.

Masterpiece found in car

A stolen £400,000 masterpiece has been found by police in the back of a car.

The miniature, entitled Portrait of Mary Clarke, by John Singleton Copley, was found after police stopped a car in Highbury, north London, yesterday.

It was stolen from the Spink Leger gallery in Old Bond Street, central London, on January 5. A 62-year-old man was arrested.

Pair killed in car park plunge

Two men died yesterday when their car plunged from the top of a five-storey car park in Bedford. Investigators will be considering whether the car's automatic gearbox contributed to the incident. A police spokesman said the car was travelling at a relatively slow speed when it toppled from the All Hallows car park. No one else was hurt in the incident.

The victims have yet to be identified.

Lottery to keep rollover limit

Lottery players were last night denied the hope of an unlimited jackpot when the lottery regulator refused to scrap the limit on the number of times the game's top prize can roll over.

Under the game's original rules, there could be no more than three rollovers, where winner-less jackpots are added to the next draw.

Culture secretary Chris Smith announced yesterday that he would allow the lottery commission to scrap the limit.

However, the commission said it would keep Camelot, the lottery operator, tied to the restriction.

"We have no immediate plans to change the rules." a spokesman said.

fields.headline: Police outline leeway on speeding
fields.trailText: Police chiefs yesterday published guidelines revealing that motorists are unlikely to be prosecuted for breaking speeding laws as long as they keep below certain limits.
fields.body:
Police chiefs yesterday published guidelines revealing that motorists are unlikely to be prosecuted for breaking speeding laws as long as they keep below certain limits.

The Association of Chief Police Officers has rejected calls from within its own ranks for "zero tolerance" on speeding.

In a 70mph zone motorists can drive at up to 78mph before they are likely to be pulled over. In a 30mph area they may be able to breach the limit by 4mph.

The guidelines are not a blanket immunity. Officers will take into account the circumstances. A driver travelling at 32mph close to a school may be pulled over, while one travelling at the same speed on a clear road may not.

In September, Paul Manning, the association's spokesman on traffic issues, called for "zero tolerance", saying that cutting speed by just a few miles per hour could save lives. He was supported by the home office minister, Charles Clarke.

An association spokesman said yesterday: "There have to be margins of tolerance because car speedometers are not entirely accurate, and indeed speed detection equipment has not been exactly precise - although it is getting better.

"There would be enormous resource implications if we booked everyone caught doing 32 or 33mph."

The guidelines did not mean that drivers who marginally exceeded the limit could expect not to be stopped.

Police wanted to foster a culture in which speeding was socially unacceptable, in much the same way as drink driving.
