webTitle: Farm family reaps millions from stockbroker belt squat

fields.headline: Farm family reaps millions from stockbroker belt squat
fields.trailText: A farmer killed in a shooting accident had acquired squatter's rights over 57 acres of prime development land in Berkshire, a high court judge ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
A farmer killed in a shooting accident had acquired squatter's rights over 57 acres of prime development land in Berkshire, a high court judge ruled yesterday.

The four fields, which would be worth millions with planning consent, are on the outskirts of Henwick, near Thatcham, in one of the most desirable parts of the county's stockbroker belt.

Mr Justice Neuberger ruled that the farmer's widow and her father were, as his personal representatives, entitled to possession of the land, which was bought more than 20 years ago by a property development company.

The judge upheld their claim that Michael Graham, who died in 1998, had acquired adverse possession - squatter's rights - because the company had failed to show that it owned the land. "This is a conclusion which I arrive at with no enthusiasm," he said. "It seems to me that it is a result which does not accord with justice.

"It does seem draconian to the owner, and a windfall for the squatter, that, just because the owner has taken no steps to evict a squatter for 12 years, the owner should lose 25 hectares of land to the squatter with no compensation."

Developers JA Pye bought Henwick Manor farm and its land in the 1975, but sold most of it two years later. They kept the disputed acres because of their development potential.

Managing director Graham Pye told the judge that he had always intended to keep the land until planning permission could be obtained.

In 1982, farmer John Graham bought the farm at auction for his son, Michael, who married Caroline in 1987, and farmed it until the fatal shooting accident.

The judge said Mr Graham senior always knew that the disputed land was no longer part of the farm when he bought it.

From 1977 to 1984 Pye granted Michael Graham grazing licences on the 57 acres of disputed land, but then refused to grant a new licence. But Mr Graham carried on grazing the land and maintaining it as pasture. In 1997 he applied to register "cautions" against the company's titles, basing his claim on adverse possession.

The company had asked Mr Justice Neuberger to cancel the cautions on the land and to grant possession to them. However, Mrs Graham and her father, Charles Denton, successfully argued that Pye had discontinued possession of the land and that Michael Graham had acquired squatter's rights by remaining on the land for more than 12 years.

The judge said the Graham family had enjoyed factual possession and had the necessary "intention to possess" since 1984. "I believe it follows that the defendants are entitled to be registered as proprietors of the land," he added.

He gave the company permission to take the case to the court of appeal.

webTitle: How BBC made a crisis out of drama

fields.headline: How BBC made a crisis out of drama
fields.standfirst:
Gormenghast is flopping, maybe because of the missing f-factor
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: It had all the ingredients for required cult viewing: a stellar cast including Ian Richardson, Christopher Lee and Spike Milligan, lavish sets, and superb PR. And yet all this has not been enough. Figures this week reveal the numbers watching Mervyn Peake's surreal Gothic fantasy have plummeted by 40% in two weeks.
fields.body:
It had all the ingredients for required cult viewing: a stellar cast including Ian Richardson, Christopher Lee and Spike Milligan, lavish sets, and superb PR.

An entire edition of the Radio Times was given over to puffing Gormenghast, the BBC's £6m "drama of the millennium", and the press has been awash with stories ranging from tales of its creator's colourful past to the provenance of the title sequence's albino crow. The serial's pin-up, Jonathan Rhys Meyers, broods Byronically from adverts.

And yet all this has not been enough. Figures this week reveal the numbers watching Mervyn Peake's surreal Gothic fantasy have plummeted by 40% in two weeks. It may have lured in 4.2m for its first episode - an impressive figure for a BBC2 programme - but by Monday only 2.5m remained.

The BBC says it is less preoccupied with ratings than with offering diverse and challenging television.

"It depends on how you define success," Charlotte Ashton, a spokeswoman, said. "If you're going to use something as crude and blunt as numbers as a barometer, you're not doing it justice. We're concerned about something much more visceral."

Harsh verdicts from the critics as well as poor viewing figures have reopened the debate about what makes a successful costume drama: why is it that Pride and Prejudice and Moll Flanders can lure 13m viewers, while Hornblower, ITV's £12m seafaring story, won an unimpressive 6m, and Rhodes - the BBC1 production shot on location in Africa and reputed to have cost £10m - drew an abysmal 4.8m?

For Alan Bleasdale, the man behind ITV's acclaimed Oliver Twist - which won an average 8m viewers last autumn - there is one main criterion. "Great actors, a tremendous director, a professional crew all help, but what an adaptor needs is a bloody good story."

Bleasdale attributes the success of his Twist to the material he had to work with.

"It was a success because of Dickens: I was working with the work of the greatest novelist of any century, so even when I went away from the text, I knew I had him standing behind my shoulder."

He believes that Dickens is such a hit with fans of costume drama because of his pacey plotting - including the continual use of cliff-hangers - and rich characterisation.

According to Nick Elliott, ITV's controller of network drama, it is this second quality which makes for a popular - as opposed to a merely good - dramatisation.

"You can have good, unpopular drama if you have a good story and characters who are interesting and strong but with whom you don't necessarily identify.

"But for a hit like Pride and Prejudice or ITV's Far From the Madding Crowd, you've got to have characters you want to root for. For the audience to rise from 2.5m to 8m, you've got to have characters who will carry the audience along and be hugely empathetic."

Andrew Davies, the master-adaptor behind the BBC's Middlemarch, Pride and Prejudice and Vanity Fair, as well as ITV's Moll Flanders, once admitted to being wary of working on a novel without a feisty female lead since "women viewers want to be like them ... while men want to go to bed with them".

And Mr Elliott concedes the f - for female - factor is an element.

Predominantly romantic tales featuring strong female characters stir up more empathy than those preoccupied with male swashbuckling, such as Rhodes and Hornblower.

"Too much male is some times a problem, I agree. And it was a huge problem with Hornblower."

Choosing a text that is not too bleak, he believes, also ensures it is accessible.

Dickens's Our Mutual Friend - broadcast to great critical acclaim and gaining around 3m viewers - was shown on BBC2 because of its darkness, and ITV's Tess of the D'Urbevilles drew the - for ITV - "relatively dire" figures of 8m because of its gloomy storyline.

"It was just too damn depressing. Too much gloom isn't what we need,"said Mr Elliott.

For Bleasdale, there is a huge element of luck mixed in with the potentially winning characteristics.

"It's like choosing a football team. What looks good might not work. You can appear to have it all - and yet there isn't that intangible magic."

He refuses to be drawn on whether Gormenghast lacks this magic, but for Mr Elliott, there is no such reticence.

"It was emperor's clothes time," he said.

"There was no serious content in terms of narrative or people you take seriously enough to want to watch. I have to admit I turned off."

Costume drama: the triumphs and the turkeys

The hits

Pride and Prejudice

The 1995 BBC1 adaptation became required viewing for an average 10m a week. Some 11.3m saw the final episode.

Enthusiasm was fired by news of the true off-screen romance between Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle - Mr Darcy and Lizzie Bennett - and, among female viewers, his penchant for tight breeches and wet shirts.

Moll Flanders

With its 17 sex scenes, ITV's bodice-ripping 1996 adaptation, again by Andrew Davies, lured 13m viewers. The BBC's rival offering, Anne Bronte's bleaker and more demure The Tenant of Wildfell Hall, drew in around 4m fewer.

Brideshead Revisited

Figures no longer exist to attest to this ITV adaption's popularity, but it was widely-acclaimed, and brought Evelyn Waugh's tale of Sebastian Flyte and his teddy bear to the masses.

Wives and Daughters

Elizabeth Gaskell's tale of love and marriage, screened on BBC1 last autumn, was initially beaten by ITV's adaptation of Oliver Twist in the ratings, drawing 7.2m viewers for the initial episode compared to its rival's 8.4m. But on average, 7.95m viewers tuned in for each episode.

Oliver Twist

Bleasdale's acclaimed, though not entirely faithful, adaptation starring Robert Lindsay and Julie Walters just pipped Wives and Daughters at 8m viewers per episode.

The misses

Gormenghast

The lavish BBC2 drama has lost 40% of its viewers since its opening episode - with ratings falling from 4.2m to 2.5m.

Rhodes

An unprecedented flop. The £10m BBC1 production about the story of Cecil Rhodes and the founding of Rhodesia boasted superb scenery and Martin Shaw as the star. The 1996 serial slumped to 4.8m viewers, from 7.6m, after just one episode.

Hornblower

Despite being - at £12m - the most expensive TV dramatisation ever, ITV's seafaring saga drew in just 6m viewers. The cherubic Ioan Gruffudd in breeches was insufficient compensation for a lack of strong females.

Nostromo

"Don't touch Conrad," the novelist and academic David Lodge warned BBC1 after they had commissioned this adaptation. The four-part 1997 serial flopped, drawing in less than 3m viewers.

Vanity Fair

Not an unmitigated disaster, but Andrew Davies' 1998 adaptation of Thackery's novel was initially dubbed "Vanity Flop" after the 7.8m who tuned into the first episode slumped to 6.8m a week later. It was beaten by the 9.9m who tuned in for the ITV detective series, Taggart.

fields.headline:
City chaos after ALF 
hoaxes
fields.trailText: Areas of the City of London were brought to a standstill yesterday after bomb threats were issued by the Animal Liberation Front, which was protesting against a controversial animal laboratory.
fields.body:
Areas of the City of London were brought to a standstill yesterday after bomb threats were issued by the Animal Liberation Front, which was protesting against a controversial animal laboratory.

The hoax calls were made against major shareholders in Huntingdon Life Sciences, a Cambridgeshire laboratory condemned by the government three years ago and in which the Labour party's pension fund was recently found to have an investment.

An ALF spokesman, while refusing to confirm that the organisation had threatened up to eight City institutions, said the action was probably timed to coincide with today's "national campaign" against shareholders in the laboratory.

Among the firms whose offices were evacuated after yesterday's threats were Legal & General and Phillips & Drew, both highly-respected fund management groups.

Police refused to confirm the identity of the companies, but said hoax calls at just before 11am from the ALF threatened a series of explosions between 11.15am and 11.30am.

Evacuations saw thousands of office workers spilling out on to the streets of the City in Lombard Street, Aldgate and Cheapside. Barclays bank also received a hoax call and evacuated its head office for four hours.

The Huntingdon laboratory first sparked controversy in April 1997 after conditions at the Cambridgeshire research centre were declared to be unsatisfactory. Its licence was revoked for six months.

Phillips & Drew said it was unaware that the threat was connected to Huntingdon, in which it still holds an 11% stake.

Its holding was exposed a fortnight ago when it emerged that it had invested money for the Labour party's pension scheme in the company. The Labour party said last week that P&D had since sold the 75,000 Huntingdon shares in which its pension fund had invested.

As of yesterday, Legal & General no longer held any shares in Huntingdon. Until recently, it had a 4% stake in the company, which it said it had "inherited" from clients in its funds.

webTitle: Mother of Bristol heart victim dies

fields.headline: Mother of Bristol heart victim dies
fields.standfirst: More on the Bristol babies case
fields.trailText: The Bristol heart operations scandal may have claimed another victim, with the sudden death of a fourth parent whose child died after controversial surgery.
fields.body:
The Bristol heart operations scandal may have claimed another victim, with the sudden death of a fourth parent whose child died after controversial surgery.

Alison Martin, 38, was found dead on her bed; police are awaiting the results of blood tests which may indicate whether she took her own life. Her father said yesterday that she had never been able to overcome her grief.

Her six-month-old daughter, Jenna, died a few weeks after surgery at Bristol royal infirmary to correct a heart defect over 10 years ago. The consultant who carried out the operation, James Wisheart, was later struck off following an investigation by the General Medical Council.

The deaths of almost 2,000 other heart patients at Bristol royal infirmary between 1984 and 1995 are still being investigated by a government-appointed inquiry.

At least three other parents of children who died after operations at the hospital have committed suicide; police are waiting the results of blood tests to confirm the cause of Mrs Martin's death. Russell Gilvear, 67, Mrs Martin's father, told how he found his daughter's body in her bedroom at her home in Creigau, near Cardiff. He said: "When I found her there were no signs of any tablets or anything like that in the bedroom. We won't know what happened until the inquest."

He added: "She was never the same girl since she lost Jenna - it changed her whole life. Alison never came to terms with the loss."

Some of the parents involved in the Bristol case found comfort in the campaign groups set up to fight for an inquiry, but Mrs Martin chose not to become deeply involved.

Mr Gilvear said: "She was so upset she never really got involved."

fields.headline: Kids stay ahead of inflation
fields.trailText: Schoolchildren have received an inflation-busting 6.8% hike in their pocket money, according to figures released yesterday.
fields.body:
Schoolchildren have received an inflation-busting 6.8% hike in their pocket money, according to figures released yesterday.

Last year's average figure of £1.88 for six to nine-year-olds has risen by 12p, according to a survey by the Halifax building society. The research showed that the average amount had risen by 56% compared with 10 years ago, while national retail prices have increased by only 41%.

Girls earned more: £1.91, compared with £1.84 for boys. Regional comparisons reveal that children in London do best, prising an average £2.19 a week out of parental purses. But only 70% of Greater London children receive pocket money, compared with 82% in the north.

Sweets, crisps and toys are still the most popular purchases, but the number of children spending their money on CDs and videos has almost doubled in two years to 25%, compared with 13% in 1997.

The survey suggests that children are becoming less generous, with the number buying gifts for others falling to 18% from 33% in 1997.

Some children look to the future: two-thirds of the 1,700 members of the Halifax's LittleXtra Club surveyed claimed to save most of their cash.

webTitle: 'Sexual Fagin' jailed for forcing girls in care into prostitution

fields.headline: 'Sexual Fagin' jailed for forcing girls in care into prostitution
fields.trailText: A man described as a "sexual Fagin" who recruited under-age girls from children's homes into a prostitution ring was jailed for four years yesterday.
fields.body:
A man described as a "sexual Fagin" who recruited under-age girls from children's homes into a prostitution ring was jailed for four years yesterday.

Martin Malone, helped occasionally by his lover, a care worker, preyed on teenagers from disturbed backgrounds and threatened them if they refused to hand over all the money they made.

Southwark crown court in south London was told that with an average of 10 customers a night, working four or five times a week, some of the girls earned him as much as £6,000 a month.

Malone, 33, admitted six counts of living on prostitution over 20 months from January 1998. Passing sentence, Judge Andrew Goymer told Malone, who had links with up to 22 under-aged young people, that many had run away from home or local authority care, and were already addicted to drugs.

"You took advantage of them for your own profit and gain," he said "You encouraged them to continue in that way of life, you manipulated them by the force of your personality, and also by making it possible for them to continue to finance their addiction."

Pauline Young, 33, from Catford, south London, admitted aiding and abetting her former lover during a two-and-a-half-week period last summer. "You were respected and loved and ought to have known better than to do what you were doing," the judge told Young, who provided home help for disabled children and their families.

Outside court, Chief Inspector Chris Bradford said: "There was an air of the Dickensian about the way he operated and the powerful hold he had over these young girls. He was a sexual Fagin."

Martin Hicks, prosecuting, told the court that Malone ran the operation from his flat in Sydenham, south-east London. "Such was his charm that they willingly carried out his instructions as part of an elite group known as the 'posse' or 'SYD' - sexy young divas."

The children were taken to various parts of London to work; some were picked up from children's homes and driven directly to the streets they worked.

Malone was caught by a police surveillance operation. When he was arrested, girls aged 14 and 15, and a woman of 19 were found in his car.

Mr Hicks told the court that Malone befriended one girl when she was aged about 12, visiting her mother's house as their friendship developed. In early 1998, he told her she should work on the streets for him, and the girl, then aged 14, said she was too frightened to refuse.

She gave all her money to Malone for the next 18 months, and when she once decided to pocket some of the cash herself he threatened her and her family. On another occasion she said he pulled out a black object she believed was a hand gun, telling her it was loaded and warning her against trying to run away.

Other girls also told police how they found it difficult to flee from his clutches, saying he followed them and brought them back.

fields.headline: IRA arms compromise hint
fields.standfirst:
Mandelson backs off direct rule deadline, with 'words not actions' sweetener to Sinn Fein
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson launched a dramatic attempt to rescue the Northern Ireland peace process yesterday, by reassuring the IRA that it would not have to disarm by next week to prevent the reimposition of direct rule.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson launched a dramatic attempt to rescue the Northern Ireland peace process yesterday, by reassuring the IRA that it would not have to disarm by next week to prevent the reimposition of direct rule.

Amid signs of government alarm at Sinn Fein's angry reaction to his statement in the Commons on Thursday night, Mr Mandelson made it clear that he was looking for words rather than actions.

Speaking in Liverpool, the Northern Ireland secretary called for "clear changes for the better to give confidence that decommissioning will happen".

His remarks fell well short of the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble's demand for an actual start to IRA disarmament to allow him to continue in government with Sinn Fein.

Mr Mandelson's conciliatory speech came only hours after Sinn Fein reacted furiously to his warning that direct rule would be restored next week if the IRA refused to make a gesture on decommissioning.

The Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, condemned Mr Mandelson's commons statement as a "disgrace". He added: "At the time when we were actually talking to the IRA, what does Peter Mandelson do? He accuses them of betraying the process. Spin-doctoring for Glengall Street [the Ulster Unionist Party headquarters] was not in Peter Mandelson's remit."

Sinn Fein took particular exception to Mr Mandelson's criticism of the IRA for its "totally unacceptable" refusal to disarm which was a "betrayal" of everybody in Northern Ireland, including republicans.

Yesterday, Mr Mandelson redressed the balance when he said he appreciated the difficulties republicans faced over decommissioning. Speaking to the Institute of Irish Studies, in Liverpool, he said: "I know the passions that an attempt to force decommissioning arouses. I am not naive.

"Surrendering long fought and hardline political ground is one thing. Appearing to be forced to surrender altogether is quite another. That's why decommissioning is a voluntary contribution to the process of building trust. But it is also necessary in order to move forward."

He warned that direct rule would be restored next week if the IRA fails to make a gesture on disarmament, but he made clear that arms would not have to be decommissioned by then.

"If there are no clear changes for the better to give confidence that decommissioning will happen, I will put on hold the operation of the institutions," he said.

His remarks were echoed by Tony Blair, who called for guarantees that decommissioning would start. "There has to be clarity. There has got to be certainty."

The reassurance that the IRA will not have to disarm within the next week - which was stated implicitly in Mr Mandelson's commons statement, horrified sources close to Mr Trimble, who spent the day in crisis talks with senior members of his party. Mr Trimble was due to resign as first minister yesterday, but this appears to have been held off until next week.

There was speculation last night that Mr Mandelson would settle for a timetable from the IRA, spelling out how it would disarm. Unionists made clear that this would be unacceptable.

One unionist observer said last night: "We could be in for another crisis this time next week, but this time all the pressure would be on David Trimble to accept a gesture from republicans."

Mr Adams met the IRA yesterday, fuelling speculation that the provisionals might still be prepared to make a gesture within the next week. A Sinn Fein source said that Mr Adams was working "day and night" to reach a deal.

Meanwhile, the government published the parliamentary bill which would reimpose direct rule if there is no movement on decommissioning. Under the bill, the Stormont assembly and all its committees would no longer be able to meet, and ministers would cease to hold office.

webTitle: M&S rebound to come at a price

fields.headline: M&S rebound to come at a price
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer's new designer clothing will sell for the highest prices the store has ever charged, the company confirmed yesterday as it unveiled plans to put 4,000 extra staff on its shop floors to improve customer service.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer's new designer clothing will sell for the highest prices the store has ever charged, the company confirmed yesterday as it unveiled plans to put 4,000 extra staff on its shop floors to improve customer service.

The chain is also understood to be working on plans to change its famous fascia to update the company's battered image.

The new designer collections, put together for the group by Betty Jackson, Julian MacDonald, Katherine Hamnett and two other designers who have refused to allow their names to be publicly linked with the beleaguered chain, will represent a new "top tier" of merchandise.

The garments will sell for roughly half the designers' normal prices, but they will be two or three times what M&S charges for its standard ranges. They will be priced at around a 40% premium to Marks's present top range - the Italian Collection.

Former chairman Sir Richard Greenbury laid much of the blame for M&S's problems on prices that became too high, and the two most recent fashion ranges have highlighted keener pricing. But the new designer collections are designed to win back customers who have deserted the store not for the discount retailers but for more expensive labels.

The company will deploy the extra 4,000 staff at its 297 stores - which averages 13 new full-time assistants per shop - within the next 10 months. Only 1,000 will be new recruits; the other 3,000 will be "refocused" from back-room jobs.

The decision to put 4,000 more staff on the shop floor comes only a couple of months after the chain announced it was moving 2,500 administrative staff to help customers.

"It is all about getting in shape for our customers," said a spokeswoman. "We have done research and discovered our customers want more service. It is all about turning our stores into centres of excellence."

The work on the new fascia, which an insider described as "different but not radical", is unlikely to be made public for several months.

webTitle: Businessman escapes jail after abusing judges

fields.headline: Businessman escapes jail after abusing judges
fields.trailText: A businessman who has launched numerous court actions accusing the lord chancellor and judges of corruption, perjury and conspiracy escaped jail yesterday when a senior judge urged the attorney general not to push on with his high court application to have him imprisoned.
fields.body:
A businessman who has launched numerous court actions accusing the lord chancellor and judges of corruption, perjury and conspiracy escaped jail yesterday when a senior judge urged the attorney general not to push on with his high court application to have him imprisoned.

Lord Justice Simon Brown said he was "quite troubled" by the move to have Geoffrey Scriven, 63, of Cheadle, Cheshire, jailed for breaching an undertaking not to "scandalise the judges", an arcane contempt of court offence last invoked in 1931. The judge said the concept was "remote from everyday life" and the judges' best response to abuse was "a wry smile".

But he and Mr Justice Penry Davey declared Mr Scriven a vexatious litigant, barring him from launching any more actions without first getting the court's permission.

Mr Scriven has issued 11 legal actions since 1992, when he discovered his wife's divorce petition was wrongly backdated. He believed this was part of a conspiracy to bankrupt him involving solicitors, barristers and judges.

Writs were issued against an ever-widening circle of alleged conspirators, including the lord chancellor, the master of the rolls, the Law Society and the former home secretary, Michael Howard.

Mr Scriven was "outraged" to discover that appeal court judges got "secret briefings" from junior lawyers working in the court about the issues in cases involving litigants in person - those without legal representation. This reinforced his belief that the judges were biased and engaged in a corrupt conspiracy against him.

Lord Justice Simon Brown told Bruce Carr, for the attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn: "The whole question of scandalising the court is remote from everyday life. A wry smile is, I think, our usual response, and the more extravagant the allegations the more ludicrous they sound.

"Just assume we were to commit Mr Scriven to prison today for a while. Then what? Out he comes and his undertaking by then being spent, is he free to go on abusing judges? No doubt he is."

He proposed to adjourn the application to allow Mr Scriven to have legal representation. But Mr Carr said the attorney general had decided that the order barring Mr Scriven from launching any more legal actions was "sufficient protection for the public" and he no longer sought to have him jailed.

webTitle: Election woe for Labour as no-confidence vote looms

fields.headline: Election woe for Labour as no-confidence vote looms
fields.standfirst:
New Labour in power: special report

Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: The Labour party in Wales was left reeling yesterday after slumping to an embarrassing fourth place in the Ceredigion byelection only days before a threatened motion of no-confidence that could topple its minority administration in the Welsh assembly.
fields.body:
The Labour party in Wales was left reeling yesterday after slumping to an embarrassing fourth place in the Ceredigion byelection only days before a threatened motion of no-confidence that could topple its minority administration in the Welsh assembly.

The result was Labour's worst parliamentary performance in this large, rural constituency. Analysts believe the party's campaign was not helped by recent comments from the prime minister on the state of the rural economy.

The victorious Plaid Cymru candidate, Simon Thomas, who comfortably held on to a seat the nationalists have controlled since 1992, said Plaid had won on a policy of "fair play" for farmers and public services, in particular the health service.

Mr Thomas, who sports an earring, said Labour had turned its back on the constituency, which was a Liberal seat for most of the last century.

Labour, which was pushed into fourth place by the Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats, saw its share of the vote collapse from 24.3% at the last general election to 14.4% on a 46% turnout.

It has historically come third in the seat and committed few national resources to the campaign this year.

The party was second to Plaid in the 1997 general election landslide and again at last year's national assembly elections.

Dafydd Trystan, an election trends analyst at the Institute of Welsh Politics in Aberystwyth, said the party's vote had disappeared in rural areas of the constituency and was poor even in its traditionally strong council estate areas.

"You can't tell overmuch about the pattern of Welsh politics from Ceredigion but it does suggest the way the wind is blowing.

"It is clearly not good news for Labour and it is not what they would have hoped for in the run-up to the potential vote of no confidence."

Labour officials remained determined to put a brave face on the outcome which they described as disappointing but not devastating.

There was some comfort that the party's share of the vote was down by no more than 1.3% on last year's Welsh assembly elections.

"We fought a hard campaign and had the best candidate," said a party spokesman.

"This was a parliamentary election. We never accepted that it was a referendum on the assembly or on the no-confidence vote."

As Labour licked its wounds, there was a buoyant mood among the Liberal Democrats, who almost doubled their share of the vote. The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, hailed the result as spectacular.

"It demonstrates we are on course to make substantial gains at the next general election. It is a timely shot across Labour's bows when the government is doing less than it promised for public services and rural areas."

Mr Thomas, 36, a Welsh-speaking rural community development officer who was the co-author of Plaid Cymru's national assembly election manifesto, claimed the outcome was a vote of confidence in the future of Wales.

The father of two said the result sent a clear message to Labour about the way it was running Wales.

"It is also a clear message for Alun Michael and the way the assembly is going.

"I had a lot of complaints as I went around town that the assembly is failing because of leadership. Plaid Cymru is ready to give that leadership."

The snap three-week byelection was triggered by the resignation of the sitting MP, Cynog Dafis, to concentrate on his work in the national assembly in Cardiff.

The result

Paul Davies 4,138 Conservative

Maria Battle 3,612 Labour

John Bufton 487 UK Independence

John Berkeley Davies 289 Independent Green

Martin Shipton 55 Wales

Plaid Cymru 4,948 majority (19.74%)

Swing from Plaid Cymru to Lib Dem 2.72%

fields.headline: Scathing Kilfoyle attacks 'trivial'Labour
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The former junior defence minister, Peter Kilfoyle, who resigned from his post a week ago, last night launched yet another withering attack on New Labour, when he accused the party machine of alienating traditional supporters and of being obsessed with trivial issues of interest only to the chattering classes.
fields.body:
The former junior defence minister, Peter Kilfoyle, who resigned from his post a week ago, last night launched yet another withering attack on New Labour, when he accused the party machine of alienating traditional supporters and of being obsessed with trivial issues of interest only to the chattering classes.

The Labour MP for Liverpool Walton, a self-proclaimed "critical friend" of Tony Blair's government, showed himself to be rather more critical than friendly as he lashed out at spin doctors, the triumph of image over passion in politics, New Labour's preoccupation with the centre ground, the MPs' unofficial code of silence, and the general drudgery of being a minister.

In an interview for the Daily Telegraph, he said he was delighted now to be able to speak his mind and represent his constituents more fully, and he claimed many of those traditional Labour voters "just don't know what new Labour is".

Referring to the government, Merseyside-born Kilfoyle, 53, said: "Many people within Labour, natural supporters, feel as though we don't actually seem to naturally coalesce with them and their aspirations.There's a trend in politics where you just talk about the middle ground and if you talk to the middle ground too much you start to lose sight of all those other people out there."

He accused the government of becoming bogged down in what are publicly perceived as fringe matters - including the attempt to repeal Section 28, which he called "a distraction," and "futile" proportional representation. And he warned there was too much political correctness and intellectual snobbery in public life, which he labelled "a terrible diversion from everything we could be doing to deal with the very real, immediate, everyday problems of real people".

Tribes of spin doctors were dismissed as "minor functionaries giving a wholly erroneous impression of what's going on" and he warned that ridding the party of every shred of ideology would leave a dangerous vacuum at its heart.

But the outspoken MP added as a caveat: "Maybe I'm just naturally Bolshie."

webTitle: Prescott admits risk of losing core voters

fields.headline: Prescott admits risk of losing core voters
fields.standfirst:
Deputy PM says Labour needs to nourish grassroots after byelection wake-up call, but demands 'more admiration, less criticism' from MPs

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott last night rounded off another week of political turbulence for New Labour by admitting that the government is in danger of losing touch with its core supporters - exactly as the Tories did.
fields.body:
John Prescott last night rounded off another week of political turbulence for New Labour by admitting that the government is in danger of losing touch with its core supporters - exactly as the Tories did.

Five days after Peter Kilfoyle resigned his ministerial office to concentrate on nurturing support for Labour's heartlands - and 24 hours after the party was pushed into fourth place in a rural Welsh byelection - Mr Prescott moved to calm the fears of Labour's restless backbenchers, union backers and activists by admitting the danger of waning support.

Labour ignored key supporters in the north, Wales and Scotland at its peril. "We should never lose sight of the fact that it is the ordinary people of this country who we are working for," he warned.

With Tony Blair himself preaching the government's gradualist message in rural Cornwall, party headquarters at Millbank admitted the resounding Plaid Cymru victory at Ceredigion was "a wake-up call" to New Labour.

"It's a bad result, we hate losing. But unlike previous governments we have still not lost a byelection we should have won," said a Millbank analyst who admitted the party in Wales had not yet recovered from the problems over devolution and Ron Davies's "moment of madness" on distant Clapham Common.

The result - which sends Plaid's Simon Thomas to Westminster -is likely to clinch the nationalists' hopes of winning a vote of no confidence in Alun Michael, the first minister of Wales, probably next Wednesday.

Neither his nor Mr Blair's photographs were used until the last minute in the Ceredigion campaign. "They're both too unpopular," an MP said.

Labour's annual local government conference opened yesterday in Blackpool, with the deputy prime minister holding the fort for Mr Blair, who will speak tomorrow.

Mr Prescott was careful to match his concern about a disillusioned rank and file with strong criticism of backbench dissidents who complain that New Labour is little better than the Tories.

Feelings are running high in the regions - despite Mr Blair's insistence that Gordon Brown's employment policies are benefiting them the most.

Outright dissidence is not the gut-loyal Mr Kilfoyle's line. But five days after the Liverpool Walton MP implicitly criticised the party's over-concentration on middle England, the deputy prime minister warned that backbench carping smacks of disunity and played into the hands of the media.

"One lesson we can learn from the Tories is that a party can never afford to become detached from its grassroots or it will wither and decline," Mr Prescott said. "That's what happened to the Tories. First they lost members. Then they lost their activists. Then they lost the councillors ... we have to find ways of nurturing the party, of engaging in real discussion and debate about our policies and priorities."

Acknowledging that the party had badly mishandled its London mayoral selection process, Mr Prescott said Labour had to learn lessons and adjust - particularly since the process could soon be repeated with a string of mayoral elections in England's big cities.

He accused critics of failing to recognise Labour's achievements in government. Pointedly turning round Mr Kilfoyle's new commitment to become a "critical friend" of the government, he said: "I don't mind a bit of coded 'critical admiration'. But sometimes there seems to be more criticism about it than admiration."

But minutes after he sat down, Mr Prescott had to endure more criticism, from the leader of the GMB general union, John Edmonds. While recognising Mr Blair's successes, he said New Labour had to inject much more passion into politics.

He accused spin doctors of failing to publicise Labour's successes - notably a "wonderful policy of redistribution" - in case it offended middle England. The party needed to publicise a conviction "that we are not like all the rest, that we can really deliver a better future, that we believe in fairness and justice and that we really will challenge privilege and inequality".

webTitle: I expected to be promoted, says hurt Redwood

fields.headline: I expected to be promoted, says hurt Redwood
fields.trailText: John Redwood yesterday said he had half expected to be promoted, not sacked, when he was summoned to see William Hague during this week's Tory shadow cabinet reshuffle.
fields.body:
John Redwood yesterday said he had half expected to be promoted, not sacked, when he was summoned to see William Hague during this week's Tory shadow cabinet reshuffle.

In a calculated reproach to Mr Hague after days of grassroots anger over his dismissal from the shadow cabinet, the former leadership challenger told party activists that he had "now got over the shock". He also thanked them all for messages of support.

"I didn't see it coming at all. I thought I was doing all right. I got on with developing policies and attacking the mistakes the government was making in the way that a shadow spokesman should," the former environment spokesman told Radio 4's Today programme.

He coupled his remarks with best wishes to his successor, Archie Norman, the Hague intimate and supermarket millionaire, and a plea for loyalty to the party in the uphill fight against Labour. "So I just say to all those who like what I have been doing, please just get on with the job. The Conservatives do need to provide vigorous opposition ... William Hague has set up some very good common sense policies and he needs the support of all those who share our views."

As political schemers go, Mr Redwood is comparatively straightforward. But he is wounded.

Mr Hague, who promoted Michael Portillo in the same reshuffle that dropped Mr Portillo's rival, Mr Redwood, has taken a gamble in sacking a fanatically hard worker who commands grassroots respect.

Though he is committed to concentrating on Europe and other constitutional issues from the backbenches, Mr Redwood is bound to stray.

Mr Redwood is widely seen as a political anorak, but Mr Norman still has a long way to go before he is even that good.

Within 24 hours an "extremely" brave John Bercow, a junior spokesman, had told the leader to his face - at the rightwing 92 group dinner - that he was wrong. Other MPs piled in.

Mr Portillo's dramatic start as shadow chancellor, ditching old policies such as opposition to the minimum wage, has cheered some Tories. Even leftwingers think he may be the long-term answer, though some also think well enough of Mr Redwood, who won the plaudits of the anti-GM food lobby for asking awkward questions.

webTitle: Politicians who fell foul of the Tory party

fields.headline: Politicians who fell foul of the Tory party
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Sir Julian Critchley Expelled August 1999 in a move seen as William Hague's revenge for supporting the Pro-European Conservatives in the European elections. He was told the party had "cancelled" his membership and he was barred from party conference
fields.body:
Sir Julian Critchley Expelled August 1999 in a move seen as William Hague's revenge for supporting the Pro-European Conservatives in the European elections. He was told the party had "cancelled" his membership and he was barred from party conference

Tim Rathbone Expelled August 1999 along with Sir Julian also for publicly backing the breakaway Pro-European Conservative party in the European elections.

Lord Gilmour Tory grandee threatened with expulsion August 1999. The former defence secretary was warned after voicing strong concerns over euro policy but Central Office could not find any subscriptions paid by him since he was ennobled and so could not sack him.

John Stevens Narrowly avoided expulsion but deselected as Tory MEP for Thames Valley in February 1999. Co-founder of the breakaway pro-Europe party. He was allowed to retain membership and went on to stand as Pro-Euro Tories.

Brendan Donnelly Avoided expulsion February 1999 but deselected as MEP for Sussex South and Crawley after co-founding the pro-Europe group with Stevens.

Dr Adrian Rogers Expelled May 1997. The right-wing family values campaigner and unsuccessful Tory candidate in the 1997 general election, was expelled for calling on Tories to vote for the eurosceptic UK Independence party in the same election.

Raymond O'Connor Expelled 1993 from his west London Conservative Association after standing as a National Front candidate in a local election.

Neil Hamilton Disgraced former minster surprised many when he revealed, after bribe-taking scandal in 1997, that he could not be expelled from the party, as he was not a member. There is no requirement for Tory MPs to join their constituency associations, and Hamilton never did.

webTitle: I lost my heart to Casanova

fields.headline: I lost my heart to Casanova
fields.standfirst: Judith Mackrell  gets swept off her feet at Paris Opera
fields.trailText: Judith Mackrell gets swept off her feet at Paris Opera
fields.body:
The world's great ballet companies sometimes resemble a Proustian circle of aristocrats: each "family" takes passionate pride in its own lineage, yet is haunted by the competition. Which has the most precious heritage, the most elegant women, the most solid future?

As the Royal Ballet searches for a director to take over from Anthony Dowell next year, and considers its course in the new century, this monitoring has become blatant. The company is scouring the world to see if anyone else orders their affairs better. The closest source of comparison, Paris Opera, is also one of the most interesting because it does things very differently.

Paris Opera is older than the Royal Ballet, with a blood line dating back to the 17th century. Its stringent, hierarchical system breeds great dancers, whose superiority it has always asserted. However, it's not such fertile ground for new choreographers: most of the new repertory has to be bought in.

For all that, Paris displays an impressive willingness to experiment. Recent acquisitions include works by Pina Bausch, William Forsythe, Mats Ek and Ohad Naharin. The obvious advantage to this international mix is that it creates versatile dancers and adventurous audiences. There is, however, a danger that such diversity can look arbitrary - a flaky response to fashion that cannot develop the continuity between dancers and choreographers so dear to the Royal.

Recently Paris Opera seems to have reconciled the demands of fashion and continuity by forging a relationship with one of its guest choreographers, 43-year-old Angelin Preljocaj, who's made four works for its dancers in five years.

Preljocaj is French by a matter of five days, having been born in the country just after his parents fled there from communist Albania. Growing up, he benefited from the prodigal arts funding in France; by 1984 he'd formed his own group and by 1996 he was installed in purpose-built premises in Aix-en-Provence. His personal idiom is grounded in the blunt, uncompromising physicality of postmodern dance. But he's aesthetically non-partisan and he travels easily between modern and classical forms. As he's said, "To me, a body falling to the floor isn't any more or less beautiful than an arabesque."

This makes him a prized rarity among choreographers, an artist with a grip on the 21st century who can also do justice to the thoroughbred skills of classical dancers. Casanova, his latest work for Paris, may be headed by soloists and étoiles (principals), but the work itself, epic in scale, high-tech in staging, blending pure dance with spoken text, looks like nothing I've seen on an opera house stage.

The ballet is not a traditional costume drama - it doesn't even have a single dancer playing the title role. Rather it's an anatomisation of the libertine's world as exemplified by Casanova's life. Moving though eight symbolic tableaux, it focuses intensely on the conflicting "humours" of the professional lover. Desire is imaged as a violent disruption of routine, and as a claustrophobic, deadly repeating scenario of seduction and satiation. Sex is conquest and tenderness, and coldly voyeuristic lust.

The work also creates a startlingly dual perspective of the body - presenting it externally as an active object and internally as a system of sensations and tissue over which the lover has little control. This duality was specially pertinent to Casanova, who was a victim of venereal disease. The more active his adventures, the more his body suffered. The more eagerly he sought the timeless moment of orgasm, the more inexorably time marched against him.

These are complicated ideas for ballet, yet the work's design - created by Thierry Leproust and Preljocaj himself - is astonishingly evocative. The opening dances of seduction are performed within a formal drawing-room setting; gradually the stage opens up and, via a series of huge x-rays, seems to take us deep inside the human body. By the end it has become a vast chamber of blood-red walls and bony columns in which the dancers appear like tiny, helpless sparks of consciousness.

Preljocaj's movement vocabulary is supple and precise enough to make us feel these ideas as physical sensations. Classical dance, shaped into phrases of lyricism and elegance, turns brutal under the pressure of lust, and distorts and sickens under the pressure of pain. As confident lovers, the dancers fill the space; as victims, they seem to shrink. The layers of meaning are also enriched by snatches of speech: one dancer, for instance, delivers a lecture on the insidious symptoms of VD while the rest continue to glory in their apparent physical perfection.

The piece is 90 minutes long but feels much shorter. Preljocaj has a split-second instinct for timing and the dancers are a revelation, displaying alongside their virtuosity a mesmerising ease with the alien demands of speech and physical theatre.

It is an impressive work, but watching it I was aware of how dim the chances are of the Royal Opera House staging anything like it. Even though the House is aiming to re-invent itself as a dynamic institution, a work like Casanova may be too big a step. To begin with, it's set to an electronic score - and the House is virtually locked into using an orchestra. Secondly, it has no interval, and the House's budget relies heavily on takings from the bar. Thirdly, it would require some drastic marketing to bring in the kind of mixed age, cross-culture audience that Casanova is drawing in.

In any case, the issue of whether we could entice Preljocaj to create a work here may be academic - for he is now very hot property in mainland Europe. He choreographs for several other classical companies as well as for his own group in Aix, and he's currently acting as artistic advisor to Berlin Opera Ballet. He's also considering Berlin's approach to direct its new super-company in 2001, when the Opera Ballet merges with the State Opera and Comic Opera ballets.

Berlin's eagerness to bag Preljocaj isn't surprising, for creative new ballet directors are even more of a rarity than new choreographers. In the Royal's own race to appoint, there's been a dispiriting lack of outstanding runners to back. The field so far has been led by predictable names like Kevin McKenzie of American Ballet Theatre and untested ones like Ross MacGibbon, who was a dancer with the Royal but is now better known as a TV director. Preljocaj may not actually be suitable for the Royal; he possibly wouldn't even want the job. But it's a shame we're unlikely to get the chance to find out.

 Casanova is at the Palais Garnier, Paris, till Sunday. Box office: 00 33 1 40 01 17 89.

Berlin's eagerness to bag Preljocaj isn't surprising, for creative new ballet directors are even more of a rarity than new choreographers. In the Royal's own race to appoint, there's been a dispiriting lack of outstanding runners to back. The field so far has been led by predictable names like Kevin McKenzie of American Ballet Theatre and untested ones like Ross MacGibbon, who was a dancer with the Royal but is now better known as a TV director. Preljocaj may not actually be suitable for the Royal; he possibly wouldn't even want the job. But it's a shame we're unlikely to get the chance to find out.  Casanova is at the Palais Garnier, Paris, till Sunday. Box office: 00 33 1 40 01 17 89.

fields.headline: This man's no angel
fields.standfirst: Still, he does one hell of an impersonation. Bassist Richard Bona lulls  Rachelle Thackray  into a false sense of security
fields.trailText: Still, he does one hell of an impersonation. Bassist Richard Bona lulls Rachelle Thackray into a false sense of security
fields.body:
Richard Bona is a deceptively quiet guy. At Ronnie Scott's in London, his vibrant orange shirt hinted at ebullience, but he played his bass so softly that the audience, unaccustomed to delicacy, almost missed the point. His voice has been described as angelic, but rather than an ethereal sound, he has the shivery, grounded timbre of a Tiresias, shifting between childlike wail, unbearable sweetness and stern gravitas. His music's exuberance shot out suddenly, startlingly, like bright sunshine during a ballad fragile as mist. The effect was both marked and delightful.

Bona manipulated this pleasing incongruity in both his delivery and his choice of grooves. He was wary one minute, annoyed with a noisy audience the next, then gleeful, enraptured as the layers of sound accumulated. Such unnerving, lightning agility harks back to another weather-changer, Joe Zawinul, who adopted Bona into his band in 1995. It's only nine years since Bona came west from East Cameroon, spurred by the revelation of Jaco Pastorius's bass-playing; legend has it he hopped on a plane to Paris wearing only a pair of shorts.

There was more sunshine in Aaron Heick's perky saxophone and Etienne Stadwijk's Hammondesque bursts on keyboard. In Eyando (a song about turtles, but you'd never know as none of the lyrics are in English), drummer Jonathan Joseph built pace imperceptibly, a momentum of sound released gradually, winding down again to an ambience underscored by a constant, disturbing tribal pulse. That nice ambiguity continued with Stadwijk's blurry pools of sound over the sharpness of multiple rhythms picked out on percussion, guitar and bass.

Bona's ease with his music was evident when, after a track that conjured a foot-tapping African fiesta, he broke into another ballad that quickly changed from poignant moodiness into all-out funkiness, the contrast starkly illustrated by Bona's own vocal screeching of brakes. That humorous moment was surpassed when Heick started laughing and Bona himself had to stop playing, seized by hilarity. "How about a surprise?" he chuckled. "That's what makes the music so beautiful, and that's what beautiful about Ronnie Scott's. You can't do this in Japan." Pure he may be; innocent he's not.

fields.headline: A Liam in every corner
fields.trailText: Lost in music
fields.body:
'So, what are you listening to at the moment?" the person on the other end of the phone is asking me. I take a deep breath, since this is one of my least favourite questions, right up there with "Have you filled in your tax return?" and "The Stereophonics are really exciting, aren't they?".

How easy it used to be: fob them off with a couple of fictitious indie albums ("The new Salmon Riot album rocks, although I think the production on Rent My Dog's Resoluble Golliwog mini LP usurps it") and get the automatic phoney respect of your peers ("Cool, man. You'll have to do us a tape"). These days, with the mainstream so much hipper than the underground, it's become impossible to formulate a made-up or honest response that won't be rebuffed with a disbelieving silence, or a dismissive, "Oh, you're just saying that to be obscure."

What you need for credibility now is a mainstream hook to hang your esoteric heroes on. I've found one in Cotton Mather (no, seriously), one of the best bands of last year. Liam and Noel Gallagher have been passed a copy of CM's Kontiki album and gushed in a couple of interviews that it's their favourite record of the moment; Oasis as a whole were even on the guest list for the group's gig at the Camden Falcon this week.

I find this amusing, since I seemed to spend most of last year writing that Cotton Mather were what Oasis would sound like with 12 times the resourcefulness. The press officer claims it wouldn't have happened without those reviews. I try to form a mental picture of Oasis reading, and dismiss the notion.

Half full, the Camden Falcon is one of London's most rancid, claustrophobic venues. Twice full, it's a bit like a Japanese tube at rush hour, but without quite as much elbow room. You couldn't imagine Liam Gallagher wanting to come here, yet there he is, standing next to Liam Gallagher, and Liam Gallagher, and a bloke who looks like Liam Gallagher. Then my girlfriend taps me on the shoulder to tell me that she's spotted Liam Gallagher on the other side of the room.

I suddenly cotton on: instead of proper security guards, Liam is protected by a hair forcefield, made up of people who look like they might be in Oasis but probably aren't. There's Skinny Liam, Jeff Beck Liam, Mousy Liam, Baby Liam and Little Liam, who also turns out to be Real Liam. We do a quick calculation: Liam always looks about 3in taller than Noel in photos, which, we conclude, must make Noel about the size of Paul Daniels. Noel isn't here, so we can't be sure. But that's definitely Liam - short, handsome, helmet-haired, swigging a bottle of Becks, and pretending the rest of the room isn't looking at him.

Cotton Mather rock like the Beatles might have done if they'd replaced Paul McCartney with Pete Townshend. People attempt to light cigarettes, and realise there isn't enough oxygen. Liam watches, then retreats to the bar, where we overhear him say things like "our kid" and "you fucking love us" to yet more people who appear to have borrowed his hair. He seems like a nice chap, and I wish I dared go up and ask him how he heard of Cotton Mather.

Before I go, I try to have a quick word with Cotton Mather themselves. The press officer who made the "This is all down to you" remark when he was trying to get me to write about the gig is now guarding the dressing room door and says I can't come in. I think he's joking for a second, but he means it. The door swings open, and I see Liam in the dressing room. Cotton Mather are in there too, getting less obscure by the second, and, through no fault of their own, a little less lovable.

webTitle: I'm getting good vibrations but no food and drink

fields.headline: I'm getting good vibrations but no food and drink
fields.trailText: Nicer than Stalybridge | More mythical facts
fields.body:
My friend Stephen Pile planned to attend the opening of 19:20 in Clerkenwell, London, which is billed as "the first ever feng shui restaurant". Stephen rightly thought that I, as someone who regards feng shui as a silly, superstitious moneyspinner for mountebanks, would like to join him. The press release alone was beguiling. "The guys behind 19:20 are Robbie O'Neill and Shaun Wilson, the joint creative force behind such groovy ventures as Beach Blanket Babylon, The Mwah Mwah Bar..."

It turns out that I have mis-spelled the name; since the numbers one, two and three are critical in feng shui, there should be three vertical dots rather than two between the 19 and the 20. Sadly the Guardian's typeface is not yet feng shui-compatible.

Anyhow, I learned that Alessandro Picchio, the consultant, determined that Robbie and Shaun should focus on burnt oranges, browns and Mediterranean colours. "He took a compass reading of the building and divided it into nine areas of influence... including 'Contemplation': as people enter, they may contemplate whether they want the bar downstairs or the restaurant at street level". Then there is "the Journey area", which turns out to mean the stairs, and "the Helpful area: the fire escape - very useful in an emergency." Don't miss "the prosperity area - the cash register".

It certainly had my gastric juices spurting. Sadly, however, the vital chi force seems to have been flowing uphill. The launch had to be postponed because, in their feng shui enthusiasm, the owners completely forgot to apply in time for a drinks licence.

 A bad week for George W Bush, defeated in New Hampshire and thrashed by the political commentator Kevin Phillips in an article in the new edition of the American Harper's magazine. Among other things we learn that "Dubya's" party piece is his impression of Dr Evil in the Austin Powers films, and (this one amazed me) "his own mother made him sit at the opposite end of the dinner table from the Queen of England, for fear of what he might say, when he was 44 years old".

 I was delighted to see how annoyed Richard Branson was in his letter to the Guardian this week, complaining about my remarks last Saturday. What he failed to point out, still less address, was the fact that his long distance rail services are officially, by every measure, the worst in the country.

My overall point was that only Virgin and its agencies regard the Virgin brand image as cool, modern or appealing to customers. Our local department store is offering its positively final reductions on menswear. Virgin logo shirts, made by the Virgin Clothing Company, are marked down from £40 to £15. I couldn't check every garment in the shop, but that was the biggest reduction I saw.

 I was born in Ashton, Lancs, and my mother came from Stalybridge, a short bus trip from Hyde, which now, thanks to Dr Shipman and the Moors killers, seems to be the mass murder capital of Britain. It's hard to know why. I always found the whole place immensely friendly, and have only happy memories of visiting relatives in rows of tiny terrace houses. Even without the benefit of feng shui consultants, they knew to keep their toilets outside the house.

Far from being sinister burial grounds, the moors were a vast open park where you could walk for miles and get away from the soot which hung in the air, sometimes seemingly as thick as snow in a blizzard. People round there still have their own distinct accent, which most Mancunians could place with a precision worthy of Professor Higgins: a "buke" for example is a magazine. What we call a book is a "lyberary buke" whether it comes from the library or not.

People still emigrate from the area, though not because they fear imminent assassination. Years ago I went to visit my Uncle Jack in Sydney. He had married an Australian woman he met during the second world war, set up as an electrician, worked very hard, and was able to buy a magnificent house in the suburbs, a few minutes from the beach. He had a big car in the driveway, a split-level house with a vast wooden deck, and a swimming pool surrounded by hummingbird-infested tropical shrubs. I gazed at it all in awe. "Uncle Jack," I said, "this is magnificent."

"Aye," he said, his accent quite unchanged in 40 years, "nicer than Stalybridge, 'ent it?" He was right of course, but only up to a point.

 Mythical facts continue to arrive by every post. John Probert points out that Howard Hughes did not use his knowledge of structural engineering to design Jane Russell's bra for her role in the movie The Outlaw. Russell has said that all she did was stuff her usual bra with cotton wool. The Victorians did not cover up piano legs because they were prudish: "They are the least sensuous furniture legs. What about curvy chair and table legs? Some 19th century decorators couldn't resist embellishing everything." Nor, he says, is there any evidence at all that knights of old put their women into chastity belts, the first mentions of which come years after the age of chivalry.

Douglas Marchant sent in a slew of mythic quotes. Voltaire never said: "I disapprove of what you say but will defend to the death your right to say it" (it was actually Tallentyre); there is no evidence anywhere that Wellington claimed the Battle of Waterloo had been won on the playing fields of Eton, nor that Burke ever remarked "the only thing necessary for evil to triumph is for good men to do nothing," estimable though the sentiment is. (Nor, of course, did Jim Callaghan ever say "Crisis? What crisis?")

Matthew Randall, who calls himself Anglo-French, nails a persistent myth, widely believed here and in the US, the concept "that Jerry Lewis is a big star in France. He was thought of highly by some New Wave critics and directors. Jerry Lewis's films are never shown on French television, and you would need to look a long time before finding any Frenchman who could name a Lewis film other than The Nutty Professor." Mr Randall says that myths go both ways. They appear to believe that, thanks to Section 28, it is illegal to teach Oscar Wilde in British schools.

Some debunkings of myths may be myths themselves. Last week I mentioned that Walt Disney had invented the notion of lemmings committing mass suicide for a wildlife film. JK Jackson has sent an extract from the 1910 edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica, which describes how lemmings move in armies "until they reach the sea, and swimming onwards in the same direction, perish in the waves, committing what appears to be voluntary suicide".

fields.headline: The last word on...   Leisure
fields.standfirst: The highest pleasure to be got out of freedom, and having nothing to do, is labour. - Mark Twain
fields.trailText: The highest pleasure to be got out of freedom, and having nothing to do, is labour. - Mark Twain
fields.body:
At this time of year many people are planning their holidays, leafing through the Sunday supplements to ponder advertisements offering everything from Andes pony trekking to Zimbabwe big-game viewing. The majority end by choosing beaches in the middle of the alphabet - Majorca, Malaga or Morocco.

Most of these, in turn, think of holidays as paradigmatic times of leisure, by which they mean opportunity for relaxation, not just of body and mind, but - even if only in the form of a little self-indulgence - of morals too: for holidays and moral holidays go together like cakes and ale.

And in one good sense of the word leisure, they are right; for it derives from the Middle French leisir meaning to be permitted, which in turn stems from the Latin licere from which comes license. So leisure is licence, freedom - specifically, freedom from work and duties, allowing one to be at ease, to turn to pleasure, to lay obligations and rules aside.

A good example of the licence afforded by leisure is holiday romance, apt to flare and die with equal suddenness. There is a pleasing irony in the fact that holidays in this respect are an opportunity for sin, for holiday once meant holy day. This conception of leisure is now the dominant one. It is made to contrast straightforwardly with work; and the reflex view is that it is far more desirable than work.

In his famous theory of the leisure class, Thorstein Veblen claimed that a life of leisure is the highest and most beautiful kind. Most who dream about winning the lottery envisage joining that class by quitting work and taking it easy thereafter - beachcombing, playing golf, travelling, listening to the tap leak and the crabgrass grow - and leaving them so, to paraphrase Marya Mannes.

And yet leisure could only be better than work (apart from especially grinding or drudging work) if it were also a life of activity, because mere idleness, after a time, is burdensome. "Absence of occupation is not rest/ A mind quite vacant is a mind distressed," wrote William Cowper, wagging his finger but speaking truth.

Aristotle said that the aim of education is to equip us to make noble use of our leisure: and this fine sentiment implies that leisure is properly an opportunity to enjoy what makes us flourish: to pursue the arts, to reflect, to deepen understanding, to further friendships, and to pursue excellence. If work is concerned with securing life's necessities, leisure is concerned with cultivating its amenities.

It is a commonplace that high civilisation requires leisure, because both the production and the enjoyment of art need time and psychological space, which the harshness of subsistence labour practically excludes. These lofty remarks invite a reminder: that leisure has typically been the privilege of a few carried on the sweated backs of many.

Some aesthetes repine - but only for a moment - at the melancholy reflection that beauty is rooted in suffering. But the happy fact is that civilisation-producing leisure has not always been an aristocratic monopoly. It was once an organic part of work. In the season of plenty - which, paradoxically, was winter, when the grain and the salted pork were safely stored - darkness and hard frosts kept people indoors, making things; including songs, stories, carvings and textiles.

From this change of occupation which the flux of seasons enforced was born painting, poetry, theatre and music. From it also came science, in reflection on experience gathered during the working parts of the year.

The kind of holidays people usually take are not really - so these thoughts suggest - exercises in leisure, but in rest. If they were longer than two or three weeks they would get boring, and would make us hungry for mental stimulus. So viewed, leisure is not the opposite of work, it is - as Mark Twain and Aristotle both suggest - something better: the opportunity to work for higher ends.

If they were longer than two or three weeks they would get boring, and would make us hungry for mental stimulus. So viewed, leisure is not the opposite of work, it is - as Mark Twain and Aristotle both suggest - something better: the opportunity to work for higher ends.

webTitle: There's this gay IRA man, see...

fields.headline: There's this gay IRA man, see...
fields.standfirst: Joe Crilly has a gift for upsetting people in his native Northern Ireland. He tells Mic Moroney  about his latest play
fields.trailText: Joe Crilly has a gift for upsetting people in his native Northern Ireland. He tells Mic Moroney about his latest play
fields.body:
The reactionary winds of Northern Irish society have rattled many teacups down the years in the area of the arts. Take last November's placard-wielding Free Presbyterian pickets outside the Ormeau Baths Gallery, after a brightly coloured invitation to the opening of Gilbert & George's Human Shit pictures landed on Ian Paisley's desk.

Or last summer's decision by the Northern Irish Arts Council to withdraw funding from a West Belfast "community drama" called Forced Upon Us - a big, Republican peat-shovel into the early history of the RUC and the Protestant statelet. Written and acted by a local team, including some former IRA prisoners, it might have sunk without trace; but its director, the respected left-winger Pam Brighton, ensured there was an outcry about censorship, and a good half-acre of newsprint.

Sex and politics also pop up relentlessly in the work of 37-year-old actor-playwright Joe Crilly, whose new work, On McQuillan's Hill, is just about to open at the Lyric Theatre in Belfast.

Crilly's first play, Second Hand Thunder, caused quite a stir in 1988 with its irreverent look at life beneath the sashes in Orange County, rural mid-Ulster. Although set against a scantily fictionalised Drumcree, it was a homey old-style rural drama about the dysfunctional family of an Orange Grand Master, landowner and UDR man, whose respectability was compromised by his rape of a young teacher. The resultant son was hushed up, but grew up a pleasant, normal lad - a source of embarrassment to the comic double-act of the UDR man's other lame-brained sons.

It was a cleverly constructed piece which, flashing back and forwards over 20 years had a taut handle on dialogue, with a colourful larding of rural Ulster argot. The play climaxed in a double murder which, though it was camouflaged as a terrorist outrage, was the result of blackmailing land deals with a conniving Catholic solicitor from the other side of the "ramparts".

Benighted rural sexuality and paramilitarism surface again in Crilly's new play. On McQuillan's Hill is another blackly comic melodrama about a newly released IRA prisoner who comes home, itching to find out why he was shot to ribbons by his former comrades. He's also gay, and happier to reunite with his Protestant boyfriend than with his long-lost sister, or his former IRA commanding officer. Cue a clatter of traumatic revelations involving incest, hidden parenthood and paramilitary betrayal.

Once again, it's mounted by Belfast's Tinderbox, a new-writing company that originally staged both Gary Mitchell and Darragh Carville's work. "Right from the start, we looked at it as a companion piece to Second Hand Thunder," says Crilly. "That was about the Prods, and this one's about the Shinners [Sinn Fein supporters]."

Blunt as that may sound, it's hard to crowbar much more comment from him. "I suppose my central theme is the innocence of the child, and the political and social responsibility to youth and all that mullarkey... And of course, the main thrust of any piece of theatre is to get a good yarn going, rather than getting bogged down in heavy ideology. I'd just like to think I've managed a good mixture between light and shade. In rural communities generally, life is much darker once you lift the covers off."

Although Crilly has lived in London since he was 18 ("half my life, near enough"), he grew up in the rural area of Derrymacash beside Lough Neagh, and has never lost his self-deprecatory, Northern Irish affability - or indeed the accent, which occasionally relaxes into a lazy, sugary drawl.

"Yes, I'm a Loughshore boy. My grandparents on both sides were small rural farmers, but by the time it got to our generation, there was just the farmhouse. But it's less countrified than when I was a kid. The city has crawled to the town, and the town has crawled out into the country."

The local town, Lurgan, was always a hot spot, and the spire of Drumcree church was visible from his front window. "Our area is a patchwork of loyalties. The immediate area is pretty much Catholic, but there' are pockets of Protestant communities as well: good country Prods, fair-minded folk."

But ask him about the local effects of the Troubles, and he becomes evasive. "Sure, shit happened, shit went on. But my background is very much constitutional nationalism, you know - peace- loving and abhorring violence, like the vast_ well, I don't know if vast if the right word, but the majority, of people in Northern Ireland. In other words, we're a nation of moderates, which people often forget."

Why does he give republicans such a hard time in the new play? "I have no time for the militant tendency on either side," he says. "In McQuillan's Hill, the militant republican tendency does get a bit of a rattle - but that's fine. They're sitting targets."

The central character, Fra, is "basically in the Provies because he isn't loved enough. And in my youth I was aware of young guys being in the IRA because it gave them some kind of credibility, a raison d' tre, without any real grasp of ideology or any view on a wider world."

Of Fra's rather chillier IRA superior, Crilly says "he's a dysfunctional character. It's a Vietnam vet thing: the war's over, and he's redundant to a degree. But I'm getting at how these guys work, the whole on-duty, off-duty thing - and it's not just a paramilitary thing, but a military thing as well. It's a double-edged morality, the way they can switch backwards and forwards between rectitude and complete depravity."

He attributes his "tight-lipped, Ulster, country reticence" partly to the fact that his mum still lives in Derrymacash. "Also, I don't want my plays to be part of that 'tales from the war zone' thing. Anyone who grew up here during all the bullshit was affected by it, but it informs people's lives rather than governs them. On a basic level, when writing about Northern Ireland, you have to include some reference to the turbulence. It creeps into every social situation, but it's a lot more complex than a lot of your plays from behind the barricades or your films about the Shankill Butchers."

As an actor in London through the 80s, Crilly was often called upon "whenever the TV companies thought it was a good idea to produce a Troubles drama. The joke among Northern Irish actors used to be 'Have balaclava, will travel', and very rarely would you come across something that you thought was delivering something positive or even plausible."

He also consciously set out to "resurrect aspects of the stage-Ulster tradition, with its farms and its Protestants and Catholics, but to use a much more realistic take on it, and I just love the humour in the language. Listening to neighbours, I'd be very conscious of speech patterns and rhythms. It's just very attractive to capture that in some shape or form."

Although largely unexposed in mainland Britain, Crilly's work has some overlap with the wild-minded rural comedies of Martin McDonagh, with the Troubles as a risible backdrop to characters who are more haplessly tormented than psychotic. "If I'm in sitting London trying to fine-hone my craft as a theatre writer, I'm not 'addressing Northern Ireland' in some tub-thumping ideological way. It has to be done from a different angle.

"Part of the thing about living away from Northern Ireland is that you go back to it anew, having once accepted it as normal. I left during the 1981 hunger strike; it was crazy. Over the years, you realise that because Northern Ireland is such a conundrum, people are sick to the fucking eye teeth of trying to fathom it. My partner's a Londoner and we've a 16-month-old kid now."

The boy's called Redmond, no doubt with a nod to the moderate Irish Nationalist politician John Redmond. "My partner's fine about the North, but she quite obviously feels that Northern Ireland isn't quite the place to bring up a kid. Not that it's an awful place, but there's so much complexity that you wouldn't want to foist on someone. Sure, there's a new generation and integrated schools, but all that old stuff's always there."

Isn't that a damning reflection of his native land? "My instinct is to present grim things with a humorous flourish," he counters. "My gut feeling that people will out, adversity is temporary, and for all of the dark side, the last thing out of Pandora's box is hope_ Um, isn't it?"

He doesn't sound that certain.

 On McQuillan's Hill is at the Lyric Theatre, Belfast (01232 381081), from Monday till February 26, then tours till April. Details: 01232 439313.
