fields.headline: Alla Rakha
fields.standfirst: With Ravi Shankar, he took Indian music to the world
fields.trailText: The name of Alla Rakha, tabla player, who has died aged 81, will always be twinned with that of Ravi Shankar, sitar player. For decades they spread the gospel of Indian music far and wide, and Ravi Shankar, a year younger than Rakha, always acknowledged the supreme artistry of the percussionist whose wizardry on the tabla had become legendary.
fields.body:
The name of Alla Rakha, tabla player, who has died aged 81, will always be twinned with that of Ravi Shankar, sitar player. For decades they spread the gospel of Indian music far and wide, and Ravi Shankar, a year younger than Rakha, always acknowledged the supreme artistry of the percussionist whose wizardry on the tabla had become legendary.

Both men addressed each other as bhai sahib (resp- ected brother). Audiences the world over flocked to their concerts in expectation of the savaal-javaab (question-answer) sessions, when sitar and tabla conducted complex dialogues, and the larant (fighting or competition) passages. Each explosion of improvisation ended in the satisfying flourish of the sum , the beat of completion - a finale invariably greeted with a storm of ecstatic applause.

Alla Rakha, who had the honorific ustad (master), reserved for Muslim maestros of the north Indian or Hindustani style, was naturally possessed of panache, virtuosity and attack. But he could also coax the most elusive and delicate nuances from his drums.

The tabla, whose range is about an octave, is, in fact, a collective term for two drums: the smaller being the right-hand tabla proper, and the larger being the bass drum, called the banya and played with the left hand. Rakha explored new and exciting percussive possibilities and influenced musicians in many countries. Classical artists and rock stars alike sat at his feet to learn the intricacies of Hindustani time measures, or taals , with each taal having a set number of beats divided into bars.

A composer and arranger of long standing, Alla Rakha (under his full name AR Qureshi) provided the music for more than two dozen Indian films, and it was because of his connection with the Bombay film industry that he made the city (now renamed Mumbai) his home.

He was, however, born in Jammu, then ruled by the maharaja of Kashmir. His family were Muslim Dogras (though most of the Dogra clan were Hindus). Their mother tongue was Dogri and, even after having lived in polyglot Mumbai for more than half a century, Alla Rhaka was most at ease when conversing with Dogri-speaking friends.

The British categorised the Dogras as a martial race since their two chief occupations were agriculture and soldiering. Music and any kind of artistic activity were beyond their ken and, in any case, were looked down upon as fit only for kanjars , low-caste entertainers. Although Alla Rakha's father was prepared to tolerate amateur acting, he drew the line at learning to sing or to play an instrument.

Matters came to a head and the son left home at the age of 15 to take music lessons under Lal Mohamed, a disciple of Ustad Kadir Baksh, head of the Punjab gharana (or tradition) of tabla playing. In time, Alla Rakha found his way to Lahore, where he met Kadir Baksh himself. So impressed was the ustad by the young Dogra that he took him under his wing.

For a number of years, as was the custom, Alla Rakha, endured the harshest discipline, but eventually began to get work at the Lahore radio station. His apprenticeship was over. Ustad Kadir Baksh, who had no son, formally adopted Alla Rakha and designated him as the next head of the Punjab gharana . Later, he moved to All-India Radio in Delhi, and then to Bombay.

His partnership with Ravi Shankar began in the early 1950s. They officially represented India at many international music festivals and conferences, and, in the era of flower-power and the Beatles, their names became synonymous with Indian music. Although Alla Rakha remained within the Indian classical tradition, his influence made the tabla the percussion instrument of choice to express mood and atmosphere in film soundtracks, commercials and western popular music.

Alla died from a heart attack one day after his daughter Razia died suddenly following a simple operation. He is survived by his wife Bavi Begum, a daughter Khurshid, who lives in London, and his sons Zakir Hussain, Fazal Qureshi and Taufique Qureshi.

Reginald Massey

fields.headline: Richard Kleindienst
fields.standfirst: US attorney general brought down by Watergate scandal
fields.trailText: The popular perception of Richard Kleindienst, who has died aged 76, was as one of the lesser villains of the Watergate scandal. In reality, he probably did more than any member of Richard Nixon's cabinet to ensure that the American president eventually reaped the just deserts of his malfeasance.
fields.body:
The popular perception of Richard Kleindienst, who has died aged 76, was as one of the lesser villains of the Watergate scandal. In reality, he probably did more than any member of Richard Nixon's cabinet to ensure that the American president eventually reaped the just deserts of his malfeasance.

Kleindienst had been sworn in as US attorney- general just five days before James McCord and his fellow burglars broke into the Democratic national committee offices at the Watergate building in Washington on June 17 1972. He had been promoted after his boss, John Mitchell, moved to take charge of Nixon's re-election committee.

On the morning of the burglars' court appearance, Kleindienst was playing golf near Washington, when a frantic Gordon Liddy, one of those who had helped organise the break-in, tracked him down to warn him that the burglars were in the pay of the re-election committee. He was almost certainly asked to block further FBI investigations. In the event, he rang a senior official in the US justice department to order that campaign officials should be investigated as vigorously as any other suspect.

Kleindienst had already experienced Nixon's reckless approach to the law a year earlier, as assistant attorney-general in charge of the US government's anti-trust case against International Telephone and Telegraph. When a court at one stage ruled against the government, Kleindienst decided to appeal.

Leon Jaworski, later the Watergate special prosecutor, revealed the story in his memoirs. "The president called Kleindienst . . . Nixon's voice was angry and his words abusive. It was a tirade in which he directed Kleindienst not to appeal the case. Several times Kleindienst tried to interrupt but the president wouldn't let him. Nixon expressly directed Kleindienst not to file an appeal."

After that dressing-down, Kleindienst threatened to resign if the appeal was dropped. Nixon capitulated, the case continued and the government won. Later, it emerged that ITT had been a major contributor to the 1972 Republican campaign.

So Kleindienst, with no illusions about Nixon's probable reaction to the Watergate burglary, sprang the trap at the earliest possible moment. The justification for this early response became ever clearer as he tried to cope with the legal tangles of the scandal for a further 11 months. He finally threw in the towel when Nixon had to sack his two principal White House assistants for their part in the cover-up. Kleindienst resigned, pleading that he knew too many of those affected to mount an objective inquiry.

He never again had contact with Nixon, but his earlier loyalties still caught up with him later. At the senate hearing to confirm his appointment as attorney-general, he had been asked if he had discussed the ITT case with the president. To avoid embarrassing Nixon, he said he had not. With the details of the Watergate cover-up unrolling, Kleindienst eventually went to the special prosecutor to tell him of Nixon's attempt to halt the ITT case. He was convicted of misleading Congress and sentenced to 30 days in jail and a $100 fine, both suspended.

Kleindienst returned to his native Arizona to resume his private law practice. Much of his childhood there had been spent in the care of a Navajo woman, who took charge when his mother died. The result was a remarkable fluency in the notoriously complex Navajo language (which has, to cite one example, 400 words for the external parts of the body). His early university years were interrupted by the war, in which he served with the US army air force on the Italian front. In 1950, he got a law degree at Harvard.

In 1953, Kleindienst became the youngest member of the Arizona state legislature, where he hitched his star to Senator Barry Goldwater as one of a group of conservative activists known as the Arizona Mafia. He played a prominent role in securing the 1964 Republican nomination for Goldwater, and made an unsuccessful bid for the state governorship. His subsequent work for Nixon in the 1968 presidential campaign secured his appointment as deputy attorney-general in the new administration.

He leaves a widow and four children.

Harold Jackson

Kleindienst resigned, pleading that he knew too many of those affected to mount an objective inquiry. He never again had contact with Nixon, but his earlier loyalties still caught up with him later. At the senate hearing to confirm his appointment as attorney-general, he had been asked if he had discussed the ITT case with the president. To avoid embarrassing Nixon, he said he had not. With the details of the Watergate cover-up unrolling, Kleindienst eventually went to the special prosecutor to tell him of Nixon's attempt to halt the ITT case. He was convicted of misleading Congress and sentenced to 30 days in jail and a $100 fine, both suspended. Kleindienst returned to his native Arizona to resume his private law practice. Much of his childhood there had been spent in the care of a Navajo woman, who took charge when his mother died. The result was a remarkable fluency in the notoriously complex Navajo language (which has, to cite one example, 400 words for the external parts of the body). His early university years were interrupted by the war, in which he served with the US army air force on the Italian front. In 1950, he got a law degree at Harvard. In 1953, Kleindienst became the youngest member of the Arizona state legislature, where he hitched his star to Senator Barry Goldwater as one of a group of conservative activists known as the Arizona Mafia. He played a prominent role in securing the 1964 Republican nomination for Goldwater, and made an unsuccessful bid for the state governorship. His subsequent work for Nixon in the 1968 presidential campaign secured his appointment as deputy attorney-general in the new administration. He leaves a widow and four children. Harold Jackson Richard Gordon Kleindienst, lawyer, born August 5 1923; died February 1 2000

webTitle: Indonesia's Chinese hold a cautious party

fields.headline: Indonesia's Chinese hold a cautious party
fields.standfirst: Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: In May 1998, as General Suharto's regime underwent its death throes, plumes of thick smoke blackened the sky above Jakarta's Chinatown for several says as mobs ran amok. Almost two years on, the air is once again full of smoke, this time coming from celebratory incense sticks.
fields.body:
In May 1998, as General Suharto's regime underwent its death throes, plumes of thick smoke blackened the sky above Jakarta's Chinatown for several says as mobs ran amok. Almost two years on, the air is once again full of smoke, this time coming from celebratory incense sticks.

Today marks a milestone in Indonesia's transition to a democratic society. It is the first time since 1967 that the country's Chinese, or Tiong Hoa, community has been allowed to openly celebrate the lunar new year.

Dragons have been dancing in shopping malls across the city, plays about Chinese culture are once again being performed, businesses selling Chinese festive goods are reporting brisk business and people are flocking to temples.

"Throughout the Suharto years public celebrations were banned because he forced us to assimilate into traditional Indonesian society," said Errnawati Sugondo, a senior member of the Indonesian Chinese Social Association. "Now we are free to celebrate our culture again and people are very keen to do so."

That is also because this year, 2551 in the Chinese calendar, is the year of the Golden Dragon, the most auspicious in the 60-year cycle.

However, with the scars of the 1998 riots still visible all around, most people will not risk inciting more violence, particularly at a time when ethnic and religious tension between Christians and Muslims is engulfing the Spice islands. "Yes there will be dragon dancing and some public shows," said Lau Xian Sing, a worker at the Dharma Bhakti temple in Chinatown. "But I don't think it will be that big. People are still afraid."

They have good reason to be. In a classic example of divide and rule, Mr Suharto used the Chinese to spearhead his furious economic development programme but so stigmatised them as rich and selfish that they became the scapegoat for all the country's ills.

Not only were they victimised in riot after riot, numerous decrees were passed limiting their involvement in national life. The number of Chinese who could enter the civil service, universities and the military was limited, the use of Chinese characters was banned and people were "strongly encouraged" to take Indonesian names. Now these restrictions are slowly being lifted.

All the major political parties have reached out to the Chinese and the president, Abdurrahman Wahid, has even admitted that he has some Chinese ancestry.

"Gus Dur [Mr Wahid] is being very clever," said Harry Tjan Silalahi, a political analyst. "He is creating a personal link to the Chinese which will reduce people's hostility to them while making them feel more upbeat."

Mr Wahid also appointed an ethnic Chinese, Kwik Kian Gie, as his senior economics minister and a Chinese tycoon, Sofyan Wanandi, as the chairman of his business development board. He also chose Beijing as the destination for his first state visit.

However, 14 of the repressive decrees remain in force and with the country facing political turmoil and economic uncertainty, they are unlikely to be lifted soon.

fields.headline: Witness claims heiress staged abduction
fields.trailText: A terminally ill journalist was named yesterday as a possible key defence witness in the trial of Sara Olson, who is accused of being an active member of the urban guerrilla group that kidnapped the newspaper heiress Patty Hearst in 1974.
fields.body:
A terminally ill journalist was named yesterday as a possible key defence witness in the trial of Sara Olson, who is accused of being an active member of the urban guerrilla group that kidnapped the newspaper heiress Patty Hearst in 1974.

The writer, who helped Ms Hearst escape when she was wanted by police, has claimed that she stayed willingly with her captors, the Symbionese Liberation Army (SLA), and helped stage the kidnapping.

According to reports of court papers, Jack Scott suggests that Ms Hearst planned her own kidnap because she wanted to get out of a relationship, turned down an offer from him for help to escape from the SLA, and was a committed member of the group. Ms Hearst has always been adamant that she was kidnapped, raped and coerced into joining the group and was too frightened to escape.

She was convicted of SLA- related offences and sentenced to seven years, commuted after two years by President Jimmy Carter.

Mr Scott, who worked for the radical magazine Ramparts in the 70s, has cancer. An application was made to a court in Los Angeles yesterday for evidence to be taken from him at his Oregon home.

Ms Hearst has no desire to participate in the trial. But in her book, Every Secret Thing, published in 1982, she implicates Ms Olson, then called Kathy Soliah, as being part of an SLA team that carried out a robbery in which a woman was killed (not by Ms Olson). She also refers to attempts to put a bomb under a police car in Los Angeles. It is in connection with this that Ms Olson is charged with conspiracy to murder and attempted murder.

Ms Olson's website indicates that Mr Scott will contradict Ms Hearst's version of events. He helped wanted urban guerrillas hide from the law.

Ms Olson's lawyers have argued that she did not take part in any acts of violence but went on the run because she feared she would be implicated in them. She has been living under a new name.

webTitle: 10 lost years: Romania's orphans still suffer

fields.headline: 10 lost years: Romania's orphans still suffer
fields.standfirst: Donations from the west bring relief, but the country's faltering economy stokes fears of a total collapse
fields.trailText: Donations from the west bring relief, but the country's faltering economy stokes fears of a total collapse.
fields.body:
Vacant-looking and listless, 16 children at Bucharest's Hospital Home Number 8 for the mentally disabled sit on plastic chairs assembled in three tight rows in the narrow space between their beds. When they can focus, they watch an American soap opera on TV with subtitles that no one can read. There is no other stimulus in the cramped room.

At Gilau, Transylvania, close to 200 boys huddle in a medieval castle with leaking roofs, minimal heating, and a kitchen where an evil-looking black liquid seeps across the floor from a cracked oil-fired cooking range.

The outside temperature is -11C (12F) and frost covers the ground. Inside the cavernous dormitories it is not much warmer, forcing the boys to keep their anoraks and woolly hats on.

Ten years after the scandal of Romania's orphanages shocked the world in the wake of the Ceausescu dictatorship, the number of children in institutions continues to increase. All the talk about getting children back into the community as fast as possible and finding ways to prevent new ones from being dumped in these archaic places has turned out to be largely hollow.

The millions of pounds spent by foreign governments and non-governmental organisations (NGOs) have improved some facilities, but most are still dire.

Only a minority of the children are disabled but even for those who enter the institutions in a healthy state, too little is done to provide emotional or educational support. When they emerge at 18, often physically stunted, psychologically damaged and without social contacts, some have no choics but to live on the streets.

This winter has been particularly harsh. An internal report by the OMAS consortium for the European Commission warned of "a total collapse of the system" if nothing was done immediately. It spoke of food shortages, vitamin and mineral deficiencies, and damp buildings with flooded basements, defective drains and marauding rats.

Although the authorities in Brussels responded before Christmas with an emergency programme to provide powdered milk, disposable nappies and food, the building repairs which the report called for have been postponed until spring at the earliest.

In the first shock a decade ago, Europeans responded with a massive outpouring of concern. Some 10,000 children were "airlifted" out to international parents, often in dubious and barely legal circumstances; charities were deluged with donations. Yet now, as the numbers of institutionalised children rise, things are in some ways worse.

Describing the situation as "extreme", the OMAS report went so far as to warn that the Romanian government would not be able to provide "acceptable standards of care and development for the children for at least the next decade".

Indeed, after visiting half a dozen institutions and talking to a score of officials and NGO employees last week, I found that the crisis can no longer be blamed on Ceausescu. Its main cause - the crippling poverty, caused by 10 years of falling economic output and high unemployment - is new.

The word "orphanage" is a misnomer in Romania, since children with no parents number less than 1% of those in the institutions. Desperate mothers, who receive a pitiful national allowance of £2 a month for each child, give their offspring to the institutions, believing it best for the child.

This, too, is why Ceausescu alone cannot be blamed. He reflected deep-seated attitudes, among care staff, teachers and parents, that "at least the children will get three warm meals a day and a change of clothes", as Judit, a mother of five, put it.

"They have an overwhelmingly medical and physical approach, rather than psychological or social," a British NGO worker in Romania said.

A few group homes have been started, mostly run by married couples who look after eight to 10 children. Sometimes they take in a set of siblings so that a family atmosphere can be created. But these facilities are outweighed by the large residential institutions, which house more than 100 children in each.

In Bucharest, three mother-and-baby centres, financed by foreign NGOs, cater to 10 mothers each. They stay for six months after the baby's birth. The aim is to allow bonding so that the mother is less ready to dump her child.

"Between 1990 and 1996, Romania's policy towards childcare didn't change," says Tim Schaffter, health project officer in Bucharest for Unicef. "Some conditions inside the institutions got better because of massive foreign help. It was good and bad: the attraction of the institutions went up as family incomes went down."

In 1997, seven years after the crisis broke, Romania set up a child development agency.

On paper, it had everything Unicef wanted. It was human rights oriented, decentralised, and had a mandate to find alternatives to institutions, according to Mr Schaffter. The difficulty was that it did not cover the special schools for the handicapped, which often take children with only minor learning difficulties. Nor did it deal with mental hospitals, where children are dumped alongside chronically ill adults.

While the government did pass responsibility for the children to local councils, it failed to consider their budget needs.

"A village of 500 people suddenly had to finance an institution of 500 children, which happened to be in its area," Mr Schaffter. "The children came from all over the country. Obviously, the village had no tax base for that, and couldn't cope."

Handing the burden to councils sent standards plummeting; staff went on strike and children went unfed and unwashed.

The Romanian prime minister, Radu Vasile, dumped the whole issue in the Europeab Commission's lap last year, saying the government could not find the money. In response, Brussels promised emergency cash but warned Bucharest that negotiations for entry into the EU could not start until it cleaned up its act.

Romania was told it had to set up a unified child agency to oversee all institutions and draw up new care regulations which must be monitored. It was also told to find funds from the central budget to reduce the emergency.

The government agreed and, as the Romanian money began to flow again late last year, the EU released several million euros for powdered milk, food, and nappies to 157 children's "placement centres", and a lesser amount for 55 mental hospitals.

Some of the funding was spent on wood or oil for ancient stoves and, in a few places, new cookers and electric washing machines were installed. But almost nothing was done to repair heating systems and leaky roofs.

Aside from revealing how grim Romania's childcare institutions remain a decade after Ceausescu's overthrow, the new crisis highlighted a major dilemma: Should foreign money fund these institutions, or should it be targeted at alternatives such as daycare centres, mother-and-baby homes, foster parents, social-worker training and re-educating Romanians to the reality of their dismal childcare institutions?

"There is no quick fix," says Bob Edwards, the head of the Christian Children's Fund, which runs a programme of financial sponsorship for around 3,000 Romanian families with children in institutions or at risk.

"It's right to develop alternatives such as in-country adoption, fostering, return-home schemes, and small group homes," he said. "But it's totally impractical to close the institutions, and the majority of charitable spending will have to bedevoted to improving them. In the short term, though, institutions should be graded and the worst ones phased out."

Trapped by hardship's revolving door

Judit, aged 32, has five children who range in age from 13 to 17.

When she divorced five years ago and was left with one room and no maintenance from her husband, she put her two boys into the boarding school at Gilau, Transylvania.

The school there packs 200 boys into a medieval castle that lacks heat and proper shelter from nature's elements. This year's winter has been particularly hard.

She took them back after two years when she found a job as a cleaner for a foreign NGO, but because of her high heating bill during this harsh winter she is thinking of sending them off again.

"I filed the papers but withdrew. The children were crying and said they didn't want to go," she said. "One said he'd rather kill himself than return to Gilau.

"I didn't want to send my girls away because I'm scared what might happen to girls in those places. I thought the boys could handle it better. But they talk of bullying and abuse by older boys. The food was poor.

"It's three years since they were there, but they still wolf down their food as though there's no tomorrow."

webTitle: They're off - but Mrs Clinton's already limping

fields.headline: They're off - but Mrs Clinton's already limping
fields.standfirst: Hillary Clinton
fields.trailText: Five hundred people in homes around New York state will pick up the phone tomorrow to hear Hillary Clinton telling them what they have known for months: that she is running for the senate.
fields.body:
Five hundred people in homes around New York state will pick up the phone tomorrow to hear Hillary Clinton telling them what they have known for months: that she is running for the senate.

The conference call will give her an opportunity to exercise the people skills that appear to have failed her so far in her campaign. This time, at least, she will be talking to the hosts and hostesses of house parties to which a total of 24,000 supporters have been invited to watch her ritual announcement on television.

"People are really ready to hit the ground running with Hillary when she announces," said Judith Hope, chairwoman of New York state Democratic party. "These parties will be a great way to harness the energy that surrounds Hillary's campaign." The polls suggest that, for Mrs Clinton's sake, this had better be true.

Whatever she says to the people who answer her calls, she is unlikely to tell them why she is running. At the height of speculation eight months ago about her intentions, the president said he had advised his wife about her political future. "You have to know, you need to know, why you want the job ... the most important thing is that you know why you want to serve," he told her.

She must know but she has not been telling. Not during her summer-long "listening tour" of the state; not during the months of fundraisers and blunders that followed; and not during the past week when she has gone to ground to prepare the way for tomorrow's set-piece, leaving her staff to run a rapid-rebuttal operation against her certain opponent, the New York mayor, Rudolph Giuliani.

At first the vacuum created by her failure to provide the reason was filled with the assumption that a seat in the senate would take her closer to the reward that her ambition and service in saving a tarnished president required - the oval office. But that seems less plausible as she trails in the polls.

After the high school bands and choirs have done their bit and she has said her piece at the state university's Purchase College tomorrow, Mrs Clinton will still be in a far weaker position than a year ago. Polls show that Mr Giuliani would win by 49% to 40% if the vote were tomorrow.

When Mrs Clinton was 10 points ahead a year ago it was partly because of her popularity with women. But even that has fallen by 29% among those under the age of 45.

"Mrs Clinton's core constituency, young professional women, were initially energised by the opportunity to send a woman to the senate," said Lee Miringoff, the director of Marist College Institute for Public Opinion. "They were eager to have the first lady establish her own political career and triumph in her own right. But Mrs Clinton has offered little to her core constituency. She has not reinforced her image as a crusader for children, nor did she quickly emphasise her differences with Mr Giuliani on healthcare, education and the economy."

It is her mistakes that have had most impact. She first supported and then opposed clemency for jailed members of a Puerto Rican terrorist group; remained silent when Yasser Arafat's wife, Suha, accused Israel of poisoning Palestinian children; and, petty as it might seem, wore a Yankees baseball cap when she is known as a Chicago Cubs fan.Voters were reminded of one of her greatest liabilities: she does not come from New York.

Mr Giuliani's style could hardly be more belligerent but he is actually a liberal Republican supporting gay rights, freedom to choose abortion and gun controls. Recently, though, he has embraced more reliably conservative issues, targeting the homeless, taxation and the unions. Rightwing groups have been raising money around the country for his campaign and two weeks ago he was on the same platform as Jörg Haider, leader of the far-right Austrian Freedom party.

"Rightwing groups have made Hillary Clinton their number one target because they know she will be a champion in the senate for New York's working families," said her campaign spokesman, Howard Wolfson.

"The truth is that Hillary Clinton is a new Democrat who supports balanced budgets, targeted tax cuts, welfare reform and the death penalty."

There are still nine months of this to go before the vote.

Mrs Clinton's showing in at least one poll shows promise. Asked by an internet romance site survey which celebrity they would most like to date on Valentine's Day, Americans put Mrs Clinton first on 22%, comfortably ahead of actress Drew Barrymore and singers Jennifer Lopez and Shania Twain.

John McCain has surged into the lead over George W Bush in the latest opinion poll among Republican voters in South Carolina, where a crucial presidential primary takes place in a fortnight.

Mr McCain was on 44% with Mr Bush on 39% in a poll by Zogby International taken on Wednesday, the day after the Arizona senator's surprise win in the New Hampshire Republican primary. A second poll, by Rasmussen Research, showed the two Republicans neck and neck.

Just a week ago, a Gallup poll in South Carolina gave Mr Bush a 20-point lead.

At the height of speculation eight months ago about her intentions, the president said he had advised his wife about her political future. "You have to know, you need to know, why you want the job ... the most important thing is that you know why you want to serve," he told her. She must know but she has not been telling. Not during her summer-long "listening tour" of the state; not during the months of fundraisers and blunders that followed; and not during the past week when she has gone to ground to prepare the way for tomorrow's set-piece, leaving her staff to run a rapid-rebuttal operation against her certain opponent, the New York mayor, Rudolph Giuliani. At first the vacuum created by her failure to provide the reason was filled with the assumption that a seat in the senate would take her closer to the reward that her ambition and service in saving a tarnished president required - the oval office. But that seems less plausible as she trails in the polls. After the high school bands and choirs have done their bit and she has said her piece at the state university's Purchase College tomorrow, Mrs Clinton will still be in a far weaker position than a year ago. Polls show that Mr Giuliani would win by 49% to 40% if the vote were tomorrow. When Mrs Clinton was 10 points ahead a year ago it was partly because of her popularity with women. But even that has fallen by 29% among those under the age of 45. "Mrs Clinton's core constituency, young professional women, were initially energised by the opportunity to send a woman to the senate," said Lee Miringoff, the director of Marist College Institute for Public Opinion. "They were eager to have the first lady establish her own political career and triumph in her own right. But Mrs Clinton has offered little to her core constituency. She has not reinforced her image as a crusader for children, nor did she quickly emphasise her differences with Mr Giuliani on healthcare, education and the economy." It is her mistakes that have had most impact. She first supported and then opposed clemency for jailed members of a Puerto Rican terrorist group; remained silent when Yasser Arafat's wife, Suha, accused Israel of poisoning Palestinian children; and, petty as it might seem, wore a Yankees baseball cap when she is known as a Chicago Cubs fan.Voters were reminded of one of her greatest liabilities: she does not come from New York. Mr Giuliani's style could hardly be more belligerent but he is actually a liberal Republican supporting gay rights, freedom to choose abortion and gun controls. Recently, though, he has embraced more reliably conservative issues, targeting the homeless, taxation and the unions. Rightwing groups have been raising money around the country for his campaign and two weeks ago he was on the same platform as Jörg Haider, leader of the far-right Austrian Freedom party. "Rightwing groups have made Hillary Clinton their number one target because they know she will be a champion in the senate for New York's working families," said her campaign spokesman, Howard Wolfson. "The truth is that Hillary Clinton is a new Democrat who supports balanced budgets, targeted tax cuts, welfare reform and the death penalty." There are still nine months of this to go before the vote. Mrs Clinton's showing in at least one poll shows promise. Asked by an internet romance site survey which celebrity they would most like to date on Valentine's Day, Americans put Mrs Clinton first on 22%, comfortably ahead of actress Drew Barrymore and singers Jennifer Lopez and Shania Twain. John McCain has surged into the lead over George W Bush in the latest opinion poll among Republican voters in South Carolina, where a crucial presidential primary takes place in a fortnight. Mr McCain was on 44% with Mr Bush on 39% in a poll by Zogby International taken on Wednesday, the day after the Arizona senator's surprise win in the New Hampshire Republican primary. A second poll, by Rasmussen Research, showed the two Republicans neck and neck. Just a week ago, a Gallup poll in South Carolina gave Mr Bush a 20-point lead.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: CDU fails to find Kohl donors
fields.body:
CDU fails to find Kohl donors

Germany's Christian Democrats said yesterday they had failed to discover the source of the DM2m (£600,000) in secret donations Helmut Kohl has admitted accepting, but they have traced more secret money that was given to the former chancellor.

A party inquiry found that the network of secret funds dated back further than previously anticipated but will leave inquiries to prosecutors pursuing a criminal investigation against Mr Kohl. AP, Berlin.

Greek leader calls election

The Greek prime minister, Costas Simitis, yesterday called a general election for April 9 - five months ahead of schedule. Mr Simitis wishes to capitalise on Greece's economic recovery and a rapprochement with Turkey. AP, Athens.

Police hunt Pisa parachutist

Italian police were yesterday seeking a skydiver who parachuted off the leaning tower of Pisa on Tuesday and then ran away before engineers restoring the monument could catch him. A Norwegian man yesterday claimed he made the jump. AP, Pisa.

webTitle: Land where thieves get a warm welcome

fields.headline: Land where thieves get a warm welcome
fields.trailText: Zinaida Malkina just can't stop talking about the great time she had in London. She never felt so free in her life than during the week she spent in a dingy little hotel near Covent Garden.
fields.body:
Zinaida Malkina just can't stop talking about the great time she had in London. She never felt so free in her life than during the week she spent in a dingy little hotel near Covent Garden.

It was 1994. Zinaida, an accountant, was so sick of the corrupt antics of her bosses at the Moscow chemicals plant where she had worked for 40 years that she found another job in a bank.

The money was better, too. So with her first pay packet, the 67-year-old left her husband and family behind, teamed up with a friend, and embarked on an adventure - her first trip to the west and to a city she knew only from the television and from her voracious reading of Dickens in translation.

Her eyes still light up at the memory of that brief visit. But they well up with tears when she considers the depths to which Russia has sunk and when she ponders faraway Britain, the country she once thought she knew.

Zinaida's tale is an everyday story of Russian decency in the face of corruption. Unlike many, she has no nostalgia for the days of communism and supports Grigory Yavlinsky, Russia's most consistent liberal democrat.

The chemical plant where she spent most of her life was "privatised" in the 1990s and her boss absconded to America with the proceeds from selling the "workers' shares" to a bank.

A neighbour in her block of flats in a Moscow suburb works at the economics ministry and last year got himself seconded to an "aid and reconstruction unit" dispatched to Chechnya. He went there poor and came back a very wealthy man.

"He was one of us and now he's an aristocrat," she says. "It's the evil that's putting down roots here. It's a terrible place ... I just hope it's better for our children and our grandchildren."

But if Zinaida is sad about Russia, she is shocked about Britain. Out of curiosity a few months ago, she called the British consulate in Moscow to ask about emigration.

"A young gentleman told me that he would examine my case if I could contribute one million pounds to the British economy," Zinaida says incredulously. "It must be a mistake, huh? That can't be right. Don't the British know that to earn money like that here you need to be a thief, a robber or a bandit?"

She fishes a neatly typed sheet of paper headed "Your Majesty" out of her handbag. She's been carrying the letter to Buckingham Palace for weeks, but is too timid to post it. It's not that she wants to emigrate. She's too old and would never leave her family, but that million quid rankles.

"It turns out," she tells the Queen, "that the only people allowed into my beloved Britain are the very same people I want to escape from here. This is really terrible, the end of my last illusions."

But the Queen couldn't know about any of this. She adds: "I think it's probably senseless to send this letter, don't you?"

Capital Letters is a regular Saturday column rotating between Guardian writers in three of Europe's most vibrant cities: Moscow, Berlin and Rome.

webTitle: Japanese to ban driving in platform shoes

fields.headline: Japanese to ban driving in platform shoes
fields.trailText: Japanese police have placed platform shoes alongside cellular phones and alcohol as a threat to safe driving after a series of accidents that appear to prove that fashion kills.
fields.body:
Japanese police have placed platform shoes alongside cellular phones and alcohol as a threat to safe driving after a series of accidents that appear to prove that fashion kills.

Skyscraper soles, some of them up to 10 inches (25cm) high, are all the rage among young women in Japan, completing an outlandish look that also includes bleached grey hair, microskirts, blue contact lenses and unfeasibly long fingernails.

As in Britain, where Baby Spice and Naomi Campbell have come a cropper by following the shoe fashion, there have been sniggers in Japan at the frequent stumbles of its trendy young things.

But authorities are increasingly worried about the health and safety implications of this latest vogue, which has led to a lot worse than sore feet and twisted ankles.

In November last year, the media focused on a fatal accident allegedly caused by a young woman driver who was unable to brake because her eight inch heels got in the way.

With no sign that the current fashion is fading, police have conducted tests to measure the risks of driving with platform shoes. They found that reaction times were 0.05 seconds slower than those of drivers wearing trainers.

Osaka police said yesterday that they would ban people from driving with Atsuzoko butsu - thick-heeled boots - putting the shoes in the same prohibited category as traditional wooden geta sandals and slippers.

In September last year, there was also widespread media coverage of the death of a 25-year-old nursery nurse who apparently cracked her skull when she fell from her five inch high cork-soled sandals.

A poll at the Aoba Gakuen women's college indicated that one in four students had fallen from their elevated shoes, and half of those had suffered fractures or other injuries.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Yorkshire
fields.body:
Yorkshire

Even on a still day the wind blows hard over the exposed chalk cliffs above Flamborough. The day of our visit was not still. Following the coastal footpath along the cliff top of Flamborough Head we were entertained by fulmars and kittiwakes gliding on the air currents rising up from the face of the sheer chalk cliffs. In spring, the few winter tenants of the cliffs and stacks are joined by thousands of others and the species range widens to include puffins, guillemots and razorbills.

At sea level, the pounding of the North Sea has created sea caves and arches in the soft chalk, evolving into blowholes when the sea finally bursts through the cliff slope. In places, the thin soils have slipped, taking the coastal path with them. Elsewhere, there are stretches where the path feels dangerously close to the edge and it is a long way down.

At Briel Nook a solitary chalk stack stands a hundred feet clear of the water, yet someone has managed to place an old car tyre on the top. We speculated as to whether they had climbed up from a boat, dragging the tyre behind them, or thrown it, like a hoop-la contestant, from the cliff top. Either way would be exceedingly dangerous. The tyre may look odd, but a herring gull family has made good use of it as a ready made nest container.

The pressure on today's farmers mean that the fields inland reach as close to the edge as a tractor dare drive. Intensive arable has pushed the coarse coastal grass and chalk loving orchids, cowslips and vetches into an ever-narrowing strip. Skylarks nest in this shrinking habitat, under increasing disturbance from the footpath traffic. It is hoped that some of the inland arable and improved grazing pastures will be allowed to drift back to nature, letting the old grassland provide a seed bank to recolonise the fields. If this happens, skylarks will be able to nest under less pressure, perhaps in greater numbers. In a landscape where every possible inch goes under the plough, it would be a real turnaround if just some could be returned to the wild.

fields.headline: Bouquets of mutuality
fields.standfirst: Interflora
fields.trailText: Send a bunch of wilting flowers this Valentine's day to your loved one and you may risk a less than enthusiastic reception. Ninety years ago, however, there was little option if delivery was not within a short distance of your local florist.
fields.body:
Send a bunch of wilting flowers this Valentine's day to your loved one and you may risk a less than enthusiastic reception. Ninety years ago, however, there was little option if delivery was not within a short distance of your local florist.

But 15 florists in the United States got fed up with the way the flowers they sent over longer distances were wilting on the way. They agreed to exchange orders for out of town deliveries. Because the orders were sent by telegraph, they named it the Florists' Telegraph Delivery Service.

Joe Dobson, Glasgow seedsman and florist, and Carl Engelman, an Essex nurseryman, thought they could boost their business by joining the FTDA.

Unknown to each other they both applied for membership on the same day in 1918. Within five years there were enough British members to form a branch, which broke its links with the FTDA in 1935, becoming the seed from which Interflora was to grow.

The two operations later linked up with a similar Swiss body, Fleurop, under the umbrella of the International Florists Association, to create a network which today consists of 60,000 florists in about 165 countries.

They adopted an image of Mercury - the messenger of the Greek gods - as a logo and introduced their own "currency", the fleurin, to help members who felt they were not up to conversion when dealing with overseas orders. The fleurin is tied to the Swiss franc and local rates are calculated by the national bodies.

Interflora, as the British body is now known, is a non-profit making trade organisa tion based in Sleaford, Lincolnshire, at the heart of the country's flower-growing region. It runs a computer network enabling orders placed in one area to be speedily executed in another.

Its members are now gearing up for Valentine's day - their third busiest day after Mother's day and Christmas day. Valentine, a Christian imprisoned by Claudius II, is said to have started the tradition just before his execution by sending a note to his jailer's daughter, signing it "from your Valentine". His faith had, apparently, cured her blindness.

Today about £23m is spent on sending flowers, including 7m single roses, in the UK and Ireland on February 14.

Members of Interflora make about 750,000 deliveries on the day, 250,000 of which are orders taken by other members of their network.

It has not always been sweetness and light at Interflora. The body has traditionally been run by florists elected by the members. But in 1997 Doug McGrath, a hard-nosed businessmen, was brought in as chief executive with a brief to prepare Interflora for the next century.

It had become complacent, and new companies such as Jersey-based Flying Flowers, a mail order operation, were beginning to eat into its business.

However, Mr McGrath's proposals shocked the membership. They included increasing the annual membership fee from £300 to £1,750 and were widely regarded as a step down the road to ending Interflora's mutual status.

Down that road lay flotation and possible takeover.

It was the last straw for two lady florists, Rose-Marie Watkins and Bev Wood. They wrote by hand to all the members calling for an extraordinary meeting.

Extraordinary it was: the whole board, including Mr McGrath, was voted out of office and replaced by all-florist directors. Demutalisation was taken off the agenda.

The traditionalists have, however, developed an Interflora website which enables browsers to order flowers online. It has proved a boon to those who were embarrassed dictating to florists those intimate messages which accompany so many bouquets.

webTitle: Brands man with the job from hell

fields.headline: Brands man with the job from hell
fields.standfirst: Alan McWalter, M&S marketing director
fields.trailText: A revolution is under way which will change the look of the British high street - Marks & Spencer is working on plans to change its fascia. It will still be M&S, but not as we know it.
fields.body:
A revolution is under way which will change the look of the British high street - Marks & Spencer is working on plans to change its fascia. It will still be M&S, but not as we know it. The change is one of many being worked on by Alan McWalter, Marks & Spencer's brands man - its first marketing director, hired from Woolworth.

Details of the logo, which will adorn everything from shop fronts to carrier bags, are under wraps but a source close to the chain admits: "It will be different but not radical." It will also be next year, if the ailing retailer survives long enough as an independent company to put its plans into action. Once the country's top retailer, so sure of its mission and market that its shares were regarded as a core defensive stock, it is in deep trouble.

Its profits have dived, its Christmas sales figures were the worst on the high street and there are almost constant rumours of predators. It has a new chairman and there is already speculation about replacing some of his top team.

It may be hard to believe in this brand-mad world, but until now M&S has shunned marketing as a management discipline. Now it must catch up, and fast.

Many of Mr McWalter's colleagues from the world of brand building believe that the store has sunk so far, so fast, that the M&S brief is now the marketing job from hell. "It's a basket case," said one retail marketeer, who was approached about the job but says he refused to consider it.

Just plain naff

McWalter begs to differ. By his reckoning it is just "a challenge", and one he is well equipped to handle. He is not even daunted about having to operate in the air-kissing world of fashion. "There are issues to be addressed, just like any other business, and sound marketing to be applied".

He gushes about the brand - despite the battering it has taken in recent months and the fact that M&S is now regarded, not as the home of affordable quality but as just plain naff. "It is a magnificent asset. A world-renowned brand and we will keep it that way".

As the new boy and a marketing man, Mr McWalter cannot afford to appear downbeat. After just a month in the job criticism is tricky - as it would be a direct insult to many of his new, longstanding M&S colleagues. He will concede only that "the market has changed, the customer has changed and we failed to recognise that".

While the City welcomed the retailer's decision to haul itself into the modern world with the appointment of a brand specialist, they were almost universally underwhelmed when Mr McWalter was named. If M&S had managed to pull in the marketing supremo from Tesco or Asda, they would have been impressed but instead their reaction was: "Alan who?".

In fact Mr McWalter, 46, has a solid retail background. Leaving university with a science degree, he joined Unilever working on haircare products. In 1991, after spells working for Spillers thuen Thorn, he joined Kingfisher, first at Comet and then Woolworths. There he masterminded the "Winter Wonderland" promotion. That campaign was "a phenomenal success", and it was his Woolworths' experience "which has equipped me for this job".

He describes himself as "a big brand fan and big brand user" and rates Mercedes, BMW, The Gap and Disney as those he most admires. "They really mean something to people. They are things people aspire to". They also have the status McWalter would like to see returned to M&S.

But analysts and investors who reckon the only way for M&S to regain its prestige in UK retailing is to put established outside brand names on its shelves are likely to be disappointed. Such a move, he says, is not on the agenda, either for fashion or food. Instead he will concentrate on moving the M&S name into new areas, like the mobile phones launched late last year to the prams and cots coming soon.

Inside customers' heads

Last week, just five weeks into the job, he was touring M&S's European operations. "We have got to get inside our customers' heads," he says. He wants service levels improved and the first signs of that initiative came yesterday when the store announced 4,000 new shopfloor staff, made up of 1,000 new staff and 3,000 existing workers who are to be "refocused".

At the same time he was overseeing a major change to M&S's advertising strategy. The group has decided to hunt for a new agency to run a huge new image-building advertising campaign, with a rumoured budget of £15m in the first year.

It is another radical change for the retailer, which has previously employed one agency for clothing work, another for food and others for one-off projects. Now it wants one, big, creative mainstream agency to oversee the lot. It is likely to include a TV campaign - a route the retailer has largely spurned in the past, prefering to concentrate its resources on local promotions for new stores. Just before joining the Baker Street boys, Mr McWalter had a spot of gardening leave and used it to canvas opinion about where M&S was going wrong. "Every morning I took my children to school and talked to mothers -the best market research. They want to see the store back on its feet. They told me the ranges needed to be sorted out but what was coming through in spades was they thought M&S was a fantastic store."

But the evidence in the sales figures and the profit and loss account is that shoppers are no longer in love with St Michael. Or maybe it is just that the mums of Esher - one of Surrey's wealthiest enclaves and the place Mr McWalter calls home - are not M&S's core customers any longer.

The store, however, has some cunning plans to win dissaffected shoppers back - of all income groups. "The middle market is getting very difficult. It is being squeezed from the top and the bottom and we are the key mid-market player", said McWalter. "So what we can do is take advantage of our scale, broaden our range to compete with both the bottom end of the market and the top, niche retailers."

Controversial decision

In the stores that means a range of goods and prices unseen before. The controversial decision to source more goods from overseas means M&S can cut costs and pass on the savings to shoppers. Prices were cut by an average of 5% last autumn and spring fashion ranges, unveiled to widespread acclaim on the fashion pages last week, will be another 5% down.

The starting prices for key items have been slashed by larger amounts. A basic men's suit is down from £120 to £99 this year and a ladies suit is £75, compared to £99 a year ago.

At the other end of the scale M&S is about to unveil new own-label designer ranges, put together by names including Betty Jackson, Julian MacDonald and Katherine Hamnett, which will be sold from specially constructed stores-within-stores. The range is to be previewed in fashion bible Vogue next week and "it will be top tier pricing, higher than anything we've ever done before", says McWalter.

A pair of trousers from the designer range will be about £70, compared to an average £30 from the M&S standard range and £50 for its previously top-priced Italian collection.

McWalter is also heading M&S's e-commerce plans, but they are being put on the back burner until other more pressing matters are addressed. Giftwear and selected items from the spring ranges are available on the M&S website, but there will be little more expansion for the time being. "A key strength in exploiting e-commerce is the strength of the brand. So we must get the core offer right and only then can we export it to new channels like the web".

He admits any turnaround will be a long job. "This is a big thing to take on. We have already seen some improvements but with a business of this scale it will take time."

fields.headline: Emap crashes on US results
fields.trailText: Shares in magazine publisher Emap crashed yesterday after the company surprised investors with a gloomy statement about trading at its American publishing house.
fields.body:
Shares in magazine publisher Emap crashed yesterday after the company surprised investors with a gloomy statement about trading at its American publishing house.

The company said underlying advertising revenues fell by 7% in the final three months of last year - Emap's third quarter. The firm's statement said "particular declines" had taken place in the group's automotive titles.

Coupled with a warning that losses had been greater than expected on the Winter Gravity Games, a sports event in California, the statement sent Emap shares down by 72p to £13.37, a fall of more than 5%.

At one point the shares were temporarily suspended, having fallen by more than 20%, but subsequently recovered.

Although the statement was buoyed by indications that advertising revenues had now recovered and were growing, the group sent a strong signal that profits would be affected when it also pointed out that costs would be incurred in marketing subscriptions and investment to improve the core magazine franchises.

The remarks come as Emap is gearing up to launch FHM in the US with hefty promotional spending. One analyst said profits from the American division could fall to £34m for the year, against £50m the year before. However, because of improvements in other areas, the impact on group profits may be only £10m.

The statement brought some criticism in the City that Emap bought its US operations at too high a price. The group paid £720m, or six times revenues, when it acquired the Los Angeles-based publisher Petersen in December 1998.

Emap acknowledged at the time that it was paying a hefty price but argued the deal was a worthwhile means of gaining a serious presence in the US.

Emap said then that the Petersen stable of titles was in much the same condition as its own some 15 years before, indicating that it could improve margins and profits. In practice the US market has proved more competitive than the group expected.

Emap tried to soften the impact of the warning by making clear that its UK and French operations were performing in line with expectations.

Businesses in the UK will show improvements in underlying profitability on the back of higher advertising and circulation revenue.

In France, circulation revenues were better than in the first half, while advertising continued to show "good growth". FHM, which was recently launched in France, was performing well ahead of original expectations.

The market will now be focusing on Emap's digital operations, which are the subject of a briefing to analysts in March. The company said yesterday that "encouraging progress" was being made, with investments announced in Kick Media and Carparts.com

fields.headline: Vodafone rush triggers market slump
fields.standfirst: FTSE 100 now a health risk
fields.trailText: It may take a while for the Nine O'Clock News to notice but, as from this weekend, at the sweet age of 16, the FTSE 100 index is effectively dead. It is no longer an accurate barometer for corporate Britain. In fact, its very existence can be considered a health risk.
fields.body:
It may take a while for the Nine O'Clock News to notice but, as from this weekend, at the sweet age of 16, the FTSE 100 index is effectively dead. It is no longer an accurate barometer for corporate Britain. In fact, its very existence can be considered a health risk.

Witness yesterday's extraordinary market antics. As bourses across Europe shot through the ceiling, British stocks headed for the floor. The FTSE 100 fell more than 2%.

The culprit was Vodafone AirTouch which, having finally bagged Mannesman, is now creating fresh fortunes for City traders. Yesterday, almost 1.5bn shares in this company worth £5bn changed hands - which must be some sort of record for the London stock exchange.

This volume stems from arbitrageurs who are exploiting the marginal difference between Mannesmann's share price in Frankfurt and the "see through" value of Vodafone's takeover offer.

But we should expect further huge trading in Vodafone over the coming days as index-tracking investment funds, and other fund managers with conservatively run portfolios, move to adjust their weightings in this new corporate giant.

On the calculations of investment bankers Merrill Lynch, Voda-mann's weighting within the top 100 index will jump from 8.7% to 15.4%. It is estimated that if all fund managers were to correct their positions, some £40bn would need to flow into Vodafone stock.

That money needs to come from somewhere and so yesterday the assumption was that institutions would sell other British shares to pay for their new Vodafone paper. This, rather than interest rate worries or concerns about Ireland, is why the market slumped yesterday.

Three companies -Vodafone, British Telecom and BP Amoco - will now account for close to 30% of Britain's most widely-followed investment benchmark. And if big investors are selling other shares to increase their weightings in three monster stocks, there is a danger that the process becomes self-replicating.

This matters. It increases the risk attached to a good portion of the nation's savings (on the eggs in one basket principle). It also makes it difficult for companies which are not telecoms or oil firms to reward their employees through option plans. And what is more, it makes the job of reporting on the stock market very boring indeed. It's time to reform the index system.

EU humbug
Never again. That was the verdict after the world trade talks collapsed in Seattle. Never again would developing countries be pushed around by the big and powerful nations of the west, never again would the voices of Africa and the Caribbean go unheeded. Never again would agreements be negotiated on a take-it-or-leave-it basis.

Well, that was the theory just two months ago. The deal struck yesterday between the European Union and 71 African, Caribbean and Pacific coun tries shows that nothing has really changed, despite the claims yesterday that it was ground-breaking and the last word in generosity.

There are three problems with the overhaul of the Lomé agreement which 25 years ago provided a system of trade preferences for exports of goods from developing countries into the European Union.

The first is that it is worth less in real terms than the old agreement, even though the gulf between rich and poor parts of the world has widened inexorably over the past quarter century.

The second problem is that it comes with strings attached. Countries that want to take advantage of the €13.8bn on offer over the next five years will have to sign up to faster trade liberalisation, whether or not this fits in with their long-term development strategies.

However, the real sting in the tail is the insistence by Brussels that developing countries agree to take back illegal immigrants who have arrived in the EU from their countries, even if they were not nationals of that country or were stateless.

Fortress Europe, in other words, is alive and kicking, and still peddling familiar protectionist nonsense. Allowing too many goods, let alone people, in from developing countries, it is said, could pose a threat to the prosperity and stability of the European Union. It might cost jobs and votes.

The gap between Europe's anti-racist rhetoric and its anti-immigrant policies could hardly be more starkly exposed. In the week that 14 EU member states have ganged up on Austria over the views expressed by Jorg Haider, some might say that this smacks of double standards, and they would be right.

It is humbug of the worst sort.

webTitle: Turning point Nikkei heads along the road to recovery

fields.headline: Turning point Nikkei heads along the road to recovery
fields.standfirst: The growing confidence in Japan's economy pushed Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index past the 20,000 mark yesterday for the first time since the start of the country's financial crisis more than two years ago,  writes Jonathan Watts
fields.trailText: Analysts warned that the burst of enthusiasm for Japanese equities was fuelled more by high liquidity and unproven hopes for a US-style internet boom than by concrete signs that consumption and investment were recovering.
fields.body:
Analysts warned that the burst of enthusiasm for Japanese equities was fuelled more by high liquidity and unproven hopes for a US-style internet boom than by concrete signs that consumption and investment were recovering.

The Nikkei's move past 20,000 points was short-lived, but it was a cause for celebration after the 2 years since it was last at that level on August 1 1997.

Since 1998, when collapsing banks and brokerages threatened the global financial system, the Nikkei has gained more than 56%. But it is still at barely more than half its record high of 38,915, which it hit in 1989.

The real impetus behind the renewed interest in stocks has been the rise of information technology and telecommunications firms, such as Softbank and DoCoMo.

Behind the latest boost is the success of a huge new investment fund launched by Nomura Asset Management, which has topped the ¥800bn mark since its launch on Wednesday.

As well as providing extra liquidity, the popularity of the fund suggests that individual investors, who hold assets of ¥1,300 trillion, are finally moving their savings out of banks and into riskier, more fluid markets.

webTitle: City tunes in to children's TV

fields.headline: City tunes in to children's TV
fields.standfirst: Bob the Builder provides foundation for takeover plan that would create global programming force
fields.trailText: He has a yellow hard hat, blue dungarees and his best friends are Scoop, Muck and Dizzy. His ability as a handyman is unrivalled and he spends much of his time arguing with a scarecrow named Spud. He is also very big business.
fields.body:
He has a yellow hard hat, blue dungarees and his best friends are Scoop, Muck and Dizzy. His ability as a handyman is unrivalled and he spends much of his time arguing with a scarecrow named Spud. He is also very big business.

Bob the Builder, a cartoon construction worker, has become a hero to a generation of pre-school children.

His eponymous animated television series is shown in 66 countries and 14 languages. His website attracted 500,000 visitors in its first week. About 500,000 videos were shifted in the run-up to Christmas and there are now 120 Bob-branded merchandising products available in the shops.

Over the past 18 months the City has woken up to the children's entertainment sector. In that time the share price of the series' producer, HIT, has risen from less than £4 to £22 before a recent five-for-one share split and now stands on an eye-watering price earnings rating of 150 times.

Now HIT is attempting to use its shares to buy Britt Allcroft, owner of the Thomas the Tank Engine, Sooty and Captain Pugwash characters. Chorion, owner of Noddy, Winchester Entertainment, owner of the Jellabies, and the Just Group (Pinky and Perky) have all enjoyed good runs re cently. Just ask BBC Worldwide about the Teletubbies.

HIT says that with Britt it would create the biggest producer of children's television outside the US with global export agreements and leverage ability rarely enjoyed by a British television company.

Britt, named after the founder who mortgaged her house to finance the first Thomas series, is thought to be stalling at the moment and looking for a significant cash sweetener to an offer that would value it at about £224m. Disney and Flextech were rumoured to have expressed an interest but the whispers seem to be fading.

In an age when digital television has caused a proliferation of channels, children's TV programmes have become premium assets, according to Celia Leaberry, an analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson. She says that, even before the rerating media stocks enjoyed in the wake of the recent AOL-Time Warner merger, companies like HIT and Britt offered content that could be leveraged in a way many other types of programming cannot.

"Their programmes do not carry any cultural baggage when they are dubbed," Ms Leaberry said. "With drama it can be more of a problem. Thomas the Tank Engine is sold to 120 countries, broadcast in 11 languages and is one of the most popular licensed characters in Japan."

Peter Orton, chief executive of HIT, says the unique appeal of children's TV is that it renews every three years. "Old shows can be shown again and again. It keeps costs low."

The US is the most important market, accounting for 27% of HIT's revenue. Bob and another popular HIT character, Kipper the Dog, are shown on Nickelodeon, the children's channel owned by Viacom, and HIT aims to strike similar deals for other characters.

Programme makers are also excited about the potential of the internet as an educational medium. They say the interactivity of the net will allow characters like Bob to form the basis for learning programmes which young children are likely to find enjoyable and stimulating.

But the real financial prize is in merchandising agreements. Merchandising sales account for 80% of Britt's revenues. Licensing News says the children's consumer products market in the US is worth $15bn.

HIT has reached agreement with Mattell for a range of toys based on Angelina Ballerina, a tutu-wearing, dancing mouse. Angelina dolls will be pitched head to head with Barbie in the battle for the young girls market. Expect support from Bob, Spud, Muck and Dizzy soon.

His website attracted 500,000 visitors in its first week. About 500,000 videos were shifted in the run-up to Christmas and there are now 120 Bob-branded merchandising products available in the shops. Over the past 18 months the City has woken up to the children's entertainment sector. In that time the share price of the series' producer, HIT, has risen from less than £4 to £22 before a recent five-for-one share split and now stands on an eye-watering price earnings rating of 150 times. Now HIT is attempting to use its shares to buy Britt Allcroft, owner of the Thomas the Tank Engine, Sooty and Captain Pugwash characters. Chorion, owner of Noddy, Winchester Entertainment, owner of the Jellabies, and the Just Group (Pinky and Perky) have all enjoyed good runs re cently. Just ask BBC Worldwide about the Teletubbies. HIT says that with Britt it would create the biggest producer of children's television outside the US with global export agreements and leverage ability rarely enjoyed by a British television company. Britt, named after the founder who mortgaged her house to finance the first Thomas series, is thought to be stalling at the moment and looking for a significant cash sweetener to an offer that would value it at about £224m. Disney and Flextech were rumoured to have expressed an interest but the whispers seem to be fading. In an age when digital television has caused a proliferation of channels, children's TV programmes have become premium assets, according to Celia Leaberry, an analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson. She says that, even before the rerating media stocks enjoyed in the wake of the recent AOL-Time Warner merger, companies like HIT and Britt offered content that could be leveraged in a way many other types of programming cannot. "Their programmes do not carry any cultural baggage when they are dubbed," Ms Leaberry said. "With drama it can be more of a problem. Thomas the Tank Engine is sold to 120 countries, broadcast in 11 languages and is one of the most popular licensed characters in Japan." Peter Orton, chief executive of HIT, says the unique appeal of children's TV is that it renews every three years. "Old shows can be shown again and again. It keeps costs low." The US is the most important market, accounting for 27% of HIT's revenue. Bob and another popular HIT character, Kipper the Dog, are shown on Nickelodeon, the children's channel owned by Viacom, and HIT aims to strike similar deals for other characters. Programme makers are also excited about the potential of the internet as an educational medium. They say the interactivity of the net will allow characters like Bob to form the basis for learning programmes which young children are likely to find enjoyable and stimulating. But the real financial prize is in merchandising agreements. Merchandising sales account for 80% of Britt's revenues. Licensing News says the children's consumer products market in the US is worth $15bn. HIT has reached agreement with Mattell for a range of toys based on Angelina Ballerina, a tutu-wearing, dancing mouse. Angelina dolls will be pitched head to head with Barbie in the battle for the young girls market. Expect support from Bob, Spud, Muck and Dizzy soon.

webTitle: Quiet exit for Mattel chief who danced during board meetings

fields.headline: Quiet exit for Mattel chief who danced during board meetings
fields.trailText: The departure of Jill Barad, the woman who built Barbie into a $1.8bn corporate monster, enjoyed little of the fanfare that accompanied her stint as head of Mattel, the US toy company.
fields.body:
The departure of Jill Barad, the woman who built Barbie into a $1.8bn corporate monster, enjoyed little of the fanfare that accompanied her stint as head of Mattel, the US toy company.

After a long board meeting she slipped quietly through a side door and flew back to a mansion carrying a 6ft model of the doll. One of only four female chief executives in America's 500 largest companies, Ms Barad resigned late on Thursday night as Mattel announced a fourth-quarter loss of $18.4m.

The losses had started with the $3.5bn acquisition of the Learning Company, a software group bought to address Mattel's strategic need to diversify out of traditional toys.

Shares in Mattel fell slightly after the announcement but few analysts blamed concerns over Ms Barad's departure. Instead, they were surprised that a successor had not been found and disappointed about the interim measures taken. Since 1998, a year after Ms Barad's pro motion, about three-quarters of Mattel's market value has been lost. Shares roughly halved last October when Mattel warned that the Learning Company would lose $105m in the third quarter rather than make $50m, as promised a few months earlier.

Disgruntled investors filed claims against the company. While the board came in for some criticism, most of it was reserved for Ms Barad herself, a former model, and her brightly coloured short skirts and management style.

She raised eyebrows by dancing during business meetings and took an emotional approach to staff presentations. At the end of company video presentations she would tell staff: "I love you." But one of her biggest failings was her inability to retain senior staff. One female analyst who refused to be named said: "She is difficult to work with, partly because she takes all the decisions and is supremely aggressive." Other high-flying women have defended Ms Barad against such personal attacks, however.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
TUC supports stakeholding
The government was given a boost yesterday when the TUC announced it would host a stakeholder pension scheme which could cater for millions of subscribers.
fields.body:
TUC supports stakeholding
The government was given a boost yesterday when the TUC announced it would host a stakeholder pension scheme which could cater for millions of subscribers.

Although stakeholder schemes - the low-cost private pension plans unveiled by the government - do not officially become available until April 2001, the TUC aims to begin its scheme this autumn.

Most of the big unions are represented on a group that will discuss how the scheme will work and which pension provider it will team up with.

The scheme might be open to non-union members, a spokeswoman said.

Pegasus battle heats up
Electronic Data Processing, which sold its 7.2% stake in computer services company Pegasus in December, yesterday said it would consider a takeover bid. Pegasus is already the subject of an agreed £30m cash bid from Australia's Solution 6 Holdings and a £46 m share swap offer from Freecom.net.

EDP's possible offer would be a mixture of cash and shares valuing Pegasus at a small premium to its current market price.

Car sales back on the increase
There were 185,040 new car registrations in Britain in January, a 1.8% rise on January 1999, the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said yesterday.

The Ford Focus was the best-selling car, with 10,048 units registered, followed by the Fiesta with 8,651. The Vauxhall Corsa, Astra and Vectra were third fourth and fifth, each scoring just over 8,000.

Help for Ben & Jerry's
Ben & Jerry's, the ice-cream makers facing hostile bidders, could have found a white knight wearing the armour of their trademark social responsibility.

The Vermont-based company said yesterday that it was in talks with a "socially conscious" investor group, although no offer had yet been made. In December, the company announced that it had received several unwanted takeover approaches from large multinationals.

A report yesterday suggested that the white knight bidders could include Tweezerman, a personal grooming business, and Robert Barton, the chief executive of Catalyst Financial Group, an investment bank which specialises in environmentally friendly causes.

No light from Wassall
Wassall, owner of Thorn Lighting, remained reticent over talks that may lead to an offer for the company while reporting a 66% rise in 1999 profits yesterday.

Industry sources said that US based private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts was considering a cash offer for Wassall, possibly valued at around £600m.

Austrian lights company FM Zumtobel Industrieholding is also believed to be interested.

Pre-tax profits before exceptional items for the year to December 31 increased to £63.6m. It proposed an unchanged final dividend of 5.5p, making a total for the year of 7.8p, also unchanged.
