webTitle: Snook happy as Orange peels off

fields.headline: Snook happy as Orange peels off
fields.standfirst: When Klaus Esser launched his defence of Mannesmann in the Savoy Hotel's ballroom last November, Hans Snook, chief executive of mobile telephone operator Orange, appeared unusually tense and subdued in his role as a relatively junior member of the German group's top management,  writes David Gow
fields.trailText: But now Mr Snook, who has won 5m customers through his firm's quirky ads and sponsors the women's fiction prize, said the company is "looking forward to returning Orange to the market as an independent company".
fields.body:
But now Mr Snook, who has won 5m customers through his firm's quirky ads and sponsors the women's fiction prize, said the company is "looking forward to returning Orange to the market as an independent company".

The Vodafone-Mannesmann merger will lead to the demerger of Orange, which is a Mannesmann subsidiary. Orange is convinced "it would have created substantial value within the Mannesmann group but is now committed to creating even greater value outside the group," said Snook.

Chris Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, confirmed that Orange will be run at arm's-length under the direction of trustees, and that Vodafone AirTouch will have no influence over its future.

Mr Gent said that Orange, bought by Mannesmann only last October for nearly £20bn, should be demerged to the wider Vodafone AirTouch and Mannesmann investors after their merger is completed - by the end of March, he hopes.

The demerger of Orange is the minimum price the European commission is expected to demand for approving the Vodafone-Mannesmann marriage. But Mr Gent conceded that the Brussels competition authorities could exact a sale "and if that's what they guide us to do, we will".

Several interested parties have already contacted the Vodafone chief executive about buying the rival phone operator set up in 1993 under the controlling interest of Hong Kong-based Hutchison Whampoa - which retains a 5% stake in New Vodafone.

webTitle: Tesco link with Esso to create 4,000 jobs

fields.headline: Tesco link with Esso to create 4,000 jobs
fields.trailText: Tesco and Esso are opening one new forecourt grocery store a month and expect to be operating about 180 outlets by 2003.
fields.body:
Tesco and Esso are opening one new forecourt grocery store a month and expect to be operating about 180 outlets by 2003.

The expansion plan should create 4,000 jobs, the two companies said yesterday.

The Tesco Express outlets are part of a growing trend among British supermarkets and petrol retailers to offer one-stop shopping for fuel and convenience food. BP Amoco has invested over £100m in a joint venture with Safeway and they operate 39 joint venture sites in Britain. Somerfield is opening stores on Elf forecourts and Spar is also opening outlets at petrol stations.

They are the smallest of the supermarkets' outlets, and regarded by small local stores as a threat to their futures as the supermarkets' distribution networks allow them to carry more fresh food. The concept has grown rapidly in the US in recent years, and supermarkets have invested substantial sums in building networks.

Tesco Express's director, Keith Macaulay, said that Tesco and Esso had opened eight new outlets in the past nine months and were now expanding the alliance.

webTitle: M&S prices get the couture touch

fields.headline: M&S prices get the couture touch
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer's new designer clothing will sell for the highest prices the store has ever charged, the company confirmed yesterday as it unveiled plans to put 4,000 extra staff on its shopfloors to improve customer service.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer's new designer clothing will sell for the highest prices the store has ever charged, the company confirmed yesterday as it unveiled plans to put 4,000 extra staff on its shopfloors to improve customer service.

The chain is also understood to be working on plans to change its famous fascia to update the company's battered image.

The new designer collections, put together for the group by Betty Jackson, Julian MacDonald, Katherine Hamnett and two other designers who have refused to allow their names to be publicly linked with the beleaguered chain, will represent a new "top tier" of merchandise.

The garments will sell for roughly half the designers' normal prices, but they will be two or three times what M&S charges for its standard ranges. They will be priced at around a 40% premium to Marks' present top range - the Italian Collection.

Former chairman Sir Richard Greenbury laid much of the blame for M&S's problems on prices that became too high, and the two most recent fashion ranges have highlighted keener pricing. But the new designer collections are designed to win back customers who have deserted the store not for the discount retailers but for more expensive labels.

The company will deploy the extra 4,000 staff at its 297 stores - which averages 13 new full time assistants per shop - within the next ten months. Only 1,000 will be new recruits; the other 3,000 will be "refocused" from back-room jobs.

The decision to put 4,000 more staff on the shopfloor comes only a couple of months after the chain announced it was hauling 2,500 employees out of administrative posts to put them back in front of customers.

The work on the new fascia, which an insider described as "different but not radical", is unlikely to be made public for several months.

webTitle: Risk takers need to learn home truths

fields.headline: Risk takers need to learn home truths
fields.standfirst: Analysis
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is beginning to look positively blessed in his government's dealings with the City. What started with the prawn cocktail offensive launched by his predecessor, the late John Smith, has blossomed into a relationship so cosy that it is becoming difficult to slip a Rizla between boardroom policy and Downing Street mantras.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is beginning to look positively blessed in his government's dealings with the City. What started with the prawn cocktail offensive launched by his predecessor, the late John Smith, has blossomed into a relationship so cosy that it is becoming difficult to slip a Rizla between boardroom policy and Downing Street mantras.

Now it seems that the big financial guns of the Square Mile are about to grant the latest item on the prime minister's wish list. And it has taken only a short time for the magic to materialise.

Professional investors who control £650bn of funds are getting ready to risk some of the insurance policy and pension fund money in their portfolios to help this government realise its dream of creating an entrepreneur-driven society.

It seemed as though all Mr Blair had to do was bemoan the lack of venture capital money available for the new generation of business start-ups to spark the National Association of Pension Funds into action. The NAPF and the British Venture Capital Association commissioned a study into the risk profile of private investment and to look into why pension funds in Britain have been steadily reducing their exposure to this form of investment.

Just as the results of that research were beginning to see the light of day, the Association of British Insurers, announced that it, too, is about to hold a conference (again in partnership with the British Venture Capital Association) looking into financing small business.

Spearheading these initiatives are two immensely financially and politically adept women. Mary Francis is only recently installed as director general of the ABI and as a former high-flying civil servant she clearly retains impeccable Whitehall connections, while her opposite number at the NAPF, Ann Robinson, has increasingly demonstrated acute political antennae.

Together they seem to be ready to contemplate the notion that the country's biggest investment organisations should use what is effectively seed-corn to try to encourage the wealth and job-creating start-ups in an attempt to guarantee the long-term financial health of the country.

There are, of course, concerns. Coming in the wake of the pensions misselling debacle and coinciding with the alert to endowment mortgage holders that they may face big shortfalls, any sign that investment firms are planning to take greater risks with the nation's savings would be unwelcome - doubly so because investment returns are likely to continue under pressure while the low inflation-rate environment persists.

This is where the NAPF's research comes in. It points out that while overseas pension funds have increased their exposure to Britain's venture capital market, homegrown pension funds have cut back. In 1998, overseas sources accounted for 73% of the total funds raised by British private equity firms.

Yet the research, carried out by the London Business School, argues that the risks of investing in private equity funds is less than most investors perceive and certainly limited only if it is undertaken as part of a diversified investment portfolio. The cashflow profile of many start-ups and the outlook for strong returns can be very attractive to big investors, the researchers argue. Regulations governing the investment strategy of pension funds, such as the minimum funding requirement, present more of a psychological barrier than a real depletion in liquidity, they say.

Part of the reason for the half-hearted involvement of Britain's biggest investors lies in the fact that they have been doing very nicely with the money they have got in big blue-chip companies. Why take a punt on a start-up when there are spectacular returns on offer from Autonomy or Arm?

But the runaway performance of many e-commerce start-ups - coupled with the difficulty in predicting the likely winners and losers - is encouraging big investors to consider a more adventurous use of their funds. Impetus is also coming from the fact that many of the biggest active fund managers, such as Phillips & Drew, Mercury and Schroders, have been lagging in the league tables and are desperate to find alternative investments to give a fillip to their performance.

Although the NAPF's Dr Robinson has not advocated that pension funds pile willy-nilly into the venture capital market she has said that her organisation "would certainly encourage pension scheme trustees to discuss with their investment advisers the merits of this asset class in the context of their scheme-specific strategy".

Other investment experts such as Alan MacDougall, managing director of Pensions Investment Research Consultants, are supportive of the idea that big fund managers should direct some of their investment in a way that could be regarded as "in the national interest".

Despite the recent half-hearted approach of the big fund managers, Britain has managed to develop a reasonably vibrant venture capital market: nearly £28bn has been ploughed into 18,000 businesses since 1983. That is second only to the US. It could, however, be much, much more if the biggest pension and insurance funds start investing for Britain.

webTitle: Europe's corporate culture comes under siege

fields.headline: Europe's corporate culture comes under siege
fields.trailText: It is impossible to exaggerate the implications of Vodafone AirTouch's success in its titanic takeover battle of Mannesmann. The world's corporate financiers now hold almost all industry in the palms of their hands.
fields.body:
It is impossible to exaggerate the implications of Vodafone AirTouch's success in its titanic takeover battle of Mannesmann. The world's corporate financiers now hold almost all industry in the palms of their hands.

It is not the size of Vodafone's final record bid for Mannesmann that is important - but it is the cultural implications of Mannesmann's capitulation that are of greatest significance. A mountain on the German industrial landscape has been appropriated by a foreign company against the expressed wishes of its management, its staff and the German chancellor himself, Gerhard Schröder.

Hostile takeover bids are extremely rare in Europe. In part this is because such actions breech the spirit in which business has traditionally been conducted on the continent. But also it reflects practical obstacles to their success in the form of networks of cosy cross-shareholdings, friendly investment stakes and opaque takeover regulations.

Hostile takeover bids for European companies by outsiders are virtually unheard of. Free competition is not considered an economic virtue across the channel as it is in both the US and Britain. Protectionism is the order of the day, and it can rapidly turn into xenophobia.

On launching its bid last November Vodafone instantly ran into a wall of resistance. Although the British company did not help its cause - its chief executive Chris Gent being reported to have made some particularly crass remarks about his German counterpart while relaxing at a cricket match - its tenacity was admirable.

Peeling back the layers of hyperbole and self-publicity surrounding the success of Vodafone's bid, it can be seen that this is really a victory for shareholder power. For all the noise from Düsseldorf, Mannesmann's share register was truly international. Such investors, the company's owners, expected Anglo-Saxon standards of behaviour from its employees and, in the end, it got them.

One can feel some sympathy for Mannesmann chief executive, Klaus Esser. He ran a company that was regarded as a success. Not only that, but it had its own international ambitions, as evidenced by last autumn's acquisition of the Orange mobile business in Britain.

But Mr Esser did manage to secure Mannesmann shareholders a materially greater share of the new merged business than was originally on offer from Vodafone. In appearing im movable, and remaining mindful of Vodafone's strategic desperation to consummate a marriage, he ensured that the benefits of the deal are skewed heavily towards his paymasters. They are surely grateful.

A mountain on the German industrial landscape has been appropriated by a foreign company against the expressed wishes of its management, its staff and the German chancellor himself, Gerhard Schröder. fields.headline: Vivendi chief plays decisive role
fields.trailText: Although the battle between Vodafone and Mannesmann was billed as a confrontation between Anglo-Saxon and Rhineland capitalism, a key role in deciding the outcome went to a Frenchman, Jean-Marie Messier, the boss of media and utilities group Vivendi.
fields.body:
Although the battle between Vodafone and Mannesmann was billed as a confrontation between Anglo-Saxon and Rhineland capitalism, a key role in deciding the outcome went to a Frenchman, Jean-Marie Messier, the boss of media and utilities group Vivendi.

At the end of last month Mr Messier decided that Vivendi should team up with Vodafone in a new internet venture, effectively destroying Mannesmann's hopes of building up an alliance with the French group which, had it come off, would have helped bolster its defences.

Through the tie-up Vodafone and Vivendi will be able to offer internet services to their combined customer base of about 70m people but the move was also seen as an endorsement of Vodafone's bid for Mannesmann.

At first sight Mr Messier looks a typical French businessman. He was educated at the Ecole Nationale d'Admin istration and served his civil service apprenticeship: in the mid-1980s he was an adviser on privatisation to the then prime minister, Edouard Balladur. It was only after that Mr Messier broke ranks, opting to join an investment bank rather than a big state corporation.

But in 1994 Mr Messier joined Vivendi, then called Générale des Eaux - a sprawling conglomerate that spanned water treatment, theme parks, motorway services and property - which had run into problems when the French property market collapsed.

Mr Messier embarked on a new strategy: refining and developing the traditional businesses, developing the communications arm and selling a raft of stakes in other French industrial groups.

The environmental division now embraces water treatment - it is the largest supplier of water purification equipment in the US following last year's purchase of US Filter - energy, waste management and transport, which includes British rail services Connex South East and Connex South Central. But it is Mr Messier's expansion of the communications division that has attracted most interest in Vivendi. In the past five years Vivendi's communications arm has seen its revenues grow from €900m (£552m) to €3bn.

One reason behind the growth is that Vivendi is the biggest shareholder in France's second-largest mobile phone company, Cégétel, and its link-up with Vodafone will give it outright control, providing a platform for further expansion.

But there is more to Vivendi than telecoms. It has a controlling stake in pay-TV group Canal Plus and has frightened Rupert Murdoch with a 24.5% stake in in BSkyB, a relationship which has attracted the attention of Britain's competition authorities.

Through its Havas publishing arm Vivendi is also a leading player in the educational and entertainment software markets.

Last week the group unveiled estimated results for the which showed that net sales had risen more than €41.5bn, up 30% on the previous year, while net income was up by a similar amount at €1.34bn.

fields.headline: Weather watch
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor watches the weather online
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor watches the weather online
fields.body:
It may be a peculiarly British trait, but there is something satisfying about checking out the weather in the days before a holiday. It's still beyond your control, but information available on the web makes it much easier to decide what clothes to take and how much sunscreen and insect repellent is called for.

Skiclub
For skiers and mountaineers, of course, reliable weather forecasts are a necessity. If you're off to the slopes soon, visit Skiclub's snow reports. Resident weatherwoman Laura provides details of powder quality and pistes in the best condition. Skiclub is one of the most comprehensive of the many new skiing-related sites and allows you to search by resort, covering most of Europe, Scotland and North America.

Sport Scotland Avalanche Information Service
Walkers and mountaineers in Scotland can consult the Sport Scotland Avalanche Information Service. It covers Glen Coe, the northern and southern Cairngorms, Lochaber and Creag Meagaidh, and is also an excellent source of information on avalanche risks and emergency tactics.

The Met Office
The Met Office, as one might expect, covers Britain's weather in great detail, and includes a three-day forecast and severe-weather warnings. A special section is devoted to UV radiation levels in the UK and Europe. This is also the place to read the latest shipping forecast in its oddly compelling detail, as well as reports from inshore waters.

Intellicast
In the US, Intellicast has beautifully-detailed graphical information for North American cities - satellite pictures, precipitation maps and other data for those who take forecasting seriously. Larger-scale maps are available for such places as Kuala Lumpur.

Yahoo
Finally, Yahoo's weather service offers what is probably the most up-to-date international service on the web. You can add details of your chosen town or region to a My Yahoo homepage. In terms of speed and ease of understanding, this site is the clearest; its coverage of extreme weather conditions is also very good, should you be unfortunate enough to take a holiday in an uncertain climate.

webTitle: Last knockings for a policy on the way out

fields.headline: Last knockings for a policy on the way out
fields.standfirst: As the Prudential quits this troubled area of the market the whole scheme looks increasingly dubious. Tony Levene reports
fields.trailText: The Prudential, Britain's biggest life company, has decided to pull out of endowment policy linked home loan repayment schemes - the latest in a long line of life insurers which includes Scottish Widows, NatWest and Lloyds TSB.
fields.body:
The men from the Pru - or what remains of that endangered species of door to door insurance agents - won't be knocking with an endowment mortgage any more.

The Prudential, Britain's biggest life company, has decided to pull out of endowment policy linked home loan repayment schemes - the latest in a long line of life insurers which includes Scottish Widows, NatWest and Lloyds TSB.

The Pru says it has made the decision for "economic reasons". It says low sales of the controversial schemes have made it too expensive to stay in the market. The life office denies that it has pulled its plans because they have been criticised as expensive, inflexible, and increasingly unlikely to pay off the loan on maturity as promised. "This does not imply a judgment about the suitability of endowments," the Pru says.

But it could hardly make an adverse judgment as this might give the 300,000 who still have Pru mortgage endowments the ammunition to demand compensation if their plan does fall short.

CGU, the amalgamation of Commercial Union and General Accident, has come up with a promise to increase payouts to cover the mortgage if there is any shortfall. But this pledge will be ditched if the average investment performance falls below 6% per year.

David Carrington at endowment traders PolicyPlus says that while "this scenario is unlikely, it is a positive step to reassure policyholders."

But many other endowment policyholders now face the stark choice of paying more in monthly premiums now or risking having to find a lump sum to redeem their mortgage. And the most recent spate of annual results from companies operating with-profits policies, the great bulk of plans backing home loans, can only add to those fears.

These plans offer a combination of life cover and investment vehicle plus a guarantee that their value can never fall back no matter how bad market conditions become.

Once a bonus is given, it can never be taken away. But they also suffer from high costs, including the need to pay commission to policy sellers which can strip out a fifth or more from the annual returns.

With profits companies declare two types of bonuses. "Reversionary" or annual bonuses, and terminal bonuses when the policies mature. Most companies this year have concentrated their publicity spin on their terminal bonuses.

But while terminal bonus figures are vital for 25-year endowment holders who bought a quarter of a century ago and whose policies have now matured, they give no indication of the future value of more recent plans.

Terminal bonuses are a year-to-year decision, with this year's having no impact on those still to come. Of the 12 major offices which have so far reported, eight have dropped their total 25-year payout including the terminal bonus, while the four that did rise only produced marginal increases.

The bad news for continuing policyholders is that almost all reversionary bonuses are down, giving a lower base for future bonuses and a reduced final level for the terminal bonus.

The Halifax-owned Clerical Medical, which declared its figures this week, is typical of many in cutting its bonus on the basic sum assured from 2.5% to 2% although it did better than many in holding the bonus it pays on previous bonuses, a form of compound growth, at 4%.

Crusader Insurance, now has one of the lowest bonuses with a microscopic 0.7% on the sum assured, compared with 1.1% last year and 1.6% on previous bonuses, down a full percentage point over the year.

Mr Carrington says: "We have seen a continuation of the movement away from annual bonuses with more emphasis on terminal bonuses. This is due to the belief that we are in a low interest rate/ low inflation environment and we are likely to remain in this situation for the duration of many policies.

"There has been quite a range of terminal bonus declarations with life offices taking different views on last year's volatile stock market performance. There will always be quite a range in terminal bonuses."

But no one is prepared to say whether plans purchased during the 1990s will ever acheive promised payouts.

fields.headline: Solving the Leicester debate
fields.standfirst: Leicester and the best way to win the argument
fields.trailText: Leicester City boring? How could that be when the club continue to command so much space on the sports pages?
fields.body:
Tweedledum and Tweedledee have been at it this week. Dum said Dee's football team played kick-and-rush, Dee said Dum was a footballing cretin to which Dum replied that it took one to know one.

All of which signified little except that Martin O'Neill, the manager of Leicester City, has a skin as thin as rice paper while in matters of wit and repartee Ken Bates, the chairman of Chelsea, is never going to be mistaken for Ken Dodd.

Leicester City boring? How could that be when the club continue to command so much space on the sports pages? Last autumn the boardroom in-fighting at Filbert Street was as dramatic as anything seen on the pitch in the Premiership this season. And no sooner had O'Neill's team reached their third League Cup final in four years than a further five players and three backroom staff are charged with misconduct by the Football Association over distribution of tickets for last season's game at Wembley.

Life at Leicester City sounds like Dallas without the shooting. If television made a soap of it, the critics would condemn the show on grounds of improbability. No football manager, they might say, would ever cavort on the touchline like Leonard Bernstein conducting the New York Philharmonic.

Ah, but what about the football, never mind the noises off the pitch? Hands on hearts, did not a handful of hacks opt for reporting Manchester United at Hillsborough on Wednesday, grateful to have an excuse for avoiding another dose of ET&P (extra-time and penalties) in the return leg of Leicester's League Cup semi-final against Aston Villa?

Well, yes, the thought did occur, and was made redundant by Matt Elliott's winner in normal time. But it was not so much a question of avoiding Leicester as a certain weariness with the kind of matches in which O'Neill's side tend to become involved.

As an entertainment the goalless first leg of their semi-final with Villa invited comparisons with the drying of paint, the growing of rhubarb and the mind-numbing League Cup finals of 1997 and 1999, in both of which Leicester City appeared. After O'Neill's team had forced a 0-0 draw at Arsenal in the fourth round of the FA Cup last month even the Leicester Mercury confessed to a few yawns.

This brought forth a sharp response from O'Neill in the next match programme. He praised the efforts of the players at Highbury and offered a sarcastic apology for "stupidly attempting to prevent Petit, Vieira and Henry - all proud owners of World Cup-winning medals less than 19 months ago - controlling the game".

Here, surely, is the nub of the argument. It takes two to tango and football is no different. Leicester have adopted an approach which makes them awkward opponents for apparently better teams. It is not in O'Neill's interest to open matches up and allow opponents to display their skills.

Leicester prefer to identify the principal dangers in opposing sides and deal with them accordingly. Thus Pontus Kaamark was detailed to mark Middlesbrough's Juninho in the 1997 Coca-Cola Cup final and did his job so well that Boro became lobotomised.

It ill behoved Arsène Wenger, after Arsenal had been beaten on penalties in their FA Cup replay, to claim that this had been Leicester's aim all along. All right, so Wenger protested that he was simply praising O'Neill's players for a plan successfully completed but no manager in his right mind would instruct a team to play for a shoot-out from the off. He might as well opt for Russian roulette.

The criticisms Leicester have received would be harsh if their side were more or less up to strength. The reality, of course, is that because injuries have been regularly depriving him of half a team, O'Neill has had to adjust, readjust and adjust yet again.

The ability of Elliott to stop goals at one end and then score them, in some style, at the other epitomises what Leicester are all about. In the Arsenal replay Robbie Savage, a central midfielder, started as a right wing-back and then in extra-time was making crucial covering tackles as a makeshift centre-back.

Arsenal, like Leicester, were short of several important players - Tony Adams, Dennis Bergkamp, Marc Overmars and Nwankwo Kanu - for that game but Wenger had the depth of resources to win it and would have done so but for the goalkeeping of Tim Flowers and a series of misses by Davor Suker.

A week earlier Fulham had found the touch and imagination to deny Leicester possession and lead 2-0 at Filbert Street in the quarter-final of the League Cup, only to lose on penalties after conceding two late goals before both teams scored a goal in extra-time. But at least the Nationwide team had exposed Leicester's vulnerability in the absence of Neil Lennon and Muzzy Izzet, their binding forces in midfield.

Grumbling about the style of an opposing team is as futile an exercise now as it was when Wimbledon and Watford were being criticised for their long-ball games. The best way to win the argument is to win the match through superior methods.

Leicester are merely playing to their strengths, and strength of character is their forte. Were Chelsea similarly endowed, their fitful force of foreign mercenaries might be nearer to the top of the Premiership than 13 points.

webTitle: Help: My work is spinning out of control!

fields.headline: Help: My work is spinning out of control!
fields.standfirst: My job has grown so much that despite doing all I can, I'm falling behind in everything. I don't feel up to coping with it any more.  Brian R, medical administrator, North Yorkshire.
fields.trailText: If your job altered suddenly and dramatically you'd expect to feel disorientated and in need of extra support or training. But when changes creep up in seemingly insignificant increments, you may not notice their cumulative effect in time to prevent your self-esteem being seriously dented.
fields.body:
If your job altered suddenly and dramatically you'd expect to feel disorientated and in need of extra support or training. But when changes creep up in seemingly insignificant increments, you may not notice their cumulative effect in time to prevent your self-esteem being seriously dented.

Taking on extra responsibility, covering for unfilled posts and feeling you're only just getting through the day can be sustained for a while. Once it causes you to question your ability to cope it's gone too far. Leave it any longer and you may be unable to find the energy and confidence needed to turn the situation around.

Consider taking time off to clear your mind enough to look at causes and realistic remedies. If you're in a union contact them to see what practical advice and support they can offer. You need to think back to when you last enjoyed work and quantify the changes that have caused you to feel swamped.

If there never was a time when you felt in control, you're in the wrong job. Conduct a systematic audit of the areas causing difficulty.

List everything that makes you doubt your competence. Make a distinction between tasks you don't feel skilled to do and those for which you don't have adequate time or resources. Decide if those things could be put right; perhaps flexible working arrangements, training or extra resources would make enough of a difference. Involve your employer: it's in both your interests to sort this out.
Irene Krechowiecka

webTitle: In search of the perfect boss

fields.headline: In search of the perfect boss
fields.standfirst: Women are the fairer sex after all. Right?
fields.trailText: Who holds the key to key to getting the most out of your first or second job? It's you, of course - but there is another keyholder. Your boss. And as anyone who has ever worked for a poor manager will testify, a boss who lacks the basic set of management skills can soon sap you of all enthusiasm and motivation.
fields.body:
Who holds the key to key to getting the most out of your first or second job? It's you, of course - but there is another keyholder. Your boss. And as anyone who has ever worked for a poor manager will testify, a boss who lacks the basic set of management skills can soon sap you of all enthusiasm and motivation.

But what makes a good manager? Good leadership qualities? Inspirational creativity? A direct line to the boardroom? Sex?

Yes, sex. The sex of your boss may be more of a factor than anything else. Women managers are a small but growing minority - in 1973, less than 2% of managers in the country were women while today that figure stands at 18%, according to figures from analyst Remuneration Economics.

Women managers also happen to be more efficient and trustworthy, have a better understanding of their workforce and are more generous with their praise. In short they make the best managers, and if male bosses are to keep up they will have to start learning from their female counterparts.

A dangerous and inflammatory supposition?

Maybe. But all the research points towards such a conclusion. A survey published at the end of last year by Management Today magazine serves as an indictment of the ability of male bosses to function as leaders in the modern workplace.

A majority of those questioned - 1,000 male and female managers across the UK - believed women had a more modern outlook on their profession and were more open minded and considerate. By way of contrast, a similar number believe male managers are egocentric and more likely to steal credit for work done by others.

More than 61% of those surveyed said men did not make better bosses than women. Female managers use time more effectively, with many of those surveyed commenting that juggling commitments is a familiar practice for women with a home and a family.

Most of us can probably identify at least one woman who attributes her success to an ability to be "just like the men". After years of having to adopt a masculine identity and hide their emotions and natural behaviour in the workplace, it seems female bosses have become more comfortable with using their own style as a way to move forward. So much so that women have now become the role models for managers.

The UK findings tally with a survey of female bosses carried out in the US. A five-year study of 2,500 managers from 450 firms found that many male bosses were rated by staff of both sexes to be self-obsessed and autocratic.

Women on the other hand leave men in the starting blocks when it comes to teamwork and communicating with staff.

Still need convincing? A team of researchers led by Professor Nigel Piercy and Dr Nikala Lane from Cardiff University found that female sales managers are better than men in terms of monitoring, directing, evaluating and rewarding their sales forces; that they build teams with greater commitment than men; and that they reduce people's anxieties about their job by working more closely with them. Female bosses, say the researchers, also encourage higher levels of job satisfaction among their teams and manage their teams so that staff turnover is reduced.

At the coalface, there is consensus too. Mark Williams, head of recruitment consultant Supply Chain Personnel agees that many women have superior management skills.

"In my experience and from what I have seen in many of the companies I have dealt with and from what I have heard from the candidates I have placed, women often make better managers, "he says. "Women are often considered to be better at the multi-tasking which management roles call for.

"Women managers tend to be more in touch with the feelings of those around them, understanding how their own actions and emotions affect the people who work with them. They are very capable of juggling numerous work and people issues at the same time, taking time to listen and understand every issue and point of view.

"The way men tend to work is very much by focusing on one issue at a time, finishing that job and then moving on to the next. In management, many different areas can explode at once meaning that the manager has to deal with a variety of work at the same time - a situation which is often easier for women to handle."

But let's forget about sex for a moment. If you aren't fortunate enough to have a caring, sharing boss - male or female - how do you survive and thrive? Steve Gravett, author of Managing Your Boss (How To Books) suggests the following six-step plan.

1. Ignore their behaviour

2. Adapt your response to one that complements their traits

3. Refuse to accept difficult behaviour and be assertive

4. Modify their approach by using humour and peer pressure

5. Complain to your boss's manager

6. Look for a new job

webTitle: Morgan sells Viglen shares but Mirror inquiry broadens

fields.headline: Morgan sells Viglen shares but Mirror inquiry broadens
fields.standfirst: Share tipping explained
fields.trailText: Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, yesterday sold his shares in the hi-tech company Viglen Technology in the face of a growing storm over financial dealings among the newspaper's staff.
fields.body:
Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, yesterday sold his shares in the hi-tech company Viglen Technology in the face of a growing storm over financial dealings among the newspaper's staff.

Trinity Mirror, which owns the paper, said it had hired the law firm Lovells to investigate the share dealings of its "City Slicker" columnists, Anil Bhoyrul, 33, and James Hip well, 34, after it emerged the tipsters were repeatedly recommending a company in which Bhoyrul owned 10,000 shares.

The press complaints commission has meanwhile broadened its inquiry into the Mirror to include Bhoyrul. Bhoyrul is understood to be consulting his lawyers.

A statement from the Mirror said an internal inquiry had cleared Mr Morgan of any wrongdoing in buying £20,000 of shares in Viglen on January 17, the day before the Slickers column wrote a highly positive story on the company. Mr Morgan paid around 180p a share and the stock was yesterday worth 294p, increasing the worth of his stake to almost £33,000. The statement said he would donate net profits from the sale to charity.

A Mirror Group spokesman said the company wanted "an end to the rumour and counter-rumour". The company denied suggestions that the internal inquiry led by John Allwood, deputy group chief executive, and Paul Vickers, group legal director, had investigated up to 13 staff.

It is understood that Mirror workers dealing in shares now have to declare them to the company secretary. Lovells has also been instructed to review best practice for journalists by February 18.

Mr Morgan is also under scrutiny from the stock exchange and the department of trade and industry. The stock exchange looks at stock market tips in newspapers as part of investigations into alleged insider dealing.

A commission spokesman said the inquiry into Bhoyrul would be conducted in parallel to its investigation into Mr Morgan and he expected it to reach a conclusion in March.

The commission's code of practice states journalists "should not write about shares or securities in whose performance they know that they or their close families have a significant financial interest, without disclosing the interest to the editor or financial editor". A Mirror Group spokesman said on Wednesday that the paper had not been aware of Bhoyrul's shareholdings.

The Guardian disclosed on Thursday that Bhoyrul held 10,000 shares in Belgo, the restaurant chain named as one of the Slickers' 10 tips of the year during 1999 and repeatedly recommended throughout the year. The Slickers section again advised readers to buy Belgo shares on Thursday.

fields.headline: Junkshop classic
fields.standfirst:
American Buffalo
Donmar Warehouse, London
****
fields.trailText: The American invasion of London's prime theatres continues unabated. But who is going to complain when it is the Atlantic Theater Company doing Mamet's 70s junkshop classic with just the right degree of authenticity?
fields.body:
The American invasion of London's prime theatres continues unabated. But who is going to complain when it is the Atlantic Theater Company doing Mamet's 70s junkshop classic with just the right degree of authenticity? Clearly not the public since the run is already sold out.

The intriguing question is why Mamet's play survives so well. I suspect it is because the action effortlessly implies something far larger than itself. All that really happens is that Donny, the junkshop owner, enlists his young gofer, Bobby, in a coin- collection robbery: one that starts to go disastrously awry the moment Donny's hustling friend, Teach, ousts the boy and muscles in on the action. You might say, like the man in O'Casey, I see no magnificent meaning jumpin' out of that.

But Mamet's skill lies precisely in the way the story acquires metaphorical resonance. Donny tells his young pupil early on that "there's business and there's friendship": a fatal schism that not only rebounds on Donny himself but pinpoints America's divorce of the capitalist ethic from social life. Even more tellingly, these petty hoods persuade themselves that they have some moral right to their victim's coin collection.

Alongside this, Mamet hilariously harpoons the bull swagger and sexual fear of the American male. These guys talk big in order to disguise their panic, and no one more so than the interloping Teach. He starts off with a furious paranoid rant against two women in a coffee-shop that to me implies impotence. And, as the robbery gets closer, he comes out with phrases like "You want depth on the team", as if they were planning a raid on Fort Knox. The play goes wrong only when Teach is turned into a virtuosic star-turn: a trap that Neil Pepe's production and William H Macy's performance intelligently avoid. With his straight swept-back hair and thin moustache, Macy brilliantly shows Teach to be a nervy outsider who desperately wants to be part of the game. But he also brings out Teach's bullying vanity: almost his first action is to stare at himself in a compact and virtually his last is to shelter behind Donny when he interrogates the injured Bobby.

Philip Baker Hall's grizzled Donny is good without quite conveying his final moral awakening but Mark Webber's Bobby has the right tremulous desire to please and Kevin Rigdon's set is an amazing collection of American bric-a-brac including, significantly, portraits of Lincoln and JFK. It even contains a green Buddha, which at one point Teach demolishes: a nice nod towards Pinter's The Caretaker, which Mamet's play echoes in its ability to discover infinite riches in a cluttered room.

fields.headline: Monuments in music
fields.standfirst:
Schubert Ensemble
Wigmore Hall, London
***
fields.trailText: She may now be one of the forlorn footnotes of music history, but in mid-19th century Paris, Louise Farrenc was an important and successful teacher, pianist and composer.
fields.body:
She may now be one of the forlorn footnotes of music history, but in mid-19th century Paris, Louise Farrenc was an important and successful teacher, pianist and composer. Her A Minor Piano Quintet, which the Schubert Ensemble resurrected at the Wigmore Hall, possesses an effervescent charm and deserves to be more widely known.

It would be too easy to characterise the fluency of her music as "feminine"; rather it was the supposedly "masculine" virtues of individuality and virtuosity that were most revealing in the piece. The exuberant showmanship of the piano writing and the memorably bleak transitions in the sumptuous rondo finale contributed to the impression of a distinctive voice. All that, and a double-bass, too: Farrenc's quintet shares its idiosyncratic scoring of piano, violin, viola, cello and bass with Schubert's Trout Quintet.

Two works by John Woolrich for the Schubert Ensemble received their first performances. His arrangements of familiar Bach chorales glossed Bach's invention with a veneer of dark-hued sonority. Partly in homage to Bach's 250th anniversary this year, those same chorales were the compositional foundation to Woolrich's piano quintet, A Shadowed Lesson. However, during the piece, the marmoreal strength of Bach's harmonies disappears from the surface, becoming in the process a blackly powerful undercurrent.

Eschewing the potential dynamism of the instruments at his disposal, Woolrich's structure grows into a monumental intonement of a steely melody. With the commitment of the Schubert Ensemble, this impassioned declaration was as cumulatively powerful as the great cadences of Bach's chorales themselves.

The Ensemble were similarly serious-minded in the first movement of Brahms's G Minor Piano Quartet. But Brahms is not always the "leviathan maunderer" of George Bernard Shaw's description, and their playing missed the light and shade of Brahms's part-writing. Even though they managed to pull off the outrageous Hungarian dance in the last movement, their broad-brush approach failed to register the music's delicate shifts between reflective intimacy and rhetorical grandiosity.

fields.headline: The biggest takeover yet
fields.standfirst:
Vodafone's triumph has vast implications

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Mannesmann's takeover by Vodafone AirTouch claims the headlines because of the deal's sheer size. A world player is born, with 42m customers, boosting Europe's lead in mobile telephony.
fields.body:
Mannesmann's takeover by Vodafone AirTouch claims the headlines because of the deal's sheer size. A world player is born, with 42m customers, boosting Europe's lead in mobile telephony.

Yet it also speaks to the Americanisation of Europe's business culture and, behind that, the dynamic of capitalism and the communications technologies that fuel it and are in turn fostered by it. Perhaps the deal says something too about the dimished relevance of nation states (and the struggle of such supranational entities as the European Union to keep up). "Very good news," Downing Street intoned, as if this were a test match victory rather than a complex piece of financial engineering which will permanently dilute whatever the "Britishness" of Vodafone consists in. When Klaus Esser of apparently proud German Mannesmann went awooing his shareholders, where should he fetch up but ... London?

Besides, this must be classed a transitional deal. Mannesmann's recently acquired Orange will have to be smartly de-merged. European - world - communications markets are far from sated. Take the German (now German-American) publisher, Bertelsmann. Its Thomas Middlehoff played a part in the takeover battle. Bertelsmann has ties with AOL and Herr Middlehoff sits on the board of Vivendi, the big French conglomerate. Its mobile phone business is 12% owned by Mannesmann, but it is Chris Gent of Vodafone who has recently been planning an internet venture jointly with Vivendi. And so the web spreads. There will be further deals to come. As the link between Time-Warner and AOL showed, as phone and internet companies come together with providers of "content" the applicable metaphors are pooling and co-operation. Hostile takeovers are expensive; it is estimated that advisers will make £600m out of the deal; Mannesmann's shareholders paid dear for their abortive act of self-defence.

But such sums may be a small price for the inauguration in Germany of the vaunted Anglo-American model of corporate governance - where hostile takeovers are supposed to be the engine of change in board rooms. Clinching historical evidence that the American way works (outside America) is scarce; has it in any demonstrable way made British business "better"? None the less, the scene is now set for the German motor industry to go the way of the British. German unions must look to abandon their naive claims to "co-determination". The long-term investment planning that characterised German enterprise will submit to Wall Street-induced volatility. If the opening of German board rooms is the precursor to more "flexible" German labour markets the stability-loving Germans have a turbulent time ahead.

Such predictions capture the ambiguity of capitalist development, solvent and glue at one and the same time. If Vodafone-Mannesmann now sets about extracting "shareholder value" and rationalising operations, jobs may be lost; but burgeoning demand for phone services may add them. Imagine a German-speaking part of the world where even the leader of a far-right political party also relies on phones provided by a multinational giant. Big, rootless corporations have no interest in exclusion and political disturbance, so what role might they take if the extremism symbolised by Jörg Haider were ever to threaten to break out of its parochial context? What would Austrians fear more: disapproval by foreign ministries or disconnection from a phone network over which Vienna let alone Klagenfurt has not even remote control?

webTitle: Playing it safe: Take Sun Life's money and run

fields.headline: Playing it safe: Take Sun Life's money and run
fields.standfirst: As the Canadian insurer floats on the stock market its policyholders must decide what to do with their unexpected gains. Most would be well advised to proceed with care, warns Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: As the Canadian insurer floats on the stock market its policyholders must decide what to do with their unexpected gains. Most would be well advised to proceed with care.
fields.body:
Go for the shares or take the money and run - that's the choice facing thousands of policyholders of Sun Life of Canada, the insurer floating on the stock market this spring.

They have until February 16 to decide how they want to take their windfalls, which are set to average more than £2,800 apiece. The 234,000 policyholders must choose whether they want to keep the shares they have been allocated or sell them immediately. They also have to decide in what form they want to take their shares or cash.

For a fair number of policyholders this will be their first exposure to the world of stocks and shares, and some will be unsure about what to do.

There are no right or wrong answers, but two experts quizzed by Jobs & Money indicated that for the majority of people, taking the cash could prove the wiser move. Novice investors, in particular, would probably be better off investing the proceeds in a high-interest savings account or something like a unit trust, both much less risky than holding the shares of just one company.

Their "sell" recommendations also reflect the view that some of the other insurance companies that have floated, both here and in north America, have not exactly set the stock market alight.

It was in December that members of Toronto-based Sun Life of Canada voted overwhelmingly in favour of it shedding mutual status and becoming a public company. Though it has 600,000 policyholders in the UK, only those who have "with-profits" policies are sharing in the multi-billion pound bonanza. To be eligible, the policy must have been in force on January 27, 1998.

Everyone will receive at least 75 shares, though the average handout will be 378. As to how much these will be worth, all policyholders have to go on is the company's own estimate of 14-21 Canadian dollars each (between £5.94 and £8.91). If one takes the mid-point of this range, that would give 378 shares a value of £2,806.

Meanwhile, the company's bosses have still not decided the precise date of the flotation. All they are saying is late March or early April. That means we don't know whether the windfalls will come in the current tax year or the next one, which could have tax planning implications for some people.

If you opt to take the shares, you must choose between holding them in the company's "share account" or receiving a share certificate. If you choose the share account you will be sent a statement confirming the number of shares you own and will be able to use the company's share-selling service. However, it is important to be aware that, unlike with some other flotations, the share-selling service won't be free - there will be a fixed £10 fee plus a yet to be decided "small charge" for each share sold. Also, this service won't be available until 30 days after the flotation. So if you want to be able to sell your shares when trading begins, you should request a share certificate.

If you opt to take cash, what you get will be based on the price at which the shares are sold in the "initial public offering" (where all the shares of those people who have decided to sell are offered to institutional investors and others). You won't have to pay a fee or commission but you will have to cough up a small amount of Canadian "withholding tax". You can ask for a cheque to be sent to you, or open an account with Sun Bank (a subsidiary of Sun Life based in the UK) and have your money paid into it.

Some industry observers believe that because the flotation coincides with a series of other planned insurance company demutualisations in north America, this could lead to a glut of insurance company shares and could drive the share price down.

Meanwhile, Manulife, another of Canada's biggest insurers, has had something of a rocky time since floating in September 1999. Its share price rose initially but has been falling steadily since November and is now below its initial public offering price. There was also a subdued response from investors when a large US insurer called John Hancock floated in the States two weeks ago. And here in the UK, shares in Norwich Union, which shed its mutual status in June 1997, are not looking too clever - they hit the 500p mark last year but were this week at around 370-380p.

Jeremy Batstone at NatWest Stockbrokers reckons most Sun Life of Canada windfall recipients would be better off taking the cash rather than the shares. He says this is "not necessarily the best time to be taking bank or insurance stocks", and adds that a fair number of the policyholders may well not be interested in stock market investment. Putting the money into a high-interest account would probably be a better bet.

Alex Scott at Barclays Stockbrokers says that, for the majority of people, it would probably make sense to consider investing the money in a collective investment such as a unit trust, where your money is spread across a range of companies, rather than having it tied up in just one share. "It means they're putting all their eggs in one basket. They are making a big bet that this company will be a winner. The risks of being in a collective vehicle are much lower."

Forms must be sent back by February 16. Information: 0845-606-6622/www.sunlifeofcanada.co.uk

fields.headline: Deal with your professional jealousy
fields.standfirst: Feel positive about yourself and you'll soon be best of friends
fields.trailText: It was when he started to secretly read a colleague's e-mails that Stuart Maynard, an advertising copywriter, realised he had a problem. "John had been working in our team for about four months and I was finding it harder and harder to deal with," says Stuart.
fields.body:
It was when he started to secretly read a colleague's e-mails that Stuart Maynard, an advertising copywriter, realised he had a problem. "John had been working in our team for about four months and I was finding it harder and harder to deal with," says Stuart.

"It sounds arrogant, but before John came on to the scene I know I was considered the best in the team - I got on really well with our team leader, we were always out for beers and I knew he thought very highly of me. When John joined, all that started to change."

Feeling threatened by someone equally talented as himself, Stuart started to resent John's intrusion. "He is an incredibly creative guy," says Stuart, "and he got on with our boss brilliantly. Twice his ideas were taken over mine, everyone agreed they were really inventive. I felt like Woody to John's Buzz Lightyear - totally usurped."

"It can be hard if a new person joins and changes the structure of your office - particularly if you were doing well," says Professor Windy Dryden of Goldsmith's College. "Jealousy or envy - if allowed to get out of control can be particularly destructive. The first thing to do when you start feeling this way is to decide whether your jealousy is situational or chronic - which means whether the situation really does exist, or if you are creating something that isn't really there."

For Stuart, things were somewhere between the two. "I got so obsessed with John that I started reading his e-mails so I could forestall him in meetings," he says. "I was right in one way - things had changed - but where I was wrong was in thinking that my boss felt differently about me because he also liked John. In fact, he held us both in equally high esteem - but he had to take me out for lunch and tell me that - among other, slightly less positive things - before I started to get a grip."

"There are two ways to combat professional jealousy," believes Professor Dryden. "One is to cultivate a more flexible attitude, the other is to build up your self-esteem. Office life is highly changeable - people come and go, workloads shift- and you need to be flexible to deal with that. Try not to rely too much on individuals - or place too much emphasis on one particular relationship - you need to be confident of your abilities on your own."

"I've always suffered from a lack of professional confidence," says Gina McFadyen, who works as a loans manager for a bank. "I'm fine if I'm left to get on with things, but bad in an interactive situation. My job changed slightly a few months ago and there has been a lot more telephone work involved. I sit opposite a guy, Simon, who is just Mr Super-Charming on the phone and I'm so envious of him - I'm terrible on the phone- and I'm sure I look even less capable in comparison to him."

"Often envy or jealousy stems from some sort of resentment," says Nick Isles, spokesperson for the Institute of Personnel and Development. "In many offices there is a total lack of communication - people end up doing tasks they're not particularly suited to, or have resentment at a lack of promotion - but don't feel they can talk to anyone about it. So, the jealousy builds and gets worse - and a situation that could have been dealt with easily early on, turns into a big problem."

For Gina, a particularly bad afternoon meant she decided to take control of the situation. "I'd just had enough - so I went to see my boss and told him I couldn't work in this new way. I expected him to tell me that I should be more like Simon, but in fact he said that I was a highly valued member of staff, that he respected me for coming to him and he would see what he could do. I felt about a billion times better - and just wish I had said something months ago."

If you don't remember anything else, remember this ...

Get control of your jealousy. If you don't, you'll start behaving in a way that will lose you the respect of your boss regardless of anyone else involved. Write a list of your successes at work, be proud of your own achievements and try not to compare yourself with anyone else.

fields.headline: The soul of old Cuba
fields.standfirst:
Conjunto Folklorico Nacional de Cuba
Sadler's Wells, London
***
fields.trailText: After a succession of mixed-media African shows, hi-tech flamenco and catwalk tango, we've grown used to "foreign" dances being glitzily packaged for the stage.
fields.body:
After a succession of mixed-media African shows, hi-tech flamenco and catwalk tango, we've grown used to "foreign" dances being glitzily packaged for the stage. So much so that the modesty of this programme - Rumbadelica - looks at first almost gauche. The stage is bare, the lighting basic and the costumes so lacking in designer spin they could have come from the performers' wardrobes at home.

But the Cubans are proud of their dance and it's part of their considerable charm that they don't tart it up for international consumption. This national folk company was formed in 1962 as a repository for the island's cultural heritage, and one of the real pleasures of the show is how much, and how effortlessly, it teaches us.

The first half progresses from late 19th-century son though to the rumba - and reveals how intricate the chemistry was between Hispanic and African influences. Within a single song the long ululating phrases of flamenco are heard alongside the high chirruping calls of Africa, while African percussion is overlaid with plangent Spanish guitar. The dance looks almost postmodern in its mix. The delicate hip gyrations and choppy syncopations of African dance mesh with the arched Spanish torso and majestical flouncing of flamenco skirts; when US swing enters the mix it produces the rumba.

On Thursday the audience was noisily appreciative of the snappy rumba that closed Rumbadelica's first half, as it was of an amazing male duet that resembled an early form of body popping. Yet in other numbers the mood remained muted. Though we didn't need glitz we did crave more blatant virtuosity; during the fast half some dancers proved disappointingly mediocre while the stars had too few opportunities to dazzle in choreography that was often studiously plain.

After the interval, the mood changed radically, as the focus switched to the older ritualised dances imported from Africa. These were much more theatrical in their use of costume and in their performance, with dancers passionately entering the bodies of trance-induced acolytes or mutating into rebellious slaves. These African dances may not have been what fashionable Cuba aficionados came to see (they're a far cry from salsa and the Buena Vista Social Club) but they were a powerful reminder of how much older and wilder Cuba is than the tourist destination currently topping travel agents' lists.

 Until February 13 (box office: 0171-863 8000) then De Montfort Hall, Leicester, on February 14
